headline: Not for those who want to be excited about a job or make a single connection in the workplace.
pros:
Very clear on corporate culture. 
Updates from superiors (CEO, etc.) multiple times a week.
Will pay for your licensing if you’re in a licensed role.
Pretty easy to get vacation days approved.
cons:
This is not a job for someone who can’t sit in the same chair, staring at the same computer screen for 8+ hours.
Working from home is miserable, but working in the office requires either weekly testing and tracking or the vaccine. 
I’ve never felt so lonely at a company, even though this is the biggest company I’ve ever worked for.
I barely even know my manager’s first name, that’s how disconnected everyone is.
I only lasted one month after I finished training because the job isn’t rewarding in the slightest.
Be prepared to get yelled at or called incompetent at least 5 times a day.
Don’t expect more than minimal support from any supervisor.
This position should pay much more than it actually does. 
During onboarding, they make it seem like you can move around as much as you want, as quickly as you want, and your manager will help you advance however they can, but that’s a joke.
By the end of my shift, I’m exhausted and can’t even build up the motivation to make dinner.
EVERYTHING is scheduled. You get two 15 minute breaks - one in the morning and one in the afternoon - and a 30 minute lunch, but you may not be eating lunch until hours after any normal lunch time should be scheduled. And you don’t get a say on that either.

headline: Not bad for a recent college grad and not in a phone role.
pros: Health benefits are good. You can get a job with zero finance experience right out of college with decent pay. Series 7 training is top notch. Casual dress code.
cons: I wonder if all the positive reviews are legit. Cliquey political corporate culture. Either you're in the "in" group or not. If you're not you'll know. Lots of brown nosing because that's how you move up. Pay below average. 5 year vesting on the 401k. Most roles are call center phone jobs which gets old fast. Every second you're clocked in is tracked. True advancement opportunities are limited, regardless of what they tell you.

pros: Stay ahead of trends. They offered work from home long before COVID. For being a huge company, they pivot quickly when necessary.

headline: Uncoordinated and underpaid
pros: Lots of OT and great health and 401k benefits.
cons:
Employees are asked to do more than what is expected. Employees who work loads of OT are rewarded but leads to quick burnout. Not only are you expected to make professional level calls (in a role that doesn’t provide any real call training), have high level knowledge of excel, but you are expected to complete calculations for complex pension plans.

Also be on the lookout for training new hires while keeping up with the regular workload, there is high turnover in the group.

cons:

headline: Cult
pros: Get your licenses and leave
cons: Drink that koolaid or else you won't last. This is an absolutely miserable job, manager was completely incompetent and was an absolute joke to watch her interact with other leads. Denied first time off request after 5 months of working. You're not going any where, once your're on the phones there is absolutely no movement. The internal technology is from the 1980s. I would never hold my money at this place and no one ever should. Fidelity definitely writes their own ratings because there is simply no way people give them such good feedback. The training program is actually horrible in covid conditions, if you need extra help good luck in a zoom class of 300 people. If you're a college grad and think this sounds like a good start, simply don't do it, you will have your soul sucked out of you 6 months into your career.

headline: Less Than Ideal
pros:
- Good pay
- No micromanagement
- Learning days
- Encouraged to move within company
cons:
The LEAP program has been terrible. It is essentially 4 more months of college after you graduate. Lots of hand-holding and forced classroom-style learning. Instructor-led training is mostly a waste of time here.

High chance that you will be working with an outdated tech stack after LEAP. You may also be placed into an unfavorable role with little to no technical mentorship and with minimal transferrable skills. They will try to tell you that Fidelity is a "tech company that does finance" but this is not the case.

In short, not a great place for new software engineers. If you have another offer, I would highly recommended considering working elsewhere

pros: The pay is amazing. Benefits are great. Monday-Friday.

headline: Fantastic Company
pros:
Fidelity has amazing benefits - 10% profit sharing after 1 year at the company, 18 days PTO for new hires, 7% 401k match with five year vesting, low-deductible health insurance coverage, maternity and paternity leave. They are a very generous company, and they give employees great work-life balance. You will only bump into more financial benefits the more you work there. 

The company is also genuinely high integrity. They structure their company with customer obsession as the main goal. I enjoy making clients happy, and I go to bed feeling good about my work at night.
cons: Fidelity is a good company for someone wanting a corporate job. If someone is extremely entrepreneurial, they will probably feel somewhat trapped or undervalued at Fidelity. Fidelity has a process they want employees to follow, and sticking to their process is key to long-term success.

headline: Your Experience Will Depend Heavily Upon Your Department
pros: Great Company, Solid Benefit Package. Not publicly traded, so not at the mercy of shareholders and profits.
cons:
Low Hourly Pay, Some Departments Are A Career Ender, Opportunities for advancement depend heavily upon the regional center you are located near.

Fidelity pays a lower hourly wage than most firms and justifies it by saying your quarterly bonuses (whether you earn them or not) and benefits package (whether you use it or not) brings you to the compensation level of competing firms. 

Some departments put unrealistic amounts of mandatory overtime in your schedule. Stay clear of Transition Services.

headline: Where college degrees die and anxiety is born.
pros:
Generous 401k match
Reasonably priced insurance
Flexible PTO
Positive company culture/values
They hire pleasant people
So many perks and benefits I literally cant fit it all on here.
cons:
Ever ask yourself "How can I simultaneously destroy my career prospects and waste my expensive college degree?" Well then , Fidelity Investments in Jacksonville has the perfect job for you! 

First, it's a call center people...through and through. You will talk to dozens of people on the phone. Every...single...day. Eventually, that "ding!" sound of a new call coming in will haunt your dreams. Most people don't last more than a year. You can either go the sales or service route. If you go service, there is very little room for advancement. In addition, if you move into whats called a "High Net Worth" service role, you will be responsible for a HUGE range of knowledge and actions without commensurate pay. One call could have you rushing to get a complex option trade placed within minutes of market close, while a pushy day trader berates you, and the next call could be spending an hour helping a 90 year old man reset his password as you bang your head on you desk asking "I went to college for this?!" If you go sales, then get used to working long, awkward hours and having your success defined in how many more calls you can take than the next guy/gal. 

The coupe de grace (ATTENTION ALL RECENT COLLEGE GRADS): None of the jobs they offer in Jacksonville are real finance jobs. They're just customer service/sales jobs parading as something fancier. Even the "Financial Advisor" roles are just sales, albeit well paying. Also, call center jobs are only marketable to other customer service careers. Having a call center job on your resume will actually HARM your chances of landing a job in world of ACTUAL finance. So, before you go thinking "I'll just work here for a year or two to get something on my resume"....DON'T DO IT.

None of what I just said should reflect poorly on the company itself, because Fidelity is a great company in terms of culture, mission, and values. That's undeniable. The problem is very specific to the extent of their operations in Jacksonville being call center based and that these are very stressful and career-limiting work environments. Consider yourself warned!

headline: Great benefits, but leaders can make it tough for new hires to thrive and grow their careers
pros:
Great and caring people all over the company if you can find them for your network.
Premium health insurance and superior overall benefits.
Employee Resource Groups for connecting with other employees.
Opportunities to volunteer with local charities.
cons:
Pay is lagging and not competitive or calibrated by location (no cost of living increases and most Director level salaries don't change year to year for multiple years).
Meeting-heavy culture...lots and lots of meetings.
Have to wait 1 year to participate in 401K.
Tenured employees (15-20+ year) are mostly unwilling to change or transform the way they work, or be influenced by new thinking.
Career growth is limited for back-office employees and most job requisitions require you to live in the geographical area (TX, NC, or MA) in order to be considered for the job.
Lacking leadership skills at Director level, VP, and above creating a micro-managing culture and toxic work environment. 
HR is passive in giving employee support and really only advocates and acts upon anything for the benefit of the manager and company.
Way too many Executives and layers of management.
Spending or investing via your Fidelity checking and 401K accounts are monitored by your manager.
Year-end bonus and performance evaluations are 100% subjective with manager discretion to give you 0% bonus.
Diversity and Inclusion is not a top priority for Fidelity, although they have taken steps to address some the gaps, but could still do more.

headline: Good luck!
pros: The people and how you can move up on the corporate ladder in this position
cons:
I'm not a negative person but this topic makes me so angry so 

Compensation: The base pay (at least for my role) is way too low for what I do. 

Job: My job itself is manageable but stressful at times already. When people leave, they put that person's job on other people, with no raise or any acknowledgment of how the person's doing. The job you add on, you may not even be qualified for under in the industry. Also, they add on useless tasks to do (that other locations don't do) just for no reason at all. We have all of these tasks to do with no extra pay or help from higher management. The higher up people do not even know how to do the jobs we have which I can say from my experience here for sure.

Customers: some of the clients are absolutely absurd. they come in asking for things and you try to help them and give them caring honest answers and they dont care. it just adds on to the stress.

Company: During the pandemic they've put completely unrealistic protocols that do not make the clients happy (not being able to walk in places). Although I understand it's important to be safe during the pandemic, other companies allow it, so why not here? This just makes the clients very angry, more than already about their needs, and they go off on us service reps as if it is our fault. We take the heat. When we present it to a manager they do not care and tell us to try to resolve it more. If it escalates too much to a manager then they just blame the company and seem not to care. 

P.S. If you have a fidelity account and need help, do NOT call the service number because there is a 1% chance someone will answer in the first 10 minutes.

headline: Life Changing Career Decision
pros:
Excellent Training, Outstanding benefits, Healthy work/life balance. Amazing tuition reimbursement. Great place to launch a career or facilitate a career change. 
Jaw-dropping 401(k) match and profit sharing. Best career decision I ever made! I am eternally grateful for the impact Fidelity has on me and my family. Transparently, my financial future will be dramatically and positively different because of my career at Fidelity. Very proud to tell others where I work!
cons:
The only con I have is that Fidelity is more focused on hiring externally than promoting from within. Much of this focus is due to recent cultural and economic events (i.e., 2020). From a business perspective, I understand the desire to capitalize on available and diverse talent but not at the risk of frustrating and overlooking your highly qualified and tenured associates. There is a simmering frustration among the ranks and will soon result in sizable attrition if not addressed. 

For example, I am the most credential and skilled associate of my team and keep getting overlooked for a particular role. The individuals that are being hired into this role are under credentialed and/or have less experience. It is the most frustrating thing in the world! For the first time in my tenure at Fidelity, I have started proactively looking outside the firm. It genuinely PAINS me to think I may have to join a competitor to advance my career and compensation.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Fidelity has always been a fantastic company to work for, but its ongoing transformation into an even more inclusive and diverse firm only boosts its already considerable appeal. The company has made a strong effort to put its people first; the benefits are stellar. D&I has become a top priority as the firm continues to display a strong social consciousness. Technology groups across the company have embarked on a sweeping Agile transformation. The idea of constant improvement is alive and well at Fidelity. It is a great place to work.
cons: There are no major Cons to report. All large companies have challenges. Does Fidelity present some of these? Sure. The difference is that management is receptive to feedback, and reasonable responses and appropriate action are often provided. No company is perfect, but nothing major to report here.

headline: Good and Bad
pros: Fidelity is a third generation family business that attracts a high quality employee and compensation is competitive to above market. They have diverse lines of business.
cons: This firm has legacy issues that have left its technology and business process behind the times. They have upgraded systems but still rely on internal networks, legacy systems, e-mail and spreadsheets to attend to day to day business process. Since they have so many businesses under the Fidelity umbrella, it made it hard for them to prioritize and consolidate a unified strategic approach.

headline: Excellent Community to be a part of!
pros: Fidelity is genuinely a good company that seeks to do the right thing for their customers and their people. They invest heavily in trying to improve and prepare for the future and respond to what clients and associates need to feel supported.
cons: Like all large companies, people quit managers more than they quit jobs. The company does try and help managers improve, but it is still a challenge if you do not get a good one. Also, many departments can feel like a silo; you may not like the lack in variety of jobs in your business arm and it can sometime feel difficult to move to a different department if you have already established yourself in another one. Again, I feel this is recognized and investment is made to try and fix it to move more freely across the company, but some roles will not change.

headline: Great place to start out
pros: Financial Advisors learn to operate efficiently at Fidelity. Compensation is good for advisors just starting out.
cons: Because advisors have upwards of 400-500 clients, it's difficult to go very deep with any client's financial planning. There is a focus on achieving certain metrics (ie. insurance, managed money) and there is no cumulative success - the clock starts over every quarter, which means there is limited upside potential for advisors at Fidelity. You will be judged more on what you're selling than on your financial advising.

headline: Great Company, Poor Local Leadership
pros:
Compensation
Very little prospecting of clients since the business is there
cons:
Local leadership

Advisors answer the switchboard and double as receptionists.

Advisors are asked to work the front desk like a bank teller from time to time and this cuts into their day. Slows productivity to work on service, but we are measured on sales.

Their email system is antiquated and doesn't permit for clients to be emailed from Outlook. Slows down the productivity.

headline: High stress role, but an excellent place to start a career
pros: People are friendly. Management are very supportive. There is a lot of room to grow and change to new roles within the company. I'm a white trans woman and never got misgendered once while at work (except occasionally by clients), no one treated me weird and I even got offered promotions and things.
cons: The phones role is high stress, so an ability to separate work time from your personal time is vital. This is hard to do when everything is work from home. The licensing can be tough. There wasn't a lot of room for people with learning differences to get support during licensing. If you're not a good test taker and struggle to read all day and memorize information for an exam, you will have to advocate for yourself for the support you need.

headline: Overall faith in Senior Leadership Team
pros: successful company performance year after year leads to great bonuses. outstanding benefits. areas to grow within your team (sometimes) or move to different teams throughout firm. Admin team made transition to WFH very easy. firm added a ton of benefits to help us adapt i.e 5 more days to deal with pandemic inconveniences throughout the year (2020 & 2021!). work life balance has been great for me personally but i have heard can vary based on manager/team/role/level.
cons: lots of corporate red tape makes day to day responsibilities difficult. We could be more of an industry leader in Diversity and Inclusion - some senior leaders have always been focused on this and are greatly admired throughout the firm. Generally speaking from an enterprise level, these topics are only addressed under media attention, though this level of attention has been increasing. compensation could be higher, but personally i feel is justified through their fantastic benefits. culture will vary based on business unit - some have more of a start up vibe, other units don't have that flexibility given the nature of their work.

headline: Be prepared to be pressured to upsell and micro managed.
pros: Benefits, technology and people are great.
cons: On surface, Fidelity tell you to do the right thing and best interest for client. On paper you are expected to push managed account, annuity, have 30 appointments. They will force you to hit metrics to avoid weekly one on one with management and come up with a plan on how will you improve going forward. They are constantly hiring of consultants, when I came in with another new hire. The other guy left after 4 months and I stuck it out for 8 months because I need a new job. You can expect weekly meetings on everyone’s production numbers and put you on the spot if you did not meet management expectations. Fidelity will churn and burn you and there will be a next person to replace you.

headline: They treat you like a computer
pros: Company match, salary, vacation time is front loaded. Fresh lunch options.
cons: No work/life balance. It's looked down on if you call in sick. Schedules are highly competitive. You must meet your quotas constantly on the phone. Calls must be dealt with as quickly as possible. If the rest of your numbers are good, but your call time is too long, no chance for any other opportunities in the company. Must have supervisors permission to apply for a different job in the company. If they say no, you will be stuck on the team. You work on a timer. You are given breaks, and a short 30 minute lunch which makes it difficult to eat the fresh lunch they provide since it takes almost 15 minutes to receive your food. You are expected to always be taking calls.

headline: Good Place to Learn Product Development Processes, Bad Place to Stay Relevant
pros: Excellent place to learn the various product development processes needed for a high-security application development from a FinTech domain. I was able to learn some of the best agile practices like that of the Spotify model. Although most of the systems are marred with the wounds of the waterfall model, but it gives a picture of end-to-end development with various stages of testing like Integration and User acceptance. Their core architecture teams do most of the best work in the industry which drills into the whole organisation, which paves way for niche skill learnings down the chain.
cons: Not much work comes to India Offices from the US. Best work is done in the US. Most of the work deals with a whole lot of bureaucracy, rather than rapid application development. The process are good, but this keeps the company slower than its competitors. Because of the loopholes in the way the company works, developer associates who start fresh here, tend to become clueless about their futures and in the long run, become irrelevant to even sustain in the IT industry. The company boasts the average stay of an employee here as 9-10 years, which I believe tells about the sorry state of the knowledge of the current employees besides the fantastic flexible laid-back environment of the workplaces inside. Big thing that has started the new breed to look for other careers or opportunities, they don't really pay well to the industry standards even after an employee has earned the best work review from the managers. Senior management is at the moment clueless as to their own set agendas and principles, allowing for some of the leaders leave the organisation.

headline: Fair Comp System, Not Great For Career Analysts

cons: Clique-y and clubby. A lot of Fidelity people socialize together as well as work together. Good if you like that sort of thing. PM driven. They have never gotten a career analyst role integrated into the system. Analsyts can burn a HUGE amount of cycles holding pro forma meetings that deliver no insight. Great access, but "water water everywhere, not a drop to drink" in terms of being able to really drill down into your companies in person.

headline: "F is for flexibility"
pros:
Excellent benefits, great mobility into other positions if working in call centers to turn an "okay" base pay to solid. Top of the line training for licensing should your role require it off the bat, or sometime down the line.

The workplace culture is excellent- every single manager I've had is excellent, and that's likely a result of trickle-down from *their* higher ups. Willingness to accomodate work from home is an excellent push, as long as you're okay with online training.
cons: Certain products like the one I work with currently very much feel like they're on the backburner when it comes to updating resources, educating customers, etc. It makes a call with an insane hold time even more distressing, and just leads to more OT asks. I've had the term "F for flexibility" thrown around more times than I can count. Having covid PTO is great, but the distressing air of the call center floor makes associates feel almost guilty for not doing OT, nevermind taking days off during "peak season", which, since the pandemic, has been virtually every day. I love what I do and I love assisting customers- but beware, if call center work is exhausting to you, it's going to outweigh most pros I'm giving here.

headline: Employee-Centered
pros: Fidelity provides amazing benefits, looks out for their people, and makes sure to stay competitive in pay and perks. I have never encountered an employer that put so much toward the well being of their employees! Your manager pulls for you personally, even if you're applying for a different department, and coaches you to your full potential.
cons: With the amazing benefits, Fidelity does expect a significant turnaround of work. There is occasionally mandatory overtime for service-level associates, and average stats are expected, since there are so many associates to keep track of, so your evaluation isn't always very personalized-feeling when it comes to applying for other roles in the company.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Fidelity has a good culture and great group of people to work with. Very supportive and many opportunities to move up within the company. There are opportunities every quarter and you can get promoted multiple times in a calendar year if you're performing. And if you're not performing, they're typically very supportive and try to find constructive ways to help you improve.  Benefits are great. You start off with 18 days PTO and after 2 years you get 23 days PTO off per year. OT is frequently available if you want it.
cons: The calls can beat you up on some days. Majority of the managers I've had were good,  but just like any job your experience will also partially depend on who you have as a boss. There are some that are not ideal; however, most managers are encouraging and helpful in your career path.

headline: BEWARE!!
pros: They allowed workers to work from home.
cons:
Where do I start? I spent a decent amount of time working at Fidelity. Overall, I would say it’s not a great company to work for at all. From my observations, many people have gotten stuck in this company, and it’s drained the life/soul out of them. For starts, many full-time and contractors (Fidelity TalentSource) are underpaid for the amount of responsibility on them. Many people are very unhappy here, but their soul has been trapped here way too long. They don’t know how to leave; all they know to do is stay around and complain.

Racism is obvious in this company. After the murder of George Floyd and many others, there was a lot of lip service from upper-level leaders and money donated to non-profits, but the core of this company has not changed at all. It’s racist!

Human Resources and Recruiters for the most part are awful. I think this is one of the MANY reasons why they don’t attract quality candidates, let alone keep them exceptionally long. Speaking of that, turnover is HIGH.

The leadership is really what makes or breaks an organization. The leadership here is awful. I met with a Senior Leader about issues with a product that they oversaw, and they admitted it was problematic and had obvious issues. However, since our meeting nothing about the product has improved, it’s only gotten worst. Do companies think by ignoring constant issues/problems that they’re just going to float away?

I conclude by saying, proceed with caution. Don’t let the nice buildings, benefits, etc. fool you. Once you get in, you will soon realize it was a BIG mistake coming here. You deserve better in life, STAY AWAY!!

headline: Little work/life balance
pros: Great benefits (PTO, medical etc)
cons: Good luck using your PTO- they don't approve time off if they deem themselves too busy, mandatory overtime in "peak" seasons (but they will require you to do it throughout the year), unrealistic expectations of calls taken per hour while trying to talk clients "off the edge". Promotions are based on your surveys you receive from clients and if your manager likes you- and alot of surveys are bad scores due to long wait times so it's an unfair scaling system.

headline: Amazing potential, great community, cares about culture fit!
pros:
Honestly they care a TON about making sure you fit within the culture of the team/company. The technology community is really helpful and full of such a variety of people. There's good events, they invest in you as a person from internal onsite training, to in-house education platforms to big name course platforming tools (not even counting their benefits package, that's incredible, especially for families). You can really "Blaze your own trail" when it comes to your career and people will support you as much as they can. The connections you make there can/will extend far after you leave and most of their networks are very far reaching across other large companies (or even internally).

Additionally, work/life balance is AMAZING. Most managers (particularly technology, since call center workflows are different) will let you handle life because they know that it can be unpredictable, and will help you adjust however works for you (obviously within reason), whether that's having to leave somewhat early to pick up kids or have an extended lunch because of a crisis or appointment. There's a trust that you can develop with your team and manager that you can truly make the experience less stressful, and they're willing to work with you in whatever way they can.
cons: If you're coming in as an entry-level technology role, make sure you get the best offer you can. They've historically paid under market even in their industry (though it's much closer these past 2 years) because of their benefits, but total comp is still somewhat lower than anticipated for their size. Depending on the team, it may be hard to rise up the ranks past a point due to too many managers, and organizations find it difficult to cut them, especially if they've been there a while. It's pretty hard to negotiate any pay change since raises only happen at the end of the year, and there's not a pay discussion until they're locked in.

headline: Amazing company & benefits, not enough flexibility
pros: There's always something new to learn in the job and being customer oriented was something I appreciated about the company. In addition, having a 7% company match and profit sharing component in the 401(k) plan was a great benefit. They also encourage employees to develop their careers so your job is never at a standstill.
cons: Since some jobs have you working in a contact center type of environment, there are a lot of months where call volume can be busy and it can be exhausting taking care of so many customers in a span of 9-11 hrs each day. In addition, you're set on a schedule (could be working an evening shift until further notice) and even though you might be working for a minimum of 8 hours, it can still be exhausting leaving the workplace at 8:30 pm closer to 9 pm on a Friday with hardly any other employees working with you during that time as well.

headline: Great benefits, easy to burnout
pros: Amazing benefits, understanding boss, comprehensive training, learn a ton on the job, frequent bonuses offered, always overtime, 529 clients typically nicer, opportunities for growth, tuition reimbursement, affordable healthcare/HSA, great 401k match, work with intelligent self motivated peers
cons: Super easy to burnout, it’s been so overwhelmingly busy clients often want to vent or treat me like a punching bag. High expectations on our stats that feel impossible to achieve with it being so busy. Bonuses are based on these stats. Feel isolated working from home, sitting at a desk, and not being able to communicate with peers since I’m always on a call.

I wonder if people are getting paid to give them cause no one in their right mind would say this is a great place unless they were a masochist.

headline: Cookie Cutter Metric Driven
pros: Health and Welfare benefits are good
cons: Talent Acquisition stated the C Suite recognized they needed diversity of ideas and to recruit experienced leadership and talent from other financial firms to get some fresh ideas vs. homogeneous atmosphere they have. Well their entire 10-20+ year Team Leader and Manger level folks that arrived at the firm in their 20’s and are still there aren’t on board. They want you do it “this old way” or you just don’t fit their metric driven, hourly only, completely micro managed way of doing things. It was promising in the beginning, but in 15 mos. it was obvious the firm has problems. They touted Agile ways of doing things, but that wasn’t really what was happening.

headline: Lateral Mobility , if you play the game.
pros: Benefits are pretty good, profit sharing.
cons: Worked here in many roles over 12 years. Culture has changed dramatically in last 5-7 years. Terrible team leaders that bully anyone under top 15-25%. They play favorites with people who are probably cheating the system. Was planning on retiring here, but getting older here is a death sentence.  Unethical mgrs who are puppets manufacture reasons to push you out the door. No respect for tenured reps and managers are usually just associates that couldn't compete. Blind side associates with nonsensical stats if they don't like you. Call review scoring lacks consistency. Returned to work after STD for surgery and everyday was a new nightmare until terminated without much evidence and treated like a criminal. Becoming pretty standard way of thinning out tenured reps. Loved this company and mgmt. in the beginning. Made a lot of good friends. Mgmt. now just worried their stats and look the other way when cheaters don't even care to keep their stats within reality. Very toxic and political environment with unbelievable micro-management pressure , if you're not cheating and getting these mid-mgmt cretons promoted. It's viral all the way through to senior mgmt who are conceited, entitled, no talent bullies. No loyalty among thieves either. Most jump ship with a title and leave their wreckage behind. AVOID THIS COMPANY. It's smoke and mirrors your first 5 years.

headline: FFIO: You'll basically be retired
pros:
- Benefits (Shares/Bonus/Profit sharing/401k/HSA contributions/etc) are superb.
- Very low stress and hours requirements if you land in the "right" department.
cons:
- Career progression is extraordinarily political. I've seen multiple unqualified people get promoted because they spend all day assembling powerpoints and meetings despite having zero expertise or knowledge.
- Deadlines and accountability are non-existent in many departments. 25% of the people will do 75% of the work. I once had a (full-time) coworker complain that she never worked more than 32 hours in a week before when we asked her to stay late leading-up to a deadline.
- Company is risk-adverse to a fault. Rather than identifying short-term solutions to problems, they will have a five-year plan to eventually fix the problem. In the meantime... oh well.
- It will take you >2 years to get comfortable in your job. A large part of being successful in your roll is dependent upon knowing who you need to contact rather than simply knowing what needs to be done.

headline: Great company
pros: The benefits are generous, including tuition reimbursement, student loan repayment, 401k match and profit sharing. Fidelity has a robust licensing and training program for new associates. The focus on employee success and well-being is a top priority of leadership, especially during COVID.
cons: Like any job, there are little annoyances and parts that are less desirable. Like, chasing down time card approvals every Monday morning. Don’t you want to get paid? This list of ‘cons’ will be different for everyone. The pros greatly outweigh the cons. Sometimes I have to take a step back and remember that!

headline: Great Place to Start you Finance Career
pros:
- Pre-pandemic office culture 
- Great place to get your education and licenses
- Benefits
- Established firm, respected in the industry
cons:
They have no clue how to keep their employees happy during this Covid world. Your voice will never be heard. The firm's true colors started to show once reps had to work from home. They don't care what your skillset is, what motivates you, and how well you can fit with another team. If your scorecard isn't green forget about moving up in the company.

There's a reason why people are sprinting to Robinhood, but the leadership refuses to acknowledge reality. Instead they spend the exit interview belittling their reps decisions to leave and it's not a good look.

headline: Good company to start, but you probably want to jump ship ASAP
pros: Very thorough and organized onboarding process & trainings. Lots of learning opportunities at Fidelity in the beginning. For the most part, co-workers and managers are friendly and competent. Good healthcare benefits & great profit sharing (6% match).
cons:
Almost all the job opportunities at Fidelity require you to speak to customers on the phone. Mostly horizontal movements unless you network well & have great relationships with your managers. Job can get stressful and at some point of time, you will get yelled at by customers. 

It's a big company, so even though sometimes management asks for your opinion, they'll make changes that does the opposite. You're just a number in the company and most people leave within a year or two.

headline: Good first job
pros: Benefits, office perks, decent coworkers. Good job to have straight out of college, but they definitely throw you right into the role so be prepared to work with little to no guidance.
cons: Work life balance can be difficult for this role because you’re expected to be the first one in & the last one out. You basically do everyone’s busy work & you don’t get compensated for it. The role has evolved a lot due to COVID, you’re basically doing the relationship manager role just without the extra pay. I worked in an investor center so you won’t be micromanaged, but it’s hard to do anything when you don’t know what to do. Clients can be hard to work with. If you’re not looking to get into sales don’t even bother. They advertise how quickly you can be promoted within the company but it’s harder than they make it out to be, doesn’t matter how long you’ve been there.

There some Dunning-Kruger effect in some levels of the company. Is very common someone giving wrong information in trainings for example.
Also you can easily see a very hierarchical mentality over the company even do that trying to change. This impact in lack of transparency between the team.

headline: Glorified call center job
pros: Reputable private company with good benefits.
cons: The company/hiring managers are not looking for experience, creativity, or diversity in candidates. They want young and cheap (and White.) They want you to advice clients with written scripts and one-size-fit-all investment models, albeit the obvious fact that each client is unique. Team-oriented culture usually means everyone looks and sounds identical. It is a private company, so they can run the business whatever way they want, without any pressure from the public in regards to diversity and inclusion. In interview, they often tell you that the median pay for FC is around 165k, with many earn above 200k. The base is about 45k, most people get paid around the base. That's one of the many reasons why the company struggles with high turnover.

headline: Inconsistent Values
pros: Abby Johnson, the CEO, is awesome. She repeatedly beats the drum of providing a great customer and employee experience. Some of the best benefits in the industry. Between its low cost platform to invest and its fabulous benefits, Fidelity sets the bar high.
cons:
The only concern I have with Fidelity is that it doesn't do enough to root out managers with direct reports who violate its values. The lack in accountability of its managers isn't unique to Fidelity. Yet, it's disappointing considering it sincerely strives to standby things it espouses. Everyone knows who these bad actors and bad apples are. Members of their teams can't move away fast enough to other teams, departments, or companies. 

Though the company allows them to punish or push out struggling yet sincere frontline employees, it does little to recognize that these ineffective managers are better at managing up to their bosses than lifting up their teams. Just recently, I saw a manager who was recently promoted to an enviable post who has a seriously horrible reputation. He is a poster child of everything I mentioned and is one of the worst managers in the building.

headline: Hard work and skills don’t matter
pros: Benefits ..... that’s all I can say
cons:
Hard work and skill doesn’t matter. All based on favoritism so all you gotta do is kiss their butt. If you apply in a phone call center, expect to stay there and rotate between different call centers for the rest of your life. Only opportunity they offer is different call centers. Two 15 minute breaks, one 30 min lunch and they choose when you take it. YOU HAVE TO TAKE IT AT EXACT TIMES . They recently made it so that you can take it 20 min before or after . Break feels like 5 mins and lunch is 10 min cause the lines are sooooo long in the cafe and it takes time to get your butt up off your prison cell and walk all the way over there sooo technically you got 5-10 mins to shove the food in the mouth. Easy to get burn outs and forces you to do OT or else you’ll look bad and lose that opportunity for progression. Flexibility my butt! they give you a list of unattractive hours that is available and you just gotta choose from it.

Just avoid applying for phone call centers unless it’s your last resort.

headline: Great to start
pros:
They have great training
Great work life balance
cons: They are the worst with their promotion metrics. I was performing in top 1% of the company 3 months I dropped 1 month and the used it as an excuse not to promote me up. If your a person of color as well there is no diversity at the the maagement level besides one woman of Asian heritage. Expect if you are white to be promoted even though you're not the most qualified for the role. Expect to be accused of being bad on the phone when you did everythign you did for a client yet they give you a bad rating for the 1 hour hold time they waited to talk to you, and the best part is then the company will use that against you to screw you out of your bonuses saying you didn't do a great job. Of course, there is no way to throw out the ones that that were just an upset customer and not your fault. We were told they didn't have money for raises then they cut their commissions and magically found a way to still give us a raise. They do not do any cost of living adustments so expect to live harsh while some people live comfortable in other states. So pretty much expect to be disregarded at this company they don't care about you.

headline: Nice company but very draining job
pros: Fidelity is very generous in terms of pay and benefits. It also grants a lot of time for training individuals for the job, no matter what background you may have come from before joining Fidelity, they will teach you all the basics of the industry.
cons: If you are joining Fidelity through a call center role, be prepared because it can be a very draining job. You will have nothing but back to back calls for a vast majority of your day and are lucky if you get a full minute or two to breath between calls. You will also have to keep an eye on metrics, one of which is regarding number of calls taken within an hour. Basically, if you are entering into this role just be prepared to take on extra stress in your life.

headline: Indifference and Abuse
pros: I made some friendships while I was there. Everything related to my actual job was horrible.
cons: The upper management all sort of do there own things and have their own expectations, creating confusion throughout the company. I don't think Abby really has control over some of her subordinates. Site management changed every year that I was there, adding to the confusion. Team managers have entirely too much power and there is very little recourse given to appeal their decisions or seek redress of grievances when they act in an inappropriate manner. The pay is well below industry standards and while you are able to make lateral movements within the company, moving up is EXTREMELY difficult. Pay raises rarely keep up with inflation and while I was there our variable comp was changed making it impossible for anyone to meet the new standards. My pay went down a couple of thousand dollars per year as a result. HR is not responsive and negligent at times. I went an entire year without insurance because I was somehow disenrolled in the plan that I signed up for when I got hired on. HR knew that this mistake had happened and it was documented in their system, but they didn't do anything in time to correct the problem despite my contant pressuring them. The company became even less invested in its employees during my time, essentially turning from a somewhat tolerable work experience into just another high turnover, turn and burn call center.

Managers allowing their favored subordinates to bully others, while swift retaliation awaits those that dare criticize their annointed ones, however justified.
Company politics.

Company politics.
Too many managers that lack real leadership abilities.
Company politics.
Endless, unproductive, inescapable company politics.

Company politics.
Poor quality development, old tech.
Fidelity mandate bespoke everything, so expect restricted functionality, industry standard methodologies (such as Agile) to be bloated and incomprehensible and the inevitable compromises in the quality of your own work as a result.
The office atmosphere is more like a library than a workplace. 
Company politics.
Promotions based on factors other than merit.
Company politics.
Hiring based on factors other than merit.
Company politics.
Those with below average technical abilities are too often tolerated.
Company politics.
Did I mention the company politics? I only bring it up again because at Fidelity their brand of politics is continuously shoved under your nose and right in you face, so it's better you find out now if you can stomach it.

headline: COVID has shown their true colors
pros:
It used to be a pretty relaxed and laid back job...but that's all gone now. They've even redesigned their phone system in the midst of a pandemic to make sure that everyone takes every call and is talked out of their voice by Tuesday, but you better show up and sound cheerful for Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday...or else.
The benefits in terms of insurance coverage is decent. On the surface their retirement plan looks good with all the match and profit sharing, but their vesting schedule is draconian and traps you working for them for YEARS before you would ever get to take any of their retirement contributions with you when you leave. And you will want to leave quickly.
cons:
Metrics. Matrices. Benchmarks. Expectations. Goals.
Forget Fidelity being a Finance company. Their business, what they do best, is perfecting the art of micromanagement. Think you've learned how to do your job effectively? Think again. Every few months they've designed or redesigned a new system for you to learn to use because it is NEW AND IMPROVED with many more reporting features to keep an eagle eye on every single insignificant facet of your job performance - all in the name of assigning a number and a statistic to what you do that they can then set the goal for just high enough that they can use your performance as a reason to short you on a bonus or deny you a raise.
And they have no sympathy for their front line workers being abused on the phones either. They cleared out their offices and sent everyone home in March, but everything else has been business as usual ever since. No changes in expectations even an inch even though everybody in the trenches has been putting up with 3-4x the work they were doing 100 days ago. No guaranteed bonuses. No time off availability. Overtime has been expected and mandatory from the beginning, otherwise you're labeled as "not a team player" and "hurt your Fidelity Brand"
FIdelity Green is for Greed.

headline: The Tea:
pros:
If you get a great manager they will help you grow and push you to do better. There is a lot of opportunity for growth.
Having the market knowledge was my favorite part.
It’s fun to help
Ppl along the way.
cons:
For Cei metrics they only count sevens. Which is ridiculous for the reps and it leads to getting burnt out quick.

Also back to back phone calls will get to you after a while so find ways to connect with the customer. And make up little
Competitions for yourself and your team. ( I did that a lot for
My team) it helped us improve and have fun. 
There are some managers who do not practice company values. I had three great managers. They were so amazing! Then came Angie who was sexiest and racist and I have no idea how she held on to her job for so
Long. ( she has no idea what she was doing. And she was handed a great team and she made sure it went to crap) she’s now gone from the company. But it caused me
To leave the company wayy before I planned on it. 

So reach out and build a network! Also don’t stay in one place for too long. Seek to grow!

headline: Used to be all about the customer
pros: Great benefits package, decent pay, great colleagues, various shift schedules to choose from, quarterly bonuses based on personal results. Great intro job to finance, and Fidelity will offer opportunities to move towards your finance-industry-related work, even if you have little to no experience. You MUST understand that this is a call center job, however. As such, your job is to take X number of phone calls each and every day, day in and day out.
cons: What used to be all about the customer experience has, over the past few years, heavily diverted into a metric-based environment. This leaves associates "kicking the can" down the road to the next associate who can help better, leading to a terrible customer experience, simply because associates are watching out for their KPIs. Poor KPI results will result in heavy-handed "coaching" sessions and absurd amounts of micromanagement.

headline: Great Company, Bad Jobs
pros: Great benefits if you stay long enough. Don't take work home with you. A lot of PTO. Managers are pretty supportive.
cons: Not enjoyable day to day jobs. Stuck taking phone calls 8+ hours a day for 5+ years if you want to advance. When seeking next promotions, managers don't know of any career paths other than the next tier phone taking job. Disconnect on expectations vs. reality, but that is true at any big company. Can get stuck on bad shift (SAT, SUN, or Nights). Constant ask for Overtime and even "Pre-scheduled Overtime" which is essentially them putting overtime in your schedule without asking and is very frowned upon if you opt out. Low base pay that basically never increases.

headline: Sub-Par Management and Work/Life Balance
pros: Colleagues; Cafeteria; Benefits; Licensing Process
cons: I left Fidelity Investments due to my manager and the position itself. I was a Customer Relationship Advocate (fully trained and licensed) and each day on the phones was anxiety-inducing. I did not feel properly trained, nor did I feel comfortable answering a ton of questions on margin balances, options, etc., and despite that, I was not supported further. Just about every day, I would get yelled at by clients, and yet nothing was done. There were also very few breaks from the phones, and I woke up each morning dreading work and realizing just how miserable this position was. At one point, I had to go on a medical leave and I think I went 5 weeks without hearing from my manager. He did not respond to any of the emails I sent to him, he did not check in on me, and generally, he seemed to care very little about the associates; instead, he was very focused on the metrics instead. All of this contributed to a sub-par experience.

headline: Great Company! Why look anywhere else?!
pros:
-Respectful, Inclusive Workplace! Fidelity encourages anyone to bring up to someone you trust about something someone did or said that made you uncomfortable and Fidelity has no tolerance for inappropriate and disrespectful behavior! 

-Since COVID 19 hit 99% of this company works from home! (This position allowed working from home 2 days out of the week before COVID happened.)

-Work from home but not alone! Excellent technology giving you all the tools you need to be successful and feel connected with you coworkers and managers. 

-Flex time! With this position getting one planned paid hour off a week. ( i.e Getting off at 4 instead of 5 on Friday and getting paid that hour. What company does that? 

- VERY STABLE! When companies during COVID-19  are laying off people this company is hiring.  Most businesses get busy in the summer while this company gets busy in the winter.

-Free  Essential Health Insurance

- Job Advancement! The Career Center is dedicated in giving you resources for job advancement where the people associated are there to help you obtain a job you want within Fidelity. 

- Plenty of other Pros!
cons:
Call center work is repetitive. 
(You have to really fish for cons to find them with a great company like this)

headline: Anxiety Inducing
pros: The pay and benefits are supreme. There is room for growth, but you have to actually like finance.
cons:
There are tons of metrics to adhere to, and managers are controlling. Let me be clear, you are not micromanaged, you are controlled to the point that you cannot get up to use the restroom. 

You will be berated if your computer does not work, as if you are supposed to fix that. 

If you bite back, your managers will gaslight you into thinking that you are the problem, not the super bizarre environment that they have created.They will ask you, if you are only "there for a paycheck?" The answer is yes, because they're only "there for metrics." 

The environment is not collaborative, and they will use you up until you are done. They are not dumb. They know exactly what the average associate's shelf life is(a manager told me so), and they will coldly and callously move on. 

I have seen world class people, get eaten up and swallowed alive. When you quit, you will be given a box and literally pushed out the door.

In my role, there is a fair amount of autonomy given that it's a call center type of environment but once you get past the entry level positions, it gets better.

headline: Good place to start right out of college, but rampant incompetence
pros:
- There is a big focus and investment on education, training employees
- There is a strong focus on diversity and Employee Resource Groups
- Colleagues are friendly, managers treat their employees with respect and kindness.
- The company has a new talent pipeline in its internship program, and a great bootcamp program for new hires. The company's best employees come from this program.
- Embrace of Agile Scrum and Kanban
- Upper technical management is staffed by good, eager, and talented people that want to change things for the better.
- If you are a go-getter, there is much opportunity to make it up the ranks.
cons:
- Low technical talent: The company uses about 45% contractor workforce (even in the US). A lot of technical knowledge leaves company every year. Huge turnover rate in the technical ranks. Many of these contractors have low skills that do not match their resume.
- While it is good the company gives people low on experience a chance (sometimes the first chance of their career), the flip-side is that there are a lot of people that don't know what they are doing. Huge brain drain in the early 2000s at this company that the company never fully recovered from (many firms in the same industry experienced the same).
- Very incompetent teammates. "Very" with a capital "V". You have to constantly get on people just to get the work done that they promised to do. Sometimes takes weeks to find an administrator to grant access or turn a setting on. Sometimes requirements are completely misunderstood.
- Agile scrum meetings go on for too long. Oftentimes, over half a day is spent in meetings. The prevailing attitude at the company is that strictly adhering to Agile ceremonies will magically get the Sprint work done.
- Non-technical people are scrum masters (SMs): Although it is technically not a requirement, it is a bit of an obstacle to have non-technical people as SMs for Software Engineering work. Despite my 17 years of experience as a Software Engineer, I often found myself being contradicted by SMs with less than 5 years experience, and zero years as a Software Developer. Sadly, most (but not all) SMs have very little interest in understanding the the work they were SMing for.
- You ask a question, and people are either too busy to answer, or nobody knows the answer. Either way, You are basically on your own to figure things out

headline: Not a great place to start a career in tech

Competitive benefits package
Flexible work schedule
Most people have good intentions
Seems to be a good enough place once you get to a ~Principal level as the pay + bonus potential + 401k contributions begin to stack up
cons:
Pay is considerably below average for software engineers, or tech more broadly
Rising through the ranks can be difficult and incredibly frustrating as there is a lot of politics involved
You can go a lot farther doing mediocre work on side projects rather than outstanding work for your project team (which, by the way, typically has well-defined KPIs and revenue implications unlike the one-off side projects)
Possibly depends on business unit, but rarely feels like the work has substantial impact on society
Can be a very slow process to adopt new technologies and paradigms

headline: "Technologists are expendable"
pros:
- I worked with some very smart people. It's a shame they worked here where they aren't at all valued.

- Work isn't challenging at all. You can coast and do nothing all day and slip through the cracks.
cons:
Software engineers at fidelity are very low on the totem pole, probably a step lower than call center employees if I had to guess. 

The compensation is insulting. I went to a competitor in asset management for the same role level and tripled my compensation. You could probably quadruple your compensation by going to amazon, google, etc. A senior software engineer with 10yrs of experience at fidelity makes less than an entry-level software engineer at JP morgan/bank of america/goldman sachs with no years of experience. Don't work here unless you are in asset management. Those are the only people who make any real money.

The tech is severely outdated. Some engineers were working in COBOL while I was there. Once again, this is insulting and shows that no effort is made by management to invest in good tech. 

Management makes it very clear that technologists provide negative value, we were even told this during out first week. "You are a cost center" -- I can't tell you how many times I've heard this. It's so obvious. Why do you think there are barely any technologists in the Boston HQ? Instead they're pushed to the basements of New Hampshire and Rhode Island.

Bonus is insulting too. Don't count on that. 

People brag about the generous 401k match but it doesn't kick in for 5 years. That is 5 years you could be working as a technologist at a competing asset manager making triple your compensation. 

My first week at Fidelity a manager told me that technologists are expendable because their job can just be outsourced. Ouch.

This company has no path forward. Mutual funds are a thing of the past now that low-fee ETFs have become so popular. And their brokerage is so outdated.

headline: Fidelity is great and Audit is an excellent place to start a career, but back office work can get stale after a while.
pros: Excellent work/life balance and culture. Benefits are unrivaled and base pay is competitive. Strong emphasis on collaboration and personal development. Exposure to a wide range of businesses and functions with room to specialize in areas of interest. Great pool of talent to work with/learn from. The work is dynamic and engaging, but never overwhelming.
cons: Highly political, promotions are generally based on time served instead of merit, adoption of Agile has resulted in more time spent in meetings than auditing. Leadership is more focused on pleasing clients than issuing good audit reports. High turnover as a result of top talent often being underutilized.

headline: Tiring and Thankless Job
pros:
- Will hire almost anyone who applies
- Benefits are good
- 401k match
- Potential to get licensed, where you go after that is up to you
cons:
- Definitely a call center, anyone who tells you different is lying
- Turnover rate is ridiculous, they hire 30 people a month to fill all the vacant roles
- Only real incentive is monetary
- Monitored on every call and if you don't have a high enough calls per hour you get in trouble
- You do not learn any real transferable skills, unless you go to another call center
- If you think you will switch roles quickly so you are not on the phones, expect to do a minimum of two years answering phones for 8 hours a day
- They tell you the customers are nice, but that is very far from the truth I would say roughly half are very rude

headline: Great benefits, too much office politics, no concern for employee's mental health
pros: Benefits are great. Work environment is casual. If you like investing and financial industry, you might be happy.
cons: Though the possiblity of starting in customer service and growing into other roles is highly used as a selling point in the beginning, it is nearly impossible to actually do it due to the office politics. Layoffs or forced resignations have become the norm- they are always trying to do more work with less heads. Finally, if you have any kind of personal crisis, it's fine for a day or two. but if it affects your mental health and ends up causing long-term issues...good luck! You'll likely be PIP'd out of there in no time.  As for the work/life balance they are currently advertising, the flexibility is a joke if you have a family. Yes, it's flexible for the young, childless demographic, but if you need true flexibility, steer clear!

headline: Amazing company!!!
pros: I am so lucky to work for this company, and no I’m not sugar coating it, it’s actually awesome! We are going through a pandemic right now and I feel so appreciated and valued. They have gone above and beyond to make this transition so much easier, not perfect, but it felt effortless. The benefits even prior are unmatched, you come to work but folks care about you and you leave work feeling like you made a difference. I haven’t been here but a few months and I’ve already moved up! Your career is what you make it, so you must be proactive and go after it yourself! Also, managers treat you like an equal and genuinely want you to excel!
cons: Overtime can suck, and you sometimes question how to move up, but you are never alone in it!

headline: Drains you
pros: The people you work with, and that they pay you to study.
cons:
This job will literally drain your life, you're answering 30-40 phone calls per day. You're graded on your CEI (customer survey) and your CPH (call per hour), which sometimes you get surveys for calls that is not your department (wtf 401k calls).

Promotion is not based on your CEI and CPH alone, they will promote you if they like you enough. Good luck on getting a manager that you'll get along with, some of them don't care (looking at you Lauren, coming in at 11am and leaving at 3pm), and some are so obsessed with stats that they'll work your until you die. 

Oh you're putting in overtime? That's great, we're expecting you to, who cares if you don't have work/life balance. 

Stay away from this job if you can get anything else. Don't believe it when they tell you 'oh here is a Ping Pong table you get to use', or 'you can sit anywhere you'd like', because they're too cheap to build their own place, and they're overcrowding this office. 

P.S. you better drink that koolaide.

headline: We'll all judge companies by how they treat people during tough times.
pros:
Fidelity was always a great place to work, now that covid-19 has hit they have stepped up beyond compare. Within days most employees were working from home, a week later new benefits we're rolled out to support people in these tough times. Incredible 😍

Leaders have stepped up beyond belief, I've always heard over communicate but now after 20+ years in software I've finally seen it in action. Daily and weekly updates with videos and open sessions to ask questions and just talk. 🤩
cons: None that I know 💪

headline: Headed In The Right Direction
pros:
1. Above Average Pay Mostly. Great Benefits! Great Retirement. Match 100% of your contributions up to 7% after a year and 5-year vesting program. Plus a 10% profit sharing contribution each January! Tuition Reimbursement and more.
2. Numerous different business units and sub-groups, many different career paths, multiple locations. Working remote up to 100% a possibility for many positions (off-phone), depending on business group.
3. Mostly good opportunities to improve your skills and knowledge.
4. Massive population to network.
cons:
1. Bureaucracy still reigns. Common Sense doesn't always prevail. The simplest things are made complicated... Every time a new senior leader arrives, there is a re-org or re-alignment... They say associates have a voice and they do survey associates, but if you speak up otherwise, do so at your own risk...
2. The company is making great strides towards improving career mobility but many legacy barriers remain in place, including attitudes of hiring managers and their superiors.
3. Very conservative company when it comes to risk...decisions are made by "committee" after exhaustive discussions, even over the most smallest and trivial things. Many times your work gets trapped by becoming all about the process and not the outcome.
4. Top Heavy. Appears to be a large population in the lower pay grades, but very few in the middle (managers, sr. managers), and an enormous Director, VP, and above segment. The top segment is all about taking care of each other when not competing or fighting one another.
5. Unless you sexually harass someone or get caught stealing something, no one gets fired unless it's an overall reduction in force. Lazy or inept associates are coddled or passed along.

headline: Wonderful place to live a well-rounded life
pros:
The work-life balance, benefits, and compensation package are the best I've ever had at any companies. The culture is collaborative and not stressful. There are many senior leaders that are women, including many that have young children at home, which I believe helps set a great tone for work-life balance.

Given the business is privately held and family run, I've found leadership to demonstrate more long-term and strategic thinking compared to large publicly traded companies. There is a desire to deliver today and plan for tomorrow.

Over the last few years, there has also been an earnest push to keep pace on rapid innovation with the rise of fintech and operate under agile principles. People do value pace over perfection and speed to market, but there is still a ways to go to truly be agile.
cons: Like many large companies, it can be bureaucratic and slower moving than I'd like (although better than most of the large companies I've worked at). Some individuals are motivated by self-interest and politics and kissing up can trump business results.

headline: Good Pay / Head Games / Verbally Abusive Reviews
pros: Fidelity offers a competitive compensation package
cons: In the financial center I worked, the monthly review was a verbally abusive situation.  It would involve personal insults  and create a "damned if you do, damned if you don't" atmosphere. When achieving stated goals, you would be berated in the "way" you achieved the goals. The corporate culture at Fidelity claims an "open door" policy for its employee's. In reality, an employee is committing career suicide by complaining about an abusive situation. In my 25yrs as a financial professional, I have never worked in a more toxic unprofessional environment. Perhaps brought on by age discrimination.

headline: No movement out of Call center
pros: solid benefits and bonus, was able to get Series 7 +63 after a year
cons: You take about 80 calls a day, Managers are not helpful and make the job even more stressful. They care more about customer satisfaction than they do employee satisfaction. Under payed and over worked. Expected to work overtime hours and shamed if you opt out. Don't work here. my mental health is still recovering from this sweat shop of a call center. They rant about how great their benefits are (7% comp match) which would be good if you made more than what they pay. The calls suck, customers are incredibly rude. No flexibility on hours and not very understanding on leaving early. I would not recommend this role to my worst enemy. I left on my own terms and met some really good people their but everyone is miserable because the job is ..... also don't expect to use this as a 'foot in the door type' because once you're in the call center there's no movement out. I was their for 2 years and got promoted within the call center but never once met or saw anyone get an opportunity that didn't involve answering the phones. Look elsewhere

headline: Stable, established technology-heavy company
pros:
- Long-established company
- Numerous business units offer a variety of lateral transfer opportunities
- Not one of the "bad guys" of the financial world
- "Fidelity nice": a culture heavily focused on comity and professional behavior
- Excellent compensation and benefits
cons:
- Probably the most hierarchical management culture I have ever experienced. Management evaluates ideas largely based on the pay grade of who submitted the idea.
- In the technology space, change is excruciatingly slow. Initiatives flow almost exclusively from the top down.
- Performance reviews are based solely on the feedback of your manager, so a poor relationship with your manager (or an indifferent manager) will doom your career.
- Underperforming employees tend to stick around in their current positions (making life difficult for their team members and customers) rather than being nudged into other roles.

headline: Awesome Place To Work!
pros:
I worked here for over decade, and I really enjoyed my time here. I remember the day I got hired as a temp. My world changed, and I was so excited to start my new hire training class. The people at Fidelity are top notch from the security guards, to the cleaning crew, to the executives. This company is ridiculously good at finding the right people who fit the culture and help others grow.

My manager had flexibility where required, and demanded excellence where necessary. I was never unsure of expectations because of the constant feedback loop, and I always strived to do the best work possible because of it. In my group, we had executive leadership involved as well, and even though I was a lower level employee, they were fun, respectful, and always treated me like part of a very important team. I couldn't have asked for more from Fidelity, and I was sad to leave.
cons: I honestly never had any issues here that weren't my own fault (and I had a few for sure).

headline: Fraternity like culture
pros: The benefits are decent. They offered an HSA account with company contributions (not sure if they still do this), health care and dental at a decent monthly cost, vacation, sick time, and PTO.
cons:
The managers are high strung and a bit too interested in your personal life, almost seemingly desperate to make friends with you.  If you don't want to join your team members or whoever works their for lunch, every working shift, they look at you funny. No, joke the culture is overwhelmingly in your personal business. Not recommended for the reserved type or the "I need a break from you all" type. There's also a company ball (no joke) that they request all of their staff to attend. It's like a company prom, because yes you need to wear a gown or suit. WTF. And if you don't attend, then they look at you funny.

The series 7 training is a joke. The trainers that we had were aweful. One used weird metaphors constantly to teach, and when he was told that his metaphors were confusing he would smile and use additional metaphors to explain the other ones. WTF. The other trainer was on some sort of stimulant, and would constantly speed walk from one side of the room to the other waving his arms around like a monkey swinging on a branch, but missing the branch.

Your “completed”, months overdue, deliverables will also entertain customers, who’ll find fascinating features as they test your application in production and with real money

headline: LEAP Associate Software Engineer = Grand Opportunity
pros:
Within the LEAP Program as an Associate Software Engineer, you get trained for roughly 12 weeks. After this, you'll have dedicated project time where you work on a real project within Fidelity Investments. A great plus is, you get paid during training. You'll learn things such as front end, middle tier, and back end technologies. You are basically getting equipped for your future role within the company. You work closely with your manager and they'll try to find the best role for you. Ie, if you want to work more on front end(html/css/angular), they'll try to find the best role for you. 

Trust me, as a recent college graduate, this program is unreal. It truly is a gateway to success for your Software Engineering career. It helps you get your feet wet, and feel the least bit comfortable to get off to a good start. 

Here is a list of Pros:
- 401k match (7% at 100%) + ~10% profit sharing (Ie: its ultimately 17% 401k match)
- Student Loan Assistance (Up to $10,000) 
- Great networking along the way (You are in classrooms with recent graduates just like you. Great life long friendships and connections were made!)
- Learning Front End, Middle Tier, Back End Technologies (The general ones Fidelity uses.... and no, these aren't legacy software technologies)
- Learning coding concepts/design patterns
cons: There aren't really any cons. You are getting paid to learn(say what?). It is what you make of the program.

cons:
The pay is not comparable to other major investment firms, and it doesn't keep up with cost-of-living increases we've seen in the Denver area. 
There is also a big difference in what some managers bring to the table versus others. There seems to be a 50/50 spilt between managers who show up, coach their team, and support their associates and those who, frankly, don't. If you get one of the managers who doesn't, there is no opportunity to switch.

headline: Just a Cog in the great machine
pros:
-Benefits
- Flexibility
- It honestly is a good place to start but dont plan to stay for too long
cons:
- Fidelity views all of its employees as easily replaceable. This was emphasized when Abby Johnson and Kathy Murphy said in the most recent town hall that because they always have so many people come back to Fidelity it doesn't really matter to retain them.

It's a good place to start, but there's only so much growth with in the company

There is no way to change things at a decent pace. In my role my manager knows there are issues with how things are run, our director is also aware of them, and the site GM has some knowledge. Each level agrees with our issues and agrees that present solutions make sense, but that they have no power or ability to do anything about it.

Good training and coaching for people with limited experience in the finance industry
cons: Long commute down to the Denver Tech Center from Denver itself,  it is essentially a call center job so prepare yourself for long shifts and sometimes painfully frustrating conversations with clients. Fidelity as a company is great but the job isn't glamorous.

headline: Fidelity
pros: I think Fidelity is a great place to start your career. Their benefits are really good and affordable, and they have very generous PTO and 6 weeks paid paternity leave for men. I have read a lot of reviews about there being a lack of movement. I can honestly say that I could see that being an issue for some people. In my own experience Fidelity rewards being ambitious. A lot of people here have been in their role for a very long time and become jaded. Be ambitious,  take initiative, and it's not that hard to move up here. Comparitively there is a lot of opportunity here, if you miss out on that you have nobody to blame but yourself. Not to mention every manager I have met at fidelity seems to genuinely care about advancing your career. Quarterly comp is nice. Working from home is a other nice part if fidelity, but this also varies depending on your function.
cons: The salary is the worst part. You get quarterly compensation which is nice and can be a lot depending on your function but they rarely budge on raising your base pay. This is used as an excuse to not raise your base pay when you move around. Also, this is a call center job so not specifically a con to fidelity but these type of jobs have their ups and downs.

Sounding good and being liked by your manager is more important than being effective, liked by your colleagues and trusted by your direct reports.

headline: Join and ruin your career
pros: The Indian arm of Fidelity Investments gets huge support from the US, hence you have greater transparency with the organization. Very good compensation scales and equal pay according to your grade, which is very rarely seen. A variety of benefits like insurance cover, meal card worth 1150 every month, flexible timing, free transport, work from home option, good leave policy.
cons: If you get offered as a Java/Fullstack developer role and the hiring BU is Asset Management, and you decide to get onboard, congratulations, you will ruin your career. After you join, they will ask you to do testing also. According to them a fullstack developer is the one who does backend development+automation testing+manual testing. And that too, the tools used are a decade old. No scope outside, no use of anything as whatever you learn will not help you in the future for other companies. Very toxic work environment, no work life balance. Often you will end up staying till late night. Very short and strict deadlines. They will also make you work in L2 support, in the weekends, you have to attend to bug fixes. Yes think many times before you join this BU.

headline: Best Employer.. I never want to leave
