headline: Emerging Leader Program
pros:
Fidelity at large is a good company to start your career in, there are great people at the firm always willing to lend a hand and offer career help and connections. Different from other financial services companies, Fidelity doesn't work its employees all day and night so you'll have a social life and get sleep.

I joined Fidelity after college as a part of the Emerging Leader Program - a new 18-month rotational program for college graduates based in New England.  The program pros are: 
- Exposure to senior leadership: many 1:1's with VP's, SVP's and executives once in a while
- Opportunity to travel: ad hoc and there is a trip ELP plans to tour the different Fidelity sites
 - Working new jobs/roles: you won't get bored for too long since you are rotating every few months 
- Comradery:  You do the program with other new college grads and you build a great comradery and makes the experience fun as well as gives you great new friends. 
- Connections: different from networking, you will meet great individuals along the path that will be sincerely great mentors, rotational managers, and friends at the firm.
cons:
Though the Emerging Leader Program was designed to allow liberal arts graduates to learn about financial services in an "elite" program, it has its severe downfalls and ultimately I do not recommend this program to anyone considering starting their career with ELP. My cons are as follows: 

- Commuting: for New England based associates, you are expected to travel to your assigned rotations in either RI, NH, or Boston. These assignments are chosen subjectively by your manager, and you do not know up until 3 or so weeks before your rotation begins. Though you can express interest in rotations that are based in Boston, NOTHING is ever certain or clear, you may be left surprised at your unsatisfying assignment. Not everyone in the program will get assigned a rotation that requires 2+ hours of driving so you may be a part of the unlucky few that is left to drive into the woods for a dark 4 months. You cannot log your miles driven so you do not get reimbursement for gas, the low compensation does not help  cushion the cost either.

- Rotation assignments:  The program  gives associates three 4-month long rotations in different business units within fidelity. If you have an interest in a certain group - finance, strategy, personal investing, etc. there is no certainty that you will be able to work with them as the rotations are assigned by topics - operations, product, and data analytics (which they don't even stick to half the time so it's unorganized). The way these are assigned are subjectively your manager who you share your interests with but they ultimately decide where you will go. You may be left unhappy and confused at what you are assigned and the lack of skills developed in 4 months. Management hammers into you to "trust the process" but I caution you not to. The lack of structure to how placements are assigned is the single biggest downfall of the program since final placement is correlated to the work experience you have or haven't been able to build in the past 18 months. 

- Compensation: the comp is way too low for an "elite" program and compared to similar programs at other firms!!

-  Diversity and Inclusion: though efforts are being made to advanced inclusion in the firm and program at wide, don't expect Fidelity to be as socially aware as your liberal arts college. You'll find people with similar social consciousness but as a firm they still have a ways to go - though sincere efforts are being made, culture changing is slow at a large firm. This lack of D&I inevitably trickles down to ELP management and the decisions made so enjoy :). 

I see the program thriving in 5-10 years when large structural changes have been made (which are being considered to be transparent). 

TO BE CLEAR - most of my feedback is for ELP and not Fidelity at large, there are great parts of the firm that are healthy and great career drivers that I would highly recommend.

headline: Emerging Leader Program
pros:
***This review and ratings are oriented towards the Emerging Leader Program, not Fidelity as a firm.***

Meeting Executives: ELP presents several opportunities to meet executives across the firm, and we even have a team Q&A session with the CEO. At the end of the program, we report out a capstone project to all the executives, which is great visibility. 

Enterprise-Wide View: Since you are rotating in all different areas of Fidelity, you get a great view of how the firm functions as a whole. With the firm's initiative to work better as a collective unit (as opposed to silos), this is an opportunity that allows you to bring a lot of insights to different groups. 

Work-life Balance: I have never had an instance where I've had to work more than 40 hours in a week, and management is very flexible if you need to take time off during the day as long as you're getting your work done. Planning vacation is never an issue, management would never say you can't take a vacation or anything like that.
cons:
Compensation: Compensation is extremely low for the caliber of people they expect to hire for ELP. They told us they did 'comp' research and that we're in line with other liberal arts grads in the business sector, but for the amount of knowledge and commitment they are asking (jumping around different BUs and delivering business value straight away, commuting over 110 miles a day some months) we are grossly underpaid. Several of us have done research and know we can get at least 25% more at any other comparable role. They tell us that our amazing benefits make up for it, but I don't see many of us, right out of college, using home insurance benefits or "College Success Planning." Those of us holding out are hopeful that our final placement salaries will be a significant increase. 

Management: Management is not as up-to-par as would be expected for a program that recruits from elite liberal arts colleges. One of the managers has an online degree from a for-profit university and it shows- no critical thought, inability to understand and digest feedback without getting defensive, and has worked her way up using relationship skills without actually being qualified for her position in regard to merit. Her manager, an SVP, is too busy with her other initiatives and only seems to present herself at the "fun" opportunities - team-building sessions, orientation, etc. We as a cohort have no insight into what she is doing for the program or if feedback is being relayed up to her at all. Overall, the management team may be well intentioned but lacks clear direction and minimizes transparency in order to hide the fact that they don't really know what they're doing either. 

Rotations: While ELP may present itself as a cool opportunity to explore different functions, expect to be disappointed when finding out where you got placed. Rotations are based on "business need," meaning that while you may express interest in a particular field, you may end up in a completely different field. Management will try to make it seem okay by pointing out the "positives," but it doesn't address the fact that you may potentially waste four months doing something you have no interest in doing and you could've spent doing something that would actually bring some clarity to your career options. 

Final Placement: Placement after the program is supposed to be based the rotation that you matched the most with and enjoyed doing. However, some people get rotations that have no intention of hiring someone from ELP, and get stuck with getting placed in one of their rotations they didn't enjoy or have to scramble to network to see if there are any opportunities available outside of their rotations. Once that process is done and you have your options (assuming you have more than one option), you don't even know salary information until AFTER informally accepting the full-time position- we're supposed to not worry about salary and instead choose the placement option that best "aligns" with our career wants. After this informal acceptance, we then get the "official" offer letter and sign that. I've never heard of an instance where you don't know salary information before accepting a role, but like in many other cases where things in the program don't make sense, there is always a "reason" for the way things are. 

"Trust the Process" : If I had a penny for every time I heard "Trust the Process"...this is the term used by management as a palliative for the program's serious structural issues. Hate the rotation you're in? There's a reason why you got it, you just have to trust the process. Is your rotation not even close to what your career goals are? There's a reason for that, trust the process. If you ever hear this phrase, beware!

headline: Great place to learn the industry and get trained- then you should leave
pros: Really good training, their sales process is taught to other firms but they do a great job of driving the process home. Best benefits in the industry and they are now offering flexibility to work from home. They will pay for your licenses and CFP. You can learn as much as you want to learn, plenty of resources available for you.  Great place to gain experience.  You'll never have to cold call for prospects.
cons:
At the end of the day your job is to sell a managed solution to the client by giving the illusion that you are actually doing financial planning for them.  The turnover at the branches brings down client satisfaction. It is definitely a what have you done for me lately type of place. Monthly business reviews can be brutal for people who are not producing. 

You might have managers or trainers that have never been in your seat, or could not cut it so they transitioned. Makes it difficult to have them coach when they have not done it. 

 You make just enough money that its difficult to leave, and they do that on purpose. My advice for people is to get your certifications and a few years experience and then look elsewhere before you start making so much that its hard to leave.

headline: Not For Young Professionals
pros: Biggest selling point they offer is their benefits (generous PTO, student loan reimbursement, 401k match, etc.)
cons: I worked here full time for over three years and it was my first "real job" out of college.  Company has a very "boy's club" mentality. Most VPs, SVPs, Managers, etc. (in my experience and that I encountered) were men.  If you start here young and fresh out of college, I can almost guarantee you will want to leave after a couple years, but most likely sooner than that. The corporate environment is stifling. Position title means more here than the quality of the individual.  Fidelity's values and corporate policies will state otherwise, but that should only be taken at face value. You may luck out and end up having a great boss and senior leadership team, but from my experience, those are few and far between.  You are just a number here.

headline: Difficult. When you work 401k on the floor, at least when I was there, it’s back to back.
pros:
Great benefits and amazing healthcare.
401k has a large portfolio, great matching and profit sharing if you are there for years. 
PTO and VTO,  FMLA
Maternity leave 6-7 months, Paternity leave about a month I think. 
Lots of OT for second shift.
cons:
Discriminates against pregnant women and then penalizes you and shames you for having to pee frequently. 
Gives too much VTO and doesn’t anticipate proper staffing to help cover 2nd shift at night. 
Pressures employees to do the impossible and demands perfection yet pays crap, and doesn’t even listen to their employees.
PTO can only be planned. They get angry if you have to take sick days. 
They don’t actually give credit to outstanding employees like they should. I was supposed to get a VOC award but the manager who took it never submitted it even after multiple requests. 
They refuse to change your schedule.
The company says they’re family friendly but they really aren’t. 
They force you to sign a sort of gag order which means you’re not allowed to tell incoming employees or potential employees how bad it is while you work there up to a year after you leave.

They expect you to do all of these ridiculous things during a call, jump through hoops in a quick and timely manner however also need to be able to connect with callers while being verbally abused. 
The work environment is a little toxic. Feels like high school. If you’re not in someone’s click then you’re alone. If you’re pregnant they do give you a generous maternity leave however they are prejudice against you if you’re pregnant or become so. I had to constantly get up and go to the bathroom and had severe vertigo, because of that I wasn’t taking calls which caused my stats to go down. I was constantly pulled aside and “coached”, a polite way of reprimanding, and told that I, a pregnant woman, needed to hold it till my breaks. When I called HR about it I was told other pregnant women were held to the same standards, yet my own sister in law was almost fired because of the same issues. Every pregnant woman I’ve known who worked this position quit because of the discrimination. Doing a lawsuit against the company would be pointless because they can just say I wasn’t adhering to my required stats and NH is an at will state.
Word to the wise, don’t plan on starting a family while working on the floor. They will use every excuse under the sun as to why you can’t transfer departments or grow in the company and why you can’t get a different shift. I was 1:30-9:30pm. After I got pregnant I needed to change my schedule because I couldn’t drive at night. But again I was denied. 
I left the company because my mental health tanked so low from verbally abusive callers and an employer who didn’t care about what was going on and from being isolated because it’s like high school, and I was refused a shift change that I desperately needed.

headline: Would give 0 stars if possible
pros: They have decent benefits and pay
cons:
Where to begin...

- Management is just appalling at all levels. One of the managers said "depression isn't an illness", which just sums up their entire attitude
- People are placed in roles that may not suit them (or may not be what they applied for), and are just told to suck it up
- Office politics are a joke
- Bullying is ignored
- Employees are left to stagnate if they annoy the wrong person
- Really old tech, complicated systems, way too slow to upgrade
- Use a lot of obscure tech so it's hard to find solutions online
- WFH policy isn't clear, and some managers only allow seniors to WFH, while others allow anyone who's passed probation.
- People in senior positions just because they've been working there a long time, who have no business being that level at all
- All the interesting work is taken from Ireland and given to US teams
- Dublin offices are way out in Citywest, so not an ideal location
- Bad quality laptops with virtual desktops that keep crashing, meaning it can be impossible to get work done
- Everything is slowed down by pointless bureaucracy
- Terrible canteen with unhealthy food that's listed as healthy


Overall, your experience depends entirely on who your manager is. If you get stuck with a bad one (of which there are many), it's nearly impossible to escape from them without handing in your notice.

headline: CRA role review
pros: Great and honest company that cares about its employees and it’s clients. High pay and numerous bonus opportunities through out the year. Extensive benefits package. Fidelity wants to help you succeed and grow in your career!
cons: The Customer Relationship Advocate position itself is the most draining role at Fidelity Investments. It has the most turnover, not because of Fidelity, but because you are a customer service agent via call center that services over 10 types of accounts, and you’re a stock broker. You deal with about 50-70 clients a day and 90% of them do not understand their accounts and/or the stock market. Because it is a call center, every minute that you clock in is accounted for via statistics.

headline: Very Disappointed
pros: None that would out weigh the cons
cons: It all begins with job satisfaction, people in general tend to do jobs they enjoy and are passionate about even if pay is lacking, but fidelity has clearly missed the mark. A volume based discount broker call center where even team leads (managers) are frustrated with leadership. Upper management is not there to help build a profitable successful environment but make sure numbers on spread sheet are met. 95% of the people I worked with actively are unhappy with their current job and only stay so they can get their 5 year vesting. I’m truthfully dumbfounded at the lack of communication with management down to reps. I’m disappointed to say I wasted so much time at the company and missed valuable opportunity actually being able to advise build relationships. This company the last two years had tried to put a square peg into a round hole and has lost a lot of talented people. This will continue to be the trend because Fidelity is slow pace when it comes to change. Culture there was absolutely horrible with people just struggling through daily life and I hope those who read this can take this as a warning! Unless you are absolutely desperate or doubt mind being an un valued easy replaceable cog in the Fidelity machine you can do so much better..

headline: review about fidelity investments company
pros: i dont know, i dont know
cons:
It's a call center not engineering company. It's top heavy company. More management than who are useful people. Pace over perfection is Mantra which is nonsense. They just do for the sake of doing and saving their you know, and not for the sake of work. Recently they wasted 27 million dollars during adoption of third party vendor product. They could not identify until later stages it was not the product for their need. Such is the expertise of folks here. Clearing interview is easy here so no expertise at all. People who work here get stuck for long time not able to get out, since they do work here on developed legacy systems, which are like 10 years backward in the industry.
Central infrastructure team provides infra which are just wrappers over APIs like spring APIs or so which just make u useless upon using it. Since u won't know the actual technology since u just use the wrapper APIs . If you are very nice at pleasing management, then u get promotions and not based on the ability or work done. Lot more to say, but enough for now.

headline: Work you like a mule, but great work experience

Fidelity is one of the most well known companies in the Financial Services industry, so this experience definitely boosts my reputation  as a financial professional. I worked in a call center for 2 years where I took 40-60 inbound phone calls per day and man, this was brutal but I gained an immense amount of knowledge about the economy and financial services in general. 

This position is a great starting place if you want a career as a financial consultant/planner.
cons:
- You're a small piece of a very large company
- Lots and lots and lots of calls

headline: Lost it's Way
pros: Fidelity has a good brand and most of the employees are smart and want to do the right thing. It is nice that it is a private company with huge wallets which allows them to invest when the market (stock or job) is down. Good place to work out of school and get some good experience by moving around and trying different roles. There is also a student debt benefit which is good for anybody that can leverage it. Due to their volumes, they will continue to make lots of money.
cons: They have flattened the organization as part of the "agile transformation" and expect you to make lots of lateral moves (forget climbing the ladder unless you are very junior). They have pushed out most of the good senior level leaders or bought them out via VBO. They are catering to young workers who they can pay less and shuffle from one group to another.  Leadership is not engaging or inspiring.

headline: Great benefits but low salary
pros:
You can’t beat the company match on your 401k, profit sharing and the retiree health credit.  Plus if you choose the high deductible health plan they give you 1k towards your HSA.
Other: good nice people/ coworkers. Some work/life flexibility depending upon the job.
cons:
No matter how many times employees tell them that Fidelity pays lower salary than other companies they always say it’s comparative to the current market, and of course they tout all the benefits. For some tenured employees the benefits package keeps them there but younger employees don’t see it that way and just want the base pay.  I was an employee for over 12 years and always felt I was underpaid at the base salary.  They don’t seem interested in retaining hard working, SP rating employees who execute on the work. You have to be a superstar to be recognized.
Other: so many layers of approval to get to any type of decision, lots of group consensus needed.
Career oops: they are all into talking about mobility right now but it seems to be towards more younger employees to keep them engaged.
When jobs are eliminated: it’s almost always people age 40 and above. You can have a department of 80 people and the people getting laid off are always above 40.

headline: Financial associate
pros:
Great 401k match if you can afford to contribute.
Profit sharing, PTO is given at the beginning of the year, the people work with, training program was good when I went through it, they help pay back your student loans.
cons: It’s a typical call center with hours all over the place. They will tell you there is no “mandatory” overtime but there is and if you opt out of it you will get nasty messages. Bonuses are based off of call surveys which sometimes you will get a bad survey that wasn’t even from a call you took and there’s nothing you can do about it. Even if you move to another product you will still be overloaded with 401k calls. If you have to go to the bathroom and it’s not during a break or lunch it counts against you. If you don’t plan your days off at least a month in advanced it counts against you. There are more things that count against you then for you. The environment has gotten really bad lately and you can feel it when you walk in the door. Fidelity throws benefits at you but then doesn’t bother to check in on the call center. Turnover rate is really high.

headline: Not a bad place to start off
pros:
Flexibility: This entry-level position allows me the ability to set my own schedule. As long as I work 40 hours in a week and make a certain number of calls a day, I can show up at 7 AM or 10 AM. (This is uncommon throughout the company)

Time off: Fidelity starts at 18 days of paid time off per year.  After two years, it is bumped to 23. I love this. It's higher than what a lot of companies offer people with years of experience - at Fidelity it is standard. The negative, however, is that this PTO encompasses all personal time - you don't get any sick/personal/voluntary time off in addition to your PTO. (Excluding federal requirements, maternity, etc.)
Benefits: Fidelity will pay up to $10k in student loan debt over the course of 5 years ($2k a year, or $167 a month.) They'll also reimburse you (you pay up front) 90% of college tuition/coursework costs, up to $10k a year. I am taking advantage of both these programs.
Advancement: Fidelity is not a meritocracy and you cannot move up just by doing your job well and going home at 5. That being said, there is a 'Fidelity way' of doing things, it's pretty simple, and only requires a little bit of off the clock time. In addition, I've never met anyone that won't tell you what their job is or how they got there. Upper management is easily accessible and they often participate in career coaching or mentorship sessions/programs. 
401k benefits: After one year of service, Fidelity will match you dollar for dollar up to 7% of your paycheck. Also, profit sharing at year end can be 10% of your annual salary deposited one time to your 401k. (10+7= 17% of your salary for free to your 401k.) Benefits vest 20% a year for 5 years.
cons:
Pay: You'll get less in salary than at other financial services firms. Fidelity tries to compensate for this with their generous benefits programs. I don't have much experience to compare these to other firms. 
Networking: As mentioned above, networking is necessary to move up here. It doesn't come naturally to me, so I put it in the cons. It does require extra time and thought, and the company won't pay you to shadow other positions.

headline: Amazing company

cons: n / a            n / a        n / a

headline: Bad experience
pros: My co-workers are what kept me there so long.
cons: Management is a joke.  They were extreme micromanagers and very cliquey with each other.  They made it known who they favored and many deserving associates couldn't progress in their roles simply because they weren't favored.  You have to take your breaks and lunches at the exact times they schedule you for (which differed every day) and if you got stuck on a call and went on break late, it would negatively affect your numbers - which ultimately decided your bonus.  This place is a sweatshop.  You are expected to take non stop calls your entire shift.  There is no break in between calls so you aren't even left with time to make notes on the customers accounts you just spoke to - as soon as they hang up, another call immediately comes through with no choice to decline the call.  On average there is at least a 5-10 minute wait  for customers to get through to a representative.  Customers are already aggravated by the time you speak to them - it's like the company sets you up for failure.  They clearly need to hire more people for the role.  The turnover rate is so high because employees are so unhappy.  Glad I'm out of there.

cons:
The call center environment is unbearable.  You’ll be on the phones constantly with your breaks scheduled for you. You only get time off of the phones to be yelled at by your manager for stupid, minuscule details. Nothing you do will ever be good enough.  The constant barrage of awful customers on the phone and negative feedback from management will wear you down.  And trying to get a role off the phones?  Don’t even think about it!  You’re stuck with the stigma of being a call center employee. 
Bottom line - This place will suck the life out of you. The day I walked out was one of the best days of my life.

headline: Bad place to start your career or to grow
pros: The only good thing about Fidelity are the benefits, which is why it is known in the industry as "Social Security Central" in the industry (lots of benefit-seeking, technology-averse folks who are happy to show up every day and pass/push paper around ). Don't get me wrong, the benefits are good: 7% 401(k) matching, 10% profit sharing, good quality of life (at 5PM on the spot the place is like a stampede,) and rarely do vacations get cancelled.
cons:
* Low pay. Fidelity's attractiveness comes from their retirement package but, at the end of the day, the base salary is comparatively low and it does NOT make up for the profit sharing or the additional 4% 401(k) matching contributions. I've been testing the market for a while and found out that I could easily be making 15-20% more (base salary) anywhere else. If you're considering getting a job here, be careful with the trade off because FI does NOT like, and rarely gives out, salary increases.

* Affirmative Action central. Whether you like it or not, there's a surplus of testosterone among Wall Street management levels. It's no secret. So FI has embarked in a program to even things out, which means that most of the people getting promoted as of lately are females and/or minorities. 

* Shady stuff going on. I've seen things that are outright a-legal. I can't say it was illegal because I was not privy to the final product but, having taken countless compliance classes (which you are required to take on an annual basis,) that we are exposed to this BS in such a in-your-face manner is really irritating.

* Management has ZERO people skills. There's a manager in our department that is well known to NOT like to work with other men (everybody knows this,) and he has zero men working with him. Instead of this raising a red flag, it is tolerated an even joked about as if it were... normal. In addition, when hired, I was told that the manager was looking for people to speak up in meetings... only to find out that they seems to promote the polar opposite. This seems to be "The Norm" at Fidelity: Say one thing, do another. There's... I don't know how to describe it... just a "shady" feel to the way they do business. I wouldn't be surprised if FI is in the news one day for having broken some kind of SEC rule soon. Case and point: A colleague of mine recently quit the company. His manager set up an exit interview to find out what the reasons for his departure were. They were in the conference room for 45 minutes and, according to my colleague, the manager did 95% of the talking. This is the kind of craziness you will be dealing with if you join FI.

pros: good benefits, good place to work right out of school (resume builder), opportunity to move around if you are not sure what you want to do with your career
cons:
They have bought or pushed out any decent leaders that knew how to lead, inspire and engage people. The focus now is on young, cheap talent and  "mobility." Forget about climbing the company ladder, they expect you to move around in lateral jobs like you are interchangeable pieces of a puzzle. ( I am on my 4th manager in a little over a year without even changing jobs). 

If you have more than 10 years in the workforce, I would not waste your time here as it will be a dead end.

headline: The only review that matters
pros:
Beautiful campus
You don't take work home
Big name to add to your resume
cons:
Honestly there are a lot of cons. I'll start with pay. The pay is definitely below market value. It's a hot economy and Fidelity openly admits that it pays less because the compensation is weighed more towards benefits. The problem is the benefits here aren't all that great. For example it takes 5 years to get vested in your 401k and a year before you are eligible for any match from the company. This may have been more impressive a few years ago, but many companies will vest you day 1 or within the first year of employment along with a match. 

Career advancement is slim to none for new associates. They have a career center on campus to help provide options for career growth, but the positions just aren't very attractive (phone work and processing work for various business units) and the level of effort to get those jobs is the same as just applying and interviewing for an outside role. There are too many hoops to jump through to move up within the company and honestly most people are in entry level roles for years before they move onto something else. Do you want to guarantee that you make entry level pay for years in this economy?

The biggest con is definitely the work itself. I worked in a phone role in PI and it was without a doubt the worst professional experience I've ever had. Imagine having to describe something you hated day in and day out with a character limit. This is my dilemma. 

The job is ultimately a burnout job. You take 50-60 calls a day while processing requests in customer's accounts. There are numerous challenges whether it is explaining complex trading strategies to people, helping an 80 year old log into Fidelity.com and locating documents, telling a customer you cannot recommend specific stocks to them, calming down an angry customer cussing at you. It goes on and on. This isn't to mention challenges related to technology or hold times within departments. You're getting hit from all sides and will disappoint a lot of customers with Fidelity's policies (and lack of exceptions). The worst part of this job is knowing you did it and didn't build any meaningful experience to add to your resume. You never get to think for yourself or lead any sort of project since you're always on the assembly line.

I would advise strongly against working here.

headline: Overall like the company but major issues in some areas that need addressing
pros: Great benefits and pay. Senior leadership is wonderful, and so are the values of the overall company.  Many resources and benefits provided to employees including profit sharing, bonuses, training, tuition reimbursement and career development resources available.
cons:
Difficulty in advancing, it is a lot of who you know and are network with less of the skills that you bring.  Don't count on advancing unless you spend a lot of time networking with the people/ groups that you are looking to move into. 
Culture especially in the call center can be an issue. A lot of office politics and harassment issues that get swept under the rug by management.  Some are addressed appropriately (if HR gets involved) but there were numerous occasions I have seen management quietly sweep issues under the rug, discourage people from calling HR to protect other employees and things like people getting promoted after sleeping with their boss.  While this is not every area and all departments was something that was observed by myself and others in the many years we worked there.

headline: Great benefits and atmosphere
pros:
The benefits are amazing. Between the health care, the on-campus cafeteria, and all of the various perks, it's unbeatable. The company pays for you to get your series 7 and series 63 exams. You work with licensing trainers to learn the material. You will have to sacrifice a lot during the licensing period, and won't have much free time. 
They really do work on making sure the employees are happy. They like to hire within for other positions, and encourage movement within the company.
cons: For the CRA position, you are expected to answer calls while in licensing. I felt as though it was difficult to talk about the investments while you were learning about them. This lead to customers being frustrated that we could not help them, and we would have to transfer them instead.

With the profit sharing and 401k match they pay 17% into your retirement plan.
cons: They have started to more away from some of the things that have set them apart from other call centers.

headline: Burned out
pros: Benefits are good and building is nice.
cons:
Position consists of taking relentless inbound calls. There is no time in between calls and you’re pretty much hooked up to the computer all day. The metrics they want you to meet are almost impossible to follow so employees purposefully transfer calls to keep metrics low. My
Manager criticized my calls so much at one point I realized there was nothing I could do to make him happy. Mistakes are to easy to make even if you are laser focused all day. I found a new position and was walked out after putting in my two week notice. They are paying me but i was unable to say goodbye to anyone so it looked like I was terminated after being walked out by my manager which wasn’t the case. Employees complained of being burned out constantly and management does nothing. It’s sad cause the employees are wonderful people who deserve at least 5 seconds between calls to stretch or take a sip of water but upper management doesn’t notice at all. I couldn’t take it anymore

headline: Associate Software Engineer (Leap Program)
pros:
Good benefits (compared to other companies with the same base salary).
401k matches up to 7% of your salary.
Total compensation (bonus, profit sharing, retirement contributions) becomes high if you stay there for a long time (5+ years).
In general, difficult to get fired unless you really mess up.
There are established Leap communities to hang out with, where ever you are placed after completing the Leap Program.
cons:
Low base salary and total compensation for new graduates. If you don't plan on staying at Fidelity for at least 5 years, your total compensation would be better if you moved around companies or started your career at a different company.

Average software engineers. There are a few software engineers that perform above and beyond. There are several that plan to do the bare minimum and collect a paycheck. The technical interviews were not very hard, and the ability of the software engineers reflects this. This is not a great place for top (new grad) software engineers. It takes too much time (5 years) for the total compensation to be worth it.

Risk of disliking the business unit you are placed in after the Leap program. You don't get to talk directly with your after-placement manager, your Leap manager will place you after getting to know your interests and personality. I feel like 1 in 3 Leap graduates are not satisfied with their role after placement. With some bad luck, you can be placed in a business unit that offers no growth in useful technologies, no learning opportunities, and no help from senior engineers (my experience). Or with some good luck, you could be using the newest technologies with good mentors, and learning a lot. In general, they expect you to stay at least a year in your current business unit before moving, but you can tell within 6 months whether or not if the business unit and its progress are good enough for you. It is a huge gamble to enter the Leap program, knowing there is a decent chance the business unit you will be placed in will not be that worthwhile. It's up to you if you want to roll the dice. 

Emphasis on company loyalty. They tell you to focus on the "product knowledge",  which is useful to you only as long as you are working for Fidelity, but it's not great if you plan to leave Fidelity at any time in your life. They entice you with a total compensation that increases exponentially from 0 to 5 years. This means a below average total comp at 0 years and an above average total comp after 5 years. Many are promoted based on years of service. Even if you perform twice as well, you will not be promoted twice as quickly - it would be better for you to just switch jobs.

Slow moving technology. The company is slowly moving towards agile, cloud, and other new technologies, but change is extremely slow for financial companies. This means you might not be developing skills that are useful in your career the moment you leave Fidelity. Fidelity claims to be a technology company that specializes in finance, but improvements in technology are often hindered by business desires, such as excessive spending on contractors, and not enough spending on code refactoring and architecture improvements. Its not great for your career to be constantly one step behind everyone else.

To be specific there are hardly any cons wrt to the company. But there a few managers who have come from service based companies and trying to make things harder for employees who have been veterans in the organization. From management perspective it's exciting, but from an employee perspective it's headache. Constant demands for some useless work or other.  Promotions are tad bit slower.
Apart from few cons, it's one of the best place to work in. If you have a good and considerate manager, you can learn,invest in yourself and I'll mb the ladder. I would never want to leave this place unless somesl show-offish senior management guy creates some ruckus, which has happened with many of my friends to look out.

headline: It's who you know or who you are
pros: Great place in general, it meets my basic needs. Great company match, Great profit sharing program, if you work there long enough the pay becomes sufficient depending on your lifestyle. I've been here over a decade and would love to retire here but would love a true opportunity to advance.
cons: There are so many people in one place that advancement becomes next to impossible unless you know the right people are of a specific group. My experience might not be everyone's. There are a ton of business units and opportunities but it seems most jobs that are posted appear to already have a specific type in mine if not a specific person already, but they go through the motions. When the company makes a push for something they are singularly focused, the push for millennials means you see tons of your people advancing which means older, tenured workers are relegated to associate roles. When the push is to empower women, there are networks, seminars and women helping women, sometimes to the detriment of males, especially if the manager is a woman (this is not a misogynist statement). My demographic, african-american male is the bottom rung of every category it seems. There are few leaders in my part of the country with no Sr. Level leaders that I am aware of on the national level? I've been searching the corporate hierarchy for years, while I don't have time to cycle through all 30-40K employees to try and find one that looks like me, it also shouldn't be that difficult if the company is truly as diverse as it thinks it is. I am not saying affirmative action is needed, I'm saying there has to be some qualified person of color (black) that can advance? I realize advancement is based on merit, but as previously stated merit is not the determining factor, it's who you know or your demographics in the vast majority of decisions. The company would rather invest time, effort, and energy in selecting and grooming a mentee that fits the bill than hiring a more experienced individual and doing the same. If you are over 40, black, male then you can work there, you just can't advance.

After you know your job, expect to be bored.  It becomes super easy and you'll find that Fidelity does not value the Utah office. The best advice is, to get a job at Fidelity, then have them pay for your MBA or other schooling, then move to another state to work for Fidelity or find a job someplace else.

headline: THIS IS  A CALL CENTER !
pros:
-Some of the people there are great. 
-Good benefits. 
-Very nice campus! 
-They don't hire for upper positions outside of the company.
cons:
-VERY VERY MICROMANAGED! Get ready to feel like you're in middle school.
-They don't really tell you in the interview that it's just a call center. 
-They do not pay enough nor do they negotiate salaries. Everyone starts off at $38k no matter your experience. So you will make the same as the recent college grad that started with you. 
-What they expect you to know and the quality of work they expect does not match the pay.
-Very very corporate! Management cares about you as a worker- not a person. They only care about you as long as it affects them. 
-If it's super busy, be ready to lose your voice. This is an inbound call center and the calls just come in. You're not picking up the phone. You get two 15 minute breaks and a 30 minute lunch. If you decide that your throat hurts or you have to use the bathroom outside of your two breaks, be ready to hear about how you violated the "call avoidance policy" which can eventually get you fired. 
-Even when you pass the series 7 & series 66, you only make 6-8 thousand more- which puts you at $44k-$46k.
-When you first start here, you have to work 12-8:30pm. This isn't a huge deal except for the fact that they make all the newer people work noon-8:30 but everyone else goes home at 5pm leaving you with not much support.
-Team leads WILL NOT take your 'angry customer' calls. They just tell you what to say - which only frustrates customers more. 
-You must have diabetes or low blood pressure to switch your lunch. 
-They don't hire for upper positions outside of the company. This is a pro and a con.  It's a con because these managers are being brought up from a system that has a lot of flaws but by that time, they've bought in to the things that need change whereas someone in upper management from the outside could see it a lot sooner and do something about it. 
-They do not believe in fun here. "Fun" means buying a pizza and juice that you can try to eat if it's slow in between calls or on your lunch.

headline: Financial Adviser at Fidelity  = Churn and Burn
pros: If you work hard and you are smart you can make an attractive income in the Financial Adviser (Consultant) role. Company benefits are fantastic. Fidelity has a very respected and recognized brand. Largest 401k provider in the US, provides amazing cross selling opportunities.
cons:
There are many.

1) Financial Advisers have 300-1000 households to support and no real help to do so. The support staff is too inexperienced to do much more than help with some admin stuff and if they are good enough to actually help clients they move into a Financial Adviser role.

2) Your experience as an adviser can be made much worse by terrible managers who micro manage and have little knowledge of what you actually do.

3) Assuming 1 and 2 above, Financial Consultant role is too much of a grind to be a career. You either spend 2-5 years there and then move into management or you burn out and leave.

Advisers have 300-1000+ households and there is no meaningful compensation for retention of assets given the book sizes. ($40k year for a $200 mil managed money book? - book generates $1.5 - $2 mil annual revenue and you give the adviser $40k?)

Vast majority of your comp is tied to annual sales and what you have done in the past means nothing. Therefore clients that have a plan and 100% wallet share are undesirable.

Since company is so large and has so many clients they need to fill the chairs with advisers quickly. Many advisers are 20 and 30 somethings with little or no background in finance, they do the bare minimum for planning and only want to sell products and managed accounts. There is little incentive to really deliver a sound plan because that actually takes time and who has time with 1000 clients?

Overall - the reality is Fidelity is good for “mass affluent” financial help but they are too big and cookie cutter to truly help people with more than  $3-$5 mil. Due to size they have to reduce services to lowest common denominator to ensure consistency.

cons: A lot of coaching from management that knows little to none about day to day operations of your role but Hey! That’s corporate America for you... Like to hire externally, which can seem unfair to a employee who has been developing for promotion. Also lower pay of you get promoted within.

headline: Great company to work for with great benefits

headline: Good company - feels underpaid
pros:
It’s a very, very easy job. 
There are a lot of hidden benefits like working from home and high PTO. 
Laid back office life
You’ll get dank karma on reddit with all the free time you spend on there at work
cons:
Feels slow paced
You’ll feel like you’re making 10-20% less of a salary than other firms in the feel
Depending on your department, you’ll work on old tech (software developer working with c98 standard and python 2.6). It leads you to have to redefine the wheel often
Standard 3% raises if you’re lucky
it takes your bosses a while to dole out new work. You’ll constantly find your 2 week sprints have two projects that will take you a max of 1week to finish.
Some days you reach the bottom of reddit and you feel like you’re in high school detention 
On the job experience of the systems you work on is given out painfully slow. 3 years in and I’m finally understanding how the system works

headline: Top Notch Company that allows harassment
pros: The employees outside of management are great. The cafeteria is awesome and the building is beautiful. There is a reason for this.
cons: The beauty covers the horrific harassment that is taking place in this company. There is a male manager that goes after women as his prey and tries to force them out of the company. The higher ups know about this and continually cover it up. I hope the owner reads this and goes to the Morrisville NC site to take a deeper look at all male managers. There are women managers that like to bully. This needs addressing as well. I would never recommend this company to anyone. As you see the beauty of the building it quickly deteriorates into a horrible reality that no woman should have to endure.

Sexism plays a part in whether you can grow or not, but if that’s the case, find another department, and fast. Idk how Fidelity can allow sexism managers to be where they are. headline: Micro Managed Call Center with insane goals.
pros:
Benefits are good- not great.
The campus is beautiful!
Free coffee!
cons:
1. Heavy volume call center- there is no pause between calls! The beep in between calls doesn’t even fully beep. You can’t get a sip of water in- it is that back to back.

2. You will be micro managed! They have a system in place that has your schedule mapped out for the upccoming months ahead! (Schedule adherence counts against you if you don’t follow it to the t.) Oh! And if you have a meeting planned or your computer doesn’t feel up to the challenge of running for the day- that’s counts against you too! 

3.  You will feel like a robot. You have to follow there call structure, miss any built point in the call structure and that excellent call goes to just satisfactory. It is very demoralizing to feel like you have done an amazing job and the customer was happy with your service, but Fidelity and there impossible metrics- not so much. 

4. You are expected to know everything! There is a chat where you can ask questions and get the help you need, just keep in mind it’s one person helping a team of over 25+ people at once! It takes time for that person to answer the question, but all that time is counted against you in your metrics. They want 7 minute flawless calls (over & over) to the tune of there perfect script with nothing left out- even if it makes 0 sense to bring it up!

-Not  diverse at all. All senior management is American. Company is very Boston centric and people come from the same schools in Boston. Company has a long way to go before reaching the diversity levels we see at American firms. Diversity does not mean hiring few foreigners to fix your IT issues. Diversity means promoting the best  members (regardless of their nationality) and give them the opportunity to make an impact
-Not inclusive at all (people keep stuff for themselves). 
- Arrogant culture. Employees are massively under valued
-Flat structure. People work for a pay check
-No discipline. People cut their nails in the office
-Most traders are average yet they do not know the limits of their knowledge
-Company is not techie enough to survive in the long term

headline: 4 years and counting - So far, so good.
pros:
I started as an IT contractor and was offered full time employment.  Great benefits,  work from home,  good people.    The word on the street is salaries are lower but that has not been my experience.  My salary is average for my position.  The bonus and benefits more than make up for any shortcomings.  Yes, you can make more money elsewhere but for me, we are talking 5%.

Technology is older but not ancient.  There are opportunities to learn new technologies but are slow to move.
cons:
It's a big place, so there are some politics and bureaucracy you must learn to navigate.  

Too many "true believers" outside the I.T. group. .... it's almost cult-like among the managers and directors.  This is not unusual as good jobs in general are hard to find and people outside I.T. do not have the same opportunities as I.T. folks.

Recently went to new "open office" layout and it sucks big time.   If I didn't work remotely 3-4 days a week, I would not last.

If you are an I.T. professional, your skills could become dated if you are not vigilant about it.

headline: Run FAR Away!!!
pros: Pretty campus,  promotes healthy eating, good benefits
cons: In accounting you are expected to make every deadline at cost. A co worker went to the hospital and was told "don't they have Wi-Fi?". They tout being able to work from home and having a laptop as a benefit. Sadly it just enables the expectation that you are available at all hours.  Tasks are often assigned with no training and there is a high possibility that most management doesn't know how to do it. However you are held to perfectionist standards with exacting measure. My department was constantly reorganizing and for several days in a row no one was quite sure what their job parameters or management was. Needless to say many people are leaving and they are not filling their spots. The poor people left are taking on the slack. It is not uncommon to see long leaves of absence due to the stress this job puts on your body. One co-worker had a medical exception on file and I constantly saw her having to work well outside what was advisable.

headline: Investment operations manager
pros: Good benefits package, good place to get foundational experience particularly in an entry level role. There are some great people who you can learn a lot from if you end up in the right spot!
cons:
Large company with lots of office politics and red tape, even at times folks engaging in group think. As you move into management this becomes increasingly frustrating. Decisions often are made at the top without involving those in the weeds who know details, ending up with a lot of poorly executed strategic decisions and frustrated frontline managers and associates. 

The work life balance is not always as true as advertised, particularly for those who don’t have kids. 


Salary not always up to par against the industry/ market.

headline: Leader
pros:
1.GREAT benefits! 
2.Truly a place to make a career if you are patient, goal oriented, and deliver results.
3. VERY focused on personal development; there are hundreds of ways for you to grow within your roles and progress your development.
4. The associate experience focus is just fantastic; we are striving and working to help everyone feel like they have a voice and are cared about.
cons:
1. Do NOT apply if you are not a self starter. The culture here is not one for people who cant push themselves and who don't set personal goals.
2. (not a con for me but could be for others) this place will demand your very best every day. If you are afraid of a challenge and would rather be chill and relaxed please don't apply.
3. The associate focused culture stops at the front line associates. From there up it is all about results and there is substantial pressure to deliver. 
4. at a certain level in management "promotions" are not achievable. You are given a laundry list of personal characteristics  that you need to develop. You are told to get a masters degree. Once you achieve these grand goals; a promotion is not "guaranteed". you need to wait for a manager above you to retire or get promoted. Then the promotion process is done as a round table discussion of your senior directors/vps. So even if you fill all the requirements for a promotion it still comes down to advocacy. Advocacy is based off your ability to network and your overall "personal brand" .

headline: Selective Company

pros: Excellent benefits. Friendly people.  Open and friendly culture.

Engineers in the US seem to work around the clock and never seem to implement any of the modern best practices that would make their lives easier.

headline: Excellent Pay but Political Organization with  Lots of Hierarchy
pros: You are working along side very smart, capable, and engaging co-workers.  This is a company that is generally focused on doing the right thing -- for customers and employees.  They do this because they are  proud of their brand/ heritage.  They protect their reputation vigorously.  Be prepared for change:  The organization is constantly reinventing (or improving in a Kaizen manner) itself.   Heavy focus on technology.  Fantastic benefits package.   Reasonable work-life balance.  Coming in as a new employee will feel like you are drinking from a fire hose:  a lot will be thrown at you in a short amount of time.  Hang in there -- it is worth it!
cons: Its a very political organization with lots of hierarchy.  Senior management doesn't always listen to the feedback they receive from employees.  While things change frequently, the changes are typically from the top (and not in response to employee feedback).  Some of the politics are a pain and there are always the 'management favorites' (you will find that in nearly every large company), but you will be well paid for your efforts.

Took advantage of manager apprentices, they have the same responsibilities as a manager without a pay change. One can be an apprentice for a year or more without pay change, then they rotate another apprentice in and take advantage of them.  Upper management and directors also changed frequently.

headline: Financial Service Representative
pros: The benefits are great and the campus is beautiful
cons: They reel you in with the great benefits and the pay sounds good at first, but after training is over they throw you to the wolves and you’re expected to know everything single thing they never taught you. Once you’re in the call center, it’s impossible to get out, even if you’re the top performer on your team. They emphasize work/life balance but be prepared for a guilt trip and lecture if you ever need a sick day. Everywhere outside of the call center seems to be run so much better, people here are overworked, treated poorly, you can’t even take a sip of water between calls most days and if you do then your numbers are penalized. Managers ask you what career path you want to be in but then do absolutely nothing to help you get there. HR is a joke.

HR should talk to each Fresher individually to understand his/her interest. worst part is most of us in our batch were put in areas where they didn't like to work but as it was our first company no one objected it because of obvious reasons.

headline: Find the right fit for you
pros: You will meet some phenomenal people at the company. You will also have pretty solid access to people/education that you would have to pay for elsewhere
cons:
Boy are these people good at telling people what they want to hear. We were all told (by the president of a business unit) that pay would not be negatively affected by an operating model change. I know multiple people who's salaries were adjusted down.

Upper management is extremely patronizing. Though they attempt to cover it up there is very much a culture of "Mommy/Daddy knows best" when it comes to making decisions. This thought process is extremely embedded into culture there; so much so that despite a huge organizational change, my team's day-to-day work is still prioritized by a person who is two or three pay grades above my "boss". 

They also say that career mobility is something they encourage. In practice, getting in tough with internal hiring managers is laborious and conversations are often derailed by administrative interference. 

If you do work here, do your due diligence when vetting who you'll be working with. It's easy to get with people that drink the Kool-Aid.

headline: Finance

My managers (VP and SVP level) only worried about their own jobs - and they lied to protect themselves at the expense of their employees.   Plus - do you really think someone with 1 - 3 years experience can replace someone you pushed out with VBO ?  the rest of the team were left holding the work and failing.

headline: Senior Business Consultant
pros: Flexible, Benefits, low time retirement advice
cons: lower salary, but nothing really else

headline: Apply for every other job in the world before this one.
pros: Pay and time off.
cons:
Everything is driven solely by metrics that you aren't really rewarded for. Customer service is not actually the priority. They have no problem encouraging their employees to get off the phone quickly to get to the next call. You are punished if you don't take enough calls (if you work an 8 hour shift, and take less than 50 phone calls that day, that is considered not meeting your goal). Management will coach you to take more calls than breaths you take. They present all of this in a way that sounds advantageous to you, but in reality it is just another corporation out to make the most money for themselves, and risk the sanity of their employees for that. 
The expectations change almost weekly. It's impossible to keep up with them.
Management will make you feel like you suck at your job before acknowledging that the things they request are unrealistic. AKA taking 8-10 calls per hour just to get a little above the bare minimum on the bonus scale.
"Coaching" is not really coaching. They aren't "helping you grow" they are basically reading from the most generic customer service model.

I am not just an individual that had a really negative experience, I still work there because I can't find anything that pays that well. But these are all very real issues with the company that most employees that I know feel as well. There are way better jobs out there. Mobility is not that easy either.

headline: Customer Relationship Advocate/Full Trader
pros: Some good benefits, good people to work with.
cons: Constantly monitored by stats that are glitchy at best and downright dishonest at worst. Bonuses, reviews all based on these overwhelming stats where every thing you do down to your bathroom breaks is monitored and used to stack rank you. Policies are constantly shifting, trying to move and learn and grow is often stifled. I have applied for 3 or 4 different sales positions, and I can only assume because I am a woman, have been turned down for every one of them, even though my misleading "stats" were good. These are the only ways to make a decent salary. They change your role, requirements and expectations constantly, usually to save the company money, and then spin it is something AMAZING! It's laughable. It's been a decent job overall, but the last year has been disappointment after disappointment.

Many team managers lack the technical skills and professional certifications that many in their teams are required to possess. This leads to a very confined way of working and thinking about processes, problems, and solutions in the department as a whole. Plus the metrics used to assess employee / team performance are outdated.... based on production type of work environments (like sales call centers, manufacturing etc), and not suitable for a company operating in the financial services industry.

headline: Great place to begin your career in financial planning
pros: Good culture that rewards you for taking great care of clients. Fidelity contributes 17% of your salary into your 401k each year (7% match plus 10% profit sharing contribution). Health care plan is affordable and has amazing coverage (90 / 10). Great coaching and mentoring staff - you have all the other consultants in the office to learn from (many of them CFP practitioners), your branch manager who used to be a consultant, another dedicated coach to help you be a better planner, and various product experts (annuities, life insurance, LTC, managed money products, etc.). Fidelity also paid for 100% of my CFP coursework, classes, and exam.
cons: Compliance documentation can take some getting used to. Advancement has been limited to backfilling turnover right now (headcount neutral) as opposed to adding jobs. No ETA on if/when job growth will pick back up.

headline: Great place to work

headline: Depends who you are/who you know- things change daily at Fidelity.  Depends on which manager will implement it.
pros: Starting pay and yearly merit reviews based on performance Lots of OT.  The company match is 7%. You also get profit sharing.  Health and college reimbursements. Company discounts to many companies - just say where you work and most of the time you get a discount.
cons:
Heavy volume call center - can’t sip water between calls. Didn’t hire enough people to fill in after many took the voluntary buy out package 6/2017. 
You’re expected to know everything that has changed and is changing and not all teams are unison in the messages that is announced.  Branding - it’s huge - it’s bologna when you don’t even get a chance to get to know that person- and they don’t forget it no matter how many years have passed, what hardships you have been thru, and where you are now in work life.  Fidelity allowed for managers and interim manager to bully associates.  Managers have their clicks.  You will get wrote up for using PTO when your truly sick.... depends who your manager is!  You will get accused for something you didn’t do- bc your acting manager says you did- won’t pull the call up but purposely stops the audio to say call avoidance calls for immediate termination and I was escorted out.  I transferred the caller to another associate and I never disconnected!

Slightly higher salary for a call center for the area but much lower than the national average for licensed reps.  Heck, it's lower by 10-15k base pay locally.  Co workers are nice and the building amenities (Gym, Stress room, walking desks, basket ball court, ping pong,horse shoes, etc..)  keep the day moving quickly.
cons:
If you're in a license role you almost have to leave ABQ to advance.  The ABQ hub opportunities have maxed out. Denver or Jacksonville might be better places to look into for above normal growth opportunities.  Low pay compared to the national average. No profit sharing but other sites get it.

Location is not ideal.  They should have put this hub on the westside of town.
Hard to get good quality scores for a while because each manage score card was so different.  Fast tracking fokes and nepotism in play.

So there is no process in place at this time to include the extra work into your personal metrics.

headline: Stock Plan Associate
pros: Fidelity has some great benefits: student loan reimbursement, good health insurance, they pay for your licenses etc.
cons:
You are on the phone ALL DAY LONG, dealing with mainly irritated old people.

Fidelity tries to make it seem like their is "a ton of career growth", but really it is just customer service phone job after customer service phone job.

They move you around to different departments to make it seem like you are being "promoted", but really it is the same old crap.

I worked in the Stock Plan Service group in SLC, and was excited to find a career path I was interested in.... Only to find out that Fidelity's generous $10k per year tuition reimbursement policy doesn't apply to you getting THE ONE CERTIFICATION THAT IS 100% applicable to your job. 

You wanna know why? Because everyone who gets it leaves for way higher paying jobs elsewhere. Of course, Fidelity will never tell you that's the real reason.

As soon as I found that out, I started shooting my resume out to competitors in the industry. I easily received multiple offers, off the phone, for way more money. I suggest you do the same!

Oh, and Fidelity does this really cool thing called "loans". Basically they promote you to a higher position, give you more work and responsibility but don't pay you any more money. How generous of them, right?

Managers are overloaded with work and meetings, making them hard to reach and at times completely out of the loop, this also causes problems with guidance, and mentorship.

headline: Great Place to Work!
pros:
The people who work here  are smart and innovative people who love the work they do and most are willing to share their their knowledge and experience.
Technology is state of the art with many opportunities to learn something new every day. 
Some jobs have flexibility and the benefits package and salary is above average.
cons: Most jobs here are not strictly 9 to 5.  If you aren't interested in being challenged every day, learning, and continuous improvement - this may not be a good fit some.

headline: I have had a long tenure at the company and have had many opportunities as the firm has grown and changed.
pros: My managers in the past have been flexible and reasonable. The 401k match and profit sharing are great benefits. Younger employees are taking advantage of the new College loan benefit program.
cons: Our management and employees in many departments don’t reflect our customer base. I believe this will erode our ability to connect with our customers over time. We will build solutions that will miss the mark.

headline: Grew up with this company
pros: Great benefits, meritocracy 95% of the time, quality working environment, willing to promote from within (I started on the phone and ended up in development).  Allowed me to be adventurous and try three careers in 11 years.  Smart and talented people.  Good support for women and many women in management. Beautiful campuses.
cons: Can get stuck in a position if your salary is too high for lateral move.  Bad managers can ruin the experience.  Mission not deeply satisfying.  Low diversity.

headline: IT Architect
pros: Used to be a value based company who cared about their employees
cons: Culture over the past several years has become toxic for IT employees. New management who don't have a clue and spend more time fighting with each other than together

headline: All in all, a good place to be.
pros: Fidelity puts a ton of resources into training and is absolutely all about doing the right thing for the customer.  They do a good job of attracting professional people who are willing to help.  There are plentiful development opportunities and networking opportunities in the form of employee resource groups.
cons: Politics.  They vary by business unit but they can range anywhere from a nuisance to absolutely noxious.  Yes, I understand this exists in pretty much every place, but there’s a long-standing impression that people tend to get ahead based on who, rather than what, they know.  The higher-ups also tend to play favorites and it becomes fairly obvious who those are and are not.

headline: Senior Network Engineer
pros: Free hand in your work
cons: Lot of unfit management people

headline: Once a great place to work, but things are changing......
pros: Fair pay (not exactly up to industry standards, but OK) and AMAZING benefits!  Health insurance, life insurance, many discount benefits through a number of vendors (Verizon, etc.), great short and long term disability insurance and of course a decent retirement plan.
cons: When it comes to advancement at Fidelity the mantra is, "It's not WHAT you know, but WHO".  Your skills and experience mean very little when it comes to advancement.  To get ahead you just need to be friends with the right people.  It matter more who you play golf or poker with than what your experience or expertise is.  And it's starting to show in the quality of the firm.  As is the compartmentalization of duties and leaving major decisions to each units management team with very little oversight.  This has created a few sandbox bullies who have been allowed to run roughshod over their particular departments without any ramifications.  So weigh your options carefully if you're looking at applying at Fidelity.

cons:

headline: Good, But Not What It Once Was
pros: Benefits - numerous benefits outside of the standard package. Take advantage and it will pay off later for you personally.
cons: The mantra at Fidelity is "Do more, With Less". Every year you are asked to do exactly this. The work is 24/7. When you are out of the office there are no backups and you are expected to check in on vacations. You can be very succesful here and have a great career; just know that your work is priority number 1, 2, 3. Everything else is a distant runner-up.

headline: Phone rep for 401k plans
pros:
Paid 8 week training class
Health Benefits start right away
cons: Direct Management puts so much pressure on people that the turn over rate is the highest I've ever seen. They walk around the desk area putting pressure on everyone with high egos and negative attitudes. They constantly bring people in to scold them if they are more than 2 minutes late to sign in on the computer  from break or shift and start docking pay even if you are there at your desk getting situated. You constantly see grown adults running back from lunch or the bathrooms bc of the unrealistic expectations. I have seen plenty of people in tears during my time there. The u flexible attitude is not worth the pay or lack of happiness. Don't get fooled about their high 401k match incentive to work there. It's starts after a year and most people don't make it that long and if they do they are stressed out and miserable

Great secure company to work for, but once your fully vested I would look for higher paying opportunities, unless you’re one of the people that got in good with management.

headline: Not a good place to work at!
pros: No pros as such other than being in EGL, Domlur which is in the center of the city.
cons:
Too rigid, too formal and too many restrictions. Even the cab facility provided is not very flexible in terms of timings.
Not very friendly work environment.
No work from home option for people at junior level (people who do not get a laptop).
Even for people at mid senior level, taking a work from home is not very easy.
The entire Business Analytics and Research (BA&R) team works to provide data driven solutions to optimize Fidelity's Call Center to help demand planning. As it is the work is not challenging at all; after a point in time it becomes redundant and uninteresting.
Pathetic food quality in the cafeteria (You can always go to Pyramid food court to have food).

headline: Fidelity Investments - limited upside; heavy sales culture
pros: Prospecting for new clients was simple.
cons: Compensation structure severely limits the potential growth for Account Executives/Financial Advisors. Product-based sales is also a high priority at Fidelity, which leads to advisors getting pressured by managers to sell certain products - typically annuities - to fulfill unofficial quotas. The Account Executives are not held to a fiduciary standard and may not be acting in clients' best interests.

headline: All Good until its not Good any more an the millennials run the playground
pros: Location, Parking, Cafeteria (expensive) Free Coffee (you will need it), Benefits, Bonus, Profit Sharing, Vacation PTO, Walking Paths, mobility, internal chat.
cons:
Management is very disconnected from associates below director  level. If you are a women dont believe the BS they want more women in senior level position. Very little senior women in technology side or any organization.

If you are over 40 you are playing Russian rullet with career with fido. Culture  is being geared  towards millennial to make them happy only to turn around an layoff tenor employees 

12 year employee still trying to move up while fresh faced 20's come in an refuse to perform the same work as a tenors associate does and is praised like a toddler. 

Dont forget H1B1 visa associates  preferred associate than USA citizen!!!!

headline: Stock Plan Associate
pros: Kind management.  Positive coaching and training.  Easy work/life balance.  Plenty of room to grow.  Company covers all licensing requirements.  The company is expanding rapidly and earning a lot of new business.
cons: Upward growth requires a flexible night shift one night per week.  Calls are back to back all day and can easily exhaust a person.  Every minute is tracked so be ready to take as many calls as possible.

headline: VP

cons: Fidelity can have tunnel vision at times.  Focusing on one thing and DRIVING that "idea" through without regard for other opinions.  And if you have a different opinion, that is expected in open settings.  But once doors are closed...

headline: It's All About The Team You're With

Total Compensation is virtually unbeatable. You'll enjoy competitive salaries and bonuses, along with a 10% tax-free profit sharing dump into your 401k every January. 

Office perks vary by region & location but can include great cafeteria options, minute-clinics on site, fitness centers, and amazing commuter/parking perks.
cons: Lots of inconsistency between teams and what's allowed and not allowed. While some teams enjoy a more casual work environment, others 'enjoy' lunch-less shifts with strict hours.

No career planning exists, left to individual to try to navigate the company and find a spot that fits.

headline: Business Analyst

In other words, you have to really do terrible, and I mean show up for work every single day late, talk back to the manager, never do any work, in order to be fired because if you are trying your best and doing okay they will work with you. This is a place I would love to have when I'm 40-Retirement.
cons: If you are young, it isn't a place where you are put under the gun. Extremely slow growth and tenor means everything. So if you are trying to grow your career I would not go here because it is slow and you will be extremely frustrated. In addition, pay is mediocre because they make up for it in benefits, which you aren't too concerned about when you are young.

headline: Like every company, there are pros and cons
pros: Good company to work for with great benefits.  Beautiful buildings and properties to enjoy with amenities (if you have time to use them).  People who work at Fidelity are often there for many,  many years - which speaks for itself.
cons:
Too many useless meetings that easily could be an email.  

The regularly lay off people - often without reason 

Too many "fire drills".  Sometimes it seems as if the folks liked running around like chickens with their heads cut off regarding some uber-pressing deliverable (I can imagine it makes some people feel very important) but, it often just made everyone look as if they don't have their acts together and were unorganized.  When firedrill moments are coming several times a week  then its no longer a fire drill, its a way of doing business. Which is silly.  Especially because it would glorify the concept of rushing output.  Which, in actuality, was just a breeding ground for errors, and there often were.

headline: Awesome company to work for

cons: nothing really is a con.

headline: Great company

headline: Good Company overall
pros: The majority of the people are nice.  Pay is on the lower end compared to other financial firms and everyone says the benefits make up for it. That really depends on what benefits appeal to you. Personally, it doesn't since I don't use their heath/dental etc. It is a call center that I'm in so the normal struggles you experience anywhere. No scheduled breaks/lunches which is great. My manager is very relaxed so not much micro managing. Just keep your metrics up and no one bothers you.
cons: Very conservative. Might be a pro to you but its a con to me. Lots of "politically correct" type of people.

headline: Company is trying hard to stay updated with technologies
