Free transport
Friendly peers
Encouraging ideation culture
On site visit to USA
cons:
Hardly find senior management who are technically strong. They just boss around and take away associates credit. 
Not many fun activities in company. 
Still way behind on adopting new technologies. 
ON SITE managers are way better than managers in offshore.

headline: Guidance Support Specialist
pros: Fidelity takes the development of its employees seriously. The benefit package is great and makes it hard to leave the company once you begin to work for them.
cons: Fidelity is a large firm, which can make it difficult to change in a fast paced market environment. They can miss incorporating their front-line teams into change that takes place with the organization leading to a frustrated work environment at times.

headline: Top-notch company
pros: Too many to name ... great hours, people, benefits, facility, etc. Even the cafeteria is resort-like! I think you’ll be hard-pressed to find a better environment.
cons: I really don’t have any. Everyone has been beyond kind and helpful and they all seem to really want to be there!

headline: Pretty good place

cons: Very large company with the usual bureaucracy

headline: Benefits Job

cons: Get used to back to back calls, sitting in a cube, and office politics.

headline: Customer Service Representative

cons: Controlled schedule, it's a large company - so you are responsible for finding your own direction

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: Good mobility if you network
cons: Hard to pin down what everyone does

headline: Good company
pros: Great people.  High integrity. Pays well
cons: Politics and inward focus   Lack of Leadership vision

headline: Great work! + too much politics!!
pros: If you are in Analytics. Great place to learn.
cons: Managers are given too much authority to micromanage people in a hypocritic fashion.

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Good Training, Great co workers, good benefits, good entry to financial knowledge
cons:
At the end of the day, it's just a call center. There isn't that much room for growing despite it being a finance company. The job itself is not finance related, so unless you develop your skills outside of work, you can't really move away from the call center.

Managers aren't that helpful. They will spend time trying to coach you on things that might not even matter, or might not even work. They will tell you they will look for opportunities for you, but you are on your own.

Required to stay at your role for 1 year.

Long term for vest/match to go through

Company values high metrics, regardless of how you handle your job. Good Metrics = good benefits, even if you don't do your job correctly

Lots of departments to work with. Very messy and your metrics are dependant on other people doing their job properly.

Lots of favoritism on the office.

Don't leave the position until after 1 year if you don't want to pay the bonus back.

headline: Truly best company to work for in financial services
pros: You might hear "call center"and cringe but the Fidelity regional center are absolutely amazing. I've been with the company over five years now and couldn't imagine working anywhere else. Casual dress, awesome cafeteria very low cost healthy options, the Westlake location is on a nature preserve so there are awesome walking trails to use during lunch or breaks. Lots of windows and natural light. The best benefits like 28 days PTO once you're fully vested. I'm making a great salary that in a career I feel I can stick with forever.
cons: Be ready for change with technology (which I also see as a plus). The new system you're learning will probably change again in 3-5 years. If a review for Fidelity is negative honestly they're probably in the wrong role. It can take a while to navigate to a dream position within the company (five years for me), but work hard, dress for the job you want, and you'll get there! Not a ton of work from home opportunities.

headline: Systems Analyst
pros: Strong Company, Great Benefits, Great Work Life Balance, Easy Going people
cons: Can be difficult to get other roles, not a huge sense of community/culture

headline: This place is horrible
pros: The PTO benefit is really nice, as well as the Student loan benefit. Only thing with the PTO is be careful of how you use it if you plan to leave the company, because they will make you pay them back once you leave.
cons: Open door policy is a lie. If you’re a minority keep your head down and do your work. This company lies about everything and makes up their own rules that goes against their written policy. If you are faced with a discrepancy, chain of command does not help. Managers are very controlling and seek to sabotage careers if they could. Micromanagement is very real in this workplace, management will yell at you in front of others and back each other up to make you look “combative”. Constant changes, no resolutions for errors the company is making. So basically you’re taking the brunt of the heat from clients all day. The pay is horrible, the managers try to make it seem like your raise is a lot, when in reality at most the raises won’t raise you above the $40k threshold. The company isn’t for the best interest of the client don’t believe that I’ve seen so much where Fidelity does things to hurt the client more than help them. I can write a book about this place. Don’t waste your mental health here and it’s a lie if you think that upward mobility is possible. I had a manager try to make sure I didn’t desire to be a manager because she didn’t want me trying to “take” her job.

headline: Archaic
pros: Nice office campus and beautifully maintained grounds. There is an on-site cafeteria that serves breakfast and lunch.
cons: The culture was slightly rigid and very hierarchical. Be careful to learn the unwritten rules around protocol and interacting with senior people.

headline: Have a 2-year exit strategy the day you start working here, and keep it secret.
pros: Great medical benefits, campus is nice, and this is a good place to begin a career. They have tuition reimbursement.
cons: Long term they do not value their employees, and you have to leave the company to get reasonable compensation. Management does not value different opinions even though they pretend to.

headline: Great company to start in the financial services industry, and have a long term career as well.
pros: Training, their L&D department is awesome. The trainers teach you what you need to know to start. Fidelity supports your continued growth if you want to though. Benefits are amazing! Low deductibles on Health plans and on High Deductible plans they give you money each year for your HSA. They have 10% profit sharing on your gross if you are hourly, 7% 401k match (yes 17% total, you read that right). Their fringe benefits are amazing, too many to list. Sales bonuses are based on how happy the clients are in my role and then you get extra on meeting or exceeding department goals. My boss is supportive as well as the team and if you need help with sales  language or tactics there are specialists that help you. Basically you can succeed if you want to.
cons: If you are not top of the pack you may find it hard to advance to the next role, but thats how sales works. To get to Branch offices from the phone sites is sometimes difficult, but if you are willing to relocate it can make it easier to make the transition. When you first start out you don't have as much vacation, about three weeks, but by year five you finally get to about 6 weeks.

headline: Call Center Job. Avoid if you have the choice.
pros:
-They hire good people.  It is nice to assocaite with other representatives when there is time (which is almost never).  Almost every one of my peers had a friendly personality which went a long ways on the bad days (which was most of them).  
-Management was reasonable and let me leave the phone position to an internal operations position before I had been working there one year.
cons:
-First of all, it is a call center job.  The title makes it sound fancier and in the interview they might make you think you are going to be doing a lot more things related to investments than you actually will.  Probably 80% of calls are password resets and simple financial transactions.
-Benefits are good as a percentage, but my base salary was so much lower than what I made after I left that 7%  401k match AND 10% profit sharing was less than 4.5% 401k match at my current company.  There are a lot of benefits that most people don't use that they use to justify how great the benefits are.  Like adoption assistance, tuition reimbursement, college loan assistance.  Just do the math with what you will use and how much you'll get with your salary.  Remember that your base salary grows exponentially with raises and your benefits grow based on that.  Lower base salary now = even lower base salary in 10 years.
-They say they pay for the CFA; they don't.  They specifically told me in the interview that they pay for CFA prep classes.  It also says that in the tuition reimbursement documentation.  There is one stipulation though.  It only qualifies if you take the class from an accredited university.  I don't know of any official universities that offer specific CFA review classes (you take the review classes to prepare for the test, not to get college credit).  I had a friend who took Kaplan review classes and then fought with them for months for the reimbursement and ended up just giving up.  I took and passed two CFA tests while there without a penny going towards the classes.  I don't know if they are intentially tricking people or if nobody knows enought about the CFA to know that the stipulation the put on it makes it null.
-The job itself is miserable.  So many metrics that you have to hit, fielding literally thousands or random questions and complaints.  Constant coaching (telling you what you do wrong).  One time I got "feedback" for saying "no problem" because "problem" is a negative word.  There were days when I would get up, take a shower, get dressed and then call in and go back to sleep because I just couldn't bring myself to go back there again. Some people were ok with it though.  Most, like me, were not.
-Schedules can be bad.  I worked every Saturday after I finished training until I left.  Other people got it much better and others got it much worse.

headline: Tenured Associate
pros: Great benefits, coworkers are awesome, if you weren’t a college grad you could have a good job with great benefits and pay. Often in areas where there aren’t many other good jobs. Upper management wants to do the right thing, but often dies in the middle.
cons:
My biggest issue is with middle management. If associates don’t want to go into sales, the only other option is management, which is often not a good fit. You’d have managers who just weren’t “people” people, who would be leading a team of 20+. Managers also have the ability to make or break your career. They control your pay, bonuses, reviews and even promotions. I don’t believe one (possibly inept) person should have control over basically your life. Favoritism runs rampant, which is awesome if you’re a favorite, sucks if you’re not. I had many managers, some who loved me and would mentor and promote me and sing my praises from the rooftop, and then others who gave me very low performance reviews (how is this possible?) 

They’re just SO HUGE with so many different business groups that people wouldn’t know what jobs are out there. Sales or management was all people knew, wish there was more transparency so people who aren’t fit for mgmt wouldn’t go into those roles. Upper management initiates also die at the middle management level due to their inertia and stubbornness.

headline: Not for strong performers looking for a long-term stay
pros:
There are two details worth noting before beginning my review.  First, every organization within Fidelity is siloed from the rest and even within an organization different departments can be run in a very different manner.  As such the experience can be wildly different depending on where you land.  Glassdoor will not let me post the name of my particular organization so all I can say is that we focused on workplace investing and I was a QA in the tech department.  My review is based on my placement.  Second, different levels within tech are ranked based on letter designations.  A TA is an entry-level engineer, TB is an engineer, and TC is a senior engineer.  TD is either a principal/lead engineer or a manager and every letter higher is a leadership position. 

1) Benefits and Initial Compensation
For those hired outside the company, the initial salary will typically fall around the market average plus any position at a TB level or above qualifies for a bonus.  The benefits are also very competitive.  The retirement package is practically unbeatable with a 7% match and 10% profit sharing contribution each year.  Health insurance rates were constantly creeping higher but were still reasonable and coverage was strong.  PTO was very generous for salaried employees.  There literally aren't enough desks for the employees so most people are allowed to work from home at least a few days a week.  There are also a handful of minor perks that you can enjoy like a small reimbursement for the purchase of fitness equipment or extra payments made towards existing student loans, up to $2000 a year for five years.

2) Campus
The main Durham campus has been extensively renovated over the years and for the most part is very nice.  Every floor follows the open-office concept which makes for a loud and exposed experience at a desk and the conference rooms have glass walls so privacy for meetings is sorely lacking.  Also, the stairways and back hallways have not been renovated and tend to smell like mouse traps thanks to a constant rodent problem.  However, the main spaces are well-lit and nicely decorated, desks are generally well-equipped, the front entrance makes a good first impression, parking is plentiful, the outdoor walking paths allow a chance for some fresh air, and there are certain on-site amenities that employees can use like a health clinic, tech support bar, cafeteria, and small gym.  Bear in mind that the latter two are not particularly cheap or well-equipped and are more for convenience than a cost-saving measure for employees.

3) The Employees
In the years that I worked here I met some wonderful people at the TA-TC level and a few at the TD level.  Even though I have left the company I still make an effort to stay in touch with these individuals and am glad to call them friends.
cons:
1) Long-Term Compensation
While the initial package can be competitive the generosity will deplete very rapidly over time.  Even in a good year strong performers were lucky to get a yearly raise over 2-2.5%.  Raises for promotions, at least from TB to a principal/lead level, were an embarrassing 5% plus the potential for an extra 5% to the bonus.  HR and leadership would constantly try to use bonuses as an excuse for low salaries by claiming that it could help hard workers make up for the difference in their declining salaries but due to fine print the bonuses rarely met the advertised amounts.  For example, a TB qualifies for "up to" a 15% bonus.  However, bonuses are paid from a special budget that typically gets funded 80-90% in a good year.  Bonuses are also based on performance and even a strong performer would typically get 80-90% approved while an average performer could get 50% or less.  This math means that even during a particularly strong year for the company  a top performer is likely to see their 15% bonus come in at around 8-10%.  In spite of all the articles Fidelity posts about how to convince one's boss to increase one's wages there is zero room for compromise here.  The typical excuse from management is that if they adjusted someone's salary it would only make that person happy for a few years before that person would fall behind the market and complain again so management is better off leaving people where they're at.  Meanwhile salaries are regularly adjusted for Leap hires leading to TAs and TBs making more than many TCs and TDs.  To put the compensation gap into further perspective, many top performers were making more than 20% under market value after 2-4 years at Fidelity.

2) Low Technical Innovation
Technology here tends to lag behind true tech companies by 5-10 years and most of the higher level staff don't keep up with the times which means that even when new tech is pushed it is usually done without proper planning or understanding.  QA has yet to adopt an effective strategy for automation, they are still primarily using expensive licensed products instead of moving towards open-source, and the majority of the QA staff has little to no practical experience with automation or development.  Dev only cares about pushing out as much new stuff as possible with no regard for design or long-term quality as shown by the complete lack of unit tests or acceptance criteria.  Focus areas that would seem to be up-to-date fall short.  The mobile apps for example have consistently scored ratings that are average at best and are prone to performance issues, bad design choices, and bugs.  Most of the projects claim to be agile but every single agile project that I worked on was just a waterfall project with agile terminology mixed in.  It was common to see 6-12+ month projects that claimed to be agile even though every proposed feature was committed to by management on day one with no input from the team.  Even with hot technologies like blockchain and cryptocurrencies Fidelity pretends to be paying close attention while remaining willfully blind behind the scenes.  This lack of innovation and understanding can have an impact on engineers besides making the projects boring or frustrating.  If you aren't making a personal effort on your own time to keep your skills sharp and instead rely on your job to provide this exposure then you will quickly find yourself falling far behind the market.

3) Leap
Leap is a program used to recruit college graduates.  Every single year hundreds of new, largely inexperienced TAs from across the nation are hired and put through one of the various tracks, software development for example, for six months in the Leap program before being placed in an organization.  The first two months are classroom training and the latter four are spent on a project.  Unfortunately Leap's training does nothing to prepare these associates for their career.  The classes are too generic and broad and instead of using in-house staff to help provide mentoring the Leap management hires external contractors with no experience in the company and sometimes little experience in the field.  Even in the rare cases that internal management or company representatives did lead a particular class session their talk was focused more on random Fidelity information like the makeup of the executive team or pictures of the various campuses instead of useful material for the particular track.  The projects meanwhile are throwaways that rarely serve any purpose beyond keeping the Leap participants busy.  The problems don't end with Leap graduation either.  Hundreds of TAs are being brought in yearly but the company will rarely need hundreds of new TBs or TCs each year and TD roles are incredibly rare so the result is that many engineers find little room to grow once they are placed in their organization.  The company refuses to release official numbers but the general consensus is that turnover among Leap grads within their first two years of placement is abysmal.

4) Politics
The only way you could find a more political workplace is if you went to work for Congress.  A strong performer would generally still get raises and could potentially work their way up to a TC level but for the most part recognition and job security were more about cozying up to leadership than going above and beyond in your job.  Talented engineers were constantly leaving because they were being passed over for promotions or opportunities in favor of poor talent that played into the politics.  The best example of politics would be the yearly review process.  Like most companies Fidelity forces employees to fill out a self-evaluation each year then go through an end-of-year review with their manager.  However, unlike most companies Fidelity uses a process called common judgement.  Months before employees can even fill out the evaluations all of the leadership, managers and above, go off for a few days to collectively decide the rankings and rewards for everyone.  As you can imagine this turns into more of a popularity contest.  If employee A did great work while employee B was average at best but B kissed the feet of more people in the room then B was likely to get a better review than A.  Ratings are also based on ridiculous factors like the time you've spent in your current position or whether the final results resembled a bell curve distribution.  Someone may be a strong performer but if the bell curve is skewing left or they haven't been in the role as long as others, even lower performers, they'll likely get an average rating.  It also means that the entire process of filling out self-evaluations is a farce.

5) Career Growth
Many of the employees at a TD level or above are lifers regardless of any value they may or may not add in their role.  Between this, politics, and the massive influx of TAs from Leap there is a bottleneck around the TC level.  Most associate engineers can get promoted to a TB level eventually but to get to a TC level is a mix of a waiting game and politics and to move above that is a matter of even more politics plus being lucky enough to be in the right place at the right time.  Discussions with one'smanager on how to move up are met with excuses on top of excuses.  The most common claim is that an associate has to be performing at a given level for a certain undisclosed amount of time before being moved to said level which equates to strong employees doing work well above their pay grade without any reward for their efforts apart from an empty promise that if they keep it up eventually they may get promoted.  

6) Morale
While Fidelity likes to keep their inner workings private the fact is that they've been systematically laying off thousands of employees over the past two years.  One event back in the summer of last year in which hundreds of people were let go just a month after thousands of other employees voluntarily left managed to leak out to the media and made the news.  In another recent round 100% of leadership in a personal investments organization was forced to reapply for their jobs, 75% were kicked out, and the remaining 25% that got through didn't even receive a pay bump for being rehired.  The expectations for each department are not decreasing, if anything they're increasing, so those who survive a layoff are left with significantly more work to do.  Meanwhile, in spite of record profits continuing to pad the pockets of the millionaires and billionaires running the company the yearly raises and promotions for regular engineers have remained static.  Work/life balance has become a pipe dream.  If you keep your head down, only do the work assigned to you without signing up for anything else, and only perform at an average level you may manage a reasonable work/life balance but strong performers are increasingly expected to pick up any slack in their departments and do more without any reward in return.  It was common to see 1-2 engineers doing well over 75% of the work for their team while putting in nights, weekends, and holidays or vacation days.  Many strong engineers considered it a light week if they only had to do 60 hours.  Allocation was irrelevant.  You could be assigned 100% to one project but you would still expect you to take up additional project work under the table, usually under some false pretenses of being a volunteer activity in which you were forced to participate.  This was made even worse by the overload of meetings that many teams engaged in.  It was common for project members to spend 40-60% of their week in meetings, the vast majority of which added no value, but management would not consider the meetings when planning the project timeline so engineers would still have a full load of tasks to perform on top of the meetings.  Some managers engaged in morally questionable activities like cheating hourly employees out of overtime or trying to cheat former employees out of earned PTO days.  Also, a quick search online will review numerous lawsuits that have been filed against the company in recent years by current or former employees.  If you complain to HR they will either tell you that they aren't concerned with your thoughts or they'll leak information back to your manager and you'll be punished for "unrelated reasons".  Needless to say, when combined with the other issues already listed above it's no surprise that morale here was sorely lacking. 

7) Leadership
Every single issue listed here and more all point to one major problem - leadership.  To say that leadership in my organization operated like a "good old boys club" would be an understatement and their ignorance was matched only by their arrogance.  QA leadership was the worst but dev wasn't far behind.  Across the board there is a lack of even basic knowledge regarding quality assurance, software development, or general industry trends and zero attempts are made to improve.  You could count on one hand the number of TDs and above in QA who could write "Hello World" or even a decent manual test case and still have unused fingers.  Many so-called leaders would even argue that it wasn't their job to know or understand such things.  Since leadership has no idea what they are doing with regards to technology much of the work that principal/lead engineers and managers should perform, including testing strategies or resource needs, is being pushed off to junior engineers who are better equipped for the task.  However, while leadership does nothing to support these lower-level engineers leadership would still take credit for successful deliveries or, if a release went poorly,  throw the junior staff under the bus.  This brings up the issue with leadership having no idea how to handle modern engineers or how to run a modern tech department.  The general mindset is reminiscent of an 80s approach.  For example, at a departmental all-hands meeting last fall, the only such meeting all year, senior leadership in the department acknowledged the drastic turnover among TA-TC engineers but then proceeded to rant about those "darn millennials" expecting gifts just for doing their work and how these young people should be "grateful they have a job".  Never mind that these TA-TC engineers are keeping the department afloat while being ripped off in every feasible way and openly insulted.  The general attitude from TDs on up was that they were above the common rabble.  They'll steal a lower level engineer's ideas because they have none of their own but still insist that because they outrank that engineer on paper they are somehow more intelligent.  In an effort to pad the budgets and feign importance it was common to see an overabundance of leaders in project teams.  There were assignments with one lead or manager for every 1-2 engineers even as the engineers did the work the leads and managers should have been doing.  Budget for employee expenses has been reduced to practically nothing.  Those below a TD level rarely get to travel, the laptops and other hardware are painfully dated, even small recognition awards like $20 gift cards have been cut, and there are frequent cases of managers forcing their employees to attend team lunches while making each team member foot their own bill.  Meanwhile management can afford catering for their "leadership building" events, it is common to see senior leadership traveling 1-2 times a month just to check in on their teams, and many senior leaders have brand new equipment even though they are least in need of such devices.  Leadership will ask for feedback but if you do anything other than sing their praises they will complain to your that you aren't a team player or, chew you out in your next 1:1, or give you a bad performance rating.  Attempts by previous leadership from years past to at least pretend that they cared about the opinions of those beneath them, an anonymous online suggestion box or anonymous yearly surveys for example, have been shut down under the reign of the current leadership team because according to them it wasn't conductive to their goals.  The executive team makes no effort whatsoever to reach out to the TA-TC engineers and turns a blind eye to everything going on beneath them so long as the leadership teams reporting to them bows down and claims everything is fine.  The executive team also makes poor decisions without doing proper research or math on the consequences.  For example, right before the layoffs last summer many of the older staff members in the company were "offered" a buyout.  The executive team grossly underestimated the number of individuals that would take the buyout, by almost 50% according to most sources, which means that a lot of teams lost a lot of experience and talent which in turn reduced the productivity of those teams greatly.  Perhaps the best recent example of leadership here is to point to a particular team that was once a gem for technology in the company.  Under the expert guidance of an externally-hired leader the team was able to blaze the initial trail for modern day testing in the company.  A few years ago though the executive team decided to force the leader overseeing the team to a new department and bring in a longtime company veteran as a replacement.  Under the awful reign of this new individual within 18 months over 2/3 of the staff on the team had left the company, multiple HR complaints had been filed against the new leader, and the team had become a shell of it's former self.  Thanks to the "good old boys" mentality though this leader hasn't even received a slap on the wrist and they along with their other leadership buddies will openly criticize every person that left the team claiming that those who left couldn't see the big picture, didn't understand how things work at Fidelity, or were overrated and couldn't actually do their jobs.  This is in spite of the facts that the team has gone from superstar status to an unproductive, floundering mess and the department hasn't seen a major technological breakthrough in years.

headline: Better than most but could still use improvement
pros:
- the ability to work from home occasionally (I believe this relates only to specialized groups.  Those starting out would likely not have this option.)
- excellent health benefits and 401k (on site gym, walking stations, on site doctor, reimbursement on health insurance if you follow a fit program, etc)
- decent bonuses
- some flexibility.  I say some because I have noticed that parents can be given a hard time if they ask to work from home too often or have issues come up.  This would also depend on how "favored" you are with your manager.  See "cons" for explanation.
- awesome coworkers
- longevity of the employees.  This is both a good and bad thing.  It is good because it gives a strong sense of loyalty to the company and knowledge stays within the firm.  It is bad because people assume they are "entitled" to pay raises or promotions simply because they did a job for a period of time.  (Not necessarily that they did it well.)  They are very disillusioned to how the real world works in regards to higher pay or promotions and that can become frustrating.
- the culture.  I do enjoy the culture as a whole at Fidelity.
cons:
- no mobility especially if you are already in a specialized area.  They talk about moving people up or across all the time, but in reality, it doesn't happen.  
- favoritism.  (Yes, it exists everywhere and that includes Fidelity.)  What's hard to stomach is knowing the person getting preferential treatment is a horrible worker while those who do a great job can be given a hard time.
- abuse of overtime.  It's hard to believe that management wouldn't be aware but it seems to be a common issue that is not addressed.  Those working needless hours would get a higher payout on bonuses as well based on hours worked per year.  Essentially they are being rewarded twice for "stealing" from the company.
- the bonus payout really stems from management's opinion of you.  Even being a high performer on the team does not guarantee a fair rate.  In all truth, it's impossible to understand how they derive at their numbers.
- my managers have either been disengaged or came from departments where they had little to no working knowledge for our group.  It's very hard working for someone that lacks basic knowledge of what your work entails.
- they advertise a lot about woman empowerment, but I haven't witnessed it in my group.  I would venture to say it might be the exact opposite.  If you are talented, you are more likely to be seen as a threat and this will be reflected in how you are treated and the type of compensation you receive.
- the "fit" meal program is kind of a joke.  When I started with the company, I thought it was a fantastic idea, but "fit", as far as my coworkers and I can tell, is based solely on sodium intake.  If you buy anything non-fit, be prepared to spend a small fortune for a little portion and average/below average taste.  Items like curry can be unfit.  I don't get that at all...

cons:

+Layoffs are poorly communicated

+The Kool-Aid is THICK

headline: Financial Consultant
pros:
Great 401k match, profit sharing
Exposed to a lot of clients, so you get a lot of experience
cons:
Managers can dictate your future. They control lead flow, and can make you fail if they want.
Higher value leads are given to their inner circle
They say clients first, but it Fidelity's pockets first
They really only care about you selling managed accounts and annuities, and it's a big wheel you are running on. Every year it starts over, not what you did yesterday, what you are going to sell today and tomorrow.
They expect you to be making 40 calls per day, and having 3-4 appointments per day.
They attempt to stress work life balance, but it is impossible to take all that time off if you are running on the sales wheel.

headline: Revoked Offer
pros: The employees dressed nice. (Read the Cons)
cons:
DO NOT EVER APPLY HERE. They could not care less about you as a person. They revoked my offer Today, a Friday and I was supposed to start on Monday. This is right before the Holidays and they knew about my current situation that a family member has CANCER. Not just a sickness, CANCER that I am paying OUT OF POCKET FOR. When they ran a credit report they found something that I didn't even know about, total around $4000. DID NOT KNOW IT WAS THERE. This happened on Wednesday. So I call the collections agency at their request, settle it, give them the information that things have been taken care of and they tell me today that my offer was still revoked. THEY DON'T CARE ABOUT YOU. They will screw you over, spit on you, and laugh about it. SERIOUSLY. The Recruiter did not care one cent. Now I'm completely screwed, no job, cancer, and bills. Oh, yeah! Happy Holidays! 
P.S. I have several friends who use them for their accounts and they will be closing them because of what they've done in this situation. And I will make sure this is all over my social media. This is REAL LIFE. I was COMPLETELY SCREWED OVER.

headline: Leaving Fidelity was the dumbest thing I ever did

I left on June 30 as part of an ‘early retirement’ offer that was to good to pass up. Four months later, I’m seriously regretting ever leaving.
cons: Very few. Maybe the only thing that I could complain about is the company has an irritating habit of ‘reinventing the wheel’ every five minutes. Blink twice and something has changed.

headline: Financial Representative - an exciting career talking to angry customers on the phone.
pros: The pay is decent, the benefits are good, after 6 months you are eligible to begin having your student loans reimbursed. Fidelity puts a substantial amount of effort into training you to pass the series 7 and series 63 tests.
cons:
Beyond training you to pass the series 7 and series 63, Fidelity doesn’t really train you for the job you will be performing. 
Most, if not all jobs, are customer facing phone center jobs. Half your time will be spent dealing with angry customers. Most of the time they were told the wrong way to transfer money, or otherwise service their account, by a poorly trained rep. Other times, a form will be rejected and instead of Fidelity sending an email or making a call, a poorly worded letter will be sent advising the customer to call the general service line instead of the back office group that can actually help with the problem. 
Prepare to be micromanaged. In an eight hour shift, you will get one paid 30 minute break and one unpaid 30 minute lunch. Other than that, you are expected to be on the phone. You will receive “coaching” from your manager if you spend too much time writing notes on an account, if you don’t enroll enough people in the voice recognition system, if you call the help desk too much because you don’t know how to help the customer, if your calls are longer than ten minutes, if you don’t take at least 6.5 calls in an hour, or if you don’t get enough new business leads. Also, your job performance will be judged based on what customers think of you. Customer surveys must be “top box” for them to count toward your bonus.  If you help a customer who was given bad information by a previous rep, even if you resolve the issue, if they’re still unhappy with the overall service Fidelity gave them (which they usually are), you get a poor evaluation. That poor evaluation is then used to assess how much of a bonus you get.
After passing the series 7 and 63 you get a retention bonus. Meaning, if you work at Fidelity for less than a year after receiving the bonus, you have to pay it back. This was put into place because of the huge amount of turnover that takes place once reps are done with the training and start the actual job.
Additionally, you will be taught how to avoid giving anything that resembles investment advice by directing customers back to the website for almost everything.

headline: How is it to work at Fidelity, Gurgaon location !
pros:
So, to start with, Fidelity has a great working culture.  There is a lot of inter team and intra team interaction within the organization. I was working in the operations department and it was fun to work there. 

Firstly, you become eligible for a promotion / IJP after spending 18 months in the current role. Good thing is a lot of IJPs (Internal Job Process) keep coming out. So you can plan to switch your role.
Secondly, there are a lot of fun activities, events and stuff that keep taking place
Thirdly, cab facility and complementary dinner and lunch facility available.
cons:
There are a few disadvantages as well.

1) At times, the promotion process is really slow and delayed. This may result in decreased motivation and frustration.
2) You can't expect a great appraisal. It is mostly 10-12%

headline: Historically strong company, high pay, but in a downward spiral
pros: Fidelity has always paid (overpaid?) its employees, and has been evolving its benefits package to stay competitive. It is a good place for an inexperienced to cut their teeth and learn some tangible skills in a large corporate environment.
cons:
For the last 18 months the entire retail business has been in turmoil with one new "operating model" after another. What this actually amounts to is an impossible tapestry of control and as a result there is no meaningful work getting done as everyone thinks someone else is in charge of making decisions, or worse yet - groups go off to build something in a silo. 

Interestingly, there has been several waves of layoffs during this time, so it is hard to know if this organizational dysfunction is just incompetence by top management, or if it serves a larger objective to pare down the staff. Fidelity is under unbelievable pricing pressure and with flows leaving managed products and share of wallet favoring competitors like Vanguard, the Fidelity workforce will need to be drastically smaller in the coming years.

headline: Conformity Culture.  Innovators and Fast Movers Stay Away.
pros: The firm's client service delivery is second to none.  Abby and her team have recognized that the culture is slow and have attempted to make changes over the years.
cons:
Legacy leaders point to minor wins as progress.  Small thinking and high school culture wins, and friends are rewarded.   Medium bets are avoided for less risky career steadying choices.  

The Voluntary Buyout program targeted legacy leaders over 55, while giving opportunities to legacy leaders...over 50?  A clear message was sent.  What sense is there waiting for higher positions at Fidelity if you are in the first half of your career.

The same leaders drive the same mediocre results, and continually keep positions in the firm.  Repeated service model and strategy changes cannot change the mediocre managers leading each team. 

Leaders in the business with finance backgrounds do not bridge the gap to "innovation" in products, they can measure but are not creators.  Always concerned that if the market tanked, I wouldn't be able to sell products at Fidelity's prices with the cost structure so heavy.

Shift assignment is "random" and you could be like me and get stuck working 
2-11pm for the first 6 months when you were told it would be a 9-6 during the interview process. Even now I'm still not on a day shift. Very little time not taking phone calls and it can be 8 hours of back to back customer service calls during busy season.

headline: World Class Organization
pros: Fidelity invests lots of training, resources and time for new employees. Not everyone makes it in the first 8-10 weeks of training and they either quit because they find out that the job is not for them or they fail the Series 7/63 tests. It's a great feeling of accomplishment after you get through the initial training program and pass the financial licensing exams and you feel like you belong to a strong reputable company. From there you can move on to other departments like sales, stock and options trading, 401K investment guidance, pensions, operations, management, training and education, support desk help, compliance, etc depending on your interests. Everyone that I worked with in management was very supportive of my goals in wanting to move up in the company or try different areas of the business. As long as you have a plan and show interest in another position, they help you secure the position by working with the managers of the group or department that you are interested in. The 401K/health/reimbursement benefits are the added incentives to staying with Fidelity long term and the 401K matching/profit sharing is the best in the financial services industry, maybe even most of corporate America.
cons: The downsides to Fidelity is that you are working in a call center and sometimes day to day activity can become boring, mundane and very repetitive. Some managers are known to micromanage when you can take breaks including how often and they monitor operational metrics very closely (number of calls taken, average handle time and how much time after every phone call). They are very persistent about coaching on what is the best language to approach each customer, sometimes to a point of emphasizing perfection. If you are there for 5 yrs or more, base salary becomes stagnant and it becomes more challenging to apply for positions and roles that offer more compensation potential because the people in those positions have been there for 10 years or more.

headline: Poor technology practices
pros: The 401k in the USA is pretty good. You should get a return above 6% of thereabouts. No reason you won't have over $100k in your 401k account after 5 years. This is the only pro to working at this company.
cons:
If you're looking for a technology position, I would go to a technology company. Fidelity is a financial services company first, and as a result they have some questionable practices. They have their own version of agile which just doesn't work. Be prepared for hour long stand ups in the morning, project managers that are not technical and fail to keep track of meeting minutes.

From a salary perspective Fidelity is way behind technology companies. I left a senior position in Fidelity, and joined a junior position in a technology company. My salary went from $74,800 to $120,000. 

Once you get to senior in Fidelity, the path to principal, manager, director and above is almost non-existant these days. Your promotion path is not based on job performance, it is based on putting the time in with the group you're with. This much was admitted to me in my review meetings. If you join as a senior or get promoted to senior and want to be promoted to principal be prepared to put in more than 5 years before even being considered for it, and chances are the company will use a down turn in the economy as a reason for not giving you the promotion you deserve.

If you're near retirement you'll be fired so the company can save money by not giving you a full retirement package. I know a lot of people that this happened to in 2008, and again recently. 

The company keeps changing direction. When I joined in 2007 teams were organized by function - developers, testers, etc. Recently they re-organized by product. You can be sure in another 6 - 8 years they'll go back to being organized by function after an independent consultant comes in and makes the case for it.

Every 8 years the company sheds around 10 - 25% of their staff - most of them are the people it pays the most.

headline: Senior Portfolio Specialist

cons: Extremely limited on what you can do for clients. You are given a mold to fit into whether you like it or not. Once in this position there is nowhere to go without taking a significant pay cut. Middle management simply takes orders and relays them to the workforce. Very little flexibility.

headline: FPCMS
pros: The benefits are some of the best in the industry. The 401K match, profit sharing, bonus opportunities, student loan payments, etc. No firms currently come close to matching that level of benefits. They offer a lot of career paths and do a great job at hiring internally.
cons: With all of the job growth in the DFW metroplex, they are starting to struggle with talent retainment. There have been a few retention packages offered, but they are not working. FPCMS in WLK has gone through several leaders. The decisions made at times seem to contradict the firms values. The current leaders have their select few chosen ones, who can do no wrong. However, it is apparent that they have their own form of nepotism. They will force out people who may block their people from getting promo'ed. This has happened time and time again. People are taking on roles that they lack the qualifications for, just because they are favorites.

If you are looking for a meritocracy where the best ideas win out, where the best performers are recognized, and where the right people end up in the right positions, you will never find that at Fidelity Investments.

headline: A big company with big company pluses and minuses
pros: I worked for Fidelity in two stints lasting a total of 12+ years on the IT operations side.  On the whole I was treated very well, but it was about what I put into it.  I felt that I worked hard and was rewarded (promotion and $ wise) appropriately.   As with any big company, your success is very dependent on your supervisor and how they choose to treat their staff.  But I always felt that if you worked hard and performed well, you got what you deserved.  Benefits are very good and I felt I more than compensated fairly for my work.
cons: Fidelity by nature is risk averse because of its reputation and that is also it's biggest issue when it comes to innovation.  Fidelity, for all it's lip service as a leading edge company, is behind the curve on technology and is working to make strides in cloud services and robo investing services to keep up with more innovative companies attempting to steal the millennial generation market.  In addition, there is no real accountability within technology operations (including the need to really measure performance against budget) so there is a lot of stagnation among long-time employees and in  management.  Fidelity moves very slowly on re-orgs and layoffs after telegraphing changes are coming, leaving employees in limbo for long periods and impacting productivity.

headline: Good place to work
pros:
Great compensation and benefit programs.

Opportunity to progress in career.

Fantastic facilities.
cons: Forced corporate culture - Terminology and processes  are "Americanized" . Many employees bought in to the culture and weren't themselves within the office space. However, this is somewhat understandable in a financial services firm.

headline: Great Internship
pros: I had a great internship at the Durham, NC office.  The culture at Fidelity is friendly and you have a great group of colleagues to work with.  The pay is fair.
cons: Too many meetings.  Sometimes I would have meeting after meeting with very little time to actually get any work done.

headline: Run away
pros: Good benefits and they do pay well, but not well enough for the meat grinder you're about to go through
cons: Micro managed to death, no appreciation for employees, questionable at best integrity

headline: Benefits specialist

headline: Low Pay - Great Benefits - Degrading Culture
pros: The benefits are definitely pros. 401k matching up to 7%, tuition reimbursement and medical are all noteworthy benefits.
cons: Your pay will be low unless your are in sales. Service used to get paid well if you worked your way to the top, however, Fidelity recently restructured variable compensation and top performing reps are taking up to a $10,000 pay cut. While they cut your pay they are asking you to do twice the work by consolidating roles and drastically increasing calls per hour expectations. Expect to  handle complex problem resolution on matters like alternative investments, international wires, or incorrect cost basis research all while taking 7 calls per hour.  You will get paid around $50,000  for practically handling every aspect of service for all clients and financial consultants who very likely know less than you but get paid over twice as much. In summary the pay is low, the goals are practically (now) unattainable, job security is not the best.

PTO, VTO,  helps with gaining great work and customer service experience , encourages volunteer work and does a lot of good for the community

headline: Business Analyst
pros:
Working at the Durham office had its perks that start with the beautiful campus which had an on-site gym, lots of walking trails, decently priced cafe food and solid office space to work throughout.

Benefits are very good but don't expect too much of a work/life balance.  Fidelity didn't innovate/realize early enough to understand the changing employer landscape which has cost it a lot of turnover.  Around when I left there was a large effort to catch up to and implement changes from market leaders in employment statisfacation/culture.

I enjoyed a lot of the mid level management during my tenure, but never really found upper management to be helpful.
cons:
-Lots of change within to reduce spending which also reduced employee perks
-Too many folks that do the bare minimum and are showed favoritism by management
-Upper management rarely meets with their associates below, unless they meet quickly to announce something
-Pay is below market average
-A lot of interim positions open up, but not many full time positions are opened internally
-Tons of legacy systems you have to work with that are 15+ years old

headline: High Net Worth
pros: Overall, I was extremely happy with my experience with Fidelity. I chose to move firms due to issues I had with my site and my role, not with Fidelity as a whole.  I felt that the pay was reasonable, but any gap was more than made up with the incredible benefits. 7% 401k match, 10% profit share, 10k of student loan payoff (after only a few months in the role!), and great health and dental insurance. The people are friendly (for the most part) and I had a great relationship with my manager.
cons:
The HNW role could be extremely frustrating at times, to say the least. We were fully licensed brokers, but the majority of my time was spent doing password resets and distributions - I'm not sure why the firm would pay our licensing fees only to have us perform repetitive tasks any (unlicensed) customer service rep can do. Dealing with the general public is trying - people will call in and scream/curse at you over something you had no control over. To be fair, most conversations weren't negative but the really bad calls could ruin your entire day.

There is little opportunity for career development (outside of sales) and a large bottleneck for leadership/management positios.

headline: Excellent company
pros: Opportunity for  advancement in multiple areas of the company.  Benefits are excellent and the workplace is diverse.  Growth is self directed and supported.

headline: Good place to get settled after moving into desired job role.

headline: Overall, a great company
pros:
Amazing benefits - 401k (100% up to 7% matched), profit sharing, medical/dental, paid holidays, paid vacation, gym membership reimbursement, tuition assistance, student loan pay off, ability to work from home in many departments/roles...  I could go on and on!

Great work environment.  Nice facilities. Great culture.  Awesome folks to work with. Management  was wonderful.
cons: In my department  (Learning & Development), there are constant changes and reorganizations, thus leading to shifts in teams and eventually lay offs.  Fidelity is a chronic  "reorg and then lay off" company and I experienced it firsthand after being with them for 11 years, along with many others in my group - some with long tenure and even more with incredible talent.  Since the owner, Mr. Johnson, stepped down and allowed his daughter, Abby, to take over, so much has changed and not in a good way.  It is really unfortunate.

3. Decent pay and perks.
4. Caring and considerate HR policies. 
5. Experience is handsomely rewarded.
cons:
1. Not suitable for a management graduate from IIM or other premier institutes. Decent work for techies not for MBA types.
2. In India, it's just the tech and operations back office. So very little exposure to actual business for someone with an MBA background. But great place for tenured folks as compared to other captives.
3. In short, all pluses and minuses of a captive. With a great work life balance.

headline: Great heritage. Questionable future.
pros:
The benefits are still excellent, despite having been cut back over the years. 

 Fidelity has tremendous resources and a strong presence in the financial services space, which will give anyone working at the company phenomenal exposure to the industry and an excellent opportunity to learn about virtually any aspect of the business from capital markets to 401ks, from mutual funds to institutionally manged funds, from insurance to retail advice.
cons:
Long ago, Fidelity became less of an innovator and more of a follower.  It has been late-to-the market in a number of areas such as online trading, ETFs, passively managed funds, separately managed accounts and a slew of other financial innovations over the past several years.  

The financial services industry is in a state of change.  Passively managed money has eclipsed active management.  Automation is taking the place of highly-paid financial advisors and portfolio managers.  And fees for all aspects of the delivery of financial services are declining.  As a high-margin, slow-to-innovate company, Fidelity is at risk.

headline: Financial consultant
pros: Great place to start, learn the ropes and prepare for a career.  Phenomenal benefits/ 401k profit sharing.  Leads tee'd up for you. Great tech. Nice office. A lot of resources to learn and get better. A lot of nice people in branch offices. Easy to close business.
cons:
The longer you work here, the less you'll like it.  They micromanage you on everything, literally.  How many meetings, referrals, toa's, managed money, annuities, flows, mutual fund sales, how you say hello and goodbye to a customer. Non-stop meetings with "coaches", who are either people who never really did sales or did it for a few years here and ran for the hills to get out of the branches.  Some branch managers require a debrief with their consultants after every meeting.

The elephant in the room is that they have good products but we are constantly forced to push PAS which is their worst product.  

It's cookie cutter, they want every client to have a managed account and an annuity.  You definitely can't think for yourself, or help clients in unique ways- everything is run through a computer template. 

There is way too much garbage meetings to do any real planning for people.

headline: Used to be a great place to work....
pros: Fidelity's benefits package is amazing, I don't know of a company that has better benefits.  Every group I have worked in has an array of diverse, intelligent and super friendly people.  I have made life long friends throughout my years at Fidelity. For a newly graduated college student, Fidelity is a great place to get your feet wet, to learn (their training programs are topnotch) and for an entry level position, the pay is very competitive.
cons: I have been with Fidelity almost 12 years and made my way through a few different departments along the way.  For the first few years, there really seemed to be a Fidelity culture, we were all proud to be working at such a great company with such integrity. But as the years wore on and I sat in a role where I felt doomed to stay because moving up beyond my current position at the time was not an easy feat, I did finally land that "destination role" position, the one I thought I would be with until I retired. Fast forward to today, currently two year in the "salaried" position and miserable. I am doing the work of three people because they won't back fill our department, we work some times 80 or more hours a week just to stay on top of what is put in front of us. The promised "big" raises, we were told was nixed from above. The morale is horrible. I have been sick more than I care to mention from the stress. I entered this role knowing very little about the position and there wasn't any training, I was handed 130 clients to start with and told, you'll figure it out. My laptop has never worked properly, mail doesn't go out or come in all the time, to name one of the many issues, no one knows how to fix it, nor will they replace it.  I never thought I would say this about Fidelity, but I do feel like a number. I have talked to many of my co-workers in other groups who are feeling the same way, so it's not just the group I am in. Right now, until I can find (or have time to find) another job, it's just a paycheck, not a career.

headline: review

headline: Opportunity with drawbacks

headline: Stain on my resume
pros: Not a lot of pros here but the hours weren't bad I guess...
cons: This is a call center environment.  Pay is minimal and management has poor communication over all.  Actually that's not true, they have NO communication over all.  You are always being monitored.  What I mean by this is that all the calls are listened to and graded, if you stop calls to go to the bathroom, it counts against you.  If you don't take your break/lunch EXACTLY at the specified time, it counts against you.  If you're stuck on a long call and you go past your break time, you're SOL.  And it counts against you.   The computers are so old and constantly freeze and crash on you, which gets increasingly frustrating everyday.  You would think for a multi-million dollar company they could provide their minions with some semi-functional equipment in order to do their jobs efficiently.  But I guess not.  Fidelity also boasts about all the opportunities they have for their employees to branch out to, and frankly the opportunities are few and far between.  They sell you the dream.  And even if you are lucky enough to get a different position, you'll still be on the phone all day taking ~60+ calls per day.  The job descriptions are very vague as to what you'll be doing.  And the little information that is conveyed is very deceitful.   No where was it ever made clear that this is a call center.  Had I known this, I wouldn't even have applied.  I did not go to college to work in a call center.  PLEASE do not apply here!!  Run far and fast!  If you really want to work at a call center, find a different one.  Do your future self a favor and DO NOT WORK HERE!  You WILL regret it.  You'll be thinking about this review while you are sitting at your desk and be thinking "why, why didn't I listen to this person!"  This job was such a joke and a stain on my resume.

headline: Beware
pros: Unmatchable benefits. Good training ground for career following Fidelity.

headline: Financial Sales
pros: Very flexible with schedules and time off for family reasons. great 401k match plus yearly pension payment. health insurance is affordable, HSA yearly payment from the company.
cons: very very slow making changes to be more competitive.  There are some very poor EVPs, mis-matched alignments in upper management service groups managing sales organizations and the resulting loss of long term focus and goals.  This call center is very "good ole boys club",  promotion is all about who you know.  The pay is very low compared to competitors in the same region.  For being a privately held company who manages a trillion dollars have not had a pay increase in over 10 years and management of my group has very specifically changed quarterly comp goals in order to pay employees less for the same amount of work.  Can be a very toxic environment but those situations seem to come and go

headline: great company, great benefits, but things are different
pros: Fidelity has a great name.  Customers trust Fidelity.  The firm has tried to come up with innovative benefits to retain talent.
cons: Pay is low relative to the industry.  Fidelity's best days are behind it, but still a strong company.   Unfortunately management has evolved over recent years and now there is a bit of a toxic culture, where appreciation is not shown or felt by the rank and file.  The "new breed" of branch management is primarily to blame for this.

headline: Good place to work. Low relative pay
pros: Good work environment. Easy going. Not overwhelming.  Friendly people. Good bosses.  Nice campus. Has a gym and cafeteria. Great benefits.
cons: Very low relative pay. About 20-30% less than comparable positions at other companies. The idea, I think, is that they make up for it by having good benefits  (which they do) but really the benefits don't come anywhere close to the benefit of having making 50-60 vs 40. Also promotions are mostly "sideways" and come with negligible pay raises.

headline: Financial Consultant

headline: High Net worth
pros:
Lots of experience
Lots of flexible PTO
cons:
Joke of a salary.  Your compensation is based off of customer experience surveys, and anything less than a 7/7 is a failure and counts against you.
They tell you that you'll only spend a year on the phones but here I am 3 years later, zero mobility, and second level leadership is the most aloof group of people I have ever met. Major disconnect between what they tell you to do and what you actually have to do.

headline: Has Pros and Cons
pros: Nice modern facilities. Company promotes healthy living (cafeteria food, fitness, etc) Company promotes training and education. Industry leading health, dental, and vision benefits. Excellent bonus program.
cons: Extremely high stress environment (for me) which actually made me ill. Divisions in the company are competing and not working together (like the US Congress) Too many CIOs which causes nothing to get done. Senior executives (along with the chairman) react violently to market changes and government regulations causing big layoffs.

Lots of offshore contracting going on. This means you'll be getting up early to talk to your offshore team and hating doing it since of the probable communication barrier.

headline: May be going downhill
pros:
Fantastic benefits
Friendly environment
If you're liked, it's easy to move around to different positions
Great for a sales environment (not pushy to customers - always what's in their best interest) - I would highly recommend Fidelity to anyone who really likes sales and a high intensity environment
7% 401(k) match + profit sharing contributions every year
Great training if you start off not knowing anything about the financial industry
Recently they've been trying to (at least act like they are) make changes to make the employee experience better
Industry leader and well known
cons:
A 529 plan is a tax-advantaged higher education savings plan made possible under section 529 of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC). A 529 plan allows individuals to save money for a beneficiary by contributing up to $14,000 (or $28,000 if married and filing jointly) annually without incurring gift or generation-skipping transfer tax liability. Earnings in this plan grow federal income tax-deferred and the distributions are federal income tax-free as long as they are used for qualified higher education expenses. There may be additional state tax benefits to participants, contingent on their state’s tax regulations. 

Nepotism
Who you know can get you a job
If your manager doesn't like you, it's going to be nearly impossible to move up in the company
Last year they bumped up the new hire pay by I think $5,000 to get more people interested in applying, but none of the pre-existing employees have gotten any type of compensation adjustments to make up for it
The annual salary review (and usual salary increase) is being pushed back this year, so that it's a year and a half from our last increase
Don't get settled into what your role is defined as, because it'll most likely change without your opinion being considered
Everything is going full-blown sales - they push a "customer first" attitude, but all of the compensation and management feedback is exactly the opposite
We used to be able to take time to do research and follow up on our clients' needs, but they're punishing us for taking the time to ensure our customers have good experiences because we're not constantly taking phone calls/chats/emails etc.
The only things that our bonuses are really based on are how many interactions we're taking per hour, how many sales leads we can get, and then our customer feedback survey scores - but they keep lowering the amount of impact the feedback surveys have... it seems like they're caring less and less about the customer's experience, and more and more about how much money they're making (to be honest, it's a dog-eat-dog world out there for investment firms right now though)

headline: Terrible place to work
pros: Amazing opportunities for incompetent people.
cons: Only incompetent people get promoted. Managers and upper management are extremely insecure and have no idea what they are doing. Constant lies are feed to the employees on a daily basis. The good performers are stuck in their roles and do not get promoted so that the manager can benefit from their stats. Terrible employees always get promoted so that the manager does not have to deal with them anymore. If you are a woman here you will immediately get promoted and preferential treatment. Lots of stress here and terrible work environment. Management and upper management in this company are the most conniving narcissistic people you will ever meet.

headline: North Carolina location

cons: Limited growth and advancement opportunities, lower than industry average salaries

headline: Loved working with corporate management but regional management was very inexperienced  and lacked the resouces to grow.
pros: Pay and incentives are good but not always rewarded fairly.  If you align yourself with the right people you can move up fast.  The culture has changed a lot in the past 10 years.  Very different when Ned Johnson was in charge.  Not sure if that is a con or pro only time will tell.
cons: Many employees get positions on who they know not what they know.  It seems they only want to be seen as a company of miliniums and put very little value in hard work and a good  work ethic.  Trying too hard to be a tech culture without the knowlege of what it takes.

headline: Company where employers have a voice.
pros:
Good work life balance 
Connecting from home option. You can connect from your personal computer if there is no office machine. 
Free, AC transport which will cut down lot of travel time and risk to your life 
Higher management which always tries to make our life better. 
Freedom to change our teams internally, manager won't be having any power to stop by it. This makes manager to be in top of his game. 
Very humble President in India. 
Matured captive unit in India, which gets lot of ownership in india
Employees have the freedom to use their leave quota provided it is planned. 
Good learning environment, company invests a lot in learning materials. They want to keep employees very relevant in the market.
cons:
Common judgement process for employees is a pain. You need to be Rockstar to climb the ladder. 
Culture of meeting too often, no proper focus while working on complex code 
Mid level management is bit incompetent and arrogant 
Sometimes goals are written in blood. They aren't flexible. Innovation is must no matter complexity of your project. 
People are insecure because of this. They try to take credit for others work. It's about survival among fittest.

headline: Financial Service Rep
pros: Open 24/7 so that gives you a lot of flexibility.  Great benefits! 6 weeks fully paid parental leave for males and 16 week I believe for women who had a baby.  Tons of overtime opportunities in tax season.  Low stress, pay is great for entry level.  401k match and profit sharing totals to 17% a year (profit sharing 10% and 401k match 7%) managers want you to do well, flexible breaks and lunches, flexible with school schedules and family schedules, Fidelity all in all is a great place to work!
cons: It's a call center, at least you get paid well.  Sometimes you feel like a operator transferring calls. Bonus is effected by how your team does as a whole.  They make a lot of changes throughout the year and you need to be on your toes to keep up with all of it.  Colleagues can drag you down by being negative about their job.  Customer experience surveys are a very big factor in eligibility for larger bonuses and annual raises.  You can take thousands of calls but 30 surveys can make or break your eligibility for a raise. Some other small things, but this position is a call center position it's not always easy but definitely a good starting job to get you comfortable with the lingo and customer facing position.

headline: Global Economic study grouop
pros: Full of opportunities during the part-time
cons: not long enough for part-time

headline: Sales Employee
pros: Good licensing and support for more certifications. Retirement benefits are good. Great financial license teachers and ongoing training. Good work/life balance. Good starter company for the industry then get out after vesting as so many do.
cons: Salary is the worst especially given the number of competitors in close proximity. No raises this year and many positions being cut. A fellow employee was literally let go due to persistently low customer surveys which you have to get a perfect score. Anything else counts as an F. If you get a good score you're still screwed. This employee had his CFP and masters paid for by the company. What an asinine  policy to spend all that money on someone and then walk them out.

headline: Retirement Solutions Rep  (this job is the worst)
pros: They have good benefits.  They are sitting on a pile of retirement money with alot of customers to work with.
cons: They will squeeze the life out of you to get the job done.

headline: Good People...Hard Work
pros: Great environment but long days and competitive.  A little slice of Boston in the West of Ireland. A good place to work.
cons: Can be a little self referential..a lot of senior people have been with the company a long time which can lead to a feeling of stasis.

headline: Great Company
pros: Well run company.   They will help you achieve success, however you define it.
cons: 401k matching doesn't start until 2nd year.

headline: Horrible Employer
pros: They pay you while you study for your exams.  Only positive
cons:
The firm constantly states how conservative and honest they are, but that is only in regards to their clients, not employees.  Upper management constantly lies about anything and everything.  False promises across the board.  Stated that simply working a full calendar year qualifies you for their 10% profit sharing payout.  After a year of work, told we wouldn't be receiving the payment because we missed the "deadline" that was never mentioned.  When speaking to managers/directors about why this was never mentioned to us, simply told that "you should have received it."

Promotions are just lateral moves.  Want you to assist their customers on the phone, but if they talk to much it ruins your metrics and you get yelled at for it.  Nothing is done to problem customers.  You will spend an hour on the phone calling the Risk group about a blocked account for someone who a negative balance with the company.  Of course you can't hang up on them either.  Don't let them lie to you about how you're a "financial professional."  Very little finance, everything about appeasing their horrible client base.

"Promotions" are almost constantly handed to the most unqualified applicants.  It isn't what you know or how well you perform within your role, its all about how big of a shill you can be for the company.  

When applying for a new position, every female candidate will be promoted regardless.  This trend can be seen throughout the whole company.  Women make up maybe 10% of Personal Investing but when it comes to manager roles its around 70/30 Female to Male.  

If you're looking to get sponsored for your 7/63, work here for the 2 months it takes to get them and then leave like everyone else.  Turnover rate is rampant.  Pay is garbage and no one is looking out for you.  Wait for the near future for more layoffs.  Vanguard is taking all of Fidelity's clients and no one is safe from the chopping block.

headline: Remained close to your job and worked dedicatedly

headline: Customer Relationship Advocate
pros:
Benefits package
Schedule (sometimes, depends upon if you get hired after a hiring freeze or not)
Dress code
cons:
I originally found this job posting when searching for Hospitality related jobs. Hospitality professionals, BEWARE. They are going to tell you that you don't need a finance background and that they can teach you everything you need to know. This is not all together true. They are going to train you the absolute minimum that they can, and then they throw you onto the phones. 

This is not a customer service position. It's sales. Most of the calls are awful, and people pretty much yell at you all day for things that are completely out of your control.  Need help? Call your help desk that's most likely to belittle you and make you feel like an idiot. It's bad enough that customer's are rude, but any other department you call for guidance is rude too. 

Have a bad day? Well, everyone is going to know about it. They send out a stack rank email every day with your calls handled, hold time, after call work time and survey score to your entire time. Oh, the survey score scale rating goes like this: Highest score = 100%, and not the highest score = 0%. Seems fair right? Even better, they ask three questions, one of them being satisfaction with rep, and it doesn't even count. The only one you get scored on is the one that asks about their overall experience. 

I understand that this job is just not for some people, as I found out pretty quickly. I was told that advancement could happen quickly, however the path to an off-phone role can take years. This is why so many people seem jaded when I was in training, but I didn't see the red flags quick enough. 

Also, you get a 30 minute break and a 30 minute lunch for an eight hour shift. You have to use your break time to go to the bathroom so it doesn't eat up your after call work and effect your metrics. You pretty much feel like a kindergarten that's being monitored consistently.
