cons: Be ready to work REALY HARD!!!!!!!

headline: Bad Apples rot the Barrel
pros: The money is great, the benefits are outstanding, the travel can be interesting. The people, the frontline people, especially in Information Technology, are great. Fidelity recruits from top colleges and they get really good people.
cons: Managers are rewarded for results without a care about how they get them. By Director and VP, more money is performance based than base. You can't disagree. You can't be seen as an obstructionist. If you aren't on the team, you are out of the game.

headline: Planning and Guidance Associate
pros: Great people, the benefits are amazing, they will pay for licensing ( if you can pass)  and the training is fairly extensive.  The additional support offered that allows for a better work life balance is hard to beat.
cons: pay, transparency or lack of.  Some areas are growing so fast that the company cant seem to keep up... feels like some managers are moving up prior to being ready

headline: Just pay your reps
pros: Best benefits package in the industry. The best training to get your licenses in the industry. Impeccable company record throughout the industry.
cons: The best benefits package in the industry means below average pay regardless of profession. There are limited options once you reach a certain point at the phone sites. Fidelity is a great place to have a career but not for motivated reps.

headline: Research associate
pros:
1. Good Work life Balance
2. Great independence
3. Awesome learning experience
cons: 1. Career growth is not well planned

headline: Retirement solutions representative
pros: Great benefits, employer match, profit sharing, and low drama.
cons: Very little on site fun things to do like ping pong, pool, games.

headline: Great place to build a career
pros: Great total comp package, relationship based culture, privately held allows for longer term thinking
cons: Made up of several companies with different priorities.  Causes challenges working across silos.

headline: High Net Worth Representative
pros: Amazing trillion dollar company with amazing resources, thousands to employees and an enormous and loyal customer base.  Think:  MEGA aircraft carrier!  Try slipping that baby into a small dock.
cons: Too many layers of managers who are too focused on playing internal games to claw their way up the ladder and not focused enough on understanding customers' needs and how to empower employees to meet those needs.  We give what we tell 'em they want!  And they'll like it.  Or else!!

headline: Living in the past, no opportunities
pros: Great benefits, beautiful campuses, great "fit" regime w/ great healthy food available in the cafeterias where it is dirt cheap for what you're getting, especially compared to the less healthy food.
cons: Very strict, living in the past, no opportunity for job growth. Employees are trapped in roles everywhere they go and are lied to about the role they are getting into. Management says one thing and does another - always tries to make things seem like what they are not. No vacation time available, ever. Only certain amount of hours on certain days allotted for the department and they'll be gone early in the year. Required overtime. "Clock in, Clock out" environment.

headline: Retirement Planner
pros: Building financial security for employees and their families. Access to additional financial certifications.
cons: Limited growth opportunities,  stagnant salaries, high demands, low pay, long hours, lack of support.

headline: Outbound Interface Analyst
pros: great benefits, great friends, good salary
cons: long hours at the end of year

headline: GTE Review
pros: Great work culture. You get to work with latest technology stack, competitive salary, travel benefits. Lots of one-on-one with supervisors.
cons: You might get lost in the pyramid because it is huge company. There might be some delays in getting ideas pushed dude to higher management and business needs.

headline: Undefined goals, lack of leadership
pros: Benefits are great, the 10%. 401k drop each year excellent.
cons: Constantly micro managed, sales team told not to pedal products, however failure to sell PAS or annuities results in performance management. Calling strategies for Relationship Managers are not clearly defined. I worked 10 years for them in multiple roles, including sales and would never go back. They jump from objective to objective and tell people its all about change and to adapt. Fail go list to employees good suggestions and management is very political.

headline: Great place to work for an Entry level Developer
pros: Healthy competition and good stress
cons: Sometimes over expectations from client

headline: Giant companies are a mixed bag
pros:
There are incredible, bright people
There are plenty of exciting challenges
Great benefits, bonus, 401k opportunities, etc
Honest desire by management to continuously improve
cons:
There are ... less incredible, not-quite-as-bright people
The challenges are there because there's a lot of ancient cruft
You might find higher base pay elsewhere
Entrenched financial companies are conservative by nature and bold ideas are hard to shepherd into reality

headline: Rate a Company
pros: Good working culture, overall one the great company to work for
cons: The company may not ideal for freshers

headline: Dc service representative
pros:
Paid time off
Nice complex and cafeteria
cons:
Uneven workloads
Major difference in pay compared to other sites

headline: Senior Engineer
pros: People are great to work with, intelligent, dedicated, and professional
cons: Layoffs can happen at any time, Mgmt wants less employees that do IT work to drive down costs.  Can work 60 hours a week for months at a time, and no one cares.  Always trying to do more with less, try to cut costs all the time, something will give.

headline: Fidelity Investments
pros: The company provides generous 401k and healthcare benefits to employees.  The PTO days of 28 after 5 years is also a substantial plus.
cons: Salaries tend to be slightly lower than competitors due to the generous benefits.  Opportunities for advancement are fairly limited in the Jacksonville area after you have been with the firm for several years.

headline: Sales
pros: One of the best companies to work for.  The benefits are phenomenal and the culture is solid.
cons: People's careers here tend to be very long and that can be detrimental, because people become complacent or, worse, get promoted to managerial roles based on their length of service and not on their ability to manage.

headline: so so
pros: wages to some extent, that is it
cons: politics, so much. not much more to say

headline: It all depends on the Project
pros:
1.Great training program for fresh graduates.
2.Certain projects in certain Business Units give immense exposure
3.All individuals are treated with respect Irrespective of the designation.
4.Great Culture and Work life Balance .Convenient for women
5.Work from home and cab facilities are good.
6.20% of the staff has been with the company for 10+ yrs. So great continuity.

I loved my stint at Fidelity.Was Lucky to have a great projects and managers.
cons:
1.Salary is a bit on the lower side for the quality of skills possessed
2.Growth in terms of designation is slow.
3.On-site opportunities are diminishing year-by-year due to fund crunch
4.20% New Product Devl and 80% Legacy and maintenance work .
5.Life as a QA or Prod Support can be miserable and work uninspiring.
6.Great Senior Management and great junior devs.Problem is with the middle management.

headline: Research Specialist
pros: Good culture and work life balance
cons: Less career opportunities. Management narrowly focused.

headline: Financial consultant
pros: Great company, awesome benefits would recommend
cons: Low salary but high commission

headline: Intern
pros: Friendly people, work hard but also enjoy internship activities
cons: Technical interns in another building so don't get to meet them

headline: Phenomenal firm to work with!
pros: Solid growth opportunities.  I felt empowered in my position and loved every minute of it.  Set goals early on of future positions and roles and met each and every one of them.  Would recommend them in a heart beat!
cons: Market uncertainty - can definitely affect sales performance, etc.

headline: Asset Management Compliance Intern
pros: Very nice people who really want to help you out
cons: Wasn't given many responsibilities and tasks were pretty redundant

headline: Defined Contributions Representative
pros: The benefits were good. Company match on 401k up to 7%, which is the best I've seen.
cons: Never ending calls. I would never recommend working in the call center. It's exhausting and highly highly monitored. You'll feel very insignificant to the company. It's all about metrics.

headline: Has potential.
pros: Talented and dedicated employees. Family oriented.
cons: No career growth opportunities or development plan.

headline: Trading Execution Representative
pros: Wonderful company.  They have a great 401k matching program and truly care about their employees and take great care of them.
cons: The commute sucked due to where I live, and the role changed so much.  What used to be a fun job that was highly quantitative and fast-paced turned soft and became nothing but sales, attempting to bring in new money and maintain it through sycophancy.

headline: Investment Consultant
pros: Great Benefits and work/life balance.  If you work hard and network properly, you can move up quickly
cons: They have moved to more of a product-push culture recently, especially in the Pacific market.  Certain managers lack the skills to lead

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Great company w/ great benefits
cons: A lot to learn and know

headline: Great place to work, but its not a technology company like they believe...Software Engineer - Leap Hire
pros:
-Great retirement benefits
-laid back environment ( my business unit no longer has a dress code )
-great set up ( 2x 24" monitors for everyone )
-other benefits are really great (maternity/paternity leave was increased, tuition reimbursement, college loan help)
cons:
-pay, team quality, manager quality, and the projects you work on differ enormously between business units and groups within those units
-too many managers with little to no technical experience making technical decisions (my boss still thinks git and github are the same thing)
-managers seem to make decisions that please everyone vs making the right decision
-hiring process was terrible, my technical interview consisted of the following questions:
        1) is javascript a subset of java?
        2) how would you write an SQL query.
        3) what is a class?
        * this sounds awesome until you realize how dumb you could be and still get hired if this is all the knowledge you need

headline: General
pros: Good HR Policies, Better Compensation. People stick around for long period.
cons: Restricting Hierarchies. Oldies in the organization create Red Tape.

headline: Ok
pros: Good work environment. Helpful shadow buddies
cons: No bonus for first year even though you might be excelling

headline: Great benefits
pros: Excellent benefits, make me really feel valued as an employee
cons: Could be easier to find switch jobs within company--still working on this

headline: Great benefits, underpaid for the industry
pros: Benefits are great, 2k annual student loan, 7% 401k match. Great culture.
cons: Underpaid compared to others in the industry

headline: Investor Center Manager
pros: Despite its many layers and different internal organizations, Fidelity provided an overall great experience. Solid training, cutting edge technology and likely the top benefits package in the industry. Brand recognition and commitment to marketing are also great advantages.
cons: Fidelity tends to continually change the compensation plan for their reps and management teams. Very corporate culture which was always a bit heavy on conference calls and offsite meetings. Identity crisis at times in terms of promoting a sales versus customer satisfaction culture. All depends on whose in charge at the time.

headline: Director
pros: Good company culture, people care of quality of their work, a lot of collaboration, improved employee experience in the past couple of years.
cons: Downside of any big companies, too many people involved in the process, move slowly, role and responsibilities may not be crystal clear. Politics are in play.

headline: Easily the BEST run financial firm I've worked for.
pros:
I've worked for Scottrade, T. Rowe, and a couple others and this is by far the best run company I've worked for. You meet and work with the sharpest people and business partners. The exposure to products, investment strategies and financial planning subjects provides a Graduate level education in finance. 

Who your manager is makes a difference as far as culture and our is AWESOME. And for such a massive company, they are extremely aggressive with innovation and rapidly implementing changes to drive success. Top management really knows what's going on in the field and is nimble in providing solutions. Fidelity's value proposition and products often sell themselves so driving business is very easy. A FC role is highly coveted so if you can land it then it will fast track your career at Fido as its a gateway role to many other career paths.
cons: Multi asset class managed account performance.

headline: Director Software Engineering
pros: Great people, good benefits , great technology.
cons: Horrible management and beauracratic. Some of the VPs in our group were morons. I wont hire them as even entry level analysts. Very bad employee review system.

headline: Great Company, Great People, Important Mission
pros: Fidelity is serious about helping customers be ready for retirement and for their children's education expenses. The people are highly ethical, hard working and smart.
cons: I really can't think of any

headline: i was associated with one of the worst team within Fidelity Investments Westlake TX
pros:
None as i know.
4 guys leaving team because of manager's cheap tricks, dirty politics and rude behavior
cons:
- Discrimination based on region, race and color
- Mood swinging decisions of service and product s need to be punished
- Sick treatment to contractors

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Full training provided and there is a lot of room for growth and advancement to other departments. Managers are generally pretty friendly and want to see you succeed.
cons: Being tied to your phone all day is really awful. The company micro-manages your schedule and you pretty much have to adhere to a very strict phone schedule.

headline: Help Desk Support
pros: Once off of contract the company is great! They really care for their full-time employees.
cons: May be on contract for 2+ years before being hired permanently. Little to no benefit for contractors.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Nice collaborative environment to work with. People are very friendly. New ideas and innovations  are welcomed
cons: Office location could be an issue for some.

headline: Great work culture
pros: Great work/life balance, benefits are generous, and management really cares about their employees.
cons: Depending on location there may be caps on advancement

headline: Good Company if You're in the Right Team
pros: Decent Salaries, great bonuses, great benefits, insane 401k matching, and generally fun coworkers. Fidelity tries to figure out what makes their employees happy - for example they recently started helping with student loans which was incredible. Certain teams have great dynamics and click really well with each other. There's a ton of diversity, so you get interesting perspectives from everyone.
cons: They tend to promote people based on who has the loudest mouth.  They also have a streak of hiring incompetent people and then moving them around instead of firing them. There are politics abound in most of the upper management and they try to obfuscate everything from lower employees. It is difficult to move around in Fidelity. I tried several moves, but kept getting blocked so I ended up leaving.

headline: High Net Worth Representative
pros: If you are lucky to land on a great team there will be unlimited opportunities for your personal advancement and flexibility with your work schedule. High performers stand out and are quickly recognized. Very generous profit sharing and 401K plan matching.
cons: Conversely, the wrong team manager will make your life miserable by micro managing and being completely inflexible. There are many of these new managers that do not recognize the need to manage people as individuals - instead everyone is painted with the same broad brush and treated as an inexperienced new hire.

headline: good start
pros: good if in need of money.
cons: There are minimal growth opportunities and minimal pay.

headline: A learning experience
pros: 1)A nice learning experience and environment for interns.
cons: 1)Full time salary salary should be more.

headline: Best and flexible
pros:
*Very Flexible.
*Employee friendly.
*Very good benefits.
*Newer tech adaptation.
cons:
*Linear growth.
*Expand Bangalore operations.
*More seating in Manayata.

headline: Review
pros: The management has your best interest in mind and if you are looking for growth opportunities, Fidelity is great for that.
cons: The starting pay at Fidelity is very low and as a Financial Rep, even once licensed it still does not move up very much.

headline: Politics...
pros:
Profit sharing plan
Great for a 9 - 5
Nice place to wind down a career
Great for millennials to move around and get exposure
cons:
No work/life balance 
Very Top Heavy
Politics
Nepotism 
Management is disconnected 
No Loyalty
"What have you done for me lately?"

headline: Director
pros: The 401k matching is generous at 7% dollar for dollar.  The cafeteria is very nice with discounted rates subsidized.  The campus suroundings have woods and trails.
cons: The management is very insular and strategy does not match needed direction.  The company is not run very efficiently.  For many employees they feel that they are often at risk of being moved, outsourced or laid off.

headline: Great design management on Innovation Team
pros:
+Great management
+Cross functional teams
+Committed to design methodology
+Visibility to top
+Great, cheap cafeteria food
cons: -None that I can think of

headline: Great work environment
pros: Great place to learn, where everyone is willing to show their work, give advice and answer questions.
cons: I did not have much workload as an intern

headline: Security Representative II
pros:
They usually train SR's in AML, which can translate to a great future job.

Lots of down time to work on AML cases and schoolwork if you have it.

Plenty of programs to take advantage of in order to advance your career.
cons:
Since its such a small region you will stay security with no promotion, most likely. Unless you get a degree or excel at one of the investigations programs. Even then there is no guarantee, unless you are willing to relocate. You could potentially work as an SRII for 5 years.

Might as well look at it as a career step and take the downtime and use it to advance yourself in some way.

headline: Good employer
pros: Very hospitable environment. Folks are nice to work with. I was unfortunate enough to have one person in my team that appeared to have a vendetta against me. Otherwise it's a great company to work for.
cons: Legacy technology, difficult to be heard because of "experienced" and large management team, slow administrative process.

headline: RM
pros:
-great benefits
-great people to work with
-customer focused
cons: -frequent changes within the company

headline: Vice President
pros: Great pay, and a very nice environment to work in. Management is very fair to associates.
cons: I enjoyed my tenure with Fidelity. No cons.

headline: Good place to start
pros: Good Benefits, great coworkers, good place to start to get you licenses.
cons: Lower than average industry pay, to much office politics; get out of the call center roles ASAP

headline: Great learning experience
author_position: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant I
pros: They help with licensing and have a great training program. The benefits are some of the best in the industry.
cons: Such a big company you feel disconnected and that you are just part of a phone team. It is better than most phone jobs though.

headline: Interim Service Delivery Manager
pros: excellent culture of coaching, positive environment, very modern and progressive
cons: not many opportunities opening up for new managers

headline: review
pros: company pays good pay and benefits

headline: Specialist - Operation Processing
author_position: I Have Overall III Years and IV Months of Experience
pros:
Good working environment.
Flexibility in work.
cons:
Process moving to Chennai.
Not good management.

headline: Employee centric
pros: Very employee centric. Transport and meals are taken care of.
cons: Orthodox nature. Doesn't believe in sharing information or advertising the brand.

headline: Good Company But
pros:
Good Working Environment
Flexible working Hours

Less Onsit
Micro Management
Lots of manager than developer

headline: Client service
pros: Great Benefits. Ok job if you are entry level and you do learn a lot about investing. Good job if you are white male
cons: Below average pay and little opportunity to advance. Employees are extremely over worked.and stressed. Very difficult to serve the clients under these conditions

headline: Great place to work
pros: Excellent work culture. Decent pay hike. Good learning opportunities. Work life balance.
cons: Not much fun in office. Need better office space in Bangalore. A conservative growth in career.

headline: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant 1
author_position: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant I
pros: Great leadership, plenty of opportunity for personal development, challenging but rewarding goals, excellent benefits, great corporate culture.
cons: Schedules can be demanding, employees are often required to work different shifts to maximize time for talking with clients.

headline: Good work but...
pros: Good work. Smart people to work with. Good technology.
cons: Trust issues between business and technology resulting in mismanagement

headline: Financial Representatives
pros: Good environment, Great Opportunities to move up, Amazing Benes, Decent Pay

headline: Modern & state of art environment!
pros: I believe it's a great place to work.
cons:
Their customer service position is a lowered salary then most in the industry. Their interview process was exhausting and tedious. 

They headhunted me, but I no longer do call center jobs, although I needed a job!

Never was offered a position.

headline: good company to work for
pros:
Have a good work life balance
Good Culture
cons: Do not provide good salaries

headline: Customer service
pros: Great company Pay and benefits
cons: I really have no complaints best company ever

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great company to work for, great benefits, subsidized meals in cafeteria, happy environment to work in.
cons: Low salaries compared to other companies.

headline: Executive Assistant
pros: Great place to work - excellent benefits - excellent career possibilities - easy to move into new roles throughout the company
cons: Depending on the group you're in and the manager you have, life balance can be hard to work out.

headline: Awesome place to work!
author_position: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant I
pros: Fidelity sincerely cares for both their employees and customers. They provide amazing benefits, opportunity to grow and learn in your role and my managers cared about me. They are a responsible firm in that the clients experience always comes first and Fidelity keeps one step ahead in the financial industry. Now that I no longer work with Fidelity they are still the investment firm that I and my family (per my recommendation) have accounts with.
cons: Having an endless opportunity to grow in your role and need for your work means long hours. It can be difficult to maintain a work/life balance. Particularly during tax season.

headline: fidelity work culture
pros: great work culture , free cabs and meals
cons: favouriatism within organisation, growth less, no free time

headline: Quantitative Analyst
pros: Great company that provides excellent career paths.
cons: Rapid growth can sometimes impact deliverables.

headline: Not like it used to be
pros: Good back end benefits. (401(k) matching, paid education, matching contribution to charitable gift fund)
cons: Upper management decisions and policies are NEVER affected by consulting with the people actually doing the jobs.

headline: cc rep
pros: they are a great company
cons: long process to get in

headline: UX Developer
pros: Fidelity UXD has some of the most talented, hard working, genuine people in the UX design space. It was a pleasure to come into work every day and get to know my coworkers on a personal level.
cons: Very little guidance from management on expectations and performance. The onboarding process was garbage. They hire contractors because they're easy to get rid of when their budget gets slashed.

headline: Great company
pros: Great benefits and great products.
cons: The culture at the higher level is not matched at the lower level.

headline: Terrible  company
pros: there are no pros at fidelity
cons: Terrible pay terrible hours and terrible management

headline: Career suicide
pros: Pay isn't terrible starting out. Benefits also aren't terrible. 401k match is ok but the bearing schedule means you'll likely not get the company $$. Those are the only pros to speak of.
cons:
Favoritism runs rampant both with compensation and any kind of career advancement (which is still non existent). This isn't finance and won't set you up to do anything besides sales. My career was ALMOST irreparably damaged from my time here. 

Don't work here if you have any kind of long term career aspirations whatsoever.

headline: Average
pros: Good work environment , friendly colleagues
cons: no h1s , very less onsite opportunity

headline: Good company to work
pros:
Great work life balance
More domain training's to learn
Good work culture
cons: carrier growth will be very slow.

headline: FFAS Intern
pros: You get hands-on experience with some of the industries best tools, experts, and training programs. "Drinking from the firehose" is the name of the game, and in this atmosphere, you learn quickly and become very connected with those around you.
cons: Do not try to overstep your boundaries. The program is tailored very specifically, and is not very lenient for people who want to do their own exploration into the company. Stick to the curriculum, and it will be a wonderful experience.

headline: Best Company in Gurgaon
pros:
Work life balance
Day timings (9 to 530)
All work is delivered from Gurgaon Office
Less calls ...more work
Facilities wise its above average
Compensation is also above average
Good year on year hikes (You join from outside or an internal employee, your pay will be similar)
cons:
Too many managers
If you want technically challenging work then you dont like here

headline: Great place
pros: Employees treated well; benefits excellent
cons: Large and slow moving.  Difficult to innovate.

headline: Great Company
pros: Good environment values the employees
cons: Alot of phone calls if your doing an entry level position

headline: Facility Manager
pros: Good company to work for
cons: Nice place to work at

headline: Mezza, mezza
pros: Great benefits, just can't be beat...
cons: If you get stuck in a group where there are some snobby people, look out, and get out as quickly as possible. Never stab anyone in the back because the next day they could be your manager.

headline: Retirement Relationship Manager
pros: Total flexibility in hours, as long as you get 40 and meet your performance expectations. Pay great for what work you do. Can legitimately help people with their financial plan.
cons: Company politics, constant problems with your performance measurements and reporting.

headline: Amazing is an understatement!
pros: The benefits are incredible. Fidelity offers great 401k plans, corporate perks and impeccable developmental programs, this company is such an amazing place to work. People are very supportive in this organization and genuinely want to see you grow. Networking plays a big role at Fidelity, its all about who you know when it comes to advancing to the next step in your career so the more people you meet the better.
cons: The Talent Acquisition folks can be unpleasant at times even to internal hires. I have also heard from a few friends that working in the phones suck so if working in a call center isn't in line with your career objectives then I would encourage you to stay away from that area and actually find a position within other divisions.

headline: Investment Consultant
pros: Great benefits, great overall company to work for.
cons: You have to enjoy the call center atmosphere if you don't work at a branch or have another role.

headline: One of the best in town
pros: Excellent corporate environment. Flexible schedules and lots of opportunity for advancement. Pay is average for the industry in the area. Nice workplace with all the amenities and lots of natural light.
cons: Outdated systems and vague resources makes accuracy very difficult.  Little to no manager oversight on a daily basis. You basically only see them when you've done something wrong. Very little personal coaching and development from your direct supervisor.

headline: work culture
pros: amazing, superb, good, awesome, lovely
cons: politics, bad, worst, inferior, sad

headline: Good if you are a "follower or a conformist"
pros:
- Work life balance it almost impossible due to the company going lean.
- Ethical company.
- Company politics play a continuing theme and reward employees who conform to the 'kool aid' standard.
- Many layoffs and movement of positions to employees who earn less.
cons:
- Overly hierarchical in certain areas with little access to senior management. 
- Senior management makes all strategic decisions with little input from associate level.  
- Not much transparency when is come to plans from upper management.
- Pay is not industry standard.
- Work/life balance difficult with increased demand and less headcount.

headline: How to Make Productive, Experienced Employees Quit
pros: Good place to get your series 7/63. Benefits comparable to most other large companies. If you are a millennial, company values and caters to young millennials. Good pay for a first job.
cons: Raises are 1% to 3% yearly so new reps with no experience are paid more or slightly less than reps with over 10 years of experience. Do not stay in this position for more than 3 years or the company will label you a loser.

headline: Great place to work if you enjoy status quo.
pros: Great benefits. Job will last as long as you perform at average levels. Top performers get rewarded with company shares, bonuses etc.
cons:
Old fashioned policies when it comes to promoting. Your advancement is conditional to your current position, qualifications notwithstanding. Company seems to love status quo. Challenges to it are met with resistance.
Too many layers and bureaucracy makes everything slow. Project management is stuck in the 90s.

headline: Investment Solutions Rep
pros: Fidelity will pay for your series 7 and series 63
cons: Deceptive hiring practices, lack of upwards mobility outside of the call center, & lazy work ethic of management

headline: Sr. Manager
pros:
Excellent company to work for
Great customer focused philosophy
Employees are valued and treated with respect
Salary and Benefits are good
cons: There was a tendency to use contractors for full time IT work

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good place to work. I enjoyed working here.
cons: I thought that the place was very competitive.

headline: Company
pros: Great benefits; great pay; great people
cons: career advancement; nothing else I can think of

headline: Financial Rep
pros: great leaders that take care of their people as far as going out to nice places to eat for fun
cons: you will literally be a number at a desk. I wish I didn't have to put it that way, but that's the truth. After working there for 3 years I still experience people not having an idea of who I' am after going to meetings, outings, and plenty of other events with them.

headline: Non Qualified Service Lead
pros: Great benefits, 7% match and 10% profit sharing. Insurance plans, HSA, FSA, student loan reimbursement and tuition reimbursement.
cons: It can be easy to get stuck in the same positions for a long time. Not much transparency when is come to plans from upper management.

headline: Brokerage
pros: Innovative, Technology, Benefits, Flexibility,

headline: Good if you are a "follower"

headline: RIC
pros: Great people. Outstanding training. Top notch technology. Very innovative. Private. Great benefits
cons: Location location location. Also a little short on pay. World is shrinking with regulations

headline: Fidelity Advisor interview
pros:
Great company to work for
Very supportive
cons: Hard to advance within the company

headline: fidelity
pros: the place is really not the best if you are seeking to break into the world of finance
cons: no the best if you are seeking a career in finance, not a family friendly company at all

headline: Financial Rep
pros: Good benefits and very nice knowledgable people work at Fidelity
cons: Don't pay that well. Your a little fish in a big pond good company but ocverrated. Have to past Series 7 exam on the first try. Have to past tests to get ahead (63, 9, 10, 24), not based off of performance

headline: Account Executive
pros: Good benefits, extra retirement/health care account if you work there over 10 years
cons: Regional managers and some branch managers have been employees for over 25 years and do not have insight or experience to understand the competition.  Also they were in "sales roles" when Fidelity was pitching mutual funds and they don't have experience or understanding of how to perform consultative sales.  They are not leaders, they follow orders and pass them down.  Very military and micromanaging.  They have said in meetings that the WAS program and those RIA's are their competition.  Definite conflict of interest when selling advice to clients.

headline: Director
pros: Good salary & Benefits.  Growth Opportunity.
cons: Competitive environment; need to keep balance so as to not burn out.

headline: Just okay
pros: I love my coworkers, they are truly nice people to work with. Fidelity has excellent benefits - medical, dental, 401k with 7% percent match (though you have to be there a year to get match and work 5 years to be vested), quarterly bonuses on performance and profit sharing. I truly love Fidelity and what they stand for. I just hate the role I'm in.
cons: The role just sucks, especially if you work nights because they never hire enough people to work late nights so people can wait up to 10 minutes just for a password reset! It's a call center so it's constantly taking call after call and people can be too needy or hostile because they can't treat their retirement account like an ATM. You have to be in the role for at least a year to even be considered for other roles though it will just be another job on the phone all day. Also your calls are graded all the time and depending on your manager... it's a miracle if you do anything right on a call. Some people call in to get a balance and just because you didn't get the persons life story doesn't mean the call was "inconsistent". Metrics are so whack.

headline: Security Officer
pros: Great staff and support.  Clean environment.
cons: Not enough staff to cover buildings, especially at night

headline: High Net Worth Representative
pros: Good Benefits, quick advancement. Flexible.
cons: Call center environment. Often times grueling.

headline: Good
pros: This is one of the best MNC. There is a room to grow in this organisation. Younger generation get benefit a lot. There is a mutual learning between employers and employees. There is a positive waves created in this company.
cons: I don't feel any negative waves emerges in this company. There is much social responsibility in this organisation. There should be full freedom to express.

headline: Great company to work
pros: Benefits, opportunities, growth, diversity, education
cons: Not applicable, working hours, commuting,

headline: Review
pros: Good company with strong culture, competitive compensation, great training, and room for advancement.
cons: Sitting at a desk tied to a phone isn't so good if you're more active.

headline: Great Benefits and Salary
pros: Benefits, salary, people, work, culture, office, everything
cons: sometimes there isn't a ton of work to do, lulls

headline: Good company, not great
pros: Culture is great here and the company really tries to maintain a higher retention rate by building careers internally. They want to see you advance. Work life balance depends directly on the nature of your job.
cons: Upper management has been trying to improve by having reorganizations. This causes a lot of confusion and discomfort among associates. On boarding process can be a lot better. Minimal training was offered and little team building exercises. Personally speaking, my onboarding process was nonexistent because management was tied in with reorganizations and retention rate was low.

headline: High Net Worth Associate
pros: Awesome Industry, Great Benefits, Nice Campus
cons: Taking inbound calls all day, short breaks, hard to schedule PTO

headline: Excellent
pros:
-good work culture
-reachable senior management
-bonus, gifts, parties etc.
-pays a lot of attention to employee well-being
cons: none that i noticed so far

headline: Class A Company
pros:
Great benefits, even including dental, vision, health reimbursements, computer reimbursements, workers comp, leaves of absence, 401k and retirement planning. 

Up to date systems and large availability to work from home.

Friendly, innovative atmosphere for all voices to be heard. 

Many opportunities to expand and grow within the company.
cons:
Unstable work needs, many layoffs and moving positions to employees who take less wage. 

Big changes every couple years in management, not bad for those adaptable.

headline: Fidelity
pros: Innovative, forward thinking company. Fosters career upward movement
cons: Work/life balance but it's a known issue and change is being talked about

headline: Good so far
pros: I have been employed for around 1.8 years here. It's a great place to work. Very flexible and friendly environment. As in any place, work culture will depend a lot upon your manager, but generally I observed the company to have good working culture across teams.
cons: Lay off is not something unheard. But I believe it is something inevitable at any big company.

headline: Great Place to Grow a Career
pros: Fidelity cares not only about their associates, but cares tremendously about the customer.  They do what is right by the customer, not what is easy for them  They treat their employees and customers with respect and dignity, and make you proud to be a member of the team.
cons: There are not many downsides that I can think of, but if I had to provide one it would be that there is not a Utah site that is not located directly in a metropolitan area.  Some of the other locations are campuses, which is nice - it would be great if we could get one here in Utah.

headline: Office Manager / Executive Assistant
pros: Great working environment. Great people - I worked for a wonderful team.
cons:
Would like to see more part-time / job sharing positions for those with children.   
Would like to see more telecommuting positions, even if one-two days per week.

headline: Retirement solutions representative
pros: Absolutely incredible place! Base is just the minimum you make. If you work hard, you can double your pay easy!
cons:
Stressful, but worth it!
If you are expecting a big salary for no work, then go elsewhere, but I'm sure it will be hard to find. If you work hard, smart, and are ambitious, then this place will make wonders!

headline: Investment solutions and sales representative
pros: Amazing benefits, 7% match in the 401k, 10% profit share. Great place to start a career.
cons: Minimal advancement opportunity at the jacksonville location. Pay structure could be much better.

headline: Nice benefits, slow advancement
pros: Great benefits, good management, great work/life balance
cons: Slow career progression from within, inefficiency in work

headline: CUSTOMER SERVICE REP
pros: benefits are good if you are full time the cost is good, however if you are part time the cost is too high!
cons:
Hard to move up based on who likes you!
Other fidelity companies do not want to hire Associates that work in their call center.

headline: Indian Management need a change
pros: Work culture is good, interaction with partners makes a difference to the work culture here in India. Good learning experience to work with folks who are decades old in the organization!
cons: If you are working with US folks then you are in right place, it is pretty much difficult to work with Indian Management. They don't really bother about the growth of the employees.

headline: Good people.  Poor upper management.
pros: The people you work with day in and out are great.  The technology you work on is great.  There are multiple ways to grow your career.
cons: When the budget goes wrong, instead of getting rid of the people that overspent or were in charge of watching the budget, what do they do?  Get rid of hard working individuals who had nothing to do with spending a dime of that budget.

headline: Customer Service
pros:
Excellent place to work.
Good benefits.
A work place that cares about employees as well as the customers.
cons: For me there were no cons, this was a wonderful work experience

headline: System Analyst

headline: Senior Associate

headline: Great company, excellent benefits

headline: The people are great; work is demanding

cons: Work can extend to many hours and eat into personal time.  There are many and periodic layoffs which do no good to morale.

headline: Director

headline: Weak in the knees
pros: The company offers good compensation and solid understanding of work life balance.  That plus the deals on food from the chef enabled cafeteria.
cons: Upper middle management is weak in the knees and leaves their people to swing in the breeze when obstacle teams make noise.  Instead of backing the troops in the field they turn and run because it appears less of a headache.

headline: Great people
pros: Great benefits and great people to work with.  Always something new
cons: Unless you are connected or fit the right profile, promotions are limited.

headline: 10 year veteran
pros: Privately owned company with huge market-share.  Fidelity still keeps the customer-first approach and believes heavily in creating a great job-experience for it's employees.  The benefits are good and they seem to be continuously looking for ways to improve upon the existing benefits package.
cons: Fidelity isn't known for being the highest paying employment option.  They know that the trade-off is that you get a better overall day to day experience working here than you might working for a competitor who might pay better.

headline: Awesome Place to Intern!
pros: Everyone is EXTREMELY helpful, want you to grow within the company, encourage you to make connections, pay very well, relaxed atmosphere, intelligent people. Great opportunity called "Leap" that interns can apply for.
cons: Not a large workload. Most interns aren't given a ton of work to do. Still learn a lot, though! Onboarding takes a while, but that is all part of the more relaxed atmosphere.

headline: A good place if you want to get comfortable
pros: Good pay along with transport. Special attention paid to employee safety
cons:
Got  to work in shifts. Good if you want to earn more but does not help in the long run
Purely operational work, with very limited opportunities no learn something good
BPO unit is still working in stone age technology which has become obsolete. People still use systems made on VB 6.0 and MS access
Joining the organization, especially the BPO unit wont help if you are looking for job which actually involves thinking and applying industry practices. Most of it is data entry and you get stagnated after one point

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Friendly environment, great pay, awesome benefits, and overall just an excellent company to work for.
cons: Not enough time to prepare for the Series 7.

headline: Clear leader in financial services technology
pros: Ongoing investment in technology, generally puts customer needs first, hires and retains good people.
cons: A lot of politics, and for a while, turmoil in the executive suite (I've heard it is better now).

headline: Fidelity feedback
pros: Market leader in several businesses; good/smart/honest people; good comp and benefits package
cons: Limited growth opportunities in Boston

headline: Very tough and political, but you will learn a lot and be very marketable
pros:
- Tremendous brand name that helps your work have a big industry impact
-  Privately held company - doesn't worry about quarterlyy earnings
- Great resources to accomplish whatever you need to do
- Opportunity to grow for younger workers
- Excellent salaries and benefits
cons:
- Very tough and political organization. To be successful, you will have to be a strong corporate politician
- Not a very friendly place for older workers. The benefits and HR strategy focus on making Millenials happy while managing out older employees.  Fidelity is a great place to start your career.
- Privately held company - Since management isn't exposed to Wall Street pressure, they are slow to change.  For example, Fidelity has been a slow follower in developing online trading, launching an ETF business, creating passive investment products, and developing a robo-advisor.  The company is not innovative. It seeks to copy initiatives from other successful companies.
- Senior management is not willing to take risks. They are so well compensated that they have nos insensitive to put their lifestyles in jeopardy. 
- The company is very large.  Projects and product development have become very bureaucratic.
- Dogmatic commitment to active management.
- Products are too expensive and have seen erosion in their competitive position from companies like Vanguard

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Good Transport Facility, Able to balance work and life. Good for women employees. Best for those who are looking for a long term career - no tensions, no work pressures.
cons:
No long term onsite (Management doesn't usually support long term onsite). They encourage only short term business trips. 
Food is worse,

headline: Satisfied
pros: Great benefits, high integrity and always looking to put the client first.
cons: Not the highest pay. Reps sometimes feel stuck in a rut.

headline: Great Benefits

headline: Associate

headline: Financial associate

headline: Changed my life

headline: Software Engineer

Good Work/Life Balance
CAB facility is provided
Excellent work culture
Good learning opportunities
Trainings will be provided in excellent manner.
Overall it is very good place to settle down in career if you are jumping from any other organization. But when start your career with Fidelity, the salary may not be greatly compared with as that of employees those coming from other organization. It will be less.
cons:
Depends on the team where you are going to join.
Not much Cons.

headline: Good postgrad job or for moving up the call center "status" ladder
pros: Benefits package. Onsite amenities. Weight "Fidelity Investments" carries on a resume going forward into any field, not just financial, due to reputation and vetting process.
cons: WAY TOO CORPORATE. Ramrod you through training and expect you to be an expert afterwards. "Coaching moments" just corporate bullet points, no concrete help to improve. It's a call center, and it's in regards to people's money to amplify it - very stressful being on the phone all day. The only vertical movement is moving up financial customer service rolls via licensing, etc. while still being on the phone all day. It's a meat factory. If you don't pick it up right away once you're on your own (become an "expert") you're in trouble.

headline: Financial Services Representative

headline: Bad

headline: Senior QA Engineer

cons: Unfortunately, Fidelity is too quick to staff up during good times and equally too quick to staff down during bad times. This instability makes Fidelity a difficult place to work. I would not advise somebody that Fidelity is the type of company where you can expect to retire from.

headline: Great place to start
pros: Fidelity Investments is a great place to start your career. I started right out of college 2 years ago and the starting salaries are competitive. Plus, you get amazing benefits such as dollar for dollar match on 401K up to 7%. In addition they give you 10% of your salary for profit sharing at the end of the year. I have worked with a lot of very intelligent people that challenge me everyday to make me better. I enjoy the challenge because if we aren't helping each other improve and to learn new things a job can get stale very quickly.
cons: While the salaries are competitive at the beginning the raises are almost none existent. And, to get a promotion is even more difficult. If your looking for somewhere to grow quickly then Fidelity isn't the place for you unless your lucky. Also, there is a lot of politics involved in this company. You will see coworkers move past you that are terrible at their jobs (borderline clueless as to what is going on), but network very well and talk to the right people. This can be very discouraging to those who actually try and work hard. Because, at the end of the day your picking up their slack and they're reaping the benefits.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: good to be here and work

headline: It's a great company to work for.
pros: Lots of potential for career advancement. With a company as large as Fidelity, it is easy to find different ways to have fulfilling work. The benefits are also outstanding.
cons: There is a lot of competition for executive roles and the compensation isn't great. It is also likely that if you want to end up in upper management the you will likely have to move to the northeast.

Stable paycheck

Little responsibility

High-level management seems to make impulsive decisions, such as over-staffing to the point where they are asking people to go on unpaid leave just to keep the lights on

headline: Fidelity
pros: Benefits were great and upper management genuinely seemed to care about your well-being.
cons: Ultra strictly regimented schedule and mandatory overtime leads to a poor work/life balance.  Focus on arbitrary metrics rather than productive metrics.  Base pay is sub-optimal.

headline: Professional Organization
pros: Competitive salary and benefits but the best is the working environment.  Most employees strive to achieve world class results.  The firm is ranked #1 or 2 in many financial, HR, 401K and other businesses. Employees are given fantastic resources, training and professional development in order to be successful in their roles.
cons: While pay overall is very competitive, it feels like senior management comp is disproportionate to pay of front-line employees.  Large firm, sometimes new ideas are tough to get through or are unduly complicated by silo-style business units.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Honestly, just about everything about working at Fidelity is a 'Pro'. The atmosphere there is just top notch and makes you feel like you have purpose.

headline: Great place to work

headline: Great place to start, but move on
pros: Fantastic benefits, above average compensation, great co-workers, and lots of professional training.  Great place to start a career, but not a place to work for ever.
cons: Fidelity does believe in its employees.  I experienced it multiple times, they only believe in their name.  On the surface Fidelity appears to value its employees, but in reality they have no loyalty to its workers.  That will only become apparent after 5+ years of working for them.  The pay offset the negative aspects of the company.  You would think that there is room for advancement in such a large company.  However, that is not case.  The Pros do out way the cons for a period of time, 5-7 years.  After that, take your experience and move on.

I had 4 years of being a internal wholesaler at another well respected firm prior to joining Fidelity. Westlake is in the middle of no where-terrible commute from Dallas or Fort Worth. Many of the Sales Managers were once Internals and understand the frustrations of the job but have little empathy. The turnover on the Sales Desk is the highest that I have seen in my career and through friendships build at other companies.

headline: Financial Associate

headline: Financial Representative-Health and Welfare
pros: Fidelity has a great culture. I have never worked at a better company. Great perks, decent pay, bonuses, amazing cafeteria, overtime and VTO always offered. Manager Apprentice program, PTO, 4 months maternity leave, loan and tuition reimbursement . I love the Employee Resource Groups. Great way to start career out of college.
cons: The job. We are answering calls from employees and retirees from well known companies. Health insurance is very difficult and the calls we get are a bit much. A huge disconnect from Fidelity and the clients. It's great to help people however we get rude callers who want something now and do not understand how insurance works, no matter how we explain it. Very stressful job and I hate to look elsewhere but the stress is not worth it all.  If you love customer service and can take calls from angry people all day then this is for you. NOT a bad company, just the Health insurance side is not a great department or position.

headline: Financial Customer Associate
pros: Good work/life balance, opportunities exist, the 7% match and 10% profit sharing 401k bonus are very nice, too. It is a company that is slowly but surely seeking to improve the work experience. My managers have been awesome, too.
cons: Most of the opportune moves are lateral, Fidelity takes it's sweet time on paying bonuses and raises, it is a call center job and if you don't enjoy this type of engagement, opportunities are severely limited. Not many jobs here that allow you to critically think, but rather answer questions. Most co-workers treat this as a job, rather than something they enjoy (though this is not true for all)

headline: Top Tier Company
pros: Fidelity Investments is one of the top company's in the financial industry.  The firm's focus on workplace atmosphere, collaboration, career growth, benefits, and work-life balance make one of the most rewarding and enjoyable employer's.  Fidelity also regularly hires third party company's to conduct employee surveys, and that feedback is taken very seriously.  I say this because I've seen senior management respond to areas of improvement with meaningful and relevant changes that enhance the working lives of Fidelity's associates.
cons: The usual large company drawback's apply.  If you're looking to work on the most cutting edge technology or explore ways to disrupt industries, maybe it isn't the best place to work.  Although Fidelity focuses on innovation strategies and new markets, it's size means that change does not come quickly, for the most part, as there are many processes and controls wrapped around existing models. There are also significant regulations to which all players in the financial services industry must adhere, which is fine, but learning and adhering to those regulations limits flexibility.

headline: Good for Freshers

headline: Good Job

Great internal training

lots of turnover

headline: Conservative investment firm with excellent benefits.
pros: After 2 year service, dollar for dollar 401k match up to 7%, additionally an extra 10% (of your gross wages including OT) profit sharing bonus deposited to you 401j each January. Most workers are hourly and receive 1.5x OT for their efforts. 10k per year toward higher education expenses.
cons:
Five year vesting for employer 401k contributions, in 20% increments.
Start us out with more vacation time! How about a sabbatical every few years of service!

pros: Interactive company culture. Networking. Positive day to day reactions with all employees. Great way to get your foot in the door.
cons: Management in numerous sectors were fairly loose with their employees. No control.

headline: Good place to learn but breeds complacency
author_position: Senior High Net Worth Service Specialist
pros: Excellent place to begin a career and lean how the brokerage industry works. Excellent benefits overall with a strong 401k match, profit sharing program, and tuition repayment assistance.
cons: Very few upward opportunities once you reach 3-5 years of experience. Upward pay mobility is difficult once you reach certain upper level roles. Pay is also heavily VC dependent.

headline: The LEAP program is one of the worst technical programs for college graduates.
pros: The pay you receive coming out for entry level is great. The benefits you receive are okay, especially living during training since it's free.
cons: The training itself was horrible, Fidelity does a terrible job in teaching this program. The management is helpful at all... They are more about the program expanding instead of individual trainee's learning. Such a sad program. If you have multiple offers, I would think deeply when considering this one.

headline: very lukewarm, uxd intern
pros: Probably the biggest perk is the great pay as an intern. There are a bunch of really smart and friendly people to learn from if you seek them out, and the culture is really fun. People are generally  very friendly.
cons: Management was oppressive, even as an intern. No one seemed to know really what should be going on, and direction was incredibly scattered. Really likes to brag about their tech capabilities and resources, but interns were using incredibly old and faulty computers that many times would fail when we needed them to do our work.

headline: Good place to work for long time

Flexible in timing
Technology agnostic

Ran by Senior citizens on rules and politics
Compensation is average

headline: Client Manager

headline: Exactly what I expected

headline: I will never work in a call center again.

The clients are sometimes extremely rude and you just have to deal with it. They pretend like there are opportunities for advancement, then you just end up right where you are. Employees are stuck at a desk all day answering back to back calls.

headline: Great Training

headline: Good training program, learned a lot, but definitely not a career
pros:
-Comprehensive Training
-Medical/dental insurance start immediately
-Plenty of overtime available
-On-site gym ($20/month), additional insurance $$ for healthy living incentives

cons:
-Out of an 8 hour day, expect to be on the phones all 8 hours. Little development time
-Very poor optical insurance
-Overtime is expected and will effect your bonus
-Very repetitive (almost every call is someone wanting to raid their 401k)
-No discretion so customers will yell at you and there often are long holdtimes to get help on a call
-All your time is monitored (typical call center) so everytime you go on break, lunch or to the bathroom expect it to be tracked

headline: Operations Workleader

cons:
for the whole month of January and throughout the year when the stocks are up and work is demanding they make you work 11 hour days. 
There is high turnover for a reason
Everyone hates working on the phones. Long hours plus demanding participants can mentally get to you

Tons of discounts, from cell phone bill to cars. NC offices received new desks that can raise and lower ans well as two huge monitors
cons: Some people can be difficult to deal with, but that applies to any job anywhere. That's about it in terms of the company itself.

headline: Great place to intern
pros: learned alot, opened up alot of door
cons: should sponsor interns for level 7

headline: Investment Consultant
pros: The benefits are great, and work life balance if very respected. The schedule is somewhat flexible, though is always tied into a 9-5 M-F
cons: Role change without relocation can be difficult. And their are limited roles that are intended for long term growth. Management can sometimes be purely results driven rather than looking at context.

headline: Associate Financial Analyst
pros: Fidelity has one of the best benefits available. Their 401K contribution match keeps them a competitive company to work for. There are also so many opportunities for lateral movements.
cons: Salaries are okay. Raises are based of a percentage of your salary and the percentage depends on how you compare against your peers.

headline: Great Company
pros: Fidelity is a great place to work.  The benefits are the best of anyone around.  For the most part the flexibility is great, technology is very advanced and the company invests in keeping current on the tools to do your job.
cons: Too many jobs are leaving Boston and New England region so the opportunities are limited to move or advance internally.  There can be long hours due to work with off shore resources.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Decent benefits, base, salary, and a good environment.
cons: The hours are pretty undesirable and you can't change your schedule without moving to a different team.

headline: Workplace Planning and Guidance I
pros:
Great benefits
Student Tuition program
HSA
Profit sharing after your second full year
100% up to 7% of 401k match
Pays for you to get Series 7, 66, 9, 10 licenses
cons:
Managers use fear tactics to drive numbers.  
Pitch that the role is to help plan retirement but it's honestly just a sales role where you strive to put clients assets in IRA's and brokerage accounts.
Call center environment
Outbound calls are requested by the participating companies but to the customer, it is just cold calling.
Due to the industry fears, target date funds are pushed on everyone without access to the management service so there's no actual financial advising or RIA work.

headline: Things have changed
pros: Salary, benefits, growth opportunities, dedication of staff
cons: Stated values are not always supported by behavior of senior management in all divisions.  Certain divisions are in a cost cutting cycle at the expense of employees' work life balance.

headline: Estate Planning Consultant
pros: Excellent place to work; great benefits
cons: None that I can think of at this time.

headline: Great Benefits - Lots of Politics
pros: Company works hard to create a pleasant environment and provide great retirement benefits, standard bonus brackets, and private stock options for excellence in performance.
cons: There is a culture at Fidelity that you have to learn.  Your main success comes from ensuring you don't walk in the door from the outside and try and lead and influence people who have been in the company 20 years without their permission first.  A bit of political advice that can go a long way  People never leave there cause their 401K keeps growing and that creates some havoc for opportunities.

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Family owned company. Great benefits, profit sharing and 401k match
cons: Low base salary when you take whole compensation package into account

headline: Great company!
pros: This is a great place to work!  Lovely culture and office location.
cons: Nothng! This place is fantastic. Great, talented people

headline: Great Place to Work!
pros: I worked for Fidelity in a number of HR roles. I had tremendous opportunities to work with a number of different group and professionals overall. The work was stimulating and fun! I felt that I could add value in so many ways. It was one of the best places to work as an HR professional.
cons: If you don't like to be promoted and valued, then this is not the place to work.

headline: Investment Consultant
pros: Profit sharing, 401k match very good
cons: Management has too much power

headline: Not What I Expected
pros: The pay and benefits are great for the Albuquerque area, they also offer some amazing perks to inspire you to make choices.
cons:
Fidelity does not practice what it preaches.. You are told when you are hired and during training that customer service and advocating for the customer is the main goal.  That you should "own the call". However as soon as you are on the phones, you are told that once the customer is handed off to what ever dept ,  you should not be involved anymore, that you should not make too many outbound calls to the customers because we are an inbound call center , I do not consider this owning anything.  The procedures and resources are time consuming and cumbersome.  Your computer is prone to freezing when you are in the middle of a call because of all of the resources you have to have up,  and yet you can not say anything about your computer not working properly. 
  Fidelity has compassion as part of it's mission statement , yet most of the procedures could not possibly show less compassion for the customer if they tried.  In short I feel like I was lied to about the position I was hired for.   
   Management shows favoritism as well as cliquishness, and though everyone appears to be friendly it is surface only.  You never know what management expects or what they are in charge of  because it changes constantly.

headline: Good company to start with
pros: Process oriented, few BU's are really good in terms of compensation, work life balance. Transport facility is good.
cons: HR looks to have no rights, your concern will not be listen very high. Too much intervention of management for small small decision making. Indian management are not enough empowered. Cafeteria is horrible.

headline: nice
pros:
Recommends
Positive Outlook
Approves of CEO
I have been working at Fidelity Investments full-time (More than 10 years)
Pros
Large, privately held firm with values that are reinforced at all levels of leadership. Career opportunities are ongoing and the vast majority of people at the firm will help you progress if you're willing to do the work.
Fidelity provides exceptional benefits with options based on personal needs and various family situations. While pay and bonus structures are sometimes criticized, being patient will pay off for …
cons:
Fidelity retail is open 24 hours, causing scheduling conflicts for some candidates
Career tracks within the firm can be limited due to licensing requirements, or lack of licensing flexibility in the groups

headline: Good!
pros: Good environment, Work life balance, good code of ethics and values
cons: No proper/ frequent change in the pay scale as compared to the other companies. Growth within the organisation is limited.

headline: Good experience. Great upward mobility
pros: Easy promotion. Manager's focus on developing you to ensure more success. The benefits are amazing
cons: Heavy emphasis on meaningless stats. Some of them will only matter if you get basis points (commission) from them

headline: A good place to start
pros: great 401k match 100% match up to 7% and usually an annual 10% profit sharing match.  The Health and dental were excellent.
cons: You can be paid more elsewhere but I never felt I needed to compromise on my integrity.  Although Fidelity claims to be a meritocracy, I found that knowing the right people was more important than sales and customer service performance to one's promotability.

headline: One of the best financial firms
pros: Longer term outlook for business decisions because the company is privately owned, and not run based on quarter-to-quarter results. I work with smart people, who for the most part are motivated by more than just money.
cons: There's a lot of change all the time - sometimes it's hard to operate in the environment of uncertainty, and it takes its toll on morale too.

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Great benefits including help paying down student loan debt and great 401(k) match program. Friendly environment.
cons: Promotions are much more about who you know than your effort. I feel like at times I am not told the whole truth from upper management. Everyone puts on a smile, but not always genuine.

headline: I miss working at Fidelity
pros: Fidelity has great benefits and pay very competitively. When I was there, they tried to hire and pay at the 75th percentile, so I had a lot of great coworkers. There were lots of opportunities inside the company, so it was pretty easy to stay engaged and content.
cons: It's financial services... not rocket science. Even though it's a fantastic company, I eventually got bored. I was in a smaller regional office, and there weren't a lot of opportunities to move around without moving. And I disagreed with the "culture" the local business head was creating - definitely not a Fidelity norm.

headline: Good all around benefits
pros: Good Benefits, flexible work schedule
cons: Promotes total benefit structure to the point it feels like they are using it in lieu of compensation increases. Easy to get lost in the corporate ladder

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Excellent benefits. 401k had 7% match and 10% profit sharing. Occasionally there is free breakfast and lunches. Room to grow in the company if you are willing to move
cons: On the surface the Financial Consultant position seems great. They give you a book of clients, there's no cold calling since they provide leads and you can make over 6 figures with average effort. But in reality it's a pure sales role with very little concern about what's right for the client. Definitely not a fiduciary advisor and the turnover is extremely high.  It's all about selling product and filling the buckets. Fidelity FCs are managed by the ever present spreadsheet. Everyone is stacked ranked and if you are below average on any category your branch manager or RPC ( who are usually inexperienced coaches that stink at sales) will come talk to you to see how to improve. The problem is there are like over 20 categories of things they measure you on. So you will always be below average in something! Another annoying thing is every click on the computer, every phone call, every email is tracked like big brother ! They also continually roll out some new method or spreadsheet and say this is the way things are going to be so get used to it. 4 months later you never hear about that spread sheet again. There is no adjustment if you are new, if you are in different markets or have a smaller or a more established book. There is a certain level of gamesmanship with the numbers too. Click here it counts, click here it doesn't even if you did the work. Talk to a client for like 30 seconds and tag their deposit and you get credit. Drop this client from your book without the client knowing and you won't get hit with an outflow.   The people who do well in the role game the system the best. All the managers are ok with this and all they care about is selling managed money, annuities and bringing in new assets. Who cares what's right for the clients. That's really the sad part the clients think you are helping but in reality you are just selling what pays you the most basis points and hope they never call you after the sale. My advice is if you get this position plan to work it for 2 years then find something else in Fidelity not in the branch network.

headline: Nice company to work with
pros:
Work life balance
chance to learn lot of things
cons:
low salary comparatively
poor people management

headline: H & W Customer Services
pros: Great investment options regarding 401K and ability to really become knowledgeable about investing.
cons: Development opportunities are just not there

headline: Customer Service Representative
pros: Training is pleasant. They hire right out of college. Work-sponsored outings are a delight. Great facilities, beautiful campus, on-site Starbucks is the greatest perk of all. Friendly coworkers. Pretty packaging for what proves to be quite an awful deal.
cons:
Customer service representative work and culture is truly toxic, mentally taxing, entirely sedentary, and unsettlingly monitored by management. You are physically chained to your desk by a phone set for nine hours a day, and provided with two 15-minute breaks and one 30-minute break, all of which are timed by the tracking system. 

There's a big sentiment of favoritism that guides promotions, bonuses, and on the flip side - verbal / written warnings. You don't need to be able to think in order to excel in this role, you just need to be able to follow chain of command and avoid questioning anything. Voicing your opinion will always work against you.

For anyone who studied finance / econ / business, be warned: this is NOT a finance job in any capacity. You will not learn anything about the financial service industry by being here - unless you move into a licensed role, in which you'll really only be able to learn about the industry to pitch the same handful of Fidelity products that benefit the company, so it's really just a glorified sales role. I work with many people who previously worked in grocery stores, coffee shops, or retail shops, who never went to college. It doesn't matter what you know - if anything, it'll benefit you to avoid all forms of thinking whatsoever, as Fidelity does not value ideas, only obedience. 

Your schedule is monitored by a system that quantifies every second you spend on / off the phone into performance metrics that determine your fate at the company. Do not drink too much water at your desk. If you take bathroom breaks, it'll harm your metrics and your manager will have to talk to you and possibly issue a warning. Management speaks like they "want to help you", but they really want to help themselves climb the Fidelity ladder, and couldn't care less about their expendable employee base. Pay is very low for a financial services industry job...customer service reps are barely making $38k. And this was after a much-raved about "pay increase" that we should've been so humbled and honored to receive, for the grueling work we struggle through. 

Coaching sessions are torturous. You'll be placed in a room with your manager and possibly two to three other colleagues, to listen to each others calls, and tear them apart to bits. You are expected to adhere to a call structure and parrot the same lines, check off a certain number of transfers to certain departments, pitch a certain number of "contribution increases" to bring more money to Fidelity at the customer's expense. Managers never tell you what you did well on calls, only what you did poorly. It's not that we don't want feedback and to improve - but sometimes, we did some really nice things on the calls and want to be recognized for our positives too.

Minor technicalities are a guaranteed pull down the rabbit hole of warnings. If you have a technical error, the quality team screens more of your calls, notifies your manager, and you get a "verbal warning". They'll screen exponentially more of your calls than they do for anyone else, so that they catch more mistakes you made that everyone else makes too - regardless of how minimal they may be, the repercussions escalate very quickly. Management gets excited to prosecute their employees and never looks at the full situation when quality provides feedback. Half the time, they don't even read their emails or listen to the call, just issue a warning because you "messed up," and they don't care about your side of the story. Sometimes if you try to explain, they'll ask you to stop talking.

If you start in a phone center, you will end in a phone center. Before you begin working, management will pitch to you that the "sky's the limit" with career growth in the company, but they don't tell you about the red tape that stands between you and the sky. Fidelity sucks people in for years and years, until they don't have any speakable skills to pitch anywhere outside the company because they've been on the phones for so long, and they're stuck there. It's a culture run by unfair management who talks down to you like you're an incompetent toddler. You will be overworked, underpaid, and undervalued for all the efforts at self-betterment in this job, as it all goes to waste. If they like you, they like you. If they don't, nothing will change that. Either way, get out of there sooner rather than later. The brand name that Fidelity provides isn't worth the mental and emotional suffering of their customer service work.

headline: Financial Service Rep

Benefits package is very good including medical, dental, vision and 401k.
cons:
Opportunity for advancement is limited.
Call center environment so there is strict adherence to a schedule.

Good benefits.

headline: Financial Representative Full Trader

headline: Senior business analyst

cons: Work you like a dog

headline: Great Benefits
pros: Great benefits for employees, including on site amenities
cons: Some organizations are brutal to work in.

headline: Good opportunity
pros: I very much enjoyed my time at fidelity, had the opportunity to work with a great team, family environment.
cons: Must work with a lot of stubborn clientele. Lots of work with low pay. If management doesn't like you there will be no mobility in your career. Management is overly strict  and need to relax

headline: Awesome people
