cons: it's a lot of work - it sometimes feels like I'm running around and constantly being interrupted. All part of the job though.

headline: Be aware of what you are getting into
pros: Great benefits and amenities on site
cons: Limited upward growth potential, favoritism among managers

headline: Highly political
pros: Decent salary. Good benefits. Some coworkers that can share your values about doing big things. A company that prides itself in conservative investing contrasted with technology and first-to-market product and services.
cons: A highly political company with unknown employee measurement and hidden scores. As a senior person in my position you get to know the skill set that is important for your job. When you do outstanding work you soon realize that advancement Is not based on merit but who you are aligned with. A company that is interested more in protecting management with an emphasis on the org chart and less about the work itself. Constant internal battles and intentional reorganizations. An internal employee goal program that ignores how you want to grow as an individual instead focusing on how a manager wants you positioned. If you get a good manager that focuses on the work it can be a wonderful place but soon there will be a reorg and and you will find yourself having to pay more attention to the political back channels and less on your passions and skill set. Politics is extended externally as well with profits spent on preventing governmental "regulation" but internally a love of regulating the employee. Highly protectionist from the top on down. This protectionism even extends to internal technology where systems in place are more about what management wants rather than what the employee needs.

headline: Great Company to work in
pros: Open Transparent environment, Great Management and fun loving culture
cons: Nothing as such all good here

headline: Good Atmosphere, a bit time consuming
pros: Great work environment, great benefits, people are very friendly, get to experiment with a lot of different technologies.
cons: Can be a bit time consuming, installs can involve a lot of late nights, not a lot of room for experimentation sometimes.

headline: Financial Advisor

cons: stagnant base pay, shrinking bonus with increased production, corporate meeting with very little to do with helping clients or improving production

headline: Senior Business Analyst
pros: Great benefits, decent career advancement...easily the best financial services company to work for.  Fidelity leverages technology some of the most innovative ways making work here interesting at times.
cons: Conservative work environment.  Very hierarchical.

headline: Financial Service Representative
pros: Excellent benefits and excellent working environment
cons: Few career path options and not much room to advance

headline: Analysts don't always make good leaders

headline: Phone Associate
pros: It is a stable company so layoffs are extremely rare. The 401k match is pretty good. Overall their benefits are decent.
cons: Management has an agenda in terms of who gets promoted and quite often it is not based on merit. Nepotism occurs everywhere, but at Fidelity it's an epidemic. However Fidelity has mastered the method. If you don't fit into their cookie cutter template or don't have a close friend or relative blazing a trail, plan on being stuck in your role for years while relative new hires leave you in their dust.

headline: Stock Plan Representative
pros: Health Benefits.  Work friends.  Company paid for FrontRunner transportation.
cons: Politics.  Bring in a million dollars from another company, maybe hear a "good job".  In a way it's a glorified call center.  Need to be in Salt Lake if you want to advance. Overtime.

headline: Financial Representative
pros:
- if you like to be treated like your 12 this call center is for you
- if you like to work in a cheap office surrounded by homeless people this is the place for you 
- if you like to have to time out when you go to the bathroom this is the place for you
Every second of your day is supervised. You will more than likely have a 10 hour shift where you will spend 9 hours and 15 minutes of it on the phone and if you don't you will get in trouble and receive "verbal warnings" that turn into "written warnings" .
You receive two 15 minute and one 10 minute break (to go potty) 
You have to time out during your one hour non paid timed lunch break.
Now factor in every person calling in extremely mad because there is an issue with the website and they had to literally wait 45 minutes to get to you so they take their anger out on you.
It is not even sure if it's the Walmart of the financial industry. 
If you never want to make 6 figures in your life this is the place for you - well you might make LOW figures if you spend literally your entire life there sucking up to some of the strangest people you will ever encounter which in return will suck the life out of you.
cons:
This is 100% call center.
Nothing in the financial industry to do with this job - You do get your series 7 and 63 so that you can do the most exciting thing with your job and take orders from customers. Don't screw up or you'll get a boo boo aka trade error. #verbal warning
Its filled with people either making a mid life career change and they are so excited about a 401k and insurance (because they were going nowhere in their life) or you come straight out of college and if the person is halfway normal they are gone in less than two years.
The managers are some of the biggest jokes I have ever experienced in my life.
If you think women don't have an equal opportunity please go to Fidelity Salt Lake City. Women are promoted and have higher jobs for the sole fact they are women.
My manager would call me homeslice, homeboy, homies, holmes, homes, gangsta, etc 
She was so out of touch with the team it was truly remarkable. Unfortunately though that seemed to be the common theme.

headline: Financial Representative

cons: Track every move you make while studying for your exams. Call center job is beyond monotonous. If you can't get a real job in finance- do not succumb to a call center job. You can make more money doing a blue collar job where you get to breathe fresh air and not stare off into a never ending phone pit. There's a reason so many people quit Fidelity- they offer no way out from the call center.

headline: Director

I wish I could stay and grow my career with the company but feel like I am hitting a ceiling in my career. They really don't help you or encourage you to move outside of your group. You need to leave the company to pursue your next upward career move, get that next level of experience and then re-apply for a more senior position at Fidelity in order to move up in your career.  Sad to say but it is the reality at Fidelity.

headline: Financial Consultant - Branch
pros: Great training (actual curriculum and off sight classes), great benefits (7% match on 401k, profit sharing), great tools and resources (internal and external tools). Leads generated for you, and pretty good experience with all phone site reps and "spokes."
cons:
Great place to work for a very specific demographic. Everything is sales based, regardless of the "relationship model" that you hear about. Your success can depend on your geographical location, too. Some branches are extremely "flow heavy," while you really have to grind at others. 

There's a lot of talk about being wealth planners, but you may spin your wheels if you attempt it; there's simply no time to focus on anything that isn't closing a sale. 

Need to be employed for a whole year before match or profit sharing start. Vesting doesn't begin until you've been employed 2 full years.

headline: Review from an SSE
pros:
-Good flexibility
-Work from home option
-Good transportation facility
-Sufficient leaves
-Fidelity US is a great company, Fidelity India should should live up to that.
cons:
-Your future depends on the the Business unit you belong to. But in most business units, growth is extremely slow. Even a SSE to lead promotion is extremely difficult. Most people are in the same level for more than 4-5 years.
-If you have a good and dynamic manager, your growth and hike would be good. But if you have a bad one, life can be miserable.
-They are not a vertically growing organisation, so the requirement for higher positions are very low. They are glad if senior resources move out.
- If you are in a support role, learning hits a dead end unless you pro-actively keep updating your skills.
-Moving to other teams are extremely difficult, unless you have a very strong network.
- HR's are non-existent, as someone rightly said.

headline: It could be great or it could be terrible
pros:
Good benefits & pay
Not a lot of pressure to get things done
Nice office/campus
Free rent for 5 months
Get paid to do pretty much nothing all day

This was my first job out of college as a software developer. They have a training program where they send you to North Carolina for five months to learn about various technologies and to work on a "real life" project.

About halfway through the program you get notified of the actual team that you'll be on when you return to your job site. You have some input with this, but the decision is ultimately made by management.

The program itself isn't too bad. I learned about a lot of technologies that I hadn't heard of and it gave me a little bit of real world experience.
cons:
Work non-existent/not challenging
Office is located in the middle of nowhere (Texas)
Old fashioned attitudes
Not a lot of young people unless you work in the call center
Old technology
Too much bureaucracy

The downside to the training program is that the team that you get placed on is very hit or miss and very much or if your control. Some people were placed on awesome teams working with cool products and technologies while others were stuck working on software that was 20 years old. 

Also during the training there are a lot of B.S. corporate events/talks, which were super cheesy and unnecessary. Some of the topics during training were a waste of time too, like learning how to write an e-mail (yes, I'm serious).

The team I was placed on seemed to have no plan in place for me when I got there despite the fact that a manager has to request an associate from the aforementioned training program so it's not like I was placed on their team by surprise or without their knowledge.

The whole time I was there I wrote probably a total of 20 lines of code because the product was in maintenance and there was very little new development. There wasn't really any work for me to do, so I essentially got paid to read reddit all day.

There are tons of meetings to attend and most of them are just people from various teams/business units arguing over minute details about random aspects of a project. The amount of red tape that you have to go through to get things done is pretty high.

headline: Good program

headline: Workplace Planning & Guidance Consultant
pros: I enjoyed autonomy, I created my own schedule, although certainly certain goals had to be met. I was paid a salary, plus a variable compensation, which was largely derived from my activities, so I had a better chance to drive my own success.
cons: For my region, a huge amount of travel was required, which took much of my productive time. This was often not the case with my peers, whom I was ranked against. Certain employer events would also cause flows of assets beyond my control. They attempted to capture this in the goal setting, but that was done so far in advance that it was certainly not an exact science. The travel time made it very difficult to have much of a personal or social life as well. I often worked 12 hour days, and then spent the evenings doing all the paperwork and entering notes into our tracking system, so it wasn't unusual to have a 14-15 hour day, then have to catch a plane to another location and do it all again the next day.

headline: Depends on where you are in the company
author_position: Workplace Planning and Guidance Consultant I
pros: Amazing benefits. 7% 401k match, 10% profit sharing into your 401k every year, 5 year period for full vesting. That can get lucrative after a while. You also can have the Portfolio Advisory Service manage your 401k free of charge as an employee, and you have access to beautiful grounds (the complex is thousands of acres large with a pond and hiking trails and two cafeterias and a couple gyms, tennis and basketball courts and softball field and volleyball court). The health insurance is a little pricey but the plan itself is the best I've ever seen in terms of what it will cover. And last but not least, if you do your years i the dumpster up front, there is excellent income potential within the company.
cons: My experience is all within Workplace Participant Services business unit., working with workplace retirement plans such as 401ks and 403bs, and the company that pay us to service those plans. In WPS, we are underpaid for what we do (median in New England for our job type would be closer to $70k), the expectations are always changing, applied inconsistently, and you are prodded and driven to do overtime because they choose to understaff for the busy seasons to save money. In the call center positions, you're on a clock, you get the legal minimum required breaktime, and there is a general lack of respect for work/life balance. Everywhere else in Fidelity, I hear the experiences are great, so I would say this is a reflecting on being within Workplace Participant Services, not Fidelity as a whole.

headline: Good company but job functions are unclear
pros: Fidelity is a good company because it offers a ton of benefits and the salaries are fair and they treat employees well.
cons: Job functions for the most part are very ambiguous and employees are left to try to figure out (or carve out) how they to shape their functions. I worked in a department that service multiple Fidelity companies and was in charge of trying to figure out prioritization for multiple projects. Decisions were being made all over the place and constantly overriding previous agreements. I know that is how most large companies work but Fidelity takes it to a different level.

headline: Portfolio specialist
pros: Great benefits package and a large company so lots of opportunity to grow. You can advance quickly if you have ambition. The retirement benefits alone make it worth it. 10 percent profit sharing...Seven percent 401k match. You can expect to make over 100k as a portfolio specialist which is decent and is truly under 45 hour work week. They are rolling out things like16 weeks paid maternity for women and 6 weeks paid for men. The best thing about the job is you do meet life long friends and work with a ton of amazing people.
cons: They are old fashioned. They don't have a work environment that inspires creativity.They have call models and sales models that they want you to stick to "to make you successful"...they actually focus more on those models than educating about the products they want you to sell...it can sometimes make you feel like a robot and clients pick up on it. They measure performance a lot by things that don't really make business sense and have particular buckets they want you to fill. If you can get past that aspect of the job it can be a nice career.

headline: A Values Based Company that you can build a long term career with!
pros:
I am in my second decade with the firm and I am so happy I chose to work here out of college.

Family Owned:
This company takes care of its people.  I have been through 3 major economic downturns in my career and the firm always takes the long view and does cut into muscle and bone during trying times.  The Johnson family thinks in the here and now, but they also have a view 50 years out.  They are humble and grounded individuals that are always looking for opportunities to improve our business and our employee experience.  

Benefits:
We are industry leading, period.  Childcare assistance, tuition reimbursement, college loan repayment, healthy meals at a deeply discounted rate, onsite gyms, onsite healthcare facilities, onsite CFP programs, 6 months of leave for moms, computer purchase assistance, etc, etc, etc...  
If that wasn't enough, the firm isn't comfortable with out offering in this space.  We are in the midst of a major benefits reassessment.  Abby and her new head of HR are leading the charge in this effort.

Work Environment:
The family and the company goes to great length to ensure we have the best facilities for our teams.  Our major corporate campuses are spread across the country in beautiful locations.  While Fidelity is a conservative company, they build our buildings to last centuries and the are constantly refreshing them.  

I have read many posts about the call center environments.  I felt compelled to respond.  Call centers with any company are tough.  There is no way around it, it is a tough job.  However, it is an entry level position where you can learn a lot in and then leverage that learning to different roles in the future.  I know of 5 Executive Vice Presidents, several SVPs, and VPs who started in the same positions at the firm.  If you are coming out of college, you will likely start in an entry level position at some firm and you will have plenty of opportunities to work up and sideways from there.   

The firm could do a better job of facilitating that movement, but I will mention it further in the "cons" section.
cons:
Career counseling: 
Many of us were told early in our career that you needed to pull yourself up by your own bootstraps when it comes to career planning. Essentially meaning, the cream will rise to the top, and the driven folks will figure it out. 

While there is merit in this strategy,it is outdated for the size of our company.  Like many companies of our size it can become difficult to navigate.  I feel that is why many of the comments on glassdoor related to this topic are correct from the perspective of the person writing the review.  However, this is absolutely not the intention of senior leadership.  The leadership team wants to hire college grads and watch them progress out of entry level positions and branch out throughout the business.  The individuals who do, are generally immensely successful.  

The problem lies in the lack of programmatic career planning conversations and marketing of the internal opportunities and job matching. To their credit, the firm has recognized this issue and I have heard is working on building career centers to help facilitate these dialogues and career plans.  I would expect comments related to issue to start to subside as this rolls out. 

To make a long story short, the sr. team has shown that they care and want to help find the solution.

HR systems and training:
Simply put, we have antiquated systems in HR, and training needs to be modernized to adapt to the way college grads learn.  A better mix of classroom training integrated with a lacking digital solution that ties to our HR systems. 

HR system and staffing:
HR needs an overhaul.  Specifically in staffing.  We have a very traditional model and staffing and HR are loaded with career HR and staffing people.  We need to take a cue from Silicon Valley companies and add more business consultants and business leaders to the HR function to modernize it.  We need to keep about a 1/3 of this business unit as traditional HR and Staffing consultants, but there is a serious lack of creativity and challenge of old processes because of the the similar backgrounds of everyone in the group.  Until we do, we are destined to be average in this space.

headline: Fidelity Financial Rep.
pros: The training program is one of the best training programs you could go through.  They do a good job of teaching you how to answer the phone in a professional manner and how to use the systems.  They give you study guidelines that will help you pass the Series 7 and 63 licenses.  Paid training, which includes studying for your licenses.
cons: Have to pass the Series 7 and 63 licenses within 3 months of starting there. They tell you that you will be studying completely for the first 6-8 weeks, but you end up answering phone calls for the 2nd half of the day starting the 4th week. And the first 3 weeks are teaching you how to answer phones and use the systems.

headline: Good Luck
pros: Very easy and money just falls in your lap cause of the brand name. Easy competition for the stack rank. It's fairly new so it isn't micromanaged yet but it is trending that direction. More relaxed than other roles in the phone site.
cons: The compensation is much less than what it should be for the money you move in and service provided. Confusing bonus structure that is constantly changing and bonus is dictated by manager entirely and not by production and stack rank so it can be very bias. In reality the stack rank is pointless cause 2nd place can get a bigger bonus than 1st. It is starting to become more and more micromanaged. It has become more of an efficiency role instead of quality even though the main point is sales and not service. Very unorganized part of the company. It's a little niche compared to the rest of the company so there is constant change and no one including directors know what's going on in the future. Also misrepresented growth opportunities. They say they are expanding and you can promote to the more prestigious phone role or into the field however when one of those spots is vacated they backfill it with two people in this role instead of replacing. So be prepared to be stuck.

headline: High Net Worth Associate
pros: Lots of great resources, training is definitely better than average for the industry, lots and lots of great employer provided benefits, facilities are very up to date and modern, tons of resources at your disposal, and a great place to learn more without necessarily having to be in a pure sales or commission environment.
cons: Pay and bonus structure is significantly subpar - every time this is brought up you're reminded "how great" Fidelity's non-salary benefits are, which is somewhat true, however the fact that I have access to all kinds of benefits that don't apply to me ,or don't really have any personal benefit to me, personally, irrelevant.  I can't pay rent, buy food, or pay all the other bills I have will my "great benefits."  Money is the only thing that helps with that - and the salaries Fidelity pays, compared to the broader industry, are ridiculously low.  Moreover, there have been numerous changes that have occurred in the last 12 months that are ostensibly to "make things better" for the customer, as well as the associate, but the net effect has been the opposite ... for both.  They've basically significantly increased the scope of the role, while narrowing the performance metrics ... all while creating an increasing environment where it essentially makes it impossible for you to provide the positive experience the customer is expecting, and meet your goals.  How this has played out out to associate is ... you can kiss making more than the bare minimum for your quarterly bonuses (which also ... in not very much at all) goodbye.  Also, over the last 12 months or so, there seems to have been a dramatic concern with turnover, primarily among the associates who have been with the company less than 12 months.  The company has become ridiculously preoccupied with finding ways to keep this demographic with the company that they're basically throwing everything but the kitchen sink at them in the misguided hope it will keep them from leaving.  Basically ... they're focusing all their measures on increasing salary, compensation, and quality at work to the employees who have been there the least, and contribute the least to the company's overall functionality.  I've been with the company, and in this function for years, and even though I've been given yearly bonuses and increases I sit next to people who have been licensed less than 6 months, and are making the same amount in salary as me, or more.  It's really insulting, not to mention makes all the experienced, and seasoned employees feel extremely unappreciated.  Then there's also the issue that performance and ability really have no bearing whatsoever towards promotions or recognition for achievement - the current situation at the location where I work reminds me more of my senior year of high school, and everything boils down to a popularity contest.  The end result is you have people who weren't even competent to begin with and routinely failed to meet even the most basic of their performance metrics, being given increased levels of responsibility and management if they're "popular."  Granted this exists to some degree or another no matter where you work, however the level I've witnessed over the years is on the order of 20 times worse than anything I've experienced in nearly 15+ years in the workforce.

headline: Running itself into the ground
pros: The benefits (401, medical, etc) are above standard for most employers. They're also the most likely firm to get you to pass a series 7 if you have no finance experience or degree to fall back on. If you can handle call center work there is some job mobility in that function, just don't expect to get into the back office or anything beyond a phone unless you're a lucky duck destined for management.
cons: Where to begin...The mantra being preached to new hires is that your contribution matters and you're helping our customers just by answering the call. In reality, training is now so utterly warped and schizophrenic that you likely will need a promotion above the entry level position to assist with anything more complicated than cutting a check or trading a mutual fund. Consequently, it is absolutely crushing that you can't help half the customers that wait hours in line to get to you and that's even worse when you first start to where you transfer 95% of your calls. Management is unhelpful and most of the call center managers you honestly scratch your head at what they actually do other than go to meetings and give you self-directed coaching assignments. As with any call center, metrics are King. I got promoted entirely because I got through calls fast and didn't ask questions only for the next role to be even worse. Certain departments (core/hnw services mainly) have forced overtime right now that is held against you if you don't meet the supposed goal or have other activities that prevent you from doing so. The new systems internally have also taken hold times and raised them exponentially because of the new/barely trained reps having to transfer everything and attrition causes old reps to leave for jobs outside of fidelity or internal promotions with the stress the new system has lumped on them from new hires being functionally useless. Volumes aren't even as bad as they were last year but it's still a high stress job that keeps you tied to a cubicle having to apologize to clients for management failing to see the problem in changing the entire service model at the busy time of year when clients are already in a hurry and coming in in droves. The money isn't enough to make this worthwhile.

headline: Benefits Specialist

Mind you seven years of working with the company and most ( mainly of ethnic background) are just getting their first promotion. I was there 7 years was give great feedback during review time but managers always found a reason not to give me a raise ( I received on raise the entire time I was employed). One made up reason given when my manager spent a min tripping over her words to think of what to come up with was that she heard I spend to much time in the ladies room (of course it was not true but it was good enough for her to justify when I again would not receive a raise) Most of my managers were up north therefore  managed at a distance and visited maybe every three months per year. I could go on and on but over all I would not recommend anyone in there right mind to work there ...at least not in the benefits department. I had enough of being used and overwork and constantly being told I was doing great here is extra work, but not receiving compensation.

headline: Financial Representative
pros:
Good way to get licensed. Extremely focused on making sure you pass the 7/63. Free material, a retake if your scores are close to passing and an overall good atmosphere in training..

very boring, but very thorough.

Ok job for a fresh college graduate, but other than that I would advise one to stay away.

Good food on campus. They hire good cooks to feed us while work. Decent pricing too
cons:
Once you get licensed and "get on the floor" that is when the trouble begins.

The job is extremely boring. Dealing with people calling every second of the day from about 9-4pm is horrible. Most of the time you are resetting passwords, not actually doing anything finance related. And when you do get the chance to do finance related things, all you do is enter trade tickets and hit send.

In training, they sold to us that we are "financial professionals," however, I would beg to differ. The only difference between "service associates" and a regular CSR rep is that at Fidelity, you are licensed.

The job sucks. It sucks your soul. It is not a fun environment. IF you enjoy  answering calls all day for $16-20 dollars a hour, have at it.

**Also, it should be noted that promotion to the sales side is extremely hard. There are 200 apps a year for 25-50 sales jobs. You have to kiss major butt and kill your metrics to get ahead. It is just too many people applying for those jobs. Managers will say that there are so many positions you can work in, but in reality they are all the same job, with a x<5000 in pay differential in the service side.

AS OTHER REVIEWS HAVE SAID, ONCE YOU ARE HIRED IN A PHONE SITE, THE CHANCE OF LEAVING TO A BRANCH OR TO ANOTHER DIVISION OF FIDELITY (fund management, analysis, etc). IS EXTREMELY SLIM. PLEASE KNOW THIS.

cons: As for the Cons, a lot of the employees came from Boston and they are not as friendly as people here in Texas.  When I say that I mean, I said "hello" to people for months it seemed like before they actually started responding back to me, "hello".  Quite a few people relocated from Boston to Westlake and they were all close friends. That made it tough as a new employee.  On the positive side, once they go to know me they were great friends!!

Great benefits.  Maternity leave just increased to 16 weeks and paternity is 6 weeks.  10% profit sharing, 7% match in 401k.  Retiree health benefit, HSA's, dependent care.  Tuition and fitness reimbursements. 

Good tools and resources for a financial consultant.
cons: Too many boxes to check day to day.

headline: Associate Systems Services Support Analyst
pros: Benefits are really good here, company culture on the IT side is about empowering people and allowing them to make decisions on their own.  With this, there is a lot of recognition for the work that you do.
cons: Amount of work to be done can be overwhelming at times.  Once you learn something new, be ready to teach it to others.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Volume of new cases provides a steep learning curve for Financial planning process
cons: Same volume eventually becomes a problem with no real support. Your not building anything / no equity in business. Management is militant they can end your career I'd you say something they don't like.

headline: Good work life balance, cares for employees! Nothing much...
pros:
- Good work life balance
- Friendly workplace
-  Satisfaction of working for a huge market leader in BFSI space 
- Stable corporate strategy as it's market leader with huge leverage & product road map
- Great place for experienced people to retire
cons:
- Not good for freshers and youngsters who are looking for a challenging opportunity
- Because of business model is a very slow company
- Values trust and cautiousness more than competence, sometimes

headline: Security Lending Specialist Review
pros:
- I came in with a group of associates who were young and my age
- Fidelity always provides stable job security in rough times
- depending on the department, its a good work/life balance
cons:
- the overall environment is very negative, you can tell that lots of people just do it for the job, which in my case was not enough money to justify staying
- not a lot of lateral growth outside of the operations department
- the pay is just below average and bonuses are laughable

headline: Good training, good atmosphere, development opportunities, job growth opportunities.
pros: Good training, good atmosphere, development opportunities, job growth opportunities, forward looking and innovative culture. A great place to build a career.
cons: Vertical corporate structure lends to career growth opportunities, but lack of tenure with the firm seems to be  bureaucratic red tape.

headline: Good culture. Great career starter.
pros: Great at career development, especially early in ones career.
cons: Very difficult to learn about internal job salaries.

headline: It's a stepping stone at best.
pros: Fidelity has an incredibly in-depth four month long training program that will not only bring pre-licensed financial representatives up to speed to pass their Series 7 and 63's (even for those completely new to the industry), but will also familiarize you with all of the software that would be used on a day-to-day basis. Generally speaking, upon completion of the program, financial representatives are capable of adequately performing the job duties in what is objectively a complicated job function without any sort of assistance. Also, barring a layoff climate or doing anything illegal, job security is very, very high; never hitting your numbers will still get you your weekly paycheck. If you play the game, opportunity is most certainly there to advance (and your manager will be first in line to assist you in achieving your goals), but you can only go so far in the call center, both in terms of job duties and salary.
cons: Unfortunately, the training program is where my positive experience ended. Employees are reminded every day from the first time they peruse the careers website, to the job interview, to on-boarding, to training, to team meetings, that Fidelity isn't like Merrill Lynch, Schwab, JP Morgan, or any other player in the game; Fidelity is a family-owned company and doesn't have to play to it's shareholders, and thus they are one of the few in the business "for the customer". That sure sounds nice, but beyond being family-owned, it's just not true. This job is in a 24/7 call center, and just like every call center in the world, metrics are king. You'll never move up anywhere in the company for retaining a multi-million dollar account or preventing perilous actions through education of financial instruments or any other morally outstanding action... you'll move up for finishing your calls on an average of less than eight minutes. This "time = money" focus exacerbates an already-beaurocratic business structure by incentivizing representatives to transfer their calls or to be curt to the point of being entirely unhelpful. That's fine, and almost expected from most call center representatives with other companies, but in financial services, it's unacceptable; you're dealing with people's retirement accounts and livelihoods. On the sales side, recommendations are limited to proprietary target-date funds and bloated, high-fee "managed" accounts. Going above and beyond to solve problems that are repeatedly surfacing and are consistently unaddressed is a habit discouraged by management: "that's not your job". Other than their own propaganda, nothing differentiates this company from the other financial services firms--do not take a potential paycut to choose Fidelity over them with the idea that you'll be working for some sort of Red Cross organization, even though they will spin it that way. At the end of the day, this is a 24/7 call center (where your job is to verify customers, reset passwords, give website support, send checks, and enter trades at their direction...financial professional is thrown around very loosely around Fidelity, but I would not consider the FR to be one) that is ALWAYS hiring. If you weren't able to deduce, there is an unhealthy amount of turnover at Fidelity due to employees leaving for increased responsibilities and salaries (most Jax representatives went to Merrill, which was literally across the street!). On the other hand, if you have some sort of relevant degree or experience and are out of work, there is a ton of job security and experience to be gained here. It's a stepping stone at best.

headline: Enjoyable
pros: The people here legitimately care about the clients and the work they are doing. Really great group, for the most part.
cons: Sometimes (though rarely) it really does feel like a big company. Sometimes management/HQ in Boston feels really far away. Lots of buzz about how great they are (which I believe,) but because it is such a large company, there is still a feeling of separation. Hard to stop that.

headline: Investor Center Intern
pros: Good first internship experience, networking opportunities, good pay
cons: Limited work without certifications, somewhat unstructured program

headline: Strong Company
pros: Great benefits. Quality people for the most part.
cons: Depending on your role it can be a grind. Lots of layers of management.

headline: Great place to learn
pros: I've been working FBSI more than 2.5 years. It's good company to learn more.. Good work culture and employees are equally treated..
cons: Comparing to Engineering people, Analyst role people getting less salary min of 1.75 lac. People politics are more dominant part.

headline: Analyst
pros: I love the Company Great place to work
cons: Honestly nothing for me to report

headline: Great place to work

headline: Career Company with Clear Expectations and Retirability
pros: Good people, nice work life balance, company has solid foundation and long term stability, excellent benefits and retirement plans, awesome 401k matching
cons: really big company with a lot of employees, could be a big fish in a massive ocean, I left in 1999 because I wanted to be a big fish in a smaller body of water, and it worked for me with a smaller more flexible firm, this might be one of those companies where you might start to get your foot in the door to the industry and then leave to satisfy ambition, and then go back as a quicker way to advance within the management pyramid

headline: Account Executive
pros: Great company to work for
cons: I can not think of any cons

headline: Good entry level job
pros: There are plenty of options for Upward mobility. Career path is a definite plus.
cons: Low starting salary, but the upward mobility makes up for it.

headline: High level review of company
pros: Worked at a branch. The team was awesome. Worked with great people. Good work/life balance. Had my entire evenings to myself and no need to check emails. This part was great. You also have the chance to help people.
cons: You gotta drink the kool aid if you want to succeed.  Very hierarchical. In the end it's a sales job. You gotta sell stuff: managed portfolios, annuities, probe for and obtain outside assets.

headline: FC
pros: Pay can be lucrative for workhorses.
cons: Long hours are needed to outperform generally.

headline: Excellent Company

headline: Great benefits, easy sales role, constant pressure to increase numbers, not much flexibility in schedule.

The benefits are great. Good health plan 10% profit sharing, PTO and vesting increase over 5 years.
Easy to sell with fidelity brand behind you
cons: Lack of flexibility with schedule. No mobile access to work. Pay not as competitive with outside firms. Management is never satisfied. Always wants you to increase numbers.

headline: Financial Rep

Lots of opportunity to advance
Good Benefits, compensation, and benefits

cons: Slow to make decisions at management levels.  Sometimes the complexity and size of the organization make it a more rigid environment and lead to paralysis in decision making.

headline: great place
pros: Pay, culture, coworkers, management, work life balance, voluntary time off, vacation time

benefits and compensation

not much work life balance

headline: Operations VP

headline: Good pay and benefits

headline: HNW

headline: Great Company

headline: Excellent Company
pros: Fidelity has many opportunities for advancement and offers great employee benefits.  The salary is generous and the raises and profit sharing bonuses are very impressive. I loved working for this company.
cons: Unfortunately, I was laid off. It may be best to join an internal team that is profitable.  When job cuts begin, it is usually with newer teams who have not gained profits within the company.

headline: Corporate Audit Coop
pros: good opportunities, good pay, good company
cons: no cons as such here.

headline: Seemed like a great place but...
pros: I was offered a great salary and benefits.  The hours seems reasonable and not ever having to work weekends seemed great
cons: I went through the entire hiring process and was made an offer, went for drug testing , fingerprinting and to have a badge made . On a Monday before class started I mentioned I was pregnant . On that Tuesday I recieved a call from hr asking question regarding my pregnancy , on Thursday I recieved a very rude call stating they were withdrawing my offer due to "unspecified concerns that came up during background check" even though the background portion had already been completed and passed long before... There's no doubt in my mind that they changed their mind due to my pregnancy , which Im pretty sure is illegal. I'm very disappointed , I was looking forward to this job and wasn't even expecting a maternity leave from them, I was back at my current job when my youngest was only 6 days old. There's nothing in my background that should've kept me from getting hired , per their rules that I looked over carefully. Whatever their reasons, I know that my merit and experience more than qualified me for this position , and my character has never been questioned, especially by an employer or associate. Their loss I guess.

headline: Great benefits
pros: Great benefits, training, ability to move up. Company really does put customers first.
cons: Low pay for hourly employees.

headline: Internship
pros: Great people who are more than willing to help and explain.  As an intern I felt as though I was really part of the team, where my ideas and critics were hear.
cons: Job can be very repetitive after a few weeks.

headline: Good Benefits, Pleasent Workplace
pros: The company provides good 401k matching and profit sharing. The coworkers are pleasant and easy to work with. A culture of employee development means that a will to succeed can overcome difficulties with acclimating to a job. Never will you feel that you have to choose between doing the right thing and doing what's best for your career.
cons: The company often feels slow to address employee work quality concerns. A positive spin is sometimes the solution instead of a substantive change.  Technology is cumbersome and lacks dependability.

headline: Great Employer
pros:
benefits: 401k 7% match, 10% profit sharing

also, paternity leave has increased to 16wks for the Mom and 6wks for the Dad
cons: none. I have really enjoyed starting my career at a great company

headline: OK
pros: They served us lots of good food for many of our lunches and were generally very nice people to work with.
cons: The pay wasn't as good as it could have been and the environment was nothing special, nor was the work that interesting.

headline: Excellent place to work
pros: Great pay, great benefits, and higher ups are always willing to help you advance
cons: Jobs can be extremely repetitive day to day

headline: Co-op Student
pros: Fidelity invests in their co-op students. They had between 20-40 co-op students each semester (most in Toronto Office). Every week HR organized walkthroughs of different departments and seminars to help co-op students better understand their business. Co-op students get many benefits including presentations from Portfolio Managers and guides on interviewing and recruiting to professional etiquette. Of all of my co-op terms I was treated best at fidelity and that was a common experience. Fidelity is also a very highly respected employer to have on your CV.
cons: A con to Fidelity is that there are a limited number of investment roles. Their investment team might hire one top student a year. There are roles available in Sales, Finance, Products and Accounting but no investment roles. As far as I could tell you would have a better chance getting a job with McKinsey than investing money for Fidelity. This isn't really a con to co-op students as much as it is to grads who want to actually do investing.

headline: Pay is great and benefits are awesome
pros: The pay and benefits are unbelievable.  I have had others approach me to leave but when I start considering the benefits and pay I get I quickly stop looking.
cons: It can be demanding at times depending on the department you are in.  So if you are not part of the core business you can get overlooked.

headline: a good choice for a peaceful life
pros:
Work life balance
Respectful environment
Relaxed
No pressure
cons:
Slow in decision making
Might get complacent

headline: Good people and benefits
pros: Great atmosphere with supportive management.  Outstanding benefits package.
cons: Compensation is below market rate for many positions.

headline: Great Benefits, Low on Excitement
pros: The benefits package at the time was very good. The pension plan, in particular, was one of the best around, especially once you had built up some service time. The working atmosphere was, for the most part, friendly and relaxed.
cons: In a lot of cases, progression up the hierarchy seemed to be the result of time served or by stroking the right ego. If you are the sort of person who thinks differently and enjoys a dynamic environment, this is probably not the place for you. Being told what to do by Boston, as in other US multinationals, can make for an easy, but un-challenging routine. The organisation in Ireland is also completely at the whim of management in Boston and things can turn from positive to negative (and back again, to be fair) with consequent insecurity at times.

headline: Full Trader
pros: They will teach you everything you need to know about the stock market, the training is exceptional. Pay and benefits are average but they are very generous with bonuses. In the middle of a growth spurt so lots of new opportunities and career progressions. They are also hugely profitable and a Juggernaut in the industry, you will have no fear in the company going under.
cons: They are growing their client base faster then they can hire new representatives. As a result the work load is severe, inflexible hours and mandatory overtime. You have to book your vacations about 6 months in advance in order not to have corporate operations deny your time off requests. The job is also very repetitive once you know what you are doing and as such it is very easy to burn out.

headline: Community Relations Coordinator
pros: Company is moving towards a millennial approach of work style.
cons: Hiring Process can be timely and unclear

headline: Fidelity Review
pros: Great values and culture. High integrity.
cons: Upward mobility is a very slow process. limited advancement opportunities over the short term.

headline: Overall Good Company
pros:
People are great. 
The higher ups seem to really care about the employees.
cons: You can either get a good manager who actually gives you work that could be relevant to your degree or not.

headline: Software Engineer

Latest technologies to work with
Friendly people
good work life balance

More slack time
Employer reviews mostly dependent on BU rather than individual performance

headline: Customer Service Associate
pros: Great comprehensive benefits. Flexible hours. Work life balance is great.

headline: Excellent Place to Work
pros: Cutting edge technologies, fantastic benefits, great canteen - really look after the staff. Fantastic location. In in all i would recommend this place as a work location.
cons: Formal attire in a non-customer remote location always seemed quite odd as it was a non- customer facing role. For specialist staff there sometimes seemed to be a a not always defined career path but this is not really an issue for a specialist. The area is very expensive to live.

headline: Great IT jobs at Fidelity
pros: Fidelity spend $3 billion on IT providing many great jobs in IT.   There are also many opportunities to move between business units for career growth.  Fidelity has a very rich benefit package.
cons: Fidelity's global site strategy is constantly relocating positions across United States and overseas.  Sometimes you are given the opportunity to relocate if the job is within US but never if it is overseas.  Also you could be relocated with your position and then a few years later your job could go overseas.

headline: Great company to work for..
pros: Great benefits, free food, transport, great values and everything you can dream of a job...
cons: Not many no workplace is perfect but fidelity really values its employees

headline: Financial Consultant
pros: Excellent benefits and brand name leader in the business.
cons: Micromanagement, high turnover, old boys/girls club. You are there to drive sales and that is it. You must aggressively sell their Portfolio Advisory Services (PAS) fee based accounts and annuities. Vanguard offers comparable funds for 1/4 of the price so your job involves tricking people.

headline: 401k Service
pros: Cool facility, great company to have on resume
cons: glued to your phone, long training process, LOW PAY, 30 min lunch - takes forever to move up.

headline: Financial Services Representative
pros: Benefits, 401k, professional environment, attractive building site with many amenities, corporate perks, good learning experience for recent graduates
cons: Frequent management changes, stressful timed call center environment, answering over 100 calls most days, short breaks and lunch, not enough time for training, frequent software and computer issues interfering service, pressured overtime, no off the phone career opportunities

headline: Good for just a job

headline: Call Center

cons: Your chance for success is based on your relationship with your manager.

headline: Good Place to Work and Get Experience!
pros: I was able to get marketing and product development/management experience in many of the firm's different lines of business.  The firm has structured policies and procedures.  Benefits were great!
cons: If you are committed to the Boston area and are not willing to re-locate to one of the firm's other regions, you may not have the longevity at the firm that many of us had enjoyed years ago.

headline: Phone job with little to no apportunity off the phone
pros: Covered parking, great employees (and to some degree managers) , nice looking campus, does not publicly traded, thus, does not need to answer shareholders, fantastic class setting to help you get licensed (series 7/63)
cons: Been here for 3 years. "promoted" 3 times. Fidelity Micro-manages its employees like McDonald's. 100% phone job. Want to go to the bathroom? Need to leave a note in regards to a customer issue? Need to talk to your manager for a moment? (you get the pattern) Too bad, it will eat into your phone statistics since they measure how many seconds of every minute you're actually on the phone and report it to you every morning. FORCED over time for 10 months out of the year (i.e kiss your weekends goodbye) even though on the interview they claim it's just for 1-2 months. All career development (which they don't stop talking about due to fear of the very high turn-over they have) is being concentrated around your ability to stay on the phone for the rest of your career (unless you want to be a manager of a phone team). I honestly don't know one employee that is not actively looking for a different job.

headline: Great place to work

Good Salary
Great benefits
Great people to worth with
Beautiful Campus
Company has integrity and professionalism
They care about customer service

headline: Great Experience as both Intern & Part-time Employee

Once I started back at school, the team kept me on as a part-time employee, which worked incredibly well for my life and I am still extremely appreciative of this company.

Not as personal as it once was - you are expendable no matter how long you were there, how dedicated you were or what level you were.

Strategic direction keeps changing with each new senior division leader.  Very frustrating.

headline: Fidelity Investments

headline: Associate
pros: great and knowledgeable associates, good benefits, just-announced student loan assistance program.  fitness equipment reimbursement program.
cons: The company's hyper obsessed with statistics, and although the benefits are pretty good, the pay isn't.  Fidelity demands a lot out of you.  It leaves very little free time.  The roles are sometimes very stressful.  As somebody in another comment said, this company's trying to be way too many things at once.  They send WAY too many "xxx manager's joining this team" emails that come across as self-congratulatory and crowd out more relevant messages.  Some managerial decisions--especially re: recent software updates--make no sense (financial or otherwise).  The company--and some managers in particular--love to micromanage associates, though I've heard that may change starting next year.

headline: High Net Worth
pros:
This job is technically a "call center", but don't let that dissuade you, Fidelity an amazing place to work. The benefits, training, and exposure to the financial markets are invaluable. For those wanting to enter the industry that do not have degrees from overpriced private colleges, Fidelity is the place to be. You will work alongside some of the best and the brightest, ambitious individuals who come from a wide array of backgrounds, all sharing a common desire to help the uneducated investor find success.

I can only speak for the Jacksonville, FL location, but the training is phenomenal. The series 7 instructors, alongside the rest of the learning and development team will make sure you are successful. You will have to be self motivated though, every day during the initial training you will be coming home to take 1-3 hour tests, but if you ever need assistance with a concept the mentors are there for you - and are actually encouraged to help you by being paid overtime.

Whether you want to move up in Fidelity or leave and go to another firm, this is a great place to get your foot in the door in a normally very competitive industry.

Benefits are amazing. Make sure you take advantage of everything.

With the brand new systems in place, schedules are more flexible!
cons:
If you want to go to a role involving financial analysis, or anything unrelated to the direct relationship with the clients, it is almost impossible to do starting from the phone roles, you will easily get a job at another firm with the training and certifications you gain, so you may have to jump around from firm to firm.

The advisory/guidance roles in Fidelity are less "sales" related in comparison to say Merrill Lynch, but they are still sales related. At the end of the month if you did not speak with a single customer that needed an annuity, you should not see any form of negative impact for not putting someone in one. Fidelity should be leading the industry in the charge towards a more "fiduciary" standard.

The compensation was recently increased to 42k for the entry level, which is okay, but honestly everyone across the board should receive about an extra ~10k. Fidelity can afford to do it, and the retention rates would drastically increase. Most of the employees are recent college graduates, so amazing healthcare and benefits are not as important as cash money to invest.

headline: Be ready to compromise your values...
pros: Base pay not so competitive, but generous bonus plans more than made up for that.  Good place for recent college grads to start their careers and get a solid foundation of experience.  Beautiful facilities, great design, and lots of art.  Lots of opportunities to participate in classes, seminars, information sessions, etc...both in person and online.
cons: Everything is communicated via 50+ page Powerpoint documents that no one reads beyond the 3rd slide during meetings. Annual increases are tiny or nonexistent, although the HR documentation indicates ranges for double-digit increases (dream on).  Some execs are reassigned to lead departments in which they have no experience and are clueless about strategies and issues.  Overall, they are very slow to take action on toxic performers, which causes turnover of  the solid performers who can get jobs elsewhere and not have to deal with the grief caused by the toxic colleagues.  Sr. leaders ask for feedback and suggestions, but rarely act on honest input - it's easier for them to manage the status quo.  Although the ongoing mantra is about ethical decisions and behaviors, I personally encountered an environment where confidentiality was breached and bullying was evident...the sr. exec chose to look the other way.

headline: Fidelity is all smoke and mirrors.

(They force you to watch countless hours of internally-produced videos during new hire class on why Fidelity is the best company you'll ever work for...). The secrecy of everything, including the breakdown of the bonus structure that is supposed to make your miserable job worth it. They make you feel bad for hating your job while at the same time putting under unmanageable working conditions. I had to work 10 hour shifts with a 30 MINUTE lunch, and if I took 1 minute longer than that, I got a threatening email from my manger. SERIOUSLY? I could go on, but there's so much that I could say about this company. Do not work for Fidelity unless you are desperate and have nowhere else to go. I've worked in call centers before, and this, by far, was the worst experience I've ever had.

headline: branch representative
pros: The benefits are generally good.  Job security is above average
cons:
I want to set everyone straight on this company.  
This is a financial sales company, not a financial services firm.  The goal year in and year out is to maximize sales at the cost of providing true financial planning services to clients and developing relationships.
Book sizes are over 500 and by nature, representatives have little incentive to interact with current book clients unless there is new money coming in.  Reps are constantly not following up with their own clients because there is no incentive to stay true to a relationship model.  The planning is a masked service, run by computers and over complicated pieces of marketing material.  When each "solution" for a client is a fidelity managed account, you start to question what actual planning you are really doing.  If I client does not want a managed account, there is barely anything you can do for them, besides show them how to research on their own, defeating the purpose of a "guidance" appointment.  Management is constantly looking at ways to better the years previously at the cost of the reps and the clients.  More appointments, more phone calls is the name of the game.  It is impossible to keep a relationship model when this is the driving force behind it.  

If you want to provide financial planning guidance in a more meaningful way, it is best to join an RIA, which is where fidelity is losing most of its staff to anyway.

headline: Cares about employees!
pros: I honestly love my job.  I'm so grateful for the opportunity to work for a company that truly cares about their clients!  Providing excellent customer service is absolutely necessary and we take it very seriously. Fidelity strives to hire like minded individuals that create a positive work environment.  They review their salaries to make sure they are staying competitive and there's plenty of overtime opportunity. The benefits are great. Tuition reimbursement, 10% profit sharing, 7% 401k match, health reimbursement (gym memberships), etc.  They are very lax compared to other companies when it comes to using sick time, last minute vacation, and changing your shift to accomplish a better work/life balance. Fidelity is very open about upcoming changes within the company with all levels of employees.
cons: Not so much Fidelity as it is the industry we work in but tax season (leading up to the tax deadline of April 15th) and distribution season (retirees requesting their minimum required distributions before the end of the year) can be incredibly draining.  Last year we were slammed and it made for a very long couple of months.

headline: Great people and working environment.
pros: People are professional and they care.  Leadership is excellent and C level executives are very in tune with what is happening in the business.  Open environment where ideas are encouraged.  Fairly conservative and cautious company which means quality triumphs over speed.  This means you actually have time to think and do things right with less pressure to simply deliver.
cons: Not a performance based company.   While they claim to be,  monetary reward system tends to be socialistic with little distinction for a person's productivity. Much of compensation is tied to 401K as opposed to cash in pocket.  Will know more on this once I've gone through the bonus round.  Once you get hired in you are fairly well set since they tend to steer away from terminations, rather they look first to place people in another position.   This makes it challenging for managers who are dealing with performance issues.  But even with this, the vast majority of people are top notch.

headline: Culture is Shifting
pros: Health/Dental/Life insurance. Unlimited growth potential. Tuition/Computer/Gym/Insurance reimbursements. Management is (somewhat) supportive of coaching/growth of reps. Sick days. 3 weeks Vaca. Paid holidays. Overtime is paid at almost 3X. Profit sharing is huge. Employer match is huge. Ability to work as much as you'd like.
cons: Culture is shifting within the firm to focus more on the bottom line rather than clients. Increasing micromanagement. Call center environment. There is a disconnect between decisions made from upper management and actual impact on associates/clients. 5 year graduated vesting for company match. MINIMUM 10% overtime during tax season to accommodate for inefficient/poor hiring schedule and practices.

headline: THEY DO NOT PROMOTE FROM WITHIN
pros: Benefits are satisfactory, pay could be more inline with the industry, vacation policy is ok but has not been updated for over 20 years.
cons: Massive attempt to eliminate older employees in the branch system, will not promote (especially if you are a woman) unless you are young and are a member of the so called "boys club".  If you are a young male you will be supported and promoted by management.  Managers will lie to HR to support this movement.  Fidelity is on the wrong track, this has not always been true, however, seems to be the direction they are taking in 2015. It boggles ones mind that a company the size of Fidelity would not find the best talent in the industry, instead of promoting mediocre sales people to manage branches, most of whom do not know the first thing about how to treat employees. I was one of those employees that worked harder than anyone else and was still treated badly, and after all the years I devoted to this company you still pushed me out. Shame on you Fidelity.

Decided to double the amount of people in my position in 2 months which is just reckless.  You are just another number to this company.  They do not value their employees or their clients.  The market manager told us to stop calling people in "our book" and only work with new clients.  Mandatory to have 18 appointments per week.  Leaves no time to respond to clients calls or put in any effort to plan for client appointments which is the most important part of Financial "PLANNING".

headline: If you want to be happy in the workplace, avoid this company

cons: Ok, where to start. Politics, rules this company, if for some minor reason they don't like you from the outset, you can forget about moving anywhere from your current role. Middle mgmt consistently talking badly about their employees. Pay is terrible, upward movement is slow and only to favorites, regardless of how good at the job you might be. The role itself didn't bother me as such, I knew what I signed up for (client services) its just all the BS that went with the role that finally got to me. Turnover rate was ridiculous, I started training in a class of 25, within 12mnths over half had left.  Oh and you will be micromanaged to the second.

headline: great benefits but job can burn you out.
pros: excellent training for series 7 and 63 exams, good retirement benefits with matching and professionally managed 401k.  Good training for financial representative role.   You will learn a lot about the industry.
cons: As a financial rep you are answering phone calls all day one after the next, for me it was enough to burn me out after a few months.  You get a lunch break and two short breaks in the day while the rest is answering calls.  Promotions just lead to other phone jobs for the most part.

Great people
Amazing opportunities for entry level
Developing skills
It is a great place to start a network and familiarize yourself in the financial industry
cons:

headline: Software Engineer
pros: Good Work Culture , Lot of new things to learn

headline: Its Blah!
pros: Good benefits, good salary and good work-life balance. Marketing roles are exciting since they play in a commodity industry that is highly competitive and undifferentiated.  Also Fidelity is not really about growth, it is one family's estate plan
cons: Politics. Many people have titles of VP Politics. People get moved around all depending on who they like and who they associate with.  Growth internally is quite limited, again depending on who likes you.

headline: Great company with pockets of terrible management.
pros:
Great benefits for employees. Salary+Bonus+Annual Profit Share+7% dollar-to-dollar 401k match.
Contractors treated well in most groups. (I have been contracting the last few years)
Durham NC location is pretty casual. Business casual dress with jeans on Friday. Relationships with management have always been casual side.
Some groups work with offshore resources and get to travel to other countries.
Some groups are in flexible work arrangement situations. Some people work from home much of the time. Even in other groups, you generally can work from home if needed for personal reasons from time to time.
cons:
Base salaries can be very low, especially when you get promoted to the next level.
Some groups work in crowded arrangements because leadership will not support any official work from home arrangements.
Lack of oversight on Directors and Vice Presidents with direct reports. A bad apple can really tear a department apart. 
Review process is not individual. People are stack ranked and there are quotas on high ratings. Even if you have 2 star performers, only 1 can receive the most excellent rating. The process is truly not individualized.
People provide reviews for employees they have had very little interaction with. Can get very personal.
You will have to change departments to earn more money as annual merit increases are often nominal.
Your career is in your hands here. You can not depend on any management or HR group to help guide you in advancing your career.

headline: Sr software engineer
pros: Company will gives lot of opportunites to grow your career and it's worth long term.
cons: Not worth it if you are looking for short term.

headline: Tech Con
pros:
Work life balance.
Open culture.
Moving to words technology driven company
cons:

UK driven.

headline: Manager

headline: Good people hamstrung by micro-managing senior management who won't make tough decisons
pros: Solid pay, decent work-life balance, excellent benefits. The people at Fidelity are smart, friendly and uniformly desire to do the right thing.
cons: Terrible disconnect between senior management and the people below them. Poltiical maneuvering among senior leaders is widespread, a result of C-level unwillingness to set direction clearly or resolve conflicts decisively. Company culture is consensus-driven - often from the bottom up in that individuals, groups and teams are left to work things out themselves - and when issues among teams arise that cannot be resolved below the SVP level, they remain unaddressed and left to fester until things get bad enough that someone senior HAS to step in, usually with more fallout than would have been necessary if the problem had been addressed earlier. There is a serious blind spot when it comes to recognizing the limits of consensus-building and the fact that leadership by directive is sometimes necessary.  Micro-managing is common, and far, far too much time is spent on producing presentations and reports.

headline: What you need to succeed - NOT
pros:
Competitive Pay
Some coworkers are great
Great benefits package offered
Great 401k match

Great potential for advancement
cons:
Fidelity - who is a recordkeeper for who knows how many companies 401k plans, has a 5 year cliff vesting schedule, and you're not even 20% vested in company contributions until 2 years.

The systems provided need a MAJOR overhaul.  There are procedural specific systems and client specific systems to use when handling calls.  These systems are not updated, so 1/2 the time you are under a constant worry if you are handling something incorrectly.  When cross trained on multiple products, you are not trained completely, so customers can ask questions you are supposed to be able to answer, but you can't because you don't know.  The answer is supposed to be searchable while you put the customer on hold to get the answer.  But holds can only be for 3 minutes, and it can take a lot longer than 3 minutes to find the answer because 1/2 the time when you search something the system comes back with no results. 

If a customer escalates, they don't go to your immediate manager, you're to call your "solutions desk and escalate the call" and that rep is supposed to handle the call from that point.  However the solutions desk reps are extremely lazy and will do anything and everything to push the call back on the tier 1 rep because they don't want to handle the call, thus causing the customers to become completely frustrated, yelling and screaming at us over why we are not transferring them to a supervisor, and then give us a bad customer survey.

If you need to enter a work item, they are shipped off shore to some reps in India to handle who have no idea what they are doing.  So they resolve the work item incorrectly, and we need to enter multiple work items for the same exact thing over and over.  We promise customers a 5 day work around timeframe and something so simple can take over 1 mo to resolve because the India reps just don't care.   The customers become very upset over how long it takes to resolve a simple error. 

While the company offers great potential for advancement, it is all in who you know, not what you know.  I had an interview for an internal transfer once, and while I was nervous as I didn't have a lot of interview experience at the time, my interviewer was constantly yawning and looking at his phone even before the interview started.  I don't think I was that boring, but that was extremely unprofessional and I can't believe he got the job he did because while I didn't get it, once trained I'm sure I would've been way more suited for the position. 

When you do need your manager and not a "solutions desk rep" they are nowhere to be found because they are always "in a meeting".  

This job creates a lot of extremely stressful situations, but when you become frustrated and voice your opinion, you're in the wrong and put under review or fired.  You can offer suggestions on how you think things should be and how to correct it, and management will pat you on the back for it, but then nothing is ever done to fix anything.

headline: A lot of travel, low pay, but great experience.
pros: You learn a ton about the clearing and custody business. You are one arm of the full implementation spectrum, but it allows you client facing opportunities as well as exposure to all levels of management and different departments. The experience, knowledge and exposure are the biggest advantages to this job
cons:
Travelling can be extensive. Each implementation is at least 1 - 2 weeks (including the weekends) and it's not uncommon to go from one to another. Some implementations are scheduled and promised by upper management to the client, for 10 - 12 weeks. There were many instances where employees would travel from a 2 week conversion to a 4 week conversion to another 4-6 week conversion back to back. 

I don't know if the pay grades were appropriate for this sort of commitment to the employees.

Even at the prestigious higher roles you are still only offering two cookie cutter solutions PAS (Portfolio Advisory Service) and Life Cycle Funds both of which have mediocre performance. As a Financial Solutions Rep we aren't even allowed to sell the product on performance. Why else would you hire someone to manage your money other than performance? The people that sell it don't even know what the performance is and its so hard to find you eventually give up. If you want to be paid a lot to be a robot selling mediocre products this a great place for you.

headline: Hard work
pros:
1) 10% year end profit sharing (added to 401K account) and 7% 401k match
2) Stability of company
3) "Always learning" mentality, constant weekly coaching meeting to ensure we are on top of the market
4) Good pay if you can perform well (only speaking for branch positions ie VP Financial Consultant / Financial Consultant)
5) If you are new to the field the Fidelity call centers is the perfect place to start. Fidelity will license you, train you, and help you find the right department/branch to work in. Fidelity is big in promoting internal candidates.
cons:
1) Increased stress. Due to Fidelity's business model to constantly bring in new business we are focused on bringing in new business all the time. I never take full lunch breaks and leaving at 5 PM makes me feel guilty. 
2) Hampster wheel. There is no means to the end.  Managing a $1B book ensures you may get $50 - $60k a year in "residuals/trails" at Fidelity while at a wirehouse a $1B book may generate $1MM + in residuals/trails
3) Long hours. If you are looking for an 8-5 job, working at the branch sales level isn't for you. Work/life balance is tough.

headline: Ehh
pros: Unbeatable benefits and great training as a new hire. They brainwash you into thinking this will be a lifelong career, but ultimately they want you to be a robot, triple your work load and give insulting merit raises. Don't stick around more than you need to. Learn the trade and move on to a company who appreciates your dedication and rewards and recognizes it.
cons: Management lives in Disneyland, management has no idea of day to day processes, even most lower level managers. No work life balance. Pay is stuck in 1995, they preach one thing but really expect another. It's a militant culture, and if you don't fake a smile every second of the day you will not succeed. Also, you are stack ranked against your peers. So, if the lowest score is you at 97.8 and the highest score is 97.9. You will receive a NEEDS IMPROVEMENT or INCONSISTENT PERFORMANCE. Seriously? Down to the decimal?

headline: Great place to coast by or finish your career ... otherwise avoid it!
pros:
- Good benefits plan and bonus packages, amazing 401k contributions/matches

- Large enough company to move around in and chart a career path

- Pockets of great situations (good leadership, interesting work, challenging opportunities)
cons:
- Those pockets of great situations are growing fewer and further between each day, the amount of influence one's boss can have on their career at Fidelity is astounding ... in 3 different jobs, I was rewarded (1) on par/average, (2) over-the-top with $$$ and shares and promotions, and (3) not at all .... my approach to the work didn't change in any of those jobs, so it shows that people of equal talent and skills could expect significantly different experiences at this company

 - Jobs are moving out of Boston, so local opportunities are few and far between ... those that pop up are usually pre-reserved for a hiring manager's friend (i.e. probably not the most qualified candidate), so the talent base is watering down, causing animosity, and those that want to advance their career in the Boston-area have to look elsewhere

- There is a layer of lifers at the Director / VP level that have settled into a comfort zone, earning high salaries from the days of raises/big bonuses (long gone), they are staying off the radar, and don't want to rock the boat ... so they are stifling innovation, they are roadblocks to progress, and they are blocking career opportunities for younger, talented, innovative staff members.

- Didn't get a raise in 3 years despite the company pulling in $2.2-2.4B in profit each year, was told it'd be made up to me in the form of a "higher bonus", but the bonuses were the same each year. The company manages the bonus %s, the share rewards #s, and the raise $$ in a way to keep people looking forward to something, but the overall pool of compensation rewards is shrinking every year.
