headline: Abusive Customers
pros: Excellent 401K match and profit sharing contribution.
cons: Senior management does not protect employees from abusive customers

headline: A company in Transition
pros: Excellent training and clear mission.  You can be innovative but you must indoctrinate yourself into their culture.  Its like a mom and pop shop of 50K people.  but it works at times
cons: You can get railroaded if you don't have 100% consensus.  People will appear to agree with you but they don't.  Theres much glad handing and intrigue

headline: Good to ms and my family
pros: Tons of opportunities to both move up and into new roles. Learning and development opportunities are expansive.
cons: Same as most large companies, layers of bureaucracy sometimes get in the way of productivity.

headline: Director - Business Mgmgt
pros: Long term investments.  Innovation is highly valued.
cons: Group to group & division to division, the culture can vary greatly - this can be a good or bad thing depending on the individual & type of variation.

headline: Overworked, underpaid, poor management
pros: There are some great people, remarkable resources.
cons: Departments are siloed, under-budgeted, too much work allocated to each employee without sufficient time.

headline: So far so good...
pros: Good technology exposure. Very fast to adopt new technologies
cons: Too much bureaucracy and politics

headline: Over worked under Paid
pros: Family oriented, smart co workers, great managers, great experience and lots of knowledge to be had if you want it.
cons: PAY SUCKS, will suck the life out of you, poor work/life balance, most teams are hard to deal with.

headline: Proud alum
pros: Fidelity is an evolving company with lots of opportunity for advancement. Excellent work life balance.  Excellent benefits.  Pay is good but more middle if the road compared to other companies
cons: Although advancement opportunities are good some areas are tough to advance in unless you are in Boston.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Professional environment committed to continuing education and knowledge. Family oriented with growth potential. Located all over the country so easy to stay with the company if you have to relocate
cons: If you are not in a sales role, salaries are average but not stellar

headline: Great
pros: Good people and  management  the atmosphere was family friendly.
cons: None to report at this time.

headline: Loved Every Minute I worked there!
pros: Great company, work hard and move up!
cons: Lots of meetings and processes change faster than you can get used to them!

headline: Good company in US, unprincipled and unstructured in India.
pros:
Company with great management and pedigree, but only in the USA.

Significant on-site opportunities for a valued employee in India.
cons:
Top Performers are not valued - appraisal rates vary drastically across verticals for the same performance rating.

Inept and lax HR group - I wasn't even given an exit interview upon leaving.

A very bad co. in India to start your career with - uncompetitive salaries (fresher salaries unchanged for 7+ years), no good onboarding program, chalta hai attitude-fresh recruits were kept on the bench for 15+ months with no HR assistance.

India office is full of management politicking with little opportunities that aren't gimmicks. 

Fidelity in US might be a great place to work, not so in India.

No synergy across Bangalore and Chennai India sites.

Fidelity India lies to Fidelity US (fact).

headline: Overworked but paid well
pros:
The pay is pretty good, I was in a call center. They paid for me to study and obtain my licenses. Training is really intensive, and want to make sure you know what you're doing when you start talking to clients. 
Management can be very supportive about helping you move up in the company.
cons: Management can also be very unsupportive to employees. There were some who were clearly not equiped to be managers. Nepotism is present. There is a big push on networking to get better jobs, instead of by merit. (but isn't that just corporate culture?)

headline: Senior Vice President
pros: Benefits are good compared to the industry.
cons: Too many to mention, very political and nepotism runs rampant.

headline: Vice President
pros: Strong work ethic, great colleagues, strong commitment to customer service excellence and for doing the right thing.  Great technology, great pay and benefits.
cons: There aren't many downsides unless your job gets relocated to a place you would never have dreamed of living or taking your family.

headline: Management
pros: Having experienced other financial services firms I can say that Fidelity is the best.  Smart people, great benefits and a noble cause in helping people with their money.
cons: can't think of any cons

headline: Intern
pros: Good company, good benefit, internal growth
cons: not much opportunity to growth

headline: Senior Investment Analyst
pros: Decent amount of autonomy, ability to take on extra work as interested, many smart people
cons: Typical cons of working for a big company... Bureaucracy, everything moves slowly

headline: Customer service
pros: Was a good company to work for until they became extra greedy

headline: Principal Software Engineer

cons: Hard core Agile methodology sometimes reaching absurd levels.

headline: associate

headline: financial representative

headline: Customer service

learn alot 
good people 
fast peace enironment

cons: 5 years to be 100% vested in 401K match is fairly strict compared to other employers.

headline: Sector Specialist Intern

headline: Financial Associate
pros: The people there are fantastic. I had a great time learning about this world.

headline: Team Lead

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Great learning experience & internal exposure.  Benefits such as tuition reimbursement are good for personal advancement.
cons: Very much a phone center; schedule flexibility is non-existent with low pay can be hard to deal with.

headline: Great people, long hours
pros: Benefits are fantastic.  Senior Management is very much behind the goal of being the most trusted name in retirement planning.
cons: Politics above a certain level can be difficult to navigate.

headline: A very good place to work and learn
pros:
1. Good culture
2. Good workplace culture
3. Policies are good
4. Personal-Professional life balance
5. Facilities & leanings
6. Transport system
cons: Nothing much as of now but certain areas where its need to be improved. Otherwise, its really a good company.

headline: MANAGER
pros: Excellent benefits ; On site cafeteria ; Free Coffe all day
cons: Nothing to share -- you have some good managers but the old ones are stuck on their ways.  No Vison at all

headline: Worst Company to work for
pros: Free Cab and Free Food
cons:
improper Management.
No Processes
Stuck with old people who have been working there for long time and don't know what is happening outside the company. Not aware of processes, technology.

headline: Great working environment, good IT infrastructure and great people
pros:
Current IT systems 
Great people to work with
Lovely offices in Hildenborough
Good training opportunities
cons:
Employees being held back from progression
Not great work life balance
Salaries not competitive

headline: Financial Associate
pros:
This is a company that cares and provides opportunity to show it.
1. Benefits
2. The pay is very good especially considering the work/life balance: I declined a job that paid 10k more, but fidelity pays overtime, where as the other job was gonna work me 55-65hours per week. NOT worth it. Fidelity provides a very good pay with the ability for those who want to work over-time to make more money.
3.Great opportunities for growth. They pay you to get your licenses, they have great tuition reimbursement benefits. If you are ambitious and want to grow, Fidelity is your place. I am already planning to get my licenses, an MBA, a masters in law, and move up in the next 6-7 years. 
4. A great culture with efficiency to its core.
5. Healthy lifestyle emphasis. They have the FIT food which means salads and healthy food is super cheap. How affordable? $2 for a salad vs $10 for hamburger. Yes, they want their employees to be healthy and thank goodness. They also have a recreation center and a health center.
6. Ability to get involved with community and company. They have great affinity groups for LGBT, AfricanAmerican/Hispanic, Women, and Veterans. They also have FidelityCares so it is great for people who enjoy social groups.
cons:
This is financial services and it is highly regulated, what does it mean, there are rules. LOTS OF RULES. But that is only a bad thing if you are one of those people that can't follow rules or can't follow order.

The rules are very simple: Don't be late. EVER. Not a minute. Why? Because it affects the entire company. This company handles big clients with big expectations. It handles other peoples retirements, which means their futures. Yes, there is a high level of commitment, but there is also a high level of opportunity.

headline: The job would be better, if I didn't have a terrible manager.
pros: full paid training, the tasks given, managing and helping the customers on the phone
cons: Management, terrible management, discrimination, hours, requests for overtime, unfairly treated

headline: Regional Brokerage Consultant

headline: Senior Software engineer

Work life balance
Benefits and work

headline: Financial Rep
pros: Overall, we had good benefits. Able to promote semi-often.
cons: Call center atmosphere. Metrics are ridiculously important.

headline: Not a bad start
pros: Nice People, Pay could be better
cons: Management can be obnoxius at times

headline: Technical Intern
pros: Working at Fidelity was great! The internship program was very structured and I received a lot of training and supervision from my manager. It was a great opportunity to learn, have a large share of responsibility, and understand the workings of a large company.
cons: The company is big so it can be difficult to make connections with people. However, I was able to meet many other interns and work closely with senior management.

headline: Genuine Fidelity Gurgaon Review IT Professional
pros: Major Pros: Free Cab and free food. Thats it!  Might be lenient towards female employees. Used to be a good firm 5 years back
cons:
Hi Folks,

This is an honest review from someone who is been working for 4 Years in this company Fidelity Gurgaon Unitech cyber park office.
Total experience is of 8 Years now.
I have seen this company on all its sections functioning in gurgaon. So i will comment on each dept individually. Myself been part of I.T Technology department, i have worked in development/maintenace and support roles in this company so knows in and out. This review is completely transparent and genuine.


I.T Technology Dept Review: 

1) Only if you join above "Tech spec/Project Lead" level i.e 10 plus years this company might be for you otherwise please go to any service based firm even if you are paid little less. The life below the 10 Years guy is a hazardous journey. The people at higher level are sitting for more than a decade,  they do not have any kind of skills ..be it technical/managerial. Pure office politics and not giving credits and demotivation from senior management. Knowledge sharing is not a concept here, only self learning and politics is the mantra.

2) The Support profiles in company L1/L2/L3 ,People in these roles are highly frustrated, There is no learning there are no knowledge sharing sessions between development and support team.The heads of two departments are often on rivalry which leads to suffering of employees only. They do not have work life balance, the shift allowance and oncall support allowance are worst than any other firm. Working in night shift entitles you to a mere 200 rs a day and being oncall for 24 hrs even on weekend from home entitles you to only 350 rs a day. 
The project once developed is made live and the support team is not made aware till the release day what they are going to support in production :):).

2) Zero onsite opportunity, and by chance if there is any(1 week/1 month) they make you travel on sunday night ..reach UK on monday morning directly to join office then dey make you fly back on friday evening after office...as they dont believe on spending even for 1 xtra day to employee....and per diem they give is 28 pounds. Which is lowest.

3) High disparity in salaries within peers. A mid level employee salary difference could be in 1-8 lacs, so you can imagine the disparity level as you go up.

4) Their promotion cycle is July? But the clever HR has declared minimum difference for next role change is 18 months. So that automatically comes to 2 years. And mgmt will obviously take 2 cycles as a concept to promote you so minimum 4 years of waiting for a promotion after "senior analyst programmer" which is for 5 plus years itself and ranges to 10 years.

5) Bonus potential. It is part of pkg only and based on rating it is reduced as well . So how they can call it bonus. Next is you have to wait for year end to get it, if you leave between, it is completely surrendered.

6) No HR in the company. There is high shortage of HR. There is no concept of HR meeting of whatsoever. The HR is not available in the company for anything you dont have any HR to discuss any grieviance you have. There is just payroll department. All the HR are contractual ppl passed from colleges..they are kids just for recruitng people, even talking to them feels ashamed of urself.

7) Company itself finding difficult to cut off the extremely highly paid people working in the company since beginning. These people are stuck to company like termites they have packages equivalent to what their team is getting and are not a value to company. So company is slowly trying to get rid of them and past 5 years there has been sacking of people at higher levels quietly.


Operations-Back Office Department Overview:

1) It is worst for Operations / back-office department people.  Long hours.Strict breaks of 60 mins, which are being checked via software which checks the login hours of employee on computer.If the time out is more than 1 hr then he is to be scolded.

2) Worst paid, over worked. Highly uneducated an unprofessional culture in Operations team. So 1 rating for that. Just for sake of getting a job and so called brand name ..you can join Fidelity in operations. It is worst then call centers.

headline: Good company with strong training.
pros: Fidelity is a great company with a lot to offer. The benefits are great and the compensation is fair. Fidelity does an excellent job training employees and helping new hires get licensed.
cons: Like any company, you have to work hard to be successful. Fidelity can have very demanding goals, but if you are motivated and believe in Fidelity’s process, you can have a very good career

headline: Financial Representative Full Trader
pros: Good people. Great Benefits. Great for someone who wants to start out in the financial industry.
cons: It is a position essentially in a call center.

headline: Used to be a good place to work.
pros: Get your licenses and leave.
cons: political environment.  Bullying and harassment is a management style.  Don't expect  integrity in HR.  Lack of diversity at management levels.  The most consistent complaint to HR is that the same people get the rewards and opportunities.  The definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result.  If any of above "rings true" then get whatever you can and leave.

headline: Great people, company with integrity, best benefits.
pros: Great 401k and profit sharing, lots of opportunity to learn and grow.
cons: high expectation to work overtime

headline: Fidelity Review
pros: Decent Comp, Great Facilities,
cons: Highly political, cronyism, process driven culture

headline: Company with a great mission
pros: Upward Mobility and competitive pay. Training program for the series 7 and 63 is fantastic. HMO benefits are amazing
cons: make sure you pass the series 7 or else you are let go.

headline: Director
pros: Good culture, pay and benefits
cons: Sometimes things take long time to implement

headline: A great place to work if you can stand projects moving very slowly
pros: Great benefits, competitive salary, lots of diversions in the way of talks by high profile outside speakers, art tours in the building, classes at the gym, etc.. etc.  Very nice and intelligent people work at this company and the majority are very committed to the firm.  In that way, it is truly refreshing.
cons: Projects move at a snail's pace.  A lot of politics three and four ticks down from the CEO.  If you like fast paced and challenging, this is not the place for you.  If you want to be more than just a small cog in a huge machine, this is not the place for you.  If you mind the ever-present feeling that Big Brother is watching everything you do (in and out of work), this is not the place for you.

headline: Not a team environment.
pros: Compensation is good and fair
cons: Ruthless environment for those who like to collaborate

headline: This company is great!
pros: While working here, my experience was great. LOTS of opportunities, great benefits and training. Till this day, I still use their services.
cons: There is no experience that I came across that can be labeled as a "Con".

headline: A stepping stone for those looking for a start in the investment  industry.
pros: Wellness based campus. 7% company match on 401K. Business casual dress code with some jeans days. Some good trainers.
cons: Micro-management. Push back when transferring calls to other departments. Limited technology. Low salary.

headline: Excellent ethical company for the industry
pros: Best people in the industry
cons: Lots of work in the industry

headline: Great training and supportive team, but job feels irrelevant to real future growth and you are in a true phone center
pros:
Great training
Supportive management
Available to get OT
Many diff schedules
401k, insurance, profit sharing 
Can move up quickly with decent customer service skills
cons:
Metrics
Feels like big brother is watching 
Micromanagement
Push sales in every role just called by a different name
Can move up, but only through a phone site. 
You will do one thing all day
20% OT requirement
Lower salary for industry

headline: Work Culture is changing rapidly
pros: Good total compensation (Base+Bonus+Profit Sharing (10% flat goes to 401k account)+7% $to$ 401K match+ Good Health Insurance). That's why the total comp otherwise the base may be lower than other companies. It helps if you are more than 5 years with the company.
cons: Work Culture is changing rapidly. It is not the company that it used to be, regularly laying off senior people with some or other excuses and hiring at the same time at lower level. Being a very big company, groups works in silos. So, some group may be worst than the other, specially if you are applying in SIPD group, careful. Very unstable.

headline: Great team, very supportive environment
pros: Supportive for personal development within the company
cons: Cannot think of any cons

headline: Benefits and people are great.  There are vast differences between business units.
pros:
Benefits are fantastic
Professional attitude in all they do.  Facilities are very nice.  Fidelity tries very hard to be a good employer.
cons: While one business unit is laying off and moving jobs offshore, another business unit in the same building is hiring (often from outside the firm).  THERE ARE NO RAISES.  Once you are hired, say goodbye to annual increases.  Cash pay is far below average.  They try to make it up with bonuses, but that can be hit or miss.

headline: Was a great working experience
pros:
Great working atmosphere
great use of skill & talent
opportunity to express new ideas
cons: work life balance due to work load

headline: Tremendous Company, Values Employees, plenty of advancement opportunity
pros: Leading edge technology, open door management policy, very forward thinking
cons: If don't want to move to Boston, still have plenty of opportunities, but options are limited.

headline: Strong successful employer
pros: I have been working at Fidelity for 6 years.  The company has great benefits and strong productive culture.
cons: Sometimes slow on promotions.  Hard to reach upper levels of management.

headline: Pretty good, great company, nice people, excellent health benefits, limited career opportunities in Utah
pros: Nice people, lots of training, prep for licensing exams. Large focus on customer service. HMO they provide one of the best there is for the price as a benefit.
cons: Really only customer service jobs and management positions in Utah in service or sales. Nothing that involves analysis. Moving to similiar positions at other sites possible but not completely different business units.

headline: Affected my confidence as a Developer
pros: Good Salary and benefits, flexible hours, really good graduate training, got thought good software development processes. Good corporate values.
cons: Politics, management who rewards and back slaps themselves, treated badly, this was my first job and my confidence as a developer after leaving this job was on the floor, more time spent going to and from meetings than doing development, little or no travel, favoritism, once key people get a bad opinion of you, you're put in a category of useless people

headline: Ok place to work, but not all its cracked up to be.
pros: They recruit you with the promise of quick promotion and fast track to a 6 figure income. Its as they promise - atleast in my previous roles. Fantastic 401k matching and PSP. Great benefits, great training. Overall pleasant company to start with if you're new in the industry or ready to retire
cons: Its a machine and you get treated like a replaceable cog. Heavy micromanagement to control output of product (ie what you say to clients) They're like the mcdonalds of financial services - you know what you get, whether good or bad. Working there you're forced to adopt their processes and procedures with exact scripts, very robotic - often times reminds me they want you to be a parrot (ie repeat what they say with greater enthusiasm, then they feed you a cracker like Iago from Aladdin). Management recruits you by promising you a book of business and that its like you running your own business but with fidelity's resources and support. Further from the truth. Once you're in, you always have to continue to generate revenue for the firm. This doesn't lend a good hand towards servicing your existing customers. Good pay, but its a hamster wheel. The moment you stop running, you get slapped.

headline: Been with Fidelity 10+ years
pros: Great People, and technology
cons:
Not much in management movement 
Cost cutting out of control, and temporary to make numbers, but spend doubles the following years
Promotions based on who you know
Too many politics 
No company to employee loyalty

headline: It's getting old now....
pros: Wonderful, friendly people to work with.
cons: Everyone is on an abbreviated salary schedule - hispanics and african-americans alike.  This is "old money." There is compulsory volunteering activities and people are kept in check by your typical caucasian female managers.  While I was there multiple members of minority groups left for higher paying jobs.   They will milk you for all your worth.

headline: GTE
pros: Its a great company to work for freshers, the work culture is very good
cons: Selection of team is left to the HR which is not good, initially candidates are not allowed to choose their team

headline: GREAT place to work, build a career and enjoy life!
pros: Benefits, growth, development, advancement, leadership, mentorship
cons: Salary, technology, remote work options for skilled employees

headline: Brokerage Operations Rep
pros: The ability to take care of their employees, always educating and providing networking opportunities. They would rather you change dept than leave the company. Work environment is friendly and great atmosphere to grow in career wise.
cons: The pay is not even close to what other firms pay in the same positions.  Sometimes there are too many people involved is processes.

headline: Ultimately satisfactory.
pros: Learned a lot.  Friendly helpful employees.
cons: Salary a little low for Jacksonvile

headline: Great company to work for
pros: The benefits can not be beat. Work life balance does exist and varies based on job and one's own commitment to having work/life balance.
cons: The company tends to be a bit behind the times as it relates to working remote and flexible work options.

headline: Good opportunity for career growth but watch out for RIFs.
pros: Compensation, 401(k), health insurance, bonuses
cons: The employee stack ranking policy

headline: Excellent firm with excellent benefits
pros: Great people and for the most part, a great environment.
cons:
Leadership is lacking in many areas and managers manage up (look out for themselves and not their reports).

Can be a muddling bureaucracy.

headline: Great place for a long career.
pros: Phenomenal benefits. Good potential to move upward (although if you're in a phone site it may work better to move to a branch in the boonies).
cons: I just couldn't handle spending my time knowing what someone should do, but having to sweetly guide them to it to not sound pushy.

headline: Typical Corporate America
pros: They have great benefits, paid time off, and great training to get licensed for the financial exams. Thy also have some 4 10-hour shifts you can work instead of 5 8-hour shifts.
cons: Moving up in the company is completely up to whether or not your manager likes you. Until you move up you're forced to work in service, at the bottom of the pole. You are also typically required to work weekend and nights starting out. Low pay compared to other financial companies. Only work here if you're ok with sitting at a desk answering phone calls all day.

headline: Highly Demanding, Mostly Rewarding
pros: Competitive pay, good benefits, many opportunities for advancement
cons: The micromanaging is wore than I experienced as a private in the Army. Pay is fair, but not great for the level of responsibility and the work volume. Time off is highly limited.

headline: Supportive, customer-focused company with a big-company feel and a lot of horizontal/vertical growth opportunity.
pros:
Benefits (health, tuition assistance @ 10k/year)
Compensation package (base + bonus (% depends on level) + profit sharing + shares awards + 7% 401(k) match)
Growth opportunities - big company
Very customer focused, feels like we're doing the right thing
In my department, great work/life balance
cons:
Bureaucratic and political, in almost every department
Multi-site strategy is a good thing, but most meetings are over the phone or spotty video conferencing; sometimes seems impersonal
Not every department treats/pays their employees well
Incredibly high amount of mid-level management

headline: Great
pros: Benefits. 401k. Culture and training
cons: lower starting pay for managers

headline: Fidelity Investments is not an environment for women who have families and involved in their children's lives.
pros: Good benefits (employee accounts, healthcare, vacation policy)
cons: Not much upward mobility for women and not very understanding when it comes to pregnant women in the workplace regardless of years of experience and capability/expertise. HR personnel does not work in favor of the employee. Very bureacratic environment.

headline: Amazing company that has amazing employees
pros: New facility, friendly people, amazing compensation and benefits
cons: there are no cons that i can think of

headline: Micromanagement reigns as employees are left to wither away
pros: They will hire you right out of college and pay you a decent salary with good benefits. The facilities are nice and some of your coworkers can be friendly. Training and L&D structure is quite good.
cons: Incompetent management who are only around to spy on employees every waking moment of the day. They drill you with metrics and are quick to point out the negative aspects of your performance while glossing over any positive aspects. For example, you could be leading your team in trade accuracy yet they will berate you for the fact you take a few extra seconds in between calls to wrap things up. Your metrics suffer if you have to use the restroom when you aren't on a break (often times you go a 3 or 3.5-hour stretch without one). Your schedule is outside of your control and offers no room for any leeway (I would always have break and lunch at different times every single day of the week). If you work on a schedule where you have to work on weekends there is almost zero chance of you ever getting a Saturday or Sunday off. Many of your coworkers and managers are rude, narcissistic egoists who will do anything to get ahead. There is almost no room for upward mobility if you start in the call center - something made very clear early on. It's just an endless line of phone jobs, finding a spot where you aren't working on the phone is exceedingly rare. Despite the fact that it does pay well, reps are still underpaid for the amount of work they must do. Full traders are almost always sitting in a position where there are 20+ calls holding all day for the entire 10 hour shift. Soul-crushing monotony with zero work/life balance, this job will inevitably make you wish you would get in a fatal car accident on the way in to work.

headline: Good company to work with
pros: Values drive, Respect Work Life Balance, Overall enjoyable experience and you get to learn too
cons: Things move at a bit slow pace, but ok

headline: Boring, non-challenging job
pros: Benefits (pension, bonus) are really excellent.  Training opportunities are good, advice would be to join the company, skill up on as much as you can (and you will have time to do it) then leave after a year.
cons: Where to start?  Ridiculous amount of people working on small projects that in any normal software house would take 3 weeks but take 3 months in fmr.  The Ireland offices are pretty much treated as an off-shore group, work is allocated from the US, but Ireland is not seen as an equal partner. You are expected to fill the time with coming up with "innovation" ideas, which basically means trying to convince the US partners to let you have more people ... exacerbating the first issue which is there's too many people and not enough work.  Also they have no clue what the function of a QA group in a SDLC is, and as far as career growth they expect testers to transition into "real" careers, i.e. management or automation developers.

headline: "Great company!"
pros: Smart people across the company, lots of very good career options, the benefits are great, and Fidelity has a stellar reputation.
cons: There can be high stress in certain parts of the company due to long work hours and there is also high turnover.

headline: Group's leadership is ruthless
pros: Compensation is generous. Time can be flexible. Benefits are outstanding. Negative culture is limited to my current group - however, it's a Con that the bad behavior is an open secret in the firm.
cons: Leadership is lacking. Fear is the current culture. Employees in my group are not valued. There is no credibility in reporting - negative messages are not accepted. Mobility is not encouraged or tolerated. Group leadership uses position and the necessity of partnering relationships with other groups to intimidate and manipulate outcomes.

headline: Good culture, great benefits
pros: Fidelity has a great benefits package and year end bonus based incentives.
cons: salary, slow employee development and growth.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Fidelity is truly committed to helping you develop your career. The office culture is one where professionalism and mutual respect are fostered. They truly practice what they preach and provide the tools for career and retirement savings success. It's up to you to use them.
cons: They still have some issues with breaking down silos, but they are actively seeking ways to break down the barriers between groups.

headline: Good company with great benefits. Limited upward mobility.
pros: Good benefits -- 401K Match, Profit Sharing ect.
cons: Limited upward mobility. Can become locked into particular group/role.

headline: Deceloper
pros: Good Company.Proper standards and good salary
cons: So many dependencies. Work culture is not good

headline: The sky is the limit, excellent opportunities to grow your career.
pros: Fidelity likes to hire the best of the best and it shows as you work on exciting and challenging projects.   The opportunities to collaborate and learn from really smart people is phenomenal.
cons: I don't really have any cons.  I have enjoyed my experience immensely at Fidelity,

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Fantastic company and a great place to learn, they have a generous benefit program paying for things like CFP , gym etc. This is dynamic place to work with a great culture
cons: Far too much politicking necessary to get promoted. The introverts that work hard rarely get a mention , Stingy in there raises. Inflation is 3% yet consistent dont give that

headline: Great company to work for.  Great benefits.
pros: benefits, profit sharing, privately owned family company, people don't generally leave there
cons: time off policies, overly conservative company

headline: Active Trader Services Representative
pros: Benefits are great - 401K match is 7%, and heath/dental insurance are top notch.  Great cafeterias in the offices.  Some of the nicest coworkers you could hope for.
cons:
Getting promoted from this department is next to impossible.  This used to be a 'desirable' destination, with the potential to advance one's career.  No more.  They care less about the front-line folks helping clients, and more about 'stats.'  Your breaks are timed/measured, the length of your calls is measured (long calls = baaaaaad,) and getting promoted outside of the department takes an act of congress.
Management, in general, is a bunch of glad-handing guys and gals.  You seldom see managers let go/demoted, even if they are consistently poor performers/coaches.  This leads to a lot of stagnation, and little room for advancement (unless my manager would take the initiative to seek a different role or retire, which hasn't happened in the 5+ years I have been there.)

headline: Overall positive experience and great place to start working fresh out of college.
pros: Great entry level company with solid training. Almost impossible to fail series 7 / 63 exams with all the help they provide.
cons: Inbound call center. The pay is low. Company knows what you are doing 24/7 with little to no freedom.

headline: Good training, taxing work environment
pros:
Lots of support to get your Series 7 & Series 63
Supportive management
Friendly people
Learned a lot about industry
Decent benefits
cons:
Company has no respect for your life outside of work
You are constantly urged to work overtime
Long hours on the phone leave your feeling burnt out
You are tethered to your desk at all times
Low pay

headline: Employed here 9 years.
pros: Great benefits and company culture.
cons: Not a lot of internal non-IT positions available.

headline: Company review
pros: Dedicated culture and highly skilled staff
cons: Difficulty to move to FO role

headline: Work
pros: Work life balance, good benefits
cons: Career advancement, management support

headline: Good leadership team.
pros: Compensation is good, and opportunity to learn about domain

headline: Good opportunities
pros: Great benefits, work life balance.
cons: Salaries aren't all that great.

headline: No opportunity to influence change in the Equity Trading systems group.
pros: location, bonus, shares, benefits, some intelligent peers
cons: In the tech group, there is very little (if any) opportunity to influence change. Decisions are made by architects and there is very little opportunity to have your voice heard.

headline: FI cares so much about customers, they forget to care about employees.
pros: 401k matching up to 7% of what you earned that year. Profit sharing, quarterly bonuses.
cons: They want you to work extreme amounts of overtime during the week, and they take away some of your off days. When the weather is very bad and causes unsafe road conditions, they still want you to come in instead of delaying opening, or closing for the day.

headline: Need better recruiters and training.
pros: Good hours, great pay, no working weekends.
cons: I was recruited strictly for my customer service skills.  I was concerned about metrics such as call times, call quota, and surveys and asked clear questions about these issues.  In the face to face interview, I was very mislead.  I was told the main focus was on customer satisfaction, and this was not true once I was on the floor.  Our training about the subject matter was excellent, but we received almost no training on the complex and multiple computer programs.  There was no hands on training of the system.  This lack of training on an absolutely vital part of the job is why I had to leave the company.  Also, many times we asked a manager or mentor a question, we were told something that was later disputed.  There was no consistency regarding information.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Boss was a great guy
cons: he digital world, the most important version of your bio is your LinkedIn summary. This will likely

cons: Lot of variability in your experience depending on who you report to.  Not very many opportunities to advance, but a lot of chances to move around.  Benefits are great but would be nicer to make more money instead.

IT is being pinched due to less than stellar product revenues and management is holding on to an overweight organization instead of streamlining and making things more efficient to deliver business value.

headline: Constant opportunity for development and growth for those who want it

Large, privately held firm with values that are reinforced at all levels of leadership. Career opportunities are ongoing and the vast majority of people at the firm will help you progress if you're willing to do the work.
Fidelity provides exceptional benefits with options based on personal needs and various family situations. While pay and bonus structures are sometimes criticized, being patient will pay off for those who are willing to wait.

Fidelity retail is open 24 hours, causing scheduling conflicts for some candidates
Career tracks within the firm can be limited due to licensing requirements, or lack of licensing flexibility in the groups

headline: Good place to settle.
pros:
Work-life balance.
Flex schedule for students.
Good benefits.
cons:
It's a call center.
No vision insurance, which is weird.
Unbelievably outdated phone system. Highly fragmented and poorly integrated software systems. You'll have to learn a dozen different systems to efficiently accommodate the variety of customer interaction types.
You'll work nights and weekends.
Coworkers are not very inspiring or motivated people. Most have given up on their dreams and settled for mind-numbingly dull work and mediocre pay.
It's almost impossible to get fired and there isn't much recognition or compensation for exceptional performers.

headline: Good company overall
pros: Great benefits, 401k, match, profit sharing.  Private company, run well, they have the fundamentals solved which most companies do not.  Fundamentals being defined as connectivity between work and cost, established quality control, right sized spans and layers, simple interfaces with the customer, etc
cons: A bit regressive in terms of future state.  Middle and upper management are complacent and lack current knowledge of corporate culture (want to manage like the good old days, more political in orientation versus meritocratic and performance based).  Need to focus more on problem solving than fire fighting.  Lack of proactive thinking and execution.  Over reliance on historical success and failure to recognize competition.

headline: Summer analyst Intern
pros: Great group of people and plenty of ways you can move up. Very beautiful office.
cons: No major cons for this company.

headline: Good company, good benefits, room for growth ... up to a certain point
pros: Great for young college grads to continuously learn, very good 401k match + profit sharing plan, lots of smart people doing very interesting work, for such a large company the tech is very good
cons: Management don't care about advancing your career once you've hit a certain salary grade, if too long in a position you are basically pigeon-holed, HR practices are there to defend the Firm not employees, politics get in the way of work and on-the-job happiness, despite a good line-up and impetus diversity & inclusion are not (really) a priority.

headline: Active Trader Services
pros: Cool Atmosphere. Nice Views. Bad Customers

headline: Good for young folks
pros: For experience starting out, the pay and benefits can't be beat.   The training provided is good, especially if you're on the phones and need licenses to perform your job.
cons: The company demands a lot from you, in terms of time and commitment.   It is also a very political environment, so if you don't march in step, your advancement opportunities can be limited.

headline: Flawed Employee Compensation Structure
pros: I worked at Fidelity for 6 years as a Client Service Manager in IWS. Overall, the job is challenging and rewarding but offers little flexibility in terms of how you structure your day. You have 30 minutes for lunch and be prepared for blackout periods for vacation during seasonally high volume periods (i.e. December and April). Regardless of the experience, credentials and skills you bring to the role, you will still be managed like a $10/hour customer service rep. In my experience, don't look to your manager to provide career and professional development, that is up to you. Lastly, depending on the level you are hired at (i.e. 25, 27, 29) you will not be eligible for the full, advertised bonus. This is the great unspoken fallacy of this position. Your time, effort and sacrifice will be rewarded by giving up a portion of your yearly bonus to subsidize the more tenured client managers on the team.
cons: Lack of flexibility, bonus "bell curve", adherence to high customer service levels at the expense of human capital, increasing micro management

headline: A good place to spend some prime years in your career; comp can plateau out in some cases, but generally a rewarding pla
pros: Many high quality professionals at lower and mi levels within the company,particularly on the technology side of the company.  Within the business leaders, the typical political class emerges and operates as such.  Internal communications is a priority for most of these executives.
cons: Overt focus on personal brand management and career advancement by the middle class.  As these executives are often paid well, they can be defensive and self serving due to the low likelihood comp can be replaced somewhere else.

You don't take your work home with you and also time and half anything worked over 40 hrs, no weekends.

headline: Great place to learn

headline: Principal Systems Analyst

headline: Fidelity might be a good place for you to work, depending on what's important to you...
pros: The total compensation is very generous. I worked there for 10 years, from 2001-2011 and every year we received 20% profit sharing bonus, even though the economy was terrible 2008-2010. Which means they were always profitable.  They are focused on on growing their asset share, and if you are good at sales, you will excel and be promoted often.
cons: The employees aren't the most friendly and helpful people, it is a culture of help yourself and you will do well. They are always focused on the bottom line of reaching their outrageous asset goals, at any cost, even lying to their clients. They change CEO's every four of five years which means you have to adapt to a new "vision" to drive sales.

headline: QA Engineer

Depending on the department and manager it can sway to very, very micro management environment. Favoritism, politics. Managers and Directors with zero people and management skills. When people die at their desk and leave or take time off for stress, that's a big problem they need to address.

headline: A relationship company that cares about employee development.
pros: There are very clear pathways to advancement.  Fidelity really seems to take care of its employees.  I heard when I first joined, and it seems to be true, that you can do your basic 9-5 and be fine.  No one bats an eye.  But if you go above and beyond, then you'll be rewarded with promotions & salary.  Pays well with sizeable end-of-year and 401k bonuses.  Benefits are good, 401k match is fantastic, as you would expect of a company that specializes in retirement plans.  The only people I've seen be let go by the company really deserved it.
cons: "Relationship company" means politics are everywhere, especially in middle management.  Every decision is made by committee, which while great for consensus forming means that every decision takes 10x as long as it needs to be.    Constant reorganizations.

headline: Worst company in 6 years career (FIMT, Manyata)
pros:
I joined this company reading the same reviews like most of them do in here but probably the biggest mistake of my career to have done except a few. And those few are the pros:

- Gurukool sessions
- Good quality work
- Good transport facilities
- Great marketing of own brand
- Good leave policy
cons:
After I quit the company, I realized how come there are so many good reviews about this company. Then I realised probably they're the ones who never had any work in the company during work-hrs

- no work-life balance, Managers will tell u upfront to work till 16 hrs a day and shout at you in front of everyone ( ask u to do development during day time and Prod support at night)
- improper performance review, biased and politically influenced
- Ethics helpline is just a gimmick, there is blatant favoritism etc
- HR is a puppet who are mere slaves of managers/directors
- BAD BAD COMPENSATION: Bonus is HEAVILY included in the CTC and they'll eat away all you own money
- They'll give a huge chunk like 50K as transportation which U wont get upto even a penny if u dont opt for (good for far flung commuters)
- NO TAX saving options in salary and U get MEAGRE take-home (the company earns keeping all ur money in their own FDs)
- Medical Benefits/Hospitalization is only upto 1 lac/a where in a part of premium is deducted from ur salary too (My current org gives upto 3 lacs covering even in laws paying complete premium)

headline: Excellent company overall
pros: Great atmosphere, no back-stabbing, everyone is very helpful.  Low-pressure environment because you are paid based on customer satisfaction rather than commission.  Good training program and lots of potential to move up in the company.
cons: Relatively low pay for this position, company tends to be a bit overly conservative, company is hemorrhaging 401k customers so overall, the customer base is shrinking.  Hold times can be atrocious.

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Great benefits (one of the best really!) the company trains you very well to get you licensed. This is a great place to start (but don't stay long)
cons: Fidelity is one of the lowest paying company in the financial industry. They start you at $38K. I have been offered $20K - $30K more doing the same for other companies. The quarterly bonus is a joke. If you are a decent rep you can max you bonus really fast. The company does not care if you have post graduate degrees--you will not advance for being better educated and prepared then the next guy. Also, the company has this weird mentality to promote women. If you are a woman and want to advance fast, apply here. Management will hire less qualified women over qualified men just because of their gender. I have seen friends who had 3 years experience or more apply for a job, and management will hire a girl who is still going through full trader training. If you are looking to get paid three times as much, get trained here and apply at Moran Stanley or eTrade. Fidelity does not seem to understand I cannot pay my mortgage with a class A medical insurance.

headline: Good Company
pros: Awesome benefits and pay for new associates
cons:
Political company
Very large corporation
Many business units

headline: Absolutely BEST Employer I have EVER worked for!!
pros: Superb management who are engaging and truly care about the future and current success of the employee. Very competitive compensation package including salary, bonus, profit sharing, retirement health funds, 401(k) match, education contribution match, fitness reimbursement, computer reimbursement, and MANY MANY more! Fidelity's health, dental, and life insurance offerings are PHENOMENAL!! Family type environment run by a family from the top down. Excellent opportunities to move globally and into other job types and businesses. Fidelity is a highly diversified corporation with abundant options. Depending upon the position, many teams offer flex-schedules, including working from home. Training is available in areas both inside and outside of the employee's current role enabling them to grow in areas they are interested in.
cons: Interviewing can be challenging depending upon the role you are applying for. Also, if you do not have work experience or financial industry experience, it may be difficult to get your foot in the door.

headline: Great Place
pros: Lots of opportunities for advancement, perks
cons: I would recommend higher salaries

headline: Great company, daily tasks can be repetitive
pros: Benefits, good work life balance, licensing paid for
cons: repetitive work,  daily tasks can be mundane

headline: Great company
pros: retirement benefits are amazing, including retirement health
cons: They don't really challenge the employees, other than some minor competitions

headline: A great place to start your career so that you can move on and take your experience elsewhere.
pros: Over my career at Fidelity I worked with some amazing people, had a lot of development opportunities and great benefits.  I left voluntarily with a strong professional network and tremendous experience, for which I am grateful.
cons: The culture of the company has really deteriorated - there have been many management changes and shifts in direction.  The benefits are still great, but I don't think the compensation is as competitive as it used to be.  This is a big company and you must learn to deal with a lot of bureaucracy in order to accomplish things - a person who succeeds at Fidelity is flexible, patient, smart, politically aware, knows when to give up, and can shift direction with little to no lead time.

headline: Poor Management
pros:
Good work-life balance if they aren't understaffed and requiring OT
Paid training
Easy to move up in certain sites
cons:
Poor management - There are far to many managers, doing far too little work. When call volume goes up the managers have less to do and can be seen watching youtube or congregating around a desk talking about their children. Their success depends on their teams metrics but the metrics are a crap shoot for the most part. Being promoted is all politics - its about who you know and how hard you can suck up. That may just be how the world works and I am just naive, but this is certainly not a meritocracy.

Metrics - It is understandable that a call center would have metrics, but even the best employees will miss them. They are arbitrary numbers that management places too much weight on.

Faceless Corporation - There is no room for personality, uniqueness, or creativity. Maybe a symptom of a highly regulated industry but feels more like the policies of a faceless corporation.

Monotonous - This is a call center. You take calls. All day. If you are seen taking a break out of schedule you will be told that what ever you are doing can wait till your scheduled break.

Pay - TIAA CREF offers the same position for better pay, more relaxed environment, and more reasonable metrics. They are snatching people from our offices left and right.

headline: Great culture, great benefits, okay pay.
pros: Great atmosphere and corporate culture.  Benefits and profit sharing are 2nd to none.  Best support in the industry for passing the series 7.
cons: The pay is just decent.  It is not as high as competitors.  Flow through to new positions can be quick at first but you quickly can hit a road block and movement will be limited.

headline: stable job
pros: workplace stability is assured fully
cons: people avoid conflicts creating challenges to result / goal oriented people

headline: Great palce to work!
pros: Great energy at the firm; sincere commitment to serve clients well; will commit the resources to make the required investments. Benefits and pay are competitive.
cons: Work life balance could be better.

headline: it was goood
pros: I enjoyed it pretty much
cons: i didn't like certain things

headline: Great culture
pros: Private ownership, long-term view, trusted brand
cons: Many levels slow decision-making, regulatory environment in FinServ

headline: A new challange every day
pros: Benefits, quick opportunity for advancement into other starting roles
cons: Call center. Hard to see real advancement past entry roles. Micomanaged to the minute of your day. Mandatory overtime during tax season.

headline: customer service associate
pros: building  career developing ideas team work
cons: salary promotions communication vacations salary reviews

headline: Fidelity Review
pros:
Beautiful Campus
Supportive Environment
Collaborative Environment
Solid benefits package
cons:
Somewhat bureaucratic
Opportunities are limited above senior leadership

headline: Nice Place to work
pros:
People are given importance and Ideas are listen to and if GOOD enough are backed by management.
People are help to grow personally and Learning is there
cons: No Cons Seen Just as pros the people are the core but sometimes there are too many people that some of them try taking advantage of it.

headline: Great compnay
pros: People are great and benefits
cons: Can't really think of any

headline: Financial Rep
pros: It is a very young culture because the company primarily targets individuals fresh out of college for the position. Additionally you are able to gain insight into the financial industry.
cons: Not a long term career path. The job itself is in a call center which limits the "career" to positions within a call center. Poor management of employees, and low pay in comparison to similar companies within the industry.

headline: String Company with Good work but less money
pros: Good work, salary is ok but not comparable with competitors
cons: Too much politics; slow moving company

headline: Non technical management
pros:
Good benefits
The people you work with are really nice
Lots of locations if you want to move around and travel
cons:
Management are non technical.
The software delivery process is costly and very poorly run.
There is no freedom in technology selection or career direction.
The people who do the work are rarely rewarded.
Promotions are given almost exclusively to people in management positions.

headline: Big Brother
pros: excellent 401K matching - 9%
cons: I was discharged after 3 weeks of employment because, as the Company told me, I had too much consumer debt (an auto loan and student loans).  This had nothing to do with my performance and was none of their concern but you have to sign a release to work there.  Creepy employer!

headline: Salary based investment advising
pros: A lot of jobs available.
cons:
Managers pick and choose what they want monitored based on what they are compensated or advanced by. 
Poor team meetings. Competitive environment but people are hired strictly on power rank and there is not monitoring for manipulating or cheating because it makes the managers look good also.

headline: Let Fidelity pay for your Series Licensing!
pros: Fidelity paid for my licensing
cons: If you have legitimate health issues and must use FMLA, you may as well start your job search now. Don't affect your manager's bottom line or he'll find a way to fire you.

headline: They do not value industry exp. or knowledge. A private company that is run more like a public one.
pros: Some locations offer free parking. Casual dress and jeans on Friday. Not much more to say than that.
cons: They don't provide formal reviews or offer development. You need to start there right out of school in order to succeed. Value isn't what you know about the industry but how to figure workarounds for their convoluted systems. Not a lot of opportunity for those coming from the outside.

headline: A very valuable experience that was impacted significantly by the tremendous employees that work at Fidelity Investments
pros: Very strong training program for interns that allows them to be exposed to various different business units. Fidelity treats their interns tremendously well in order to motivate them to want to return to the company following college.
cons: Very little to complain about the company, but some days would feel a little sit slow as some of the full time employees would be traveling during the summer for vacation.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Very positive and transparent culture
Great pay and benefits
Great work environment and amenities
cons:
Experience can be very different between different departments or business units
Due to groups being geographically dispersed, it can be difficult to remain "in the loop"

headline: analyst
pros: challenge but rewarding, fast pace working environment.  Great benefit.  Great opportunity within the firm.
cons: no work life balance. Demanding boss and not a lot of guidance as to how to proceed with the projects you are assigned.  I would prefer more guidance in the initial stage of projects to eliminate the possibility of redoing a great deal of projects

headline: Fidelity is a great private company that has excellent benefits with a fantastic retirement plan.
pros: The people are great to work with and have a good team atmosphere.  The facilities are great in Westlake and it is a good location.
cons: The internal politics are frustrating and it is difficult to make major changes due to the complexity of being a large company.

headline: Enjoyed working here, great benefits
pros: Excellent benefits, good values.  The campus in Westlake is awesome, although you have to walk a long way from the parking lot to the building.
cons: Promotions are hard to come by, their salary and bonuses are much lower than they used to be.  This is an entry level company.

headline: Awesome company with awesome policies
pros: Good work culture. liberty with work timings and pay
cons: nothing as such and all is well!!

headline: Financial Representative Full Trader
pros: The initial training in attaining your 7 and 63 is unbeatable. The support system is great, they don't just hand you the books and tell you to go study, they stay with you throughout the process to ensure you get licensed. Theres an initial self study period followed by a class that, if you put the work in, will thoroughly prepare you for the exams.
cons: The training thereafter in becoming a trader is incomparable. What apparently used to be a year and a half long process has been condensed into two months. They have a system of call overflow that results in inexperienced traders engaging with clients coded as private client group looking to do multi-leg options trades that their traders are not at all prepared for.

headline: Good so far
pros:
1. Very Good work life balance,
2. Pretty Decent salary.
3. Focus on innovation.
4. No compromise in the company ethics and values.
cons:
1. Very poor employee engagement activities/fun activities.
2. US employees always get preferential treatment over India employees.
3. Very poor personal growth rate.

headline: Great company to learn!!
pros: Work culture is awesome :)
cons: No good hikes and no encouragement for jr developers

headline: Worst management I've ever seen
pros: Benefits are great. Many good on-site facilities.
cons: Management does not care about employees at all. They expect too much and always think that you are not meeting the goals which are never clearly defined.

headline: Distribution Executive
pros: Quality products, strong corporate values, excellent benefits, private ownership, long-term perspective, generally nice people
cons: Heavy competition for more senior roles, investment management organization overly dominates decision making, long-time executives spoiled by past success, slow to make decisions, too many reorg's

headline: A Great Place to Start
pros:
Series 7 & 63 are paid for and the training program is excellent, they are paying a lot of money to license you and really want you to pass.
There are multiple shifts available to you which you bid for, and most people receive their first choice in shifts.
Amazing, supportive co-workers.
The best technology I have used in the Finance industry.
401(k) matching is among the best in the industry, but annual salary is not competitive.
Good work/life balance.
Team outings each quarter.
cons:
The call volume is ridiculous, and you spend most of your time resetting passwords, even once you are on the full-trader gate.
Fidelity talks a lot about career development, but team meetings and one-on-one coaching sessions with your manager are constantly canceled due to call volume.  A manager cannot develop his/her employees without ever speaking with them.
Even when you are promoted you do not get a raise, you get an increase in variable comp, and that is determined by whether you hit your metrics.  You can get a "promotion" without ever getting a "raise".
Management is hit-or-miss.  I worked for a couple of amazing, hands-on managers who were very engaged with their teams. I also worked for a few managers that appeared to do nothing other than sit around and play games on their phones all day.
A lot of push-back from different departments when you try to transfer calls.
Metrics are constantly changing.  What is important one quarter may be meaningless the next quarter.  It makes it very difficult to try to establish a routine on your calls when you don't know what measurements your bonus will be based on.
This is a call center job.  Don't try to kid yourself, you will be on the phones 8 hrs/day.  Unless you get a position in a branch, you will be on the phones, even if you are "promoted" to another role.

headline: Above average pay, but responsibility is minimal, positions are dead ends, and leadership is poor.
pros: Cushy job, above average paying role.  Occasional travel to conferences once you have experience.  Abundance of opportunity to learn if you apply yourself.  A good job out of college for a few years and then it's best to move on.
cons: This particular position is a dead end, but management may lead you to believe your responsibility will improve or that you are doing work that is important.  The work is simply making charts and analyzing numbers in Excel, which others will use to make decisions and this gets boring quickly.  The people you will work for can be high strung and passive aggressive, so they will ask you to do something and then hover over you until it is done, or they will be short with you and then friendly later on to make up for their initial rudeness.  Few of them have the time to teach you, so be prepared to learn on your own.  The corporate culture is poor because the main hires are highly intellectual people from top universities who typically have limited social ability.  People in my department went through the day with little social interaction and when they did interact it was forced and awkward.  The managers are better socially, but they don't know how to lead people because their prior roles were individualistic assignments.  Those assignments didn't allow for the opportunity to hone people management or leadership skills.  Instead of rolling up their sleeves and making the occasional tough call, managers sometimes pay people lip service and kick the can down the road.  Management's personnel decisions come slowly or not at all for fear that those decisions won't work out and it will reflect poorly on them.  Upper level executives are slow to make any drastic or necessary operating and strategic decisions, which are required in this rapidly changing industry.  The company is strategically behind the 8 ball as a result.  People usually stick around for so long because it pays well and people sort of muddle through New England life at this company.

headline: QA Engineer
pros:
Benefits , Job Security, 
Learning
Technology
free Cab :)
cons:
Salary is less
Few managers decide everything on appraisal

headline: Great company to start in
pros: Benefits are pretty amazing, 7% match dollar for dollar and 10% profit sharing as well.  great options for health insurance as well.  Training is also pretty good and you get a great opportunity to learn the industry.
cons: Depending on your role you could get stuck there for a while if there are no other job openings.  It's also pretty hard to move throughout different business units, so once you're in a certain business unit you're pretty much stuck there.  There's not a clear understanding of what other business units and do and what jobs are available there and how they pay.

headline: Great Company
pros: Fidelity has alot of benefits. They have great 401k match! They care about there employees.
cons: The pay is crappy. Not enough off phone roles in Jacksonville

headline: My experience at Fidelity has been an enriching one, full of learning and self development.
pros: Good working environment, A great place to learn, Company Cares about the employees, Safe place to be during bad times, Flexibility
cons: Growth opportunities are limited, Top heavy, Slow to change

headline: Great working culture. Nice people
pros: Dynamic environment, Established processes, work life balance, social commitment
cons: Lot of small groups, takes lot of coordination

headline: Tier 1 Customer Service
pros: It was a great company to work for, lots of opportunity to move up. Great leaders/managerial support.
cons: There is a bit of politics between some supervisors when trying to move up. I was hired on a contact with the likelihood of becoming full-time. The decision was left to supervisors, some supervisors have only worked with some for only weeks.

headline: Great career jobs with layers of bureaucracy
pros: On-boarding process has plenty of Kool-aid to drink (aka. "we're amazing and nothing wrong") that gets you excited for your new job, Plenty of movement during certain periods of the business cycle, lots of cross training, great retirement benefits and health plans, investment in employees, pay is great, clean, bright work environment.  Perfect for a long term career employer.
cons: Leadership is sub-par, upper management is extremely disconnected with the front line representatives and doesn't enable mid management, lots of politics, office culture seems inauthentic, very low flexibility on work schedule, forecasting always off, talk about providing best customer service in industry yet not providing tools or hiring sufficient staff, extremely restrictive of employee trading (no "bearish" positions, very hard to qualify for upper level options trading) due to policy not regulation, few rewards for service reps - mostly available in sales.  Very hard to effect any real change.

headline: Working at Fidelity is just like high school.  High turnover rate
pros:
Benefits are slightly above average, just as good as all other big companies.
They will hire anyone.
Good Training
Fidelity is a great place for a customer, great products, customer first culture is awesome.
cons:
The office politics are really bad
Very high turnover rate, highest in the industry
the computer technology is all over the place
Fidelity cares way too much about email Surveys.
Not much promotion from within
The promotions are like little baby steps and often never include a pay increase

headline: It was fun for the most part. A good place to start your career.
pros: People are generally really nice.
cons: Promotions are hard to come by once you are a senior developer

headline: Strong, well funded company
pros:
Private company who is not making decisions based on the fluctuation of their stock
Amazing benefits
Great funding for product development
People and potential
Great facilities (environment, art, landscaping)
cons:
Incredibly political environment
Change is a buzzword
Too many people who avoid decision-making and play the "I told you so" game
Risk averse
Entrenched product silos create friction and can dilute the potential for new offerings

headline: Moving in the wrong direction as they try to capture more of the DC and pension of the retiring baby boomers.
pros: Great Benefits. Client surveys are extremely important, almost too important. Company is strongly client focused and looks out for the clients at most levels. Walking a fine line between companies best interest and clients best interest as of late.
cons:
Lots of shuffling around, but little advancement. I see the same co-workers and management moving around, but little advancement, even at the VP level. Managers are chosen by metrics and "Personal Brand" which is simply hear-say. Advancement is limited to very specific paths. It's rare to see someone move outside of these paths. 
So many managers with so little formal education in management or prior experience. Stunned at lower level management incompetence, although they are powerless to promote change as upper management directives and metrics are etched in stone and beyond reproach as the higher level VP's strive to hit their own metrics at the expense of their departments well being. No happy work balance here. Voluntary/mandatory overtime is the norm, as the company is completely understaffed on the front lines. Do not give your opinion if asked, it can and will be used against your for the rest of your career and becomes part of your "Personal Brand". Better to just enthusiastically agree to whatever one of the many changing priorities for the month, smile and give your whole hearted support.

headline: It was a good experience!
pros: Its really cool as a starter. But after 4 months it is enough. But learn a lot
cons: Its cool to work in a big team with nice people. U learn a lot and u getting better and better!

headline: Great benefits and peers, poor judgement when selecting managers.
pros: Great retirement benefits, above average insurance, and generous when it comes to professional training. Very customer focused, which is a pro if you are a customer/client.
cons: My manager loves to over coach you to the point you feel as though you are incompetent. There are others that do the same. This is part of the coddling Fidelity does to their clients. If you are in a service role in a phone site you will be expected to place trades that fall into the complicated and varied internal rules that often defy logic. If a client wants to place a trade and you place it without questioning the client on why and how they are wanting to place it, you will be scrutinized. Fidelity's internal trading and distribution rules imply that all of their clients are idiots and we must save them from themselves. If you miss the opportunity to save the client from their own actions you will be charged an error. They will tell you how easy it is to exceed the quarterly bonus and get a full payout, but it is far from the truth. You have to trade error free, have efficient calls, meet sales lead goals, and have positive client surveys. The entire team has to meet their goals in order to maximize payout. Without significant experience most error free traders don't have efficient calls, because they are spending ten minutes a trade to make sure one of the silly rules isn't being violated. If you receive good surveys then your probably not meeting your lead goals, because despite the belief, not every client wants to be probed for opportunities. I am currently seeking a non-phone based finance job elsewhere.

headline: Fantastic experience working a Fidelity investments
pros: Visionary leadership, unlimited opportunities for those who work hard, excellent training programs, personal and professional growth is unparalleled.
cons: There are no cons, it's a wonderful place to work

headline: reputable company to work for and good overall financial philosphpy
pros:
lots of opportunities
brand recognition
great benefits (401k match, profit share)
cons:
highly metricized
larger organizations sometimes loose focus of their people and become too numbers driven

headline: Good Private Firm
pros: Profit Sharing, Health & Dental Insurance (prices have gone up a bit though), Tuition & Fitness Reimbursements, Decent Pay with good performance increases.
cons:
Can be long hours depending on your role, group, etc.  They'll try to focus on work/life balance but its never what an individual expects especially those who are salaried. If you're hourly though, then one could benefit with OT pay.

Perceived job promotions, movement, reorganizations are more lateral movements.

headline: Decent compensation but all advancement is purely political.
pros: Compensation is comparable to other large financial services companies.  Benefits used to be among the best in the industry but that has fallen in recent years.
cons:
In my department advancement, whether in the form of formal promotions or stretch assignments, go only to those with contacts at higher levels.  Midlevel managers routinely tell subordinates that they believe the subordinates deserve advancement but that none is available unless the subordinate can figure out a way for senior managers to take notice.  Senior managers don't believe this is a problem because they see promotions going to the people they know are good.  They are oblivious to how many good people work there that they don't know.  That is because people rise to the top at Fidelity by managing up, not managing down.

There are two types of senior managers.  One is the Fidelity Lifer who understands how to play the game.  Don't try to change anything, don't take any chances, figure out how to not get your finger prints on anything that might fail and know that after 20 years you can retire extremely wealthy.  The other is the short timer who comes in from another company expecting to get things done.  They take chances, they get involved in new projects that take the company in new directions and they are the first to be blamed when things fail.  These people rarely last long.

headline: They just don't care
pros: It was a good place to start and get licensed.  Strong family owned company.
cons: Middle management is terrible. Power hungry and will step on anyone to get to the next level. Watch your back and be careful who you trust.

headline: Great benefits package
pros: Profit sharing payouts are great and year-end bonus is nice. Fidelity provides matching 401(k) contributions too.
cons: Average pay for this industry. But when you take into account their total benefits package, Fidelity is above average. Talented people are not properly recognized for their contributions. As with most companies, the most popular people get promoted before the most qualified people.

headline: Great place to work
pros: People are super professional and willing to share knowledge. Great teamwork environment.
cons: Commuting into Boston is not easy for me but that's just part of living outside of the city.

headline: Not Horrible- Not Great
pros: They pay for your 7 and 63 right off the bat. Young corporate culture, lots of room for growth
cons: Room for growth limited to positions in the call center. They will talk about other areas career-wise but those positions are extremely rare and very taboo to get into i.e. Branch, research, rotational programs, marketing etc. Hard time retaining talent because of pay scale and willingness to pay external hires much more than the people they hire in initially. Entry-level service managers come off arrogant and micro manage to the point the job is unbearable. Boast about retirement benefits when in reality you do not see profit sharing nor match for the first full year and none of it vests immediately after that. Job itself incredibly repetitive and not empowering for someone with a college degree.

headline: It was ok. Good place to do time but better place to leave.
pros: Paid well. Very good benefits. Top of the industry so good learning opps and street cred.
cons: Limited creative thinking and ability to make a difference. Claim they want to be high tech leaders but wait for leadership to tell them what to do.

headline: Good place to start, but do not stay here for long.
pros: You have the potential to learn a lot about the business very quickly
cons: There is almost no upward job mobility, and the pay is very low for the industry. There is also a complete lack of job security.

headline: Used to be good place
pros: Great benefits and work culture .
cons: Too much Bureaucracy and Process which is killing work life balance.

headline: Senior Technical Project Manager
pros: A great company and with very competitive salary.  A very good benefit structure.  High percentage 401k match.  Very family oriented.
cons: A lot of bureaucratic red tape.  Different organization structures.  It was difficult to get new ideas or processes moving as many are very set in their ways

headline: Very good, but could be great with some improvements.
pros:
Private ownership and long term investment.  
Strong corporate values that are mostly lived up to
Fantastic benefits for those that want to make this a life-long career
Broad businesses to move to many different areas.
cons:
Very large size = very large bureaucracy
Too many leaders with golden parachute of great benefits - should leave but never will and hang on too long.  As a result don't aggressively drive change (go with flow is dominant and safest choice that too many make.
Less meritocracy more, play safe and conservative and survive.  Hierarchy more important than ideas.

headline: If looking for a "career" look elsewhere
pros: Good work/life balance, most of the people were very nice want to see you succeed. I think my experience was a problem at the branch I worked in rather than the whole company.
cons: Terribly run office, clear training structure not in place, letting one nasty angry employee affect the culture of the whole branch. Management did not have an effective way to deal with a problem employee. I was hired with all my licenses and 4 years of experience into the financial rep role to eventually move into a sales role (after 9 mos to a year). After 3 months I had been repeatedly told by management that I was not filling the role "effectively". I received almost no training and was expected to not make a mistake. The job is not hard but being "written up" and receiving "warnings" for every mistake caused a lot of issues.
