cons: It can sometimes be frustrating working for a very large private company

headline: Overall good company to work for.  Great benefits.
pros: Great benefits. Good company values, very customer first driven. I enjoyed my co-workers, very professional.
cons:
No work/life balance, especially in sales. You're required to pull in the same level of sales when you're out on vacation. Unfortunately, you feel stressed going on vacation and/or when you come back. 
Promotion is based on who you know, somehow the hiring manager forgets what you're past accomplishments are.

headline: A great organization
pros:
Work Life Balance
Respect for each other
cons:
Too many org changes
Depends on each leader

headline: Fidelity Account Executive
pros: private company customer focus, most employees try work for the client and not the firm.
cons: slaes driven, wrong manager can ruin a good thing.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Great work life balance 
wonderful work life balance 
lot of focus on people
cons: Slow on execution and decision making

headline: Highly Political, Layoffs Often, No Job Security
pros:
Very good competitive compensation and benefits package.
Interesting and challenging work.
Reasonable work demands in most departments.
cons: Fidelity is highly political.  Basically no matter how high the quality of your work is, if you are not "liked" especially by your direct manager you will not be around for long.  Department and company reorganizations are often and many.  It is during these times you risk falling out of favor and run the risk of frequent job eliminations. Once you are out of the company due to a layoff or job elimination you are pretty much out forever - unless you have a contact manager that will hire you. There is no job security no matter your position or length of employment.  Fidelity will never win any best places to work awards but the they pay well.  If you are looking to be loved, respected, or for a friend - buy a dog.

headline: “Best place I have ever worked”
pros: “The culture is amazing. They will work hard to find you something to work on that fits your passions and lets you make a huge impact. No corporate BS. Great people.Amazing work culture, you never see it as a work place”
cons: “Not really a con but a tradeoff for moving fast: lack of documentation”

headline: Working at Fidelity
pros: Great culture, easy and comfortable atmosphere. Currently fast flow through to higher positions.
cons: Lower than average pay for similar positions elsewhere.

headline: Learned a lot, hate being on the phones.
pros: You get to learn about a lot of the rules in the industry. Pretty good training, and very extensive. They have flexible schedules and working 4 days a week at 10 hours a day is a perk.
cons: Phone center with nearly no time to breathe between calls. Can get pretty tedious towards the end of a 10 hour shift.

headline: Good People, Great company, Learning experience . good employer great benefits great 401k matching for great future.
pros: Work in the heart of financial district. you get to learn a lot of financial knowledge and expand your horizon.
cons: same work goes around. Slow scope to grow.

headline: Good at first,  then downhill from there
pros: I will say that the Series 7 training that they provide is excellent.  Ok for a year, if it's your first job out of college.
cons: Upper management does a great cheer-leading bit but the real world is quite different. Every move you make is recorded and monitored, if you make a rookie mistake they make you feel terrible,  very little praise without a "but". Lot's of nitpicking criticism.  You have no time to socialize because every minute is accounted for.   The work itself is ok but quite a grind when you average 50 calls a day with only 2 15 min. breaks.   Grueling for little pay.

headline: Great benefits
pros: Best benefits out there bar none.  Great company to work for if you have a good manager (as is with most companies). Career advancement can be difficult in some locations so might have to be willing to move to advance. Overall great place to work.
cons: CAreer advancement can be difficult unless you are willing to relocate.

headline: Fidelity business services: not a good place for technical guys
pros:
Benefits
Less work(work life balance is good)
cons:
If you are a technical guy never join Fidelity Business Services which is in EGL. You have to work under managers who doesn't have any technical background, they will screw you to death. Especially do not join 'WI-Business Performing Reporting' which is full of a**-licking mangers who are simply surviving with out any knowledge on process or on technology. They don't understand your problems, they are like blind-bulls. 
Inter process movement with out any prior notice.
Managers do not give respect to your thoughts and ideas.

headline: Great company, great morals, great benefits
pros: we do not push product, we actually help people reach their goals based on their needs.
cons: not as competitive pay, but a more stable less pushy environment than other similar companies

headline: extremely bureaucratic
pros: Excellent work-life balance. The people are very laid back and everything moves at a leisurely pace.
cons: the management is very bureaucratic. There is a culture of being nice and merit is not really valued. the company just looks at the time spent and not the value added.

headline: Great and efficient company. Very pleased so far.
pros: Tremendous brand-name industry recognition. Even though it's a large Co with a lot of layers of management it's actually very nimble and efficient when it comes to finding solutions for clients' needs and that keeps clients and customers satisfied.  The company spends a lot of $$ on innovation and technology and it's refreshing to see how it keeps clients' needs above everything else. Client is #1.  Benefits are great: 7% co match in 401k (dollar for dollar) and also a 10% Profit Sharing (on average) after 1 year of service. HSA contributions, plus incentive performance awards are above industry average. The culture is very conservative but they do respect all people no matter the associate's  sexual or religious background. Last but not least, the company is very committed to integrity and compliance standards so it stays out of negative headlines and it's extremely well run.  It's been a great place for me to work here and I'm very pleased to be part of this organization.
cons: Very large company so it's hard sometimes to get a lot of visibility and may feel lost without proper mentoring.

headline: Systems Analyst
pros: Great company with good culture. Good retirement benefits. Team collaboration is great that    provides good learning opportunities for the employees. Company has a great reputation and is growing very fast.
cons: The biggest challenge is the career growth. If you don't join at the right level, then you will struggle for a long time before making your way up. You may find several growth opportunities within the company but you can't negotiate even if you are well qualified for the position.

headline: Great company but do not see myself here in the future
pros: Benefits: 401k, IRA-Roth, learn A LOT of how to effectively manage your money (don't even have to be an advisor to learn strategies--it just becomes innate after the frequent conversations and projects one participates in), Corporate Perks/Discounts, Corporate Amex (if applicable),
cons:
If your passion/interest isn't in financial industry, this career quickly becomes a job.
Corporate bureaucracy-- everyone seems to hate their job but will quickly act like they love it when asked -_-
Tuition Reimbursement- Continue education 90% reimbursement up to 10,000...seriously what "good" graduate school, B-School , etc has a tuition of $10,000/year...none

headline: Great Learning Experience
pros: Education of Financial Industry and Products.
cons: Call center.....sit at desk all day taking phone calls with little to no time between calls. Extreme micro-management.

headline: you're still a phone rep/clone
pros: Good benefits, decent salary. Good training.
cons: No matter how you slice it, you are working in a CALL CENTER. This means you will be micromanaged, treated like a child, and forced to work overtime because the firm refuses to staff properly during tax season. You can choose the flavor of calls you want (i.e. trading, advisory, service, retirements) but at the end of the day its still just about AHT, ACW, and the same old call center crap.

headline: Investment Representative
pros: Overtime, Healthcare, Profit Sharing, Compensation
cons: Cold as ice management - lots of undue stress

headline: a once great place to work
pros: Strong benefits packages, many smart people, top technology,.   You will be challenged.  Lots of exposure to a variety of issues in financial services
cons: Ever since the economic meltdown, coupled with mediocre investment performance, and significant competitive pressures, Fidelity has turned into a place where most people are constantly looking over their shoulder for the next RIF, or move to another locale.  A lot of management by fear which eliminates any real risk-taking by employees.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Great long term benefits, collegiate environment, good work, company really cares for customer. The firm is in a very unique and strong position in the financial services industry
cons: Average compensation (and very slow growth), slow vesting schedule for profit share/contribution matches, bureaucracy

headline: Phone Center Trader
pros: Probably the best training I've ever been through. I was hired on w/o my securities licenses and spent the first few months of work studying and in the classroom learning the Fidelity systems/culture/etc. (white getting paid). They hire great people, so everyone you work with knows their stuff and is enjoyable to be around. The company is extremely generous (10% of salary profit sharing bonus every year, fantastic benefits - I even got a $100 xmas bonus 2 mos. after being hired). If you're looking to get into the securities business this is a great place to get your licenses and cut your teeth.
cons: This is a phone center job. Your schedule is 100% set for you, down to the 15 min breaks before and after lunch, which is understandable, your job is to answer the phones. Most of the day you're not placing trades for customers but doing some sort of account maintenance (pw resets, IRA distributions, sending them forms, etc.). Everything is tracked and monitored (again, understandable, just be aware before you take the job). After training when you're on the phones all day you don't see much of your coworkers, it's mostly about talking to customers at your cubicle/desk. The job becomes very monotonous quickly.

headline: Technology Director
pros: Great people, challenging projects, best technology
cons: long hours, not a lot of support/consistency/planning from senior management

headline: Four stars for the company, two stars for the job.
pros:
The people that make up this company are really great and not only care about their coworkers, but the surrounding community as well. I made life-long friends here.

The training teams were very helpful in helping my entire new-hire class pass our licensing exams and the information I learned has been very helpful for my life in general. 

My managers seemed genuinely interested in helping me find the right job internally--ironically this helped me realize that my dreams lay outside the company.
cons:
At its core, this is a call-center job--8 hours on the phone (or more). The information you discuss with clients is more complicated than other phone jobs, so you'll be relying on internal information systems since you can't know every little policy or acronym.

There's little time to breathe between calls at certain times of the year.

Meetings and coaching get cancelled all the time right when you're ready to take a break from the phones. I really could've used some help to improve the work I was doing.

headline: Was a great place to have a career in Boston MA.
pros: Very professional environment, Ability to advance quickly. Great benefits. If you are lucky enough to get a job that will remain in the Northeast, take advantage of the very generous 401K and profit sharing.
cons: Not much bad to say here. Wish they weren't moving the employee bass out of the northeast to Texas and North Carolina. Also if you are a technologist be prepared to perform all of your change control work after hours and weekends.

headline: Financial representative
pros: Amazing employer and great benefits
cons: hamster wheel and most days feel like groundhogs day

headline: Great place to start an FA career, strong structure in place and very smart people.
pros: Great expertise, structure, environment, opportunity
cons: Limited exposure and recognition, silo'd structure results in limited areas of involvement

headline: Not have good career growth
pros: I have been working for around 2 years. Pros - free cabs, meals and work life balance.
cons: lot of politics by Senior management, poor work culture, you wouldn't get growth even if you are working hard and providing solutions if you are not buttering up your boss

headline: One of the best companies to work for
pros: High ethical standards, respect for employees, opportunities to play diverse roles across multiple financial domains, frequent travels to US.
cons: High emphasis on people management. Credit sharing. Slow growth.

headline: Decent place to get your financial licenses, and thats about it.
pros: Paid study time to pass exams.
cons: Fidelity is one of those "we grew too fast for our own good" companies.  From 1990 to 2000, the employee base grew exponentially and alot of people who had no business being in any sort of management role found themselves in charge of other people in management.  Fidelity now cannot care about their new recruits having bachelor's or master's degrees, because many of the site directors have only high school diplomas to their name.  The national director of phone centers is working on a bachelor's degree.  There is no reward for education or effort, and for a while the quickest way to get into a manager position was to be female--hardly any other qualification was needed.

headline: Financial analyst
pros: Nice environment to work. And the best place to go
cons: Nothing to complain about anything

headline: Great Connections
pros: Great benefits and a great network of employees all across the country, willing to listen to employees
cons: Not being able to carry over vacation time seems irrational/encourages employees to use all their vacation days at the end of the year

headline: Experience varies greatly with different groups, overall a sweat shop
pros: Good exposure and opportunities to learn in the Financial Industry. Fidelity is extremely dedicated to it's customers.
cons: Staffing reductions and off-shoring combined with constant reorganization and relocations make employment very precarious unless you're willing to up and move to Raleigh or Dallas. SME experience is undervalued. Bureaucratic and dilbert-like.

headline: Its a very Good Company
pros:
1) Good Working Environment.
2) Highly Employee Satisfaction in term of salary.
3) Good Benefits .
cons: 1) Not more Technology to learn .

headline: A great experience if you are willing to sell your soul
pros: Fantastic learning opportunities.  Lots of training opportunities.  Superb on the job experiences.  Great systems and infrastructure.   Plenty of very smart people (though not everyone).   Like any place, you can always find good decent people whom you will become friends with.   There is so much that the company invests in to support its growth, its customers and its employees.   A very dynamic company, in many cases cutting edge in its industry.   Very good pay for most people - in some cases, truly outstanding pay.  And great benefits for everyone.
cons: The culture is insidious.    Terribly dysfunctional, paricularly the more senior you become.   Its simply not about how well you do your job - many people have realized that doing well and being rewarded is as much about making the other person look bad to make you look better.    If getting ahead for you means throwing your co-worker under the bus, then this is the place for you.   Its such a shame, because the company could be so great, but the culture of fear is simply gripping the place so that people are terrified, yet in many cases they are paid so well that they are equally afraid to leave.   Someone who left once told me that working there was like being in an abusive relationship - and you don't realize it until after you have left.   So many examples of people who on one day are viewed as superstars, and the next day they are suddenly viewed at the bottom of the heap - in many cases this happens when their manager leaves, and the former manager loved them, but the new manager doesn't value them and wants them gone.  So, you come to realize that the ball can drop on you at any moment.   I remember one executive saying, verbatim, "we all have a bullet with our name on it, and its only a matter of time until it hits you."    Senior management used to be very inspiring years ago, but no longer - it really changed for the worse around 2008 and from what I saw and continue to hear, it keeps going in the wrong direction.

headline: Great place but only if you have a strong manager.
pros: Compensation, benefits, ability to move around.
cons: Limited growth, lack of manager training, high stress environment.

headline: Expect To Work Hard
pros:
Good Medical Benefits
Good 401k Plan with matching contributions
Some positions have good work/life balance
cons:
You will most likely be doing the work of 2-3 people due to wave after wave of layoffs
Outsourcing is on the rise, making it more difficult to move around the company.

headline: Good learning , Employee Friendly company
pros:
1) You will get chance to learn a lot about financial domain
2) Employee Friendly policies
3) Flexible working hours
4) Uses latest technologies , keep upgrading technology stack
5) Seniors are very helpful
cons: 1) Gives opportunity to employee who have stayed with company for a long time compare to new person even if former is more talented and deserving

headline: Good firm to be "from"
pros: Clients are fun to work with. Great product offerings.
cons: Micro management. Annual pay cut.

headline: Third tour and more???
pros: Great career opportunities, training encouraged, generous 401k and other savings vehicles, ability to work in many aspects of the business.
cons: Your job may move out of state.  Great if you are looking to relocate on the company dime, otherwise you hit the pavement.  Downsizing in Boston.

headline: short, but good.
pros:
-the culture is excellent in the tech divisions, laid back, down to earth people
-everyone pulls their own weight, no slackers
-upper management is friendly and responsive
cons:
-job locations
-difficulty advancing in some groups

headline: Project Manager
pros: Individual contributors work hard to release quality products and satisfy the unrealistic demands from senior management.
cons: senior management cannot be trusted

headline: Human Resources Need to Look in the Mirror - Shameful
pros: Fidelity for many years was a great place to work.  Times have changed. Think twice before accepting an offer.  Many of us are miserable here.
cons:
The human resources group can't seem to set an example for others.  They have leaders to lie and treat others poorly.  These leaders twist stories and examples to benefit their own agenda.  

Constant change in company direction and leadership.  Lots of wasted time and money.

headline: Good company, competitive low cost benefits and room for advancement
pros:
brand recognition
comprehensive benefits at a competitive price
offices all over the country so great for relocation
cons:
many levels of management
political
takes a very long time to complete projects due to management, outsourcing to India, problems with technology

headline: Excellent Work - Life Balance
pros: Opportunity to work on latest IT technologies
cons: Not much growth opportunity as Company has reached a steady state with Head count cap of 5500 employees,

headline: N/A
pros: Fair work culture and values
cons: Limited exposure to work and low quantum of work

headline: Fidelity is a great place to work
pros: Solid company and good benefits
cons: Annual salary adjustments are minimal

headline: Great company! Stay out of the branches. Phone sites are amazing.
pros: Benefits. Health care is great. Fitness reimbursement and computer reimbursement.
cons: Its hard to fire people so management can be awful in the Branches.

headline: Very Happy at Fidelity
pros: Work life balance - work at home option
cons: would like more than 4 weeks vacation after 25 years

headline: Overall a great place to get started in the Financial Services industry.
pros: Management is supportive of personal development.
cons: limited mobility if you don't work near major hubs (boston, westlake, merrimack)

headline: Great company to start- plenty of ways to move around.
pros: work/life balance, benefits & culture. It' a great company to start your career in a financial industry. It's also a private company, you do not have to worry about being laid off because the company's stock tanked.
cons: pay is horrible- it felt like a battle to get more than 5% bonuses.  All of the important roles are (upper management/decision making roles) and will always be in Boston. Jobs are relocating to NH, TX, or RI.

headline: Take your money and run
pros: Back in the "day", great 401k matching and shares pay out allowed me to save a lot of money.  Good luck with that now!!  No more "golden handcuffs".
cons: The day after I left, due to my job being "site strategized", I moved every penny of my 401k to another financial firm.  Being an insider and seeing how the company was being run into the ground, there is no way that I would trust them managing my retirement nest egg

headline: Not finance...customer service.
pros: pay, work/life balance, benefits, schedule
cons: phone calls, phone calls, phone calls.... Every position requires taking nonstop phone calls from customers. most days consist of password resets and address updates.

headline: My start in the financial service industry with Fidelity has been an awesome experience
pros: Great culture, top-notch benefits, good compensation, excellent training program
cons: Compensation for the amount of work can be better

headline: It's Who You Know
pros: Steady work.    Great retirement.
cons: Heavy middle management that has too much power.  Too many chiefs and not enough indians.   Plays favorites.  Review process is a joke.   Moving up or lateral takes forever if possible at all,  unless you have some kind of relationship with the management.

headline: In and Out
pros: Good way to get your series 7 and series 66 as they sponsor you for any exams.
cons: Dealing with obnoxious customers is frustrating

headline: Overall a good company
pros: Great training and benefits. A good place to get started in the investment business.
cons: Limited scope of business and not truly client centered. Boxed approach in sales. But a good place for clients who are independent and want to manage their own investments.

headline: Decent company to work for. Be wary of restructuring
pros: Co-workers are knowledgable and competent. Lots of resources for learning and job development. Technology is kept decently up to date.
cons: Not much interaction between departments. Management can be rigid. Constantly restructuring.

headline: Great company to work with
pros: Growth opportunities are for real
cons: None at the time i used to work

headline: The best place I've ever worked...
pros: Fabulous long term compensation, career growth, and intelligent and trustworthy colleagues. Private ownership and high profitability has translated into high investment in people, offices, and technology.
cons: Regional diversification is putting strain on finding new opportunities while putting your current role at risk. Alot of movement and reassignment of business units to various national and international sites

headline: Decent company
pros: very diversified providing many opportunities; pays for performance
cons: inconsistency in how Managers lead/manage

headline: Average company to work for
pros: Work life balance (flexiblity), nothing really more on pros
cons: No onsite travel, company politics, No promotion/growth

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Great benefits (401k match, tuition reimbursement, fitness expense reimbursement, computer purchase reimbursement).
cons: Once you work at a call center, it's hard to transition to a position outside of the call center. Old boys club culture.

headline: Used to be a great place to work
pros: great work environment and benefits; on campus cafe was top notch; plenty of budget money to get things done the right way.
cons: management has turned into a seas pool of back stabbing weasels; no opportunity for advancement if you are not part of the 'club'

headline: Lot's of career path opportunities. Great benefits. Great compensation.
pros: There is a lot of focus on helping you advance your skills and career. They reward hard work and the people you work with are typically very professional and passionate about what they do. It would be very hard to leave the generous benefits and compensation once you have moved into a more advanced role.
cons: Sometimes it feels that senior management doesn't realize that their metrics and standards actually make it harder to help clients. They are great at taking small rocks out of the way, but the bigger rocks are next to impossible to move. Even when it is clear that they should be.

headline: Great company to work for, most of the time.
pros: Competitive pay, treats employees well, lots of unique benefits, continuously improves employee experience & opportunities, strong ethical standards.
cons: Many policies set in stone without consideration to individual employee situations.  Loyalty is not always rewarded.  Very competitive and sometimes political internal advancement and mobility.  Strict & methodical salary grades.  HR screening process for applicants could be better.

headline: Terrible
pros: Good benefits, good people to work with
cons: When it came to advancement, it was about who you knew, not how much you know

headline: Brilliant teams with great work in a
pros: Great teams and good development projects
cons: Low flexibility for faster innovation.

headline: It's been a great learning experience.
pros: Gain tons of market knowledge and get great training. Work with good people, and it is a respectable firm. Good place to start a career
cons: It is hard to advance within the company some times. They don't pay fantastic and if they hire someone into the same job you're doing from an outside firm, expect them to be making a lot more than you.

headline: Upper management tells a great story, but it's just window dressing
pros: Great training for getting Series 7 licensing.
cons: Fidelity is interested in hiring young people who are willing to live in fear just to keep their job. If you have a personality or are creative and think outside the box , you are not valued here. Super uptight environment, everyone is terrified that if they make one wrong move they will be in trouble.  If you are a yes man robot, without sense of humor, this is the place for you.

headline: High intensity
pros: Great integrity.  You can leave personal items out among hundreds of people and not worry about theft.  Many intelligent people.  Great benefits.
cons: Huge on metrics.  You must stay within a few minutes of an ever changing schedule.  No face to face time with clients.  A call center for promotion after promotion.  Very few investor centers so chances of working in one are not great.

headline: Respectable Environment but moves a bit slow
pros: A very respectable environment. Employees are strongly encourages to treat each other with utmost respect. A very good work life balance is encouraged.
cons: Moves a bit slow as far as acceptance of new technologies are concerned but that is just a character of the company to make sure that they roll out solid products.

headline: Mixed Feelings
pros: Excellent employee care. Engaging team building activities.
cons: Ill maintained Work Life balance. Lack of transparency between US and India associates.

headline: They should change their name to Infidelity
pros: Decent pay, decent benefits, workable facilities. It is difficult to find another fourteen words to meet the requirements of this posting.
cons:
Good old boy type of culture there. 
If you are the type that enjoys getting credit when deserved, you can forget that here, but they will let you know if they don't like something you are doing. 
Too much fraternizing with co-workers going on, and not just hanging out (Holiday Parties are for employees only, this is where a lot of the Infidelity comes into play).
If you are relying on your merits to take you places, you can forget that here. It's all about who you know and who's jokes you laugh at.
Too many double standards (what is good for one person, is not good for the next even if they are suppose to be a level above you.)
Middle management needs to be thoroughly investigated.
They throw around the VP title to anyone; deserving or not.
No promotional opportunities unless you know someone.
HR is a joke; not really a support system and they are somewhat difficult to reach.
Fear is often used to try to get you to conform or become friends

headline: You will be feeling more secure
pros: Security and takes a lot care on employees
cons: Less onsite opportunity for employees and it too depends on the team you are put in .

headline: Was a great time. Had a fantastic team who was invested in my development.
pros: Great pay. Tons of kids your age to hang out with. You will get some leisure time (which you should use to develop your skills to help the team).
cons: A very traditional company with lots of bureaucracy, which at points was slightly annoying. Still not caught up to many of the latest tech trends.

headline: Not For Fresher but for Experienced good pay
pros:
1 If you are lucky enough then you will assign to projects else you have to do support
2 Great value system
3 Good pay good work balance
4 No work load
cons:
1 starting career here is not a good option
2 Some politics happens

headline: Good work environment
pros: you can learn latest tech
cons: poor salary and less increments

headline: Decent place to start your career in finance
pros: Good manager for myself. Nice people.
cons: Nothing really specific to Fidelity. There are some things that are just inherent to the job and industry.

headline: Decent jumping off point for new college grads
pros: Good flexible hours, overtime easily approved
cons: no real upward mobility. management non responsive in furthering careers of employees

headline: Great benefits, too much bureaucracy
pros:
Great non salary benefits
Free managed 401k
cons:
bureaucracy
Some unnecessary positions
Poor salary but benefits make up for it

headline: Great "culture" people are genuine.
pros: Opportunity for advancement and other positions
cons: there is a very strict licensing program

headline: Very good place to work.
pros:
Employee friendly, Good Salary bonus. Good learning opportunities if you are hard working.
Onsite opportunities if you are lucky.
cons:
More emphasis on the metrics, quality management sometimes annoying.
Senior management get promotions faster than middle or lower management. Too many restrictions for getting promoted for lower level.

headline: System Analyst
pros: Good working environment,work life balance, healthy and safe environment
cons: Need to be more transparent on job roles.

headline: Great company, questionable positions within it.
pros:
Awesome benefits and 401k/profit sharing
Shift differential
Great training
Nice facilities
cons:
Consistently unreachable sales goals
Primarily phone oriented
Sometimes there is no choice of shift (1st, 2nd, 3rd)

headline: good company with good hike,policies
pros: good hike, policies, work life balance, employee benefits, Job Security
cons: too much of politics, not enough growth, no onsite opportunities

headline: I work at Fidelity investments. It is a very friendly environment filled with many intelligent individuals.
pros: Easy horizontal movement. Very well treated by management. Exceptional facilities. Very strong benefits
cons: Looking at a computer all day. Yet defined to my current position

headline: Was a great place to grow for self starters
pros: Lots of opportunity good benefits generous compensation
cons: Constantly changing senior leadership

headline: If you are willing to relocate multiple times you'll do well.  If you want stability, look elsewhere.
pros:
Exposure to some brilliant and highly educated individuals
Good benefits and programs such as healthcare, profit sharing, on-site fitness and health centers, fitness and computer reimbursement, bonus opportunities
cons:
Can achieve work/life balance but usually not without paying a price (limited or no advancement opportunity, limited or no pay increases)
Under-achievers often get recognized and promoted if they know the right people and can play them to their advantage
Jobs are constantly relocated or eliminated on senior management's whim with little regard for the impact to the people or businesses they support

headline: Hard work, competitive environment
pros: Benefits for employees eligible for profit sharing
cons: Not much job security, even if you are a top performer

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Good Perks for freshers
Good Work Life Balance
cons: No growth in middle management levels

headline: Define Contribution Representative, working in the call center managing retirement plans
pros:
They sometimes give free food when you have to work overtime.
They REALLY care about the customer.....(not so much the worker)
cons:
There is mandatory overtime during the months that there is high call volume, i.e. January is when they send out 1099 R forms, customers call in for tax questions as well as statement questions. This is the time that the only way to get out of working overtime is to obtain valid permission through the program director. The overtime is 11 hours.
Another con is the phones are constantly ringing there is no break between calls as soon as the caller hangs up the next call is already through and you have to be ready.
If you want a job outside of the field you are in you have to wait a year to get to a different sector.
There are so many goals they want done on every call, you have to maintain a relationship with the caller, ask protruding personal questions of why they want to take out money out of THEIR 401ks, you have to get a guidance opportunity in where you feel like a seller, you have to get a PCC in where you talk about how much they are putting in their 401k...etc, etc. the list goes on, you have to get so much done in one call, every call.

headline: Stand your ground
pros: Very committed team, focused on quality, results driven
cons: Easy for net negative producers to slink by, double booked time is common, expect to be over allocated and under appreciated

headline: Lead Software engineer
pros: Work Life Balance is good. Salary matters on the BU one joins. Focus more on domain expertise. Probably good to join at higher position, promotions at higher level are too fast, if you have networking in office, this matters more than hard working
cons: Career Growth is challenge, Office Politics.

headline: OK
pros: Work-life balance, honesty and integriti embibed in company operations, relax and work culture, ideal place to work for women.
cons: monotonous work, very slow growth and promotions

headline: great place to start your career
pros: great compensation, nice people, good community
cons: do not have any downsides

headline: Good Company for building up your retirement money
pros: Great Benefits. Fair Salary. For very good to excellent workers the annual bonus is nice. They provide 4 weeks vacation after 5 years on the job. Excellent 401K match at up to 7% and annual profit sharing at 10% of base pay or salary plus 3k yearly for a medical retirement account. They also have other benefit perks. They provide flexible work hours that take family issues into account.
cons: For at least the past 6 years advancement opportunities were limited. Merit raises have been meager. Due to cost cutting, departments are not budgeted fully (over the past 10 years or so) and goals of individual departments are not aligned to the corporate goals (except when it comes to cutting costs). This misalignment of goals causes friction and completion between departments.  Management is more top down as the company matures. Management tends to value, in all ways, those they consider superstars and "Outstanding" while ignoring the hard workers who come in every day and keep the company moving forward.

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Excellent company to work for with great values. Management cares for their employees and their career development. Its a great opportunity for a recent college graduate to learn about the financial services industry.
cons: I was interested in a career change and had a difficult time moving into a different position within the company. There is a specific career path for Financial Representatives and is difficult to move into other positions that fall outside of that path.

headline: Not what you think
pros: incredible benefits and opportunities for advancement can be good, especially for the "right" look.
cons: poor work life balance, Extremely  unwelcoming culture for women and minorities, very political leadership. Consistent pressure to join their Financial Services Political Action Committee and to follow the lead of the Johnson family, never question them.

headline: good entry level job for anyone coming right out of college to the workforce
pros: good benefits, paid vacation, paid sick time, off for holidays (except Christmas eve)
cons: not that great of pay and being on the phone for forty hours a week can be taxing for some people

headline: Overall a decent place to work. You need to keep your network fresh to ensure upward mobility.
pros: Compensation is decent between the cash & share compensation. Certainly feel some compression taking hold though as they try to get closer to industry benchmarls
cons: Salary compression trend, continued geographic expansion out of MA. Somewhat limited promotion opportunities

headline: Fragmented and constant restructuring
pros:
- Excellent benefits (401k matching, discounts with major companies, free portfolio mgmt, etc..)
 - Great if you want a job that is laid back
 - A lot of flexibility to move laterally
cons:
- Salaries are not competitive
 - Boss had very little power in giving reasonable raises because of "company policy"
 - The work is not as challenging as it could be
 - Lots of red tape when you wish to use software that is not on the company list of "compliant" software
 - Business casual dress code forced on software engineers is never a good idea

headline: Used to be better.
pros: Benefits, some good managers, work/life (depending on your manager).
cons: Many poor managers, only "horizontal" movement - forget promotions.  Many employees that are just not qualified are put into positions (often of power).  Everything is a secret.  Who you know is key.  I tried for 4 years to get into this company, when it finally happened, I was so excited.  The benefits were amazing, the perks were fantastic and everyone seemed happy.  Shortly after, they restructured, brought in the car salesman (ax man) and it has all been down hill from there.  Took away the pension, didn't even grandfather people in - absolutely ridiculous, changed benefits, rules, compensation, and basically took the "You are lucky to have a job" attitude towards the employees.  Lay-offs, RIFS, "site strategy" (which is how they now hide lay-offs from the press).

headline: Excellent learning opportunity!
pros: Technology makes job easier due to Fidelity commitment of stream lining business, and focusing on the client experience.
cons: Easy to cap out on income here, and not a lot of opportunities for future growth without relocating to Boston.

headline: Review
pros: Good company, and a good salary
cons: Good people, nice work culture

headline: It was a good learning experience both in doamin and technology
pros: Corporate Culture, Good exposure to both finance and IT
cons: Pay is not satisfing and the company doesnt care about people who are leaving.

headline: Incredible opportunities to take your career wherever you want it to go
pros: Caring people, excellent retirement benefits and shares, plenty of career options
cons: Work-life balance can be challenging, decisions from leadership take a long time

headline: From a recent college grad standpoint
pros: Amazing Benefits, talented people, and gives back to community
cons: Might be working on old technlogies, but the company is starting to adopt latest technologies. Co works are relativly in their 40s but starting to see some 25 year old starting.

headline: Multiple companies / teams to work within
pros: Job rotation, stability, good work life balance, challenging groups, smart middle management
cons: Many layers and groups to navigate to get work done, though thats changing.

headline: Stable company with great benefits
pros: Excellent profit sharing plan and generous 401k match.  Annual bonus program - amounts vary.
cons: None to share at this time.

headline: Good but not great
pros: Good place to start a career, but you can begin to feel like you are stuck in a position with little upward mobility
cons: There is a lot of micro-managing by middle management and constant change.

headline: Manager's Paradise
pros: Managers can plan for retirement
cons:
1 Manager is almost a god as HR (just for namesake, no actual Role) follows blindly what they say. By mistake if you tell anything to HR , you can be 110% rest assured , it goes to your manager .

2.During so called restructuring, Instead of these non-technical managers, they clean up technology people having higher salary, which is really a disappointing message for all technology people. so Indirectly NOT a good company for technical people.

3.Any ladies planning to extend their family, can join the company to get good WFH flexibility .

4. Managers hardly knows good project Management methodologies , So Don't expect any kind of PMBOK knowledge from them. Hardly they share anything . One used to line from these so called managers " make my life easy" . 

5.If you get into operation based projects, forget about learning. Just time-pass. 

6. Knowledge sharing is rare in this company

headline: Great company to work for, great pay as well.
pros: I receive good compensation and worked in a good atmosphere.
cons: I did not encounter any downsides

headline: Great company to work for.
pros: Private firm, great work life balance
cons: Not as innovative as other companies in industry

headline: Overall, its a great company to work at - if one is looking for stability.
pros: The company is extremely customer focused. The management team is always trying to re-invent themselves to ensure they remain competitive.  The firm is also employee friendly and has the power to weather the economic ups and downs with minimum impact to employees.
cons: Change is constant.  Career growth prospects are extremely limited.  Anyone who is looking to move up the ladder will find it takes many years to get a promotion. In the past 5-7 years, the company's focus on cutting costs and improving productivity has resulted in fewer people working a lot more with no significant improvement in compensation. This is not a company to look at if you are looking for a 9-5 working day.

headline: Great Company
pros: Licenses. Series 7 and Series 63
cons: Salary 18.15 per hour sucks!

headline: Good Company to start your career..
pros:
Good Benefits - 7% dollar-for-dollar match, 10% profit sharing, Good Bonuses, Good retirement benefits 
Technology is paid attention to
cons:
GC is tough to get via company
offshore team politics exist

headline: The company is actually a good company, but you need to have the right job.
pros: Excellent benefits. Decent work/life balance.
cons: Pay seems to be on the lower side of industry average. It has most of the issues that plague most large businesses.

headline: Great company with numerous opportunities to expand one's career in financial services.
pros: Overall compensation is great once at a certain salary band.  Getting to that level can be a challenge depending on the opportunities given to you and support from your direct management team.
cons: Networking is key.  Knowing the right people is sometimes more important than performing one's job.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Company provides good retirment benefits
cons: IT departments are moving out of Boston

headline: Good company
pros: Benefits, associates, lower level management
cons: Political Animal, stuffy senior management

headline: HR is non-existent for non-managerial employees
pros: Good place to work for a few years to get all-round finance industry experience. However, be prepared to work like a slave, because it is all numbers game for performance metrics. Quality & customer service does not matter.
cons: Employees are disposable assets. Skills and experience does not matter. No emphasis on building able and skilled work force. High attrition rate. Upper management is all about numbers game on excel spreadsheet because that earns them huge bonuses. Little accountability in management rung. If they screw-up, they abandon the group/business and jump-shift to another business like sinking ship.

headline: Good company but don't stay too long..
pros: Market rate pay and generous 401(k); ample resources; good working environment and decent work/life balance
cons: Highly political, constant reorgs, lacks good leadership, a company in many ways past its prime,

headline: It's an okay place if you don't mind your supervisor repeatedly taking credit for your work!
pros: I like the people I work with, and the pay.
cons: My supervisor repeatedly takes credit for my work. I don't like the long commute.

headline: Worked there for a couple of years
pros: Very stable, good benefits, lots of good friends were made in the office
cons: Very stable and fun atmosphere in some offices.  However, limited room for growth and managers are creative at keeping you down because they're also being help down.

headline: low pay
pros: good insurance.  The golden handcuffs of veteran employees
cons: work-life balance is mentioned as a value, but no advancement if you are not working 60 plus hours and sucking up to the right people

headline: Stable, but you wont get rich.
pros: They offer a stellar benefits package.
cons: Not a lot of opportunity to think for yourself.

headline: Awesome training & ability to grow
pros: Training is top notch & extensive for each role that you are put into.
cons: Time frames for training & implementation are sometimes a little unrealistic. Control some of the core managers, when some think no-one is listening or watching it's worse than a NFL/College locker room w/ the language & misogynistic attitudes & conversations. Not sure if I would want my daughter working under some or at all w/in this environment in the Service division.

headline: Difficult work but you feel appreciated
pros: Market or better pay, good benefits, and open feeling office space.  Lavish christmas parties and more than most company fun events.  A "Nice" place to work where nobody is allowed to look too scruffy. You can't wear jeans or baseball caps or certain items of clothing.You can feel the money. If you are interested in understanding how big brokerage  companies like Fidelity manage to keep track of it all you would like it.  You usually feel engaged. There is a lot of software development so it's not always legacy applications if you work in technology.  Generally you will be thanked for your work and told you are doing well (unless you suck at your job) . There are lots of kitchens scattered around and there is lots of free food there often leftover from being served in meetings. Whenever you have to  work nights you often get to order out free food.It's a cube farm, no way around it. Cube walls are not too low but not as high as other places.
cons: You have to work hard there, sometimes nights and weekends, there is a bit of the workaholic culture there. Sometimes for extended periods for a big important project. The job security tends to wander with the market. When it's up you're okay, if the economy is really bad watch out. Sometimes people seem a little mean, like they don't screen for it very well in employees,  You always have a long walk from the parking lot.  Much better to be a contractor so you don;t have to work extra hours as much.

headline: A revolving door
pros: Nice customers and coworkers, nice benefits
cons: Branch managers are nothing but "yes" people who humiliate and undermine sales staff.  All about selling Fidelity products to everyone or else...

headline: Wonderful Perks
pros: Great benefits-10% profit sharing into 401k, dollar for dollar match up 7%, tuition reimbursement, etc.
cons: Monster company, which isn't always a bad thing but sometimes frustrating.

headline: Fidelity is a company with great values.
pros: You feel like you are working for a culture that is truly committed to doing the right thing both internally and externally.
cons: The opportunity for advancement and continuing challenge is mixed, depending on the area that you are involved in.

headline: Good Company to work for...
pros: Good people, Great work culture, Descent pay.
cons: There are very few thing to point out, Like slow growth in few teams.

headline: Good Place to work for.
pros:

- Good Management
- Less Bureaucracy
cons:
- None
- Keep up the good work

headline: Good... but politics is there.

Comfort in everything. No pressure
Work - life balance
People are nice except few
Shift timings.
No targets.
cons:
Monotonous work, you will get frustrated at times.
Politics
Slow growth

headline: Live in a box
pros: Training on what needs to be done to effectively run your own business- For example management of CRM system.
cons: Zero room to think outside of the box.  They have a tried a true way of doing things and you are told to do it there way or the highway.  Pay is low for the amount of work done.

headline: mixed feelings
pros: the benefits are pretty good. People are mostly nice; can't really think of any other pros.
cons: Call center job. poor training; you get left with problems which you didn't create but have to be accountable for them. some angry customers. They keep tabs on you like you are a lab rat.

headline: Leading company focused on efficiency and status quo tinkering
pros: Great DNA. Customer service is tops
cons: No innovation. None. Haven't created a new product or category or service in 10 plus years. Company makes money too easily to change.

headline: Good start in financial services but other firms probably pay better.
pros: Great training, opportunity to learn the business and get licenses. Challenging roles allow you to learn a good deal about the brokerage business.
cons: Squeeze every ounce of patience by adherence to at least 5-10 metrics while your also dealing with demanding customers. Rigid and non flexible hours. Internal staffing doesn't care about your career development, it actually seems easier to look for a job outside than internal. Limited opportunities to advance from a phone role, not much in terms of support, almost feels like the company doesn't want you to move.

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Provides the opportunity to work in an enterprise environment
cons: Advancement can be stagnate as its difficult to interchange to different product services

headline: Good place to work!
pros: Unlimited opportunities in the financial services industry for those who know how to navigate and network effectively.  Good benefits, pay and interesting work.  If you like a challenge, this is the place to work.
cons: Little appreciation for associate technical and internal knowledge, and the impact to client services, satisfaction and potentially the bottom line.

headline: A Great Place to learn and work.
pros:
Best workplace
Team spirit
Great training's 
limitless learning opprtunities
cons: Not a good company to start with it's best to settle.

headline: Dull
pros: Great benefits such as tuition reimbursement, profit sharing, 401k match, etc. All for pretty easy work as long as you can pass the Series 7 and 63
cons: stuck on a phone all day, work in a call center, sometimes deal with irrational or novice clients, not innovative work at all

headline: It's a white collar factory
pros:
I respect this compay's business
Nice facilities
Decent benefits
cons: Basically, it's a white collar factory. Come in prepared for boring routine tasks. Check your brain, ideas, creativity and opinions at the door. Lip service is paid to team building but if you are not a "favorite" forget fair treatment. The place is full of the "walking wounded" from numerious RIFs.

headline: Excellent benefits, great people, decent pay.
pros: Fidelity has the best training in the industry.
cons: There are limited opportunities to choose from.

headline: Excellent Company
pros: Fidelity is a great company to start your career. i am forever gratefull for the job. If you dont mind talking on the phone its a nice stable job with great people
cons: tough to move up without making a few lateral moves potentially

headline: Good company for technical exposure
pros:
1.Good work life balance.
2.Good yearly hikes
3.Good technical exposure and trainings
cons:
1.There is a very high % of variable component in the CTC.
2.Very Late promotion cycle
3. Frequent organizational changes

headline: Great place to work if you are in the right role.
pros: There are a lot of very challenging, rewarding, and lucrative roles within the company.  If you find yourself in the right business unit at the right time Fidelity can be an amazing place to work.  While base salaries seem low, if you are in a role where you are compensated on performance (commission, cash bonus, stock awards) you can find yourself making a great living with a great work / life balance as compared to the rest of the industry.
cons: Entry level and back office employees are not paid very much and are not eligible for many of the performance based compensation incentives (stock awards, cash bonuses etc.).  This means that if you find yourself in the position of being dependent upon one of these people to do your job, you are frequently greeted with either incompetence or apathy.

headline: Great Company to work for!
pros: Private Company, Great work/ life balance, good people, Great reputation in the industry!
cons: Depending on your position, you are stuck on a phone ALL day.

headline: Great place to start your career in investments
pros: Thorough training, lots of opportunities to learn
cons: Too much emphasis on schedule efficiency

headline: A great company if you're on the right team.
pros: Always room to move up and to learn new things.
cons: Difficult to make a big impact in such a large organization.

headline: Great company to work with (Amazing facilities)
pros: Great work culture and amazing facilities like cab, sodexho etc.
cons: Indian Management always trying to save money due to which lot of budget cuts.

headline: Not an exciting workplace
pros: good benefits when it comes to tuition reimbursement, fitness, and health. Room for growth
cons: The pay scale is pretty pathetic compared to the work you handle.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Friendly, Ethical Environment. Excellent Bennefits Packages. Great company for motivated people looking to advance their careers. Very good training and onboarding process.
cons: Pay is lower in relation to industry averages. Technology seems to lag industry and work/life balance is not a primary focus all the time.

headline: Best in the league
pros: work environment, learning,recognition, no red tapism,facilities
cons: work life balance, monotonous , work load

headline: Learning wise good company, have to be self driven
pros: Work-life balance, more towards life
cons: Sometime hard work don't pay

headline: Amazing Internship
pros:
Great opportunities for advancing
Great co-workers
cons: There are no cons, this is an amazing company.

headline: Out of Touch - Unorganized - Micromanagers
pros: Decent facilities to work in.
cons: Antiquated technology. Are not employee centric. Bogged down in corporate waste. Micromanagers. No automation. Unorganized. Uncaring. Child like management skills. Completely out of touch with their client base, the well being and needs or their employees, automated processes, modern corporate culture and technology. Limited Telecommuting.

headline: Management talk like care but...
pros:
Easy Commute if you live in Jersey.
People are nice.
Benefits are good esp. the 401k
cons:
Management is OK.
The jobs are all moving to Westlake, TX
No room for growth.

headline: Good people, learned a lot, call center environment/ stressful
pros: Good Benefits, Good people, Learned about investing for myself
cons: Call Center (call after call after call.......), Pay should be better for what you have to do everyday

headline: Don't drink too much of the punch.
pros: Flexible work schedules, great benefits, wonderful campus,
cons: Right hand NEVER talks to the left hand, micromanagers, it all depends on who you know, call center life isn't for everyone

headline: Fidelity was an extremely challenging yet rewarding firm to work for over the years
pros: Fidelity compensates its employees well and provides an exciting and challenging work environment.
cons:
1) Constant re-organizations make it difficult to make change initiatives stick within the organization.  Each new leader wants to dismantle previous leaders work and rebuild in his own vision therefore some employees choose to not embrace change because they know they can wait it out until the next re-organization.  

2)  Mid to upper management his very political and tend to focus on their own personal agenda's versus doing what is right by the firm which frustrates the people who truly want to do the right thing.

headline: Sucks
pros: Part time shifts available ghhh
cons: Matrices matter more than people's careers

headline: Other departments may be better, but avoid the Defined Benefits area
pros:
Receive bi-weekly paychecks...
When you have down time due to testing environments not working, you have some time to build worthwhile skills for a new job.
cons:
Test environments are horrible - It is impossible to actually test. They are always changing code that breaks things with no accountability. Client Configurations are always getting messed up. It's impossible to test a product completely. Random error messages every day. It is extremely frustrating to be in this type of environment and you will be stuck waiting for dev/systems to fix issues on a daily basis.

No advancement opportunities within DB - They will gladly allocate you to 120% because they like to "run lean", but they don't like to actually recognize employees monetarily. If you ever do get a promotion within the team, don't expect a good pay raise.

Atrocious raises - With each year the raises are getting worse. After leading major projects and putting in a bunch of overtime, I was presented with a 1.5% raise. Others received worse percentages. Make sure you haggle on your starting salary, because you will be at that same pay until you get out of the department.

No incentives - The only incentive is if you are hourly and can work overtime. Otherwise, you won't get recognized and there will be some time of excuse why raises/bonuses are low despite making record profits. I don't know many coworkers that want to stay in the department.

Cheap - When they do encourage team bonding, they make it known that it is NOT funded and that you have to pay. Example - lunch outings with new teammates will be talked about for a week in advance and is highly encouraged to attend, but you will have to pay for yourself. When they used to acknowledge birthdays within the group, the cakes had to be bought personally by management without being able to expense them. 

Benefits - There are health benefits, but they have increased ~220% within 2 years. So you make less money by staying with the company. If you want any type of health reimbursement, you have to track your daily fitness/diet/etc; which they do reimburse $125/quarter, but it is very time consuming

Menial tasks/job - The job itself is very menial. Other departments test a lot more that seem to overlap. You will not build any skills with this position. The hardest part of the job is understanding the complex systems, and when you have a good idea how they should function, they do not actually work. You spend most of your time writing defects. Each environment has limitations that seem to fluctuate per project. You will not build any skills that will help you develop professionally and could hinder future opportunities.

Access issues - There are so many different systems that you need access to. You will not know that you need access to a specific table/environment/program/system until you lose it and can't access something. Then you have to wait days in order for them to give you access permissions again. 

You will be "voluntold" to participate in certain tasks that are not related to your role (or even department), have no prior knowledge of and are projected to "only take 4 hours", but they end up taking multiple weeks while you still have project work to maintain. That will be on addition to the 120% allocation that you already have for projects as well. 

The main application used in DB is 20+ years old. The code is basically all patchwork to fix problems on top of problems. There's "known issues" within certain functionality that isn't actually known among teams until a high-level dev informs the teams.

headline: Good company
pros: Most people want to do their jobs well. Upper management receptive to changes if you know how to present the business value.
cons: Some people are stagnant so difficult to move positions.

headline: This is a great company to work for with awesome benefits and thorough training.
pros: Very nice, non-backstabbing people, lots of upward mobility, fun company and team events, stable company, great training. This company working here for a few years looks great on any resume.
cons: It's average pay, mostly phone roles, it feels sometimes like there are not enough representatives on the phone to handle all the calls coming in back to back. Most roles are very structured.

headline: Tax Exempt Representative
pros: Supportive Management. Excellent Training Program. Great Benefits. Consistant Feedback. Career advancement opportunities are available for those who put in the work. Flexibility is key to being successful.
cons: Managers can sometimes overlook hard-workers. Some shifts are late since the TEM department is open until midnight. The environment is constantly changing (may be a good thing for some).

headline: Great Company, but phones are too much.
pros: Great benefits, 7% 401k matching, excellent healthcare with HSA, Fun & smart people co-workers, good location.
cons: The phones are awful, I hated having set 15 breaks and a scheduled lunch that rotated every day. They try and make you believe you have growth opportunities in Jax, but don't be fooled. It's all on the phones. If you like that, great, if you hate the phones do NOT take this job. Managers rotate way too often. They bring in a new manager every few months, ones that have no clue about your subject matter.

headline: Company strives for continuous improvement however is very demanding expecting much more from employees.
pros: Good salaries, good benefits. Good company to begin career with as there is growth potential for those who stand out.
cons: Expectations are high. With layoffs employees are expected to do more work as terminated employees are typically not replaced.

headline: Roller coaster
pros: Salary, benefits, severance package.  Committed to continuous improvement.  Invests in improvements, particularly technology.
cons: Does not hire the most talented, let's mediocre players stay for 10-15 years.  Mediocrity begets mediocrity.  Conducts  disruptive purges when strategic priorities change.  Cross-functional collaboration is fraught personal animosities.

headline: Design lead
pros: Fidelity is a great place to learn how to be effective in a huge organization. When I worked there, the company was eager to show off its design group--we were allowed to wear jeans every day and had very cool hexagonal cubes, because the company wanted to showcase the fact that creative people worked at a financial institution. There was also a full usability lab, which is rarity in any industry.
cons: It was really easy for people to do very little work. Inefficiency was literally built into the design review process; I had to run every finished design by a designer--a Fidelity veteran, natch--who might have half my skill level, despite their years of experience. I left because I knew that I wouldn't learn anything there, and my skills would inevitably get stale in an environment that lacked innovation. The management was just getting excited about Flash at the time, at the moment when the industry was moving toward abandoning it! Additionally, diversity was a problem. Fidelity had very few non-white/non-Indian people, at the time, and I don't think anything has changed. One buffoon of a manager (white) thought it was hilarious to spout "ebonics" at every opportunity. It was cringe-making, at the very least.

headline: Great work culture
pros: Work culture, flexible working hours, support from seniors, taking leaves
cons: growth opportunities, job rotation, laid back

headline: Good learning opportunity
pros: Smart company, great career growth
cons: You're a cog in the machine like most corporations.

headline: Great learning experience, with lot of challenging assignments
pros: Great work culture, flexible timing, advance technology, good learning curve, good work life balance
cons: Flat reporting hierarchy, slow title promotions

headline: Come here to learn
pros: Advancement if you are willing to put in the hours and show effort to learn more than one thing
cons: Starting pay was on the lower end

headline: Ten years of dog eat dog
pros: There are some smart people there, and the pay is above average.
cons: The culture is toxic. Most SVP level and above are more interested in how they are perceived over actual business results. The result is small groups of people that prevent senior management from seeing the real issues that prevent true growth. Everyone in the 'group' is doing the best possible job, and any poor results are the cause of non-group members. Poor results are rarely reported voluntarily.

headline: Met a lot of great, talented people.
pros: Great benefits and awesome people.
cons: Frequent changes and lay offs.

headline: awesome company
pros: challenging assignments, exciting work... high spend on technology
cons: flat structure, takes lot of time to grow...

headline: Manager Micro Managing
pros: great benefits, 401k match, nice co workers
cons: Mico managers, no growth potential outside of retail sales

headline: Most toxic Corporate IT environment
pros:
Stable working environment and decent 401k benefits.
Working location in Boston is very good, right next to South Station
cons:
- Toxic and bullying IT environment
- Stupid and long-term relocation policy that alienates all IT workers. 
- Mostly a waste of time for any young IT professional I have talked to. Everyone left the company within 2 years. 

If you are a IT professional under age 30 and looking for a career, and not just a job that pays the rent, please stay far away from Fidelity. Do not believe anything they say. I once thought that a peaceful corporate environment would be okay. But I learned how a toxic environment can affect a worker's life and career potentials. It is not going to be worth your time to work in a company like Fidelity. I felt so much happier when I leave the place.

headline: great environment
pros: great co-workers, great benefits, generous employee match
cons: low pay compared to competitors

headline: Strong company in some regards
pros: When I was working there, I felt a part of the company. The company went out of its way to communicate, ensure team building, and be transparent. Very good benefits packages, and of course investment options. Good work/life balance, easy to speak with supervisors and leadership.
cons: Like most companies, there is a resource crunch in some areas. Company is very focused on standardization across groups. This can be a good and bad thing.

headline: Fidelity is a great place to work.
pros: Fidelity is a fair company and encourages the employees to be creative and drive change in the organization.  It has had an entrepreneurial spirit for many years but recently the trend is shifting to "driving only the numbers".
cons: Constant consolidation and cost cutting.  Do more with less.  The more you cut the more successful you are.

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Benefits are probably the best out there!!!  This company invests a lot of capital trying to compete with other firms in the brokerage realm and with great success!   Company is well-managed.   Depending on the area, job opportunities are abundant!  I feel that Fidelity truly focuses on the customer as an effective business strategy.
cons: Increases in pay are small but quick up front.  After 2 years the pay increases slow down drastically, even for good performance due to the control point compensation schedule they have.  Too often individuals are hired for reasons other than tenure and performance.  Politics too often play a role in advancement.

headline: A challenging but fundamentally frustrating software development experience.
pros: Great offices, good benefits, excellent coworkers.
cons: High turnover, frequent burnout, poor work/life balance, slow to adapt to new technology.

headline: Satisfactory
pros: good place to work in
cons: relaxed environment in the firm

headline: Best work culture
pros: Flexibility at work and cab facility
cons: You get use to relax and work

headline: Great place to work at
pros: Good work life balance, good culture and colleagues
cons: Very conservative in terms of products

headline: Great Company.. Westlake, TX
pros:
Benefits
Company Christmas party
Cafeteria
Great work/life balance
Employee Engagement
Career Development
Training
cons:
Compensation - It is best to negotiate salary as much as possible before taking the offer, if not you will be unsatisfied for the work that is required. During the negotiation of the salary if not offered what you want do not take it because it is extremely difficult to get good pay increases. Average merit raises were about 1.5%. Pay also depends on the area as well but for the most part it is not very competitive amongst other financial firms.
Sometimes things can be too micromanagement

headline: Somewhere in the middle...
pros: Reasonable salary and better than average benefits and corp perks. Have established procedures and good access to subject experts. If you get a manager who is in touch with you, you are in better shape
cons: Can be hard to locate who the experts are at times. Could do a little better at managing transitions during organizational change and uncertainty. Seems like formal authority still resides up north even though workforce is in many other states

headline: Phones
pros: it is a job with good overall benefits.  Nice campus setting
cons: terrible pay.  most managers should not be managers.  Management does not listen to their employees' concerns.  Favoritism.  Did not see promotions based off of business needs being accomplished but more who you know.

headline: Great company to work for....
pros: The people, the internal and external clients, the friendly atmosphere
cons: lack of work-life balance, lack of developmental plan for employees

headline: Working in IT at Fidelity will be the death of your career if you are a true Tech Person
pros: Generally competitive salaries and good benefits.  If you are very good with Technology no one is likely to ask questions as they wouldn't want to reveal how little they know themselves.
cons:
Fidelity is very political and top heavy.  Over 25% of IT people have titles of Director or above, however this is not because of ability, it is because it is the only way Fidelity can retain staff.  These people would not cut it at technology companies where engineering and merit are central.

In order to accomplish anything at Fidelity, you must have countless meeting with many groups of people, most of whom will not understand any technical aspects of the discussion.  Instead decision makers will rely on people with inflated titles whom they believe to be technical gurus, but who are simply the best at appearances and politics.

Fidelity is extremely title, appearance, and politics conscious.  Your actual ability to innovate, be creative, or lead is secondary to these factors.  If you are a true lover of technology who wants to learn and grow, then you should make every effort to join a proper technology company.  Avoid Fidelity at all costs.
It

headline: Good Company Great People
pros: Smart people to work with, good training opportunities
cons: Politics and useless upper management

headline: Good.
pros: Worked with some really great bosses.
cons: Really only advance if you know someone.

headline: Long timer
pros: A lot of interesting projects and challenges to improve product and services for customers. A good benefits package is provided. High ethics and standards.
cons: Work Life balance is not the highest focus for the firm and rewards and incentives have been dwindling. Moving out of Boston area.

headline: Do not be attracted to their well known name
pros:
Nice facilities and landscaping at the Westlake location
generous 401k matching
good health insurance coverage
decent amount of vacation time after five years
cons:
Low pay
Senior management make decisions without knowledge of what daily job looks like how it hurts them
Annual reviews are stacked to list 80 percent of employees as satisfactory
high work volume with not enough staff....told to be "efficient"

headline: Great organization with teamwork and sales as a culture
pros: Leading financial service provider that does what is right for the client. Feel good about positioning products that you know are a great value to the customer. Good culture and recognition of accomplishments.
cons: It's a very large organization and at times there are many people going for the same positions to advance. You could make more in plain salary and commissions working elsewhere in the industry.

headline: Wonderful company
pros: Good work culture and great people
cons: Don't have anything negative to say

headline: Good place to work
pros:
Nice People (most of them) 
Workplace flexibility (working remote)
Good benefits
cons:
Pay is so-so 
Tough to advance – you move jobs if really want to get  any significant pay increase

headline: Great company. Great culture!
pros: People friendly. Respect for individuals.
cons: Gets slow paced at times but is dependant on the employee how he/she paces himself/herself to grow in the organization.

headline: Very positive. Great way to get into the financial field.
pros: Private company, no shareholders to please. Focus on employees and clients strictly. The westlake building is brand new and is a great place to work. Any financial goals you have can be achieved through Fidelity
cons: None. A great company to work for if you know what you're getting into.

headline: Rigid Atmosphere
pros: loved the people whom I worked with, benefits were great, pay was little.
cons: I had 7 manager in 3 years, the last one was the worst so Its a luck of the draw, very limited mobility, new employees are more valued than tenured ones.

headline: Financial Representative
pros: They are nice bunch of people to worth with and friendly enviornment
