headline: Great Company
pros: Everyone is super nice and super helpful. If you need help with anything, people will not hesitate to help out.
cons: Only con would be the amount of time it takes to get clearance.

headline: Great company to work for.
pros: Good pay, good bonuses, promotion opportunities, genuinely cares about customers and providing the best service.
cons: Job can be difficult, especially if you mind sitting on the phone all day

headline: Fidelity Investments
pros: A great place for entry level positions. Fair pay. A lot of female leadership. Many opportunities to move between groups within the company. Very little micromanaging.
cons: There is some bureaucracy in promotions. Employees ratings are expected to fit within a bell curve, so some employees may receive low ratings because "someone has to get it." Company changes are never done within the time frame that is set. Very little support from senior lever management

headline: Great place to work !
pros: Career Pathing, Growth, Facilities, Work Life Balance
cons: Nothing at this moment, its been doing well across all areas

headline: Project Manager
pros: Very professional work environment, talented technology resources using cutting edge applications
cons: Lack of communication across groups.  Wasted money with on-going duplicate efforts.

headline: Decent Pay....Long Day
pros: Good pay; Dedicated Workers; Good Benefits
cons: Long Days; Abusive Customers; Inter Fidelity groups do not get along.

headline: Big company with great benefits
pros: Benefits, large co that spends on tech, fast paced, lots of areas to work in, challenging
cons: Change is constant and can be draining or derailing to programs, work life balance is hard to maintain with intensity expected, chance of relocation is constant

headline: Good company to learn on your own, building network and relationship
pros: excellent environment, HR policies, flexibility, good company for retirement, very less pressure in general (with some exception)
cons: Not at all good company to start the career, keep on changing strategies, appreciation for ECA rather than for deliveries

headline: great company with above average pay and benefits
pros: Salary, benefits, people, culture, fun
cons: It was a very busy place and short staffed. Some of the senior managers were difficult to speak with, stubborn and unapproachable

headline: Outstanding - autonomy to employees
pros:
Great culture
Autonomy to employees
Good regular trainings
cons: Management - especially offshore - Directors and above - need to work closely with partners

headline: Lots of opportunity for those who are hard workers and not afraid of change.
pros: I was able to grow into a career in software development, thanks to in-house and on the job training and opportunities.  The size of the company affords a great benefits package, with tuition reimbursement, and a variety of health plans, 401 K etc.   Because the company has so many different areas of business, employees can gain experience in different business units via internal transfers, and grow their career within Fidelity. Different areas almost have different business "personalities." The company also welcomes back any "alumni" who had left on good terms. There is a commitment to excellence and integrity to their customers.
cons: You will never work so hard!  Underachievers need not apply. If you don't like change, don't work at Fidelity!  (however, some people enjoy change, so this is a pro, not a con!)  Business units reorganize, individual jobs transform.  Depending upon the business unit you work in, there may be lots of bureaucracy or it may resemble a start up - this is why Fidelity is hard to generalize about.

headline: Great environment for what it is.
pros:
Well maintained company structure. 
Lots of room for internal movement. 
Great benefits.
cons:
Unrealistic company expectations. 
Very high pressure atmosphere. 
You will feel "chained to your desk".

headline: Good
pros: Good work, Good hikes , work & life balance
cons: growth is not there. not much projects

headline: Too much time spent dodging shrapnel.
pros: The company has tremendous resources.  I had the opportunity to work with some very smart and capable people.  Excellent work/life balance, and the benefits were very good.  Decent career opportunities *IF* you're willing to live where the company wants you to.
cons:
Not long after I was hired, the company went into a cut & outsource mode.  Salaries stayed flat during my tenure, as with most of the financial services industry at the time.  Too much of my time was spent changing jobs to avoid being relocated. 
Truly horrid 'Human' Resources.  While driving my child to school one morning, I learned of the latest RIF over the radio.  My child looked at me and asked, "Are we okay?".

headline: Senior Fund Accountant
pros: Great Company. Great Co Workers. Great Food.
cons: Low Money Low income Low Raises. Low Bonuses

cons:

Tendency for management to manage upwards and focus on their own prospects/careers
Not much effort made to build team spirit/morale
Compensation not very competitive

headline: Not too bad
pros: Great career opportunities and many people had been with the company for years until of course they shut down half of the Canadian operation
cons: No matter how good you are, you are indispensable

headline: Great pay but employees not valued in layoffs
pros: Great pay and benefits, very easy to get to and a commute you can really be thankful for. They spend money on technology where needed and help you get your job done.
cons: Who in management knows about you and what you do is somewhat luck when new mangers are always coming in. The review system is awkward and can't possibly reflect your achievements correctly.

headline: Good place to start...Positive atmosphere...Low pay
pros:
1.) The company invests a lot of money in Learning and Development including paying for your licenses and maintaining them in 53 states.

2.) The morale of the place is very encouraging for the most part. Upper management really does well at maintaining a positive work environment that is uplifting for its employees.

3.) Benefits package is pretty spectacular if you stay for over a year.

4.) You take so many calls that you are forced to learn ALOT and FAST! It's very good if you don't have a finance background like myself.
cons:
1.) Low Pay
2.) Small Bonuses
3.) The micromanaging of call stats
4.) On the phone all day and since the company is the biggest in the financial industry the calls never stop coming. ever.

headline: The pay is okay. Its all about who you know.

Many in middle management are lifers and do not have strong education backgrounds. Most of the skills acquired are non-transferable. Leave once you get your series license.

Once in IR role, it's really ur luck whether position opens up and ur relationship with ur manager and your numbers compare to the rest of the IR ranks. (Have 8 yrs of exp) I don't need this crap...

headline: Too much middle management
pros: Company has good benefits, good work life balance, and is still privately owned
cons: The majority of middle and senior management basically just talk about stuff and are great at producing nice presentations.  The majority of people are like sheep and do not want to speak up.

headline: Outstanding opportunity to grow within the industry
pros: Culture is fantastic, ability to move outside of your role is encouraged. Training is second to none.

headline: Company with great benefits package gave little else in terms of advancement and innovation.
pros:
Benefits are great.
Investment platform is the cream of the crop.
Mutual funds given in managed accounts are truly the right ones for the client.
cons:
You have to be friends with the right people to advance.
The company makes it very difficult to find a job outside the call center.
Feedback from managers is a drag -- managers love to point out what you do wrong.
Management are a bunch of puppets who have to do what they're told.
Managers (and senior managers) don't fess up to their mistakes.
Trade Support is ruthless.

headline: Great way to get into the Finance industry
pros: Structured promotional path.  Hard workers are rewarded.  Licenses and training paid for.  Great benefits and plenty of other perks.
cons: No cons at this time.

headline: Unstable and irrational
pros: Pay for the area is high, easy to get into an entry level job.
cons: Constant policy, goal and upper management changes.  No work/life balance, always what can you do for me attitude.  uses its employees up and then spits them out.  Company promises the world and delivers nothing.  Company severances several times a year, only to expand and hire new people at lower pay.

headline: Customer Management Representative
pros: The culture is the best of any company for which I have ever worked.  They truly care about their employees and their customers -- It is not just lip service like at so many companies.
cons: Working in a call center the schedule is regimented, but it does make the day go fast.

headline: Moving IT jobs out of Boston
pros: Some great people have gone through the doors at Fidelity.  Fidelity has traditionally invested heavily in technology and smart people.
cons: Unfortunately the company is relocating its IT jobs out of Boston and loosing its talent base and domain knowledge in the process.  The company is currently focused on cost cutting and outsourcing rather than talent retention.   A large inventory of legacy applications is a drag on innovation and its IT budget.  More cost effective products from competitors, such as ETFs, threatening their business model.

headline: Fidelity
pros: Associates are encouraged to work independently and think creatively.  Asd would be expected, the firm is conservative.  Open to new ideas.  Opportunity to make a career.
cons: Because the company is so large, jobs at some firms have been split among more than one associate at Fidelity.  It sometimes feels difficult to cut through the red tape and get things done.

headline: Need to be a Brown Noser
pros: Decent benefits overall but more expensive than other firms in the industry. You will learn a lot if you know nothing about the business to begin with.
cons: Overcrowded, work area is smaller than an elementary school desk. Advancement is based on arbitrary targets and how much networking you can fit into your 30 min lunch. Previous education, experience and overall ability matter very little and can be detrimental as everybody starts in the same place. The entire organization has a culture where they have customers and most employees believing they are all about service and not profit.

headline: Gave my all to a company that didn't give it back.
pros: The salary for entry-level associates is great and there are a lot of benefits given to the employees
cons: Fidelity's quality and effectiveness goals have been increased steadily so that even one misspelled word, missed punctuation, or keeping a client on hold more than 30 seconds can cause you to get written up. Also there's hardly ever openings for promotions.

headline: Typical Call Center
pros: Beautiful building, casual Fri, special occasion snacks, thorough training
cons: Call center cons: logging in/out on time, breaks at odd times, mandatory OT

headline: Customer first mentality in a financial services firm
pros: Great retirement benefits, great work/life balance
cons: Ongoing regionalization away from Boston

headline: Great starter company
pros:
Great Benefits Package
Training 
Starter company. Once you get training and experience look elsewhere for promotions
cons:
Compensation is fairly low so start here get trained and move on.
Employee development
Most moves in the company are lateral in pay.
No room for growth
Culture has been tainted in recent years. Everyone is out for self.

headline: Fast pace, past learning
pros: Flexible scheduling, great gyms and equipment, outdoor courts for volleyball and basketball, great track around the site to walk or run.
cons: The bus schedule is too long.

headline: Good Company
pros: Pleasant work environment, good compensation
cons: Overtime often required, hard to schedule vacation time

headline: Great company, but improve the career path and pay.
pros: Excellent work environment! Manager/Employee relationship is on the same level. Work well with outside schedule. Very customer focused vs sales focused.
cons: Lacks a healthy, competitive work environment. Lack of frequent communication from top management. If your "brand" is damaged, you will be stuck in your roll. Rigid career path; you cannot necessarily skip ahead even if you are experienced.

headline: No merit increase in salary this year
pros: Fairly good job security considering the economy
cons: Not well paid for what I do

headline: Very corporate culture, great benefits and pay, lots of bloat
pros:
Excellent 401K matching, but you're not fully vested until you hit your five years. Very good pay and benefits. 

Culture depends on the division you're in -- I used to work in Strategic Advisers, Inc. (later rolled up into Asset Allocation) and the majority of the people that I worked with in that group were incredibly nice and smart. I'd heard not-so-great things about some of the other divisions at Fidelity, though, so I counted myself fortunate. Compared to the other floors in my building (245 Summer St), my floor was relatively casual and the floor plan was more open -- large half-cubes instead of the cube farms at the Smithfield, RI campus. Because I worked on a floor with portfolio managers and other members of investment management, we also got nicer drinks in the fridge.

I also had a very kind and nurturing manager and a good team.
cons:
Even within the division that I worked in, there were a few deadweights -- people who had made it to middle management after being at the company for 15+ years and were really just complacent and there for the paycheck. Those people were always a drag to work with; fortunately, I was able to minimize my dealings with them and usually partnered with the research and investment teams, who were filled with smart, driven people.

One other con was that it IS a big corporation, so change does come fairly slowly, and there are constant re-orgs and re-branding initiatives, which can get a bit difficult to keep track of. It can also be hard to get things done in an efficient manner because there are always a million stakeholders on each project.

headline: Good company to work
pros: Good work culture, good work life balance, good hike every year
cons: opportunities for learning is limited

headline: Fidelity was THE place to be years ago but has gone downhill the past 6-7 years
pros: great people to work with. recreational facilities are fun for sports leagues. nice walking grounds and nice rural location.
cons: instability of job. constant relocations of jobs going to Texas drives morale down.

headline: Phenomenal Company
pros: The best benefits I've seen. Great training. Many opportunities for career advancement. Fun working environment.
cons: Income ceiling is lower than most financial firms.

headline: Vibrant, strong firm, may be drifting from historically strong investment values
pros: An energetic, vibrant firm, drawing very bright people and giving them incredible resources to do the job.  Offers numerous opportunities and career paths.
cons: Historically strong dedication fiduciary values is softening.  Asset gathering and internal politics are eroding strong values.  Middle manager quote:  "This is not a meritocracy."

headline: It's all about the phones!!
pros: Great training, and good job benefits
cons: Extreme micromanaging, not transparent about the actual role you take on.

headline: Good compensation, work-life balance. Bureaucracy and favoritism take a toll.
pros:
1) Good compensation as compared with peers
2) Great work-life balance - excellent place for employees with family commitments
3) Flexibility to move within the organization
cons:
1) Bureaucracy across levels, especially support functions frustratingly slow down day-to-day tasks
2) Growth within the organization is a strong function of favoritism and tenure within the organization - talent and capabilities be damned
3) Lacks purpose - sometimes feels like a government organization; little or no communication from senior management about strategy goals and organizational challenges

headline: Investments Representative
pros: Better work environment than my previous employer.  Good benefits and most people are nice.
cons: Poor management.  Managers constantly favor their friends over more qualified people when it comes to promotions.

headline: Amazing experience with the company
pros: The quality of the experience is good
cons: Lengthy Works hours and poor mid level management

headline: Great Company
pros: Great Benefits. I love this company
cons: Sometimes the work is very intense.

headline: Short sighted
pros: Excellent talented people.  Great benefits and training opportunities.  Good company to start your career with.
cons: Company has frequent RIFs just small enough to not attract media attention.  New England is not strategic unless your company is headquartered here.  Dedication and loyalty are not rewarded.  Paltry merit increases.

headline: Excellent
pros: Great company, excellent benefits and work environment
cons: Low starting salary, random shift assignment

headline: Great Company to Start and Finish a Career
pros:
Great benefits, especially retirement savings.  $1 for $1 dollar match on first 7% plus annual profit sharing contribution which has always been 10% of compensation.

Since the company is private, management is not working quarter to quarter.  

Fidelity offers a wide range of job roles.
cons:
The company can be on the conservative side.  
Weak internal employee development.
Weak middle management.
Outside local investor centers, Fidelity has only a handful of campuses.

headline: good
pros: we can learn a lot about markets
cons: its all depend on how you take it.

headline: Cushy jobs, but not an IT industry leader
pros: Great office facilities. Good benefits. A pro and a con, the office is empty at 5pm, literally. Good if you've got kids, bad if you're a workaholic. The company belongs to the Johnson family so you don't have the "make the quarter numbers or bust" attitude you'll find at publicly traded firms.
cons: Sparse vacation, only 15 days a year. Company is constricting, merit raises were half of inflation across the IT groups this year. Technologies used internally are well behind the leading edge and well behind peer institutions.

headline: Like most very large companies, it's very hit or miss.
pros: Fidelity is actually a bunch of smaller companies. If you're in FIMT or one of the trading companies, you're going to have amazing benefits, great pay, even free Cokes, Izze's, and cappuccinos in the break rooms. If you have a good manager, the sky could be the limit when it comes to advancement and opportunities. They do generally take very good care of their people.
cons: If you're not in FIMT or one of the trading companies, you wear the badge, but don't necessarily have the good pay or benefits, and you can expect to pay dearly at the cafeteria. Fidelity's companies are VERY siloed, so if you want to advance from one group to another and don't know someone there, or your manager doesn't have strong connections, you are actually at a disadvantage to outsiders trying for the same position. If you aren't under a good, well-connected manager, expect to slave at your current role forever.

headline: Felt Like Being in the Military
pros: Great reputation with solid financials to support the company. Good ethics.
cons: Too many layers and too difficult to get things done.  Also, too many people in upper managment are more concerned about the status quo than thinking outside the box.  Effectively, the company makes money by sheer inertia not because of creative thinking on the part of management.

headline: Nice collegaues
pros:
Equal opportunity company
Less politics
Decent benefits
cons:
Losing good work
Management become worse

headline: Amazing company to work for
pros: Fidelity is a great place to start your career in the financial services industry.    They will take you in, get you licensed, teach you all of the fundamentals, instill great work ethic in you, and always encourage career development.  And with how spread out the company is, you can essentially work anywhere and know you'll have a great job with great people.  The pay is ok, but the benefits are amazing which is truly what helps you setup your retirement savings.  They offer 401(k) match and profit sharing, and that all adds up quickly.  Many people spend their entire working careers at Fidelity.
cons:
There aren't a lot of cons other than some of the people--a lot of middle management can be extremely obnoxious with inflated heads & egos, and they are also the ones who somewhat control your career, besides yourself, of course.  
Fidelity is way too conservative too, which can also be a 'pro.'  And their compliance policies are some of the strictest you'll see anywhere.  
They need to show their employees how much they value them with better pay--a lot of the positions deserve to be paid a bit more for the hard work that is expected, but again, it's hard to complain about that b/c of everything else that is positive about the company.  
Even with its cons, I would recommend Fidelity to anyone who is a solid, sharp, hard working, & committed worker.

headline: Policies only apply to some.....
pros:
Great pay and benefits
Great team outings when there is funding in the budget
cons: Policies are only enforced for some employees.... others can do whatever they please!

headline: Plan sponsor marketing
pros: Great benefits including 401k match, bonus, and in-house health & wellness center.
cons: Jobs and departments may be moved to different states -- depending on current need to meet state tax break requirements.

headline: It Screwed my Happiness
pros: I really did not see any advantage
cons:
Above all Pros only if you get into a good team.
More of bureaucracy. Just like a democratic law system. People who knows the management best will take advantage.
Politics here and there. 'Be as Roman while you are in Rome' perfectly applicable. Experienced new joiners will have a tough time.
They have a weird dress code where they decide the length of dress for girls, the material to be worn.

The worst was they even told us in induction how to wash clothes. It was a bizarre experience for me when I had gone there with good work experience. They are never ready to take any feedback and the hr mostly gets hostile and uses cheap language if you try to give feedback.

headline: Amazing company that actually takes care of their own.
pros: Extremely competitive pay and benefits. Paid training. Company actually practices what they preach when they say they balance employees, clients, and the firm.
cons: Working for a large corp means sometimes your interests can get lost in the infrastructure, but its easy to get lost at any big company. Fidelity goes a long way to try and make you comfortable.

headline: Just another BPO
pros: Its all process oriented, so if you are good at following orders and maintaining the company policies with no questions asked, you may have a go.
cons: Very orthodox and not employee happy place

headline: It is a very good company to work
pros: Work Environment is very good. It will create coordination between the employees
cons: I don't have any idea regarding this.

headline: Great firm to start financial services careers
pros: Tons of support, great leadership, plenty of room for career growth.
cons: You can feel a bit micromanaged in certain roles.

headline: Balanced Review
pros: Good life work balance and flex time. Benefits are good but not what they used to be. Business casual dress code with jeans on Friday.
cons: Upper management often makes changes or asks staff to participate in projects. These changes and projects have an obvious negative effect on staff ability to get their "regular jobs" done. First line management is required to support these changes and generally does not support staff. There are too many power hungry, hostile managers at all levels.

headline: G
pros: Work-life balance, professionalism, stability, very generous retirement, very good other benefits (health, life, disability insurance).  Lots of opportunities around other parts of the company,
cons: Big company means many layers between you and decision-makers.  Not growing quickly, so growth, though good, not as good as if it were a faster-growing company.  Salaries not very high.

headline: Good challenging and rewarding experience
pros: Good scope of work, opportunities and good people to work with.High end technology available and opportunities to excel are there.
cons: Bureaucracy, managers not backing employees and more ruled by client feedback

headline: Great Company but primarily phone based interactions with overbearing emphasis on tracking every number possible
pros: Great pay and benefits, good for career start
cons: Way too focused on phone based metrics - bonuses based largely on emailed client surveys and excessively tracked metrics - phone jobs are 100% phone based so no break to do other duties

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Great Benefits, Company really does want to take care of its clients, and the people you work with are great.
cons: Pay is not great compared to industry average, not exciting, some managers are very mediocre, it is very difficult to get recognized by upper management. very tall corporate structure.

headline: Best place I ever worked. So far ...
pros:
Great work environment. Promotes advancement, continued learning, and a healthy social work environment. Compensates well for the employees that work hard to make the company successful. 

Pay was on the higher end of competitive work. We had potlucks and team meetings. I always felt like I could talk to any of the managers. Sometimes we would go to 7 eleven for treats like little kids. I met several life long friends there and that really made it a worthwhile place to work.
cons: The financial industry isn't really my thing. So I don't really have any cons for my time with fidelity.

headline: Great for competitive, motivated professionals
pros: Consistent bonuses, merit based, occasional voluntary time off
cons: Heavy metrics goals like handle time and lead generation.  High pressure at times.

headline: Institutional Trade Support
pros: It is a very fast pace role with hundreds of phone calls and trade issues need to be addressed on the daily basis. Such environment is good for a entry level individuals who would like to establish his/her career in trading. The team that I worked with are fabulous individuals with great industry knowledge and years of experience.
cons: Since it is family own, you really have to play politics well to survive and move up. There are individuals in the management team that are really not suitable for their roles while others that are really capable got ouster after losing the political fight. Also Fido's salary is kind of lag behind the industry, so do expect getting paid a little less than the peers.

headline: Nothing lasts forever
pros: The first 8-10 of my 16 years were good.  Work was challenging but rewarding.  New ideas and approaches were encouraged.  Teams of talented, hard working professionals defined the company.  Employees were told that they were the number one asset.
cons: Too much focus on process and too little on work that added value to the firm.  Offshoring and dumping people in Texas has eliminated nearly every tech job in Boston;  any honest audit of the 'site strategy' will show that it has been an ill-conceived disaster.  The costs are much higher and very little is getting done.

headline: Workload is tough
pros: Good people, good benefits, generous 401k
cons: Metrics seem to be off, workload is often tough to keep up with

headline: Overall Job
pros: 40 hours, once you leave work you have no worries.  Good culture, a lot of opportunity to move up quickly
cons: Phone job, but can move out of phone role if you work hard and want to

headline: Borderline discriminatory management. Mediocrity at its worst!
pros: Nice campus, free coffee, free parking. Quarterly appreciation event with cupcakes and games.
cons: No career. Politics counts for 90%, which hurts the evolution of projects and deliverables. Improvisation, lack of leadership skills, and management that plays favorites, not with those that contribute the most, or who do the best for the company, but those who kiss the boss's behinds more often. People will often take credit for your deliverables, and will also blame you for their mistakes and snafus. Performance reviews are a joke in all areas of the company, and the employee has no chance of refuting the facts. Management is often clueless, and worse, it often lies about status of projects, impacts, deadlines, or deliverables. Everybody is a VP. The less degrees you have, and the more bs you can talk, the better.

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Easy Series 7 training.  The benefits are pretty decent.
cons:
Phones, phones, phones, phones.... get the picture?

This job is mundane at the core.  Every single task is repetitive.  It is a constant stream of taking glorified service calls over and over, with the same requests again and again.  

There is very little outside opportunities, or work responsibilities.  

Managers are nothing but micro-managing and just want to see themselves go up the ladder.

All promotions are just another form of phone job in a service or sales related role.

How many times do you have to explain rules of IRA distribution before you go insane?

headline: Good culture
pros: Great culture, great people, great benefits.
cons: Pay is not that great

headline: Constant grind
pros:
- Great benefits
- Good learning experience in the financial services industry
- Leave work at work..no stress when out of work
cons:
- Sit in a cube all day..constant grind
- Prepare to be attatched to a phone all the time besides 2 measly 15 min breaks and a lunch
- Glorified customer service
- Managers for the most part are self appointed by who the upper managers "like" and shouldnt be managers...everything is delegated like this from upper management, down
- Forced to work OT because they don't hire enough people

headline: Awesome company
pros: The benefits are great and the corporation really knows how to treat its employees. I have been working at a branch with about 20 other advisors and everyone has been extremely supportive of one another and helpful.
cons: I have only been working for the company for about 9 months and so far I haven't noticed anything I don't like about the company.

headline: Great Company & Benefits!
pros: The training program is very effective and the benefits were great!  Lots of opportunities for overtime which was time & a half. Quarterly bonuses were nice!
cons: Its a call center, you are on the phone 24/7.  Would be nice if there were alternative ways to get off the phone and do work.  Very strict, micro-managed. compensation is lower than expected.

headline: Micro management, double standards, and politics reign supreme.
pros:
~401k and profit sharing are excellent. 
~Education reimbursement. Will pay 90% of CFP certification.
~Health benefits are good, but a bit expensive, and in order to reduce the expense quarterly, you must engage in an online "wellness" program.
~High volume business allows for lots of opportunities to hone in your investment and retirement planning skills.
cons:
We are hired for our past successes in planning, sales and relationship management, but then mircro managed and questioned for every single action beyond belief. It is hard to work here and maintain a sense of self respect and dignity! 
~Phone calls are listened-in on by management, and then your conversation with an existing elderly client is called in to question, like, why did you waste 5 minutes talking to her, continuing to build that "relationship", and looking up the status of the TOA for her, when you simply could have forwarded her to the call center cust service team? Seriously? Every rep in my branch has suffered a similar type of encroachment.
~Management will occasionally either sit in to observe an appointment, or they will have you dial their extension and listen remotely from their office phone. It is an arbitrary and random decision as to which appointments they "join", but really, nothing shakes the confidence of a HNW prospect more than thinking the advisor they are here to see is undergoing some sort to management oversight!! It doesn't matter how well the manager justifies it to the prospect, they are thinking, "run"!! Every rep in my branch has suffered a failed appointment due to this hideous micro-management.
~Fidelity preaches the relationship model, putting the customer needs first, holistic financial planning, blah blah, then really only cares about what products you "sold" to each client. Management is very very short-sighted. An appt where you meet with a multi-million $ prospect preparing for retirement in a few months, building the relationship, developing trust, laying ground work for all future wealth planning, is not regarded as a successful appointment or very good use of your time, because it did not result in actual "business" today.
~Fidelity is bombarding their clients with a never-ending barrage of email, mail, just non-stop marketing, all on the S/AE behalf, which drives most clients absolutely nuts.
~They only care about whether or not you are completing the menial "tasks", like clicking all the appropriate buttons in siebel. You are tracked and watched and measured on every single little thing you can imagine. How many clicks you clicked. How many times you dialed out...And all your numbers that are tracked are not only to ensure you are being a busy little bee, but the manager is rated on how many little clicks and menial tasks his/her advisors are doing. It's really all about how to make the manager look good to his/her manager!
~Management at the branch level is extremely lame. They want to treat you like a child, and keep you fearful, knowing every little move is being tracked and watched. Like I said, it is hard to maintain a sense of dignity and self respect in an environment like this. Those who can brown nose management, and are otherwise spiteful, political and backstabbing (to fellow colleagues) do well here. Success is: just tell management what they want to hear, and slam clients into products to satisfy management... Those with little talent and integrity stay, endure, and ultimately get promoted, perpetuating the bad leadership. They stay, put up with the games, and endure because they realize they could not make it anywhere else (except, perhaps, on a used car lot). Those with talent, integrity and truly good planning skills leave for a saner environment. 
~Clients in the S/AE book are very frustrated by the fact that every time they get assigned a new S/AE, and they happen to like that advisor and feel that they are working with someone with knowledge and integrity, that advisor ends up leaving. They keep getting turned over, until ultimately, they will end of in the book of one of the talentless, low-integrity bozos that never leave, or, they will just TOA out of Fido.
~Management, by their own admission, have never worked in our S/AE role as it is currently designed. The "relationship" model is relatively new, and as reps, they only served customers that were fed to them by the "green machine" on a transactional, not relationship, model. I think that disconnect helps explain the double standard; why they focus on tracking/forcing transactional business while falsely preaching relationship development. They like to talk about how successful "they" were in the role...but yeah, if all I had to do was take inbound calls and leads, roll the assets over and slap the client in PAS, funds, and/or FILI, then just move on to the next one with no follow up or relationship accountability...well, heck, any moron could do that.

headline: The Financial Representative is technically like a Pledge to a Fraternity/Sorority you have to swallow your dignity.
pros: Benefits, great training, company gets you up to speed fast, helps attain licenses.  Can pay for further schooling.  This is a great job to enter right out of college.  The pay is good enough.  Just get out of it as quick as you can, as it beats you down once the aura of the new job wears off.
cons: You are responsible for the whole office even though you typically are the least experience person in the office.  It's a great way to learn, but also a great way to have employees above you dislike you if you make a mistake.  The position can be quite demeaning as you order lunches for associates above you and will be treated like a secretary on numerous occasions throughout the week.  You are ordered around more so than any other employee in the office.  You are responsible for the whole office, but all the other employees are responsible just for themselves so you can get pulled many ways at once to keep people happy and of course, this typically will not help you be happy.

headline: Fidelity Investments IT Application Support
pros: Great working environment, latest technologies.
cons: Sharing knowledge with other team members.

headline: Specialist on QA/QC
pros: you can find the best working envoronment
cons: Top mangement you need not comment about:)

headline: I wouldn't work there.
pros: Competitive compensation, people I work with are pretty nice.
cons: Under staff, poor leadership at the Sr. level.  There is a disconnect between Sr. Mgt with front-line staff.  Stupid decisions are made without explanation and logic that impacts staff in a negative way.  People are working really long hours to compensate for their decisions.

headline: Overall good company only thing they make you in little nervous by doing the re-org every now and then.
pros: Work culture is good. Colleagues and top management are good.

headline: Product Manager
pros: fast-paced challenging environment, for those in TX or NC the opportunities are greater.  People are awesome but changing due to relocation out of NE.
cons: there is too much change.  Relocations out of New England and reorgs make getting your job done a challenge.  New talent trying to learn.

headline: Heavy bureaucracy, low salary and slow personal growth
pros: One of the best names in asset management and brokerage. Great customer facing brand that people recognize.
cons: Don't treat employees fairly. Hard working and value adding employees are the last in line.

headline: It is a great place to work
pros: You will be surrounded by smart people

headline: Horrible experience

cons: Very salesy, lots of red tape, very limited career potential outside of sales

headline: Nothing technical, cool job
pros:
Flexible timings and work from home.
Not much pressure as most business runs during US working hours.
People stick here for long term as not much work pressure.
Best place to settle down if not interested in learning for rest for the life.
Increments and bonus on par with industry standards.
Free cab.
cons:
Not much technical work.
No technical training given.
Mostly production/maintenance work.
Strict dress code.

headline: The best company ever I worked with. Fidelity Investment is one of the best employer in the world.
pros: The employees, who are very professional and the Company policies which impressed me a lot.
cons: As this in not a services based company like wipro, infy, tcs, there is nothing cons to say

headline: Very great company to work for.
pros: Great benefits, opportunities to get securities licenses
cons: Very slow development plan. Most representatives start out at in customer service roles regardless of prior experience with other organizations.

headline: Low class working culture for operations

headline: Awesome place to start a career
pros: The integrity, trust, honesty, benefits, stability, training, opportunities and people. Incentive to work hard and move up in the company. Learning new things every day. This is the best place to work for and I want to have a long career at Fidelity Investments.
cons: If you are working at one of the biggest, most successful, most stable financial companies in the world that offers the best benefits in the industry and gives unparalleled training, how could you find something to complain about?

headline: LET ME JUST SAY THIS "IT'S A GAME WHERE EVERYTHING IS MADE UP AND THE POINTS DON'T MATTER"
pros: 401k is good but don't let them manage it PAS w ok benefits

headline: fidelity is a well organized company that won't surprise you at both direction

headline: Fantastic company with great work/life balance
pros:

headline: GREAT foot in the door
pros: This is a great company to start off with.  Excellent training (biggest pro I would say), great team atmosphere and great benefits
cons: The double-edged sword for the great benefits is very low pay and right now there is a very low cap for raises - mostly because businesses are tightening their budget. There is a lack self-improvement.  No recognition for performance or improvements as meeting the status quo only matters.  You're only recognized if you have a negative perception.

headline: Learn valuable concepts, but no long term career path.
pros: Profit sharing plan and insurance is amazing.
cons: Pay sucks. Managers are horrible. The management sees employees as replaceable (even those that exceed expectations). It's all about how many calls you can answer. They literally schedule your pee breaks. It's ridiculous. Unless you are in an investment center or in Boston, your career will go no where!

headline: I enjoy working here.
pros: It is a great place to work and has great benefits.
cons: Not all dept. are treated equal.

headline: Great work place and good reputation
pros: Good cab service, employee friendly, Can learn financial services domain
cons: stressful prod support , middle management

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Managers offered good feedback.  Adequate opportunity for upward mobility and there was an overall great compensation package.
cons: Unfortunately lots of career change and upward mobility is about who you know, but feedback is honest.

headline: Overall a good company with good training, nice people, and pleasant environment.
pros: Chance to earn some small bonuses during the quarter and at year's end.  Company would show appreciation by catering food for employees from various restaurants during tax season.  Obtained Series 7 and 63 registrations.  Worked with a good group of people.  Learned a lot via training and by being on the phone all day with customers from all 50 states.  No take home work.  Able to leave the job behind each day at market close.
cons: Worked was mundane.  Even as a Trader, one is stuck in a cubicle all day with a headset on shagging phone calls.  Listening to abusive and ignorant customers gets old real quick.  Little room for advancement.  Company is big on looks.  You won't land an Advisor position in one of the retail investment centers unless you look like a Ken doll.

headline: Excellent organization - truly a customer centered business model.
pros: I had a great manager who gave me latitude to get things done.  Lots of opportunity to pave your own path to success.
cons: very competitive, which is a double edge sword.  politics are a bit thick

headline: Good environment
pros: Decent benefits, good work environment
cons:
Since about 2008, the company has been looking for ways to sharpen their pencils and cut costs at any opportunity.  Despite a positive market and improving business, it does not seem that there is an end in sight.

Employees in New England are increasingly the red headed step children with most opportunity being relocated to NC and Dallas.

headline: Great Entry Level Job to Get Licensed
pros: Insurance and benefits, flexible time off, series 7 training program
cons: One person grades all your calls, the metrics of handle time can be tough to meet if someone isn't knowledgeable on investing, advancement potential limited, more of who you know than what you know. A phone is a phone whether you are in service or a specialty team.

headline: Great place
pros: The people are great. I enjoyed working with smart people. The people are great. I enjoyed working with smart people.
cons: Too much beauracracy. Too much beauracracy. Too much beauracracy. Too much beauracracy.

headline: Good company, beware of politics
pros: Interesting projects, products that make a difference
cons: Politics.  This is normal in companies of this size but it seems to be more apparent as of late.

headline: Solid Company
pros: Good pay and perks. Technology and exercise reimbursement. Good company culture. Excellent training program for Series 7. Active management. The company is huge so lots of room for advancement. Best profit sharing and retirement match of any company I have worked for.
cons: It's a never ending avalanche of calls. Trading phones can be tough. This kind of job is not for everyone. Can feel robotic at times.

headline: Always challenging, the changes keep you on your toes, great folks to work with!
pros: Great benefits, flexibility ( telecommute etc), good knowledge base, access to a variety of learning resources.
cons: bit of politics, confusion sometimes around the direction of technology within the company!

headline: Retirement Solutions Representative
pros: The benefits are outstanding.  Great licensing programs.
cons: Business units operate in silos.  Hard to move up if you start in a phone role.  Senior management is disconnected from representatives.  One year requirement to stay in a phone role each time you change positions.  Six sick days per year and only 4 weeks vacation time no matter how long you have been with the firm.  Technology is outdated and they layer applications on top of old platforms.  Signifcant barrier to doing your job effectively.

headline: Mixed experiences based on department, managers do not heed management guidelines, and coworkers hostile to newcomers
pros: Excellent benefits and if you happen to be young enough to have a family there is quite a bit of flexibility regarding needs relating to school, etc. Some organizations reward proactive employees well and goals and expectation are clear and consistent. This is a company that strives for continual improvement in most areas and works hard to reward employee engagement.
cons: Depending on the job and organization, management communication can be poor or non-existent. There is virtually no on-boarding for new hires and new hires are treated badly by colleagues. You have to have a very thick skin and be willing to stand your ground in the face of some rude treatment. The environment can be quite stressful and some department management seems almost proud of the level of stress. When interviewing be sure to ask about the group's culture rather than the whole company's culture. Performance reviews can be problematic with some management teams. Most divisions require mangers to work with direct reports to establish goals and objectives. Some groups ignore this requirement and reviews can be based on the opinions of co-workers rather than on actual substantive performance measures.

headline: Best company I've worked for.
pros: Great benefits and focus is for sure on clients number 1 and employees 2.  The company is privately owned and is ran very efficiently.   If you perform your job well you will have opportunities to get promoted.
cons: Some micro management, not a lot of schedule flexibility, low pay.

headline: Relationship Manager
pros: Great co-workers, the pay is decent if you dont mind the work
cons: Company doesn't really care about you. You are just another cog in the machine

headline: Good place to begin a career, but not a place to stay
pros: People move around a lot so there are plenty of chances for opportunities.
cons: The managers tend to micro-manage a lot.  The managers will do anything to get ahead even if that means making others look bad.  The employees are treated like a commodity, meaning if you cannot do it I will have no trouble finding a replacement.  Employees tend to be paid below market value.

headline: EVERYBODY IS A VP
pros: they made me vice president to travel all over
cons: EVERYONE IS A VP AT THE COMPANY

headline: Great place to get securities licenses & learn the brokerage business
pros:
Fidelity has a great program and support to ensure that over 90% of their customer service reps get their Series 7 and Series 63 plus they pay you while you are studying.  After getting their licenses, the Financial Reps then get to use what they learn and more importantly, what they didn't learn, about the real world thru a series of graduated positions covering more complex environments.:  Mutual Fund trader, Stock trader, then Full Trader (options, IPO's, etc.).

 Also the people at Fidelity (Westlake at least) are great to work with.  They are smart, personable, and care about doing a good job.  The management team is also good and works to accommodate personal needs (e.g., medical conditions, personal conditions).

 The fact that Fidelity is privately owed gives it more flexibility to try new things that will payoff longer term.
cons:
1.  You need to be comfortable with having everything that you say and do being monitored.  Al your phone calls, transactions, emails, chats are monitored due to compliance and also for coaching and management evaluation.  You are also supposed to document all your customer interactions in Siebel.
2.  You also need to be cognizant about your time/work schedule.  Your calls will be timed, your breaks/off phone time, etc.  This is a call center; productivity and adequate coverage are important.
3.  Creativity and working/thinking outside of the box is discouraged.  Procedures are defined for everything.  If you get caught not following, you will be coached/reprimanded to do so.  E.g., when a new procedure was introduced on how to verify callers, it was gosh-awful that clients and  us financial reps were complaining.  Despite the feedback, we were told to keep with the new procedures. The President of our division came for a visit a couple of months later and sat in on some customer calls.  She told the management that the verification procedures were awful and to fix it.  It had to wait for the tops down to make a common sense change? People & managers are rewarded for being good soldiers, not wild ducks.

headline: Awesome
pros: Very professional work environment where a lot of encouragement is given across all levels.
cons: Being in the financial services space, the organization is very conservative in several ways which is not exactly a downside, but some of the young workforce felt that way.

headline: A Lot Like High School

Attitude of most employees. is is to get what they can out of Fidelity because Fidelity is not going to do much for them.  Huge amounts of expertise were  let go (ie, senior subject matter experts, IT people) in past five years to reduce salary costs;  now is literally hard to find people who understand the business they work in.  Company communications to employees are of the rah-rah We are Great! sort.  Compensation levels are below industry standards.  A policy of no promotions for past seven years or so for mid and senior IT people adds to dissatisfaction.

headline: Great Benefits, Phones Exhaust You

Great place to start a career
Good benefits
Good colleagues
Beautiful campuses

Low pay compared to other companies in the industry

headline: Highly political, bureaucratic environment
pros: Fitness reimbursement; online training courses
cons:
You're position is not "confirmed" until after your 1 year anniversary but HR does not tell you that, until then, watch your back, they will look for ways to make your life miserable enough to make you want to quit or give an excuse you don't deserve a bonus.  Full of bureaucracy, unless you're in the "in" crowd, you're pretty much on your own.
The workplace is like the Olympics, employees compete with each other to reach the gold medal, Don't expect you will get the kind of support you need from your peers or manager, it's not for the faint hearted.

headline: Great Co-Workers and Growth Potential
pros:
- My co-workers are amazing people. Everyone is very friendly, outgoing, and generally positive. I look forward to seeing them every day and miss them on the weekends!
- The training is bar none. They give you extensive training to pass the Series 7 and 63 exams, making it almost impossible for you to fail, and every new skill set you master is accompanied by at least a week of intense training. 
- The work environment is very pleasant. My desk is very spacious, the break rooms are well stocked, and we have huge windows with views of the mountains.
- If you're willing to work hard and network with people, the growth potential for your career at Fidelity is unlimited.
cons:
- The pay is less than it should be. Considering the complexity and responsibility on our shoulders with all the regulations and rules, we should be paid much more than we are.
- Some managers exhibit favoritism towards employees who are clearly incompetent at their jobs but are likable people.
- The micromanaging of your schedule is obnoxious, but it's pretty standard in a call center environment.

headline: Very Good company to work
pros: Work Life balance is very good.Work from home helps in case of emergenices.
cons: Growth is stagnant as the company is not hiring

headline: Great place to begin a career in Financial Services
pros: Fidelity does a great job at teaching their employees the basics of financial services. Their benefits are some of the absolute best in the industry as well. 401k plan match is 7% dollar-for-dollar with profit sharing of 10%. Health plans are especially good. The pay is also fair for a discount broker. Ultimately, Fidelity is one of the best places to work in Financial Services, because they have a long tradition of placing top priority on the customer experience. The Johnsons are good people who truly value their customers and their employees. When you are coached, it will be to whether or not the customer's needs were met, not whether you were able to sell them on an inappropriate product. Even working in sales, I always made more money off great customer surveys than I ever did due to sales results (although sales results are important as well). Lastly, the company is very conservative on a number of different topics. You are very unlikely to become involved in litigation working for Fidelity, because they stay as far away from "the line" as possible. Also, due to their conservative nature, FIdelity tends to be a safe place during times of layoffs unless you work in middle management.
cons:
As great as Fidelity is, they are not without fault. Many negative things that I can say about Fidelity, I can also say for other firms as well. The Johnsons are good people. They do a great job at spreading their gospel of customer service, but sometimes the message is lost on middle-management. Middle-management tends to stress too much on day-to-day figures such as Sales, number of calls taken, and the "customer experience indicator" (surveys) rather than focusing on the actual interactions that reps are having with customers. 
Managers (especially in sales) also tend to not be entirely clear on what they expect from their employees. My opinion is that this is done intentionally, because they know that they can't coach you to sell something inappropriate that makes them look better on a piece of paper, but oftentimes, they won't call you out on it either if you do in fact do just that. 
Like most big firms, Fidelity can be bureaucratic in many of their operations. The main problem (which is a good problem to have) is that Fidelity is a leader in Employee retirement plans such as 401(k)'s and 403(b)'s and a leader in personal investments such as IRA's. These are technically two separate companies, but under one roof under one name. I've worked in both sides of the house, and it can be annoying to go back and forth with colleagues on the other side of the fence who have these incorrect preconceived notions about your side of the firm. It's exhausting, but it's part of working for a big company. 
Technology is one of the biggest headaches. I can honestly say that while Fidelity invests billions of dollars into technology, much of this is to improve the website. Don't get me wrong, we have a great website for customers, but they don't spend nearly enough money trying to improve quality of life for the employees. Their systems are so complicated, it was almost always easier to tell the customer how to do transaction online rather than through a rep (which is probably what they're aiming for). Also, in this modern world of e-mail, skype, facebook, etc. Many of our employees are still unable to e-mail customers which would be fine if other firms kept the same policy. Other firms have changed with the times. While, I can say that Fidelity is "on their way." They've also been "on their way" to implementing e-mail correspondence for years now. I mentioned in the Pro's that they are conservative from a legal perspective. This is where some of the cons of being conservative come into play. 
Lastly, middle management is way too politically correct. It's annoying to many employees of all backgrounds. This especially rears its ugly head in the form of reverse discrimination. Being PC is fine as long as you continue to hire good people. Usually Fidelity does a good job in hiring the right people, but occasionally I've seen them compromise just to check a box that they're a diverse firm of employees. This can especially become annoying if you're looking to get promoted.

headline: Used to be a great company to work for, but is slipping and is now just mediocre.
pros:
- Benefits and compensation are still good (although not what they once were).
- The company still has good core values thanks to the Johnson family.
cons:
- Short-sighted leadership lurches to a new strategy every 12 months, eventually coming back full circle but wasting enormous amounts of money in the process.
- Disorganized and you'll have a new manager every 6-12 months.
- Your job is very likely to be relocated to another state, or off-shored to cheaper labor in another country.

cons: If you have EVER worked outside the firm before joining, you will be extremely surprised at some of the cultural differences.  You really have to drink the kool-aid and conform if you want to stay happy.  Really nice people, yet the firm is in a distinct identity crisis about who/what they want to be.  They can't seem to get passed the notion that if you want to have a "relationship" that means relationship, not buy  our products (proprietary funds, managed accounts and annuities)

headline: Phone sites good, branches bad
pros: Great benefits, excellent training and if you are working in one of the large sites, there is lots of opportunity for movement.  Pay isn't based on commission and Fidelity has a great pipeline for business so the leads come to you.
cons: Pay is lower than at other firms and the company is super conservative.  Guidance and recommendations will be based on tools with almost zero actual input from the financial reps themselves.  If you want to interact with clients, you'll either be on the phones or in a branch.  The branches have very little room for advancement and depending on the manager, can be very frustrating and demoralizing.  Average tenure for an Account Executive is less than a year due to attrition.

headline: Great in some areas, lacking in others
pros: Overall good benefits package: medical, dental, retirement. Medical insurance tends to be on expensive side, but coverage was good as well. Retirement benefits are awesome once you actually vest and are eligible for a match.
cons:
Work environment was lacking. Vacation days (15/year) were okay, but definitely not enough to reward for the amount of work and stress for employees. Amount of sick days (6/year) was absolutely horrendous. A family of 4, like my own, could eat up that amount of time in a matter of months, and I didn't even try to abuse the system.

The area most lacking was employee appreciation. They attempt to appreciate by focusing on some areas (i.e. generous retirement package, perq points, team competitions), but overall falls very short. 

The perq points are based on performance during quarterly competitions. I exceeded goals every competition, but received no more than equivalent of $60 each time. Those who didn't really try and wouldn't meet performance goals would still get about $40 each time. 

My team won about half of the site competitions among teams. We were a very good team. However, the rewards (usually a increase in budget based on head count) would get paid out months after the fact. When it actually did get paid out, for some reason we never seemed to have enough money to do anything fun anyway. Something was amiss in the entire process. Maybe it falls on our manager, maybe the site management. I don't know.

In my 529 college planning specialty role, recently more and more tasks were being added to our plate. It was as if they were using 529 was "Fidelity Special Forces." We took on the Canadian Remediation in the summer of 2012, started backing up PAS with their overflow toward the end of 2012, and gradually took more and more general service overflow. When I arrived, 529 had a seasonal workload where it was very heavy during some times of the year, and a little lighter at other times. When I left, we were constantly "lit" (meaning calls waiting to get through to us). Most calls we received were general service or something other than 529 calls. The 529 customers were being neglected because we couldn't provide them service in time.

The increased workload would have been fine by me if they would have done a few things:
1. Inform us in advance of how, why, and when the workload is increasing.
2. Provide an increase in compensation (or bonuses or something) since we were not originally hired to do the increased work.
3. Hire more employees to do the peon work of general service. Since they worked us a lot of overtime, you would think that it wouldn't cost as much to hire another employee with a lower salary than to pay me at time-and-a-half with my higher salary.

My last point of review on what was lacking at Fidelity is the career opportunities. Ultimately, EVERYONE needs to go the sales route to accomplish anything. All career paths on the service side reach dead-ends very quickly so employees are stuck with low salaries. My being a non-sales type of person, I realized very quickly that I needed to jump ship. Thankfully, I had the opportunity to take a job I had been wanting to do for a long time. I didn't even blink before I accepted the offer.

headline: It is What You Make of It
pros: Absolutely great place to start a career. 150+ hours paid study time with top notch resources to get Series 7 and 63 licenses. Roughly three months during first year of 8-5 classroom training to cover securities trading, compliance and investment basics. Profit sharing and 7% 401k match, after vesting get 4 weeks vacation time, 7 sick days, 1 personal day and all market holidays off. Company usually hires good people who are enjoyable to work around. If motivated, intelligent and have a good work ethic and interpersonal skills, it's realistic to go from starting salary to making really good money in 3 - 5 years if you follow the sales path. The work isn't particularly stressful and once you are seasoned there are a lot of different specialty paths to consider. Local senior management approachable and positive. Job security is very high. Company will cover almost the entire cost of an MBA or CFP.
cons: It is a phone job. How much of a "phone job" it is depends on the choices you make. The first year your pay won't be great and when you aren't in training, you'll be taking call after call from lowest tier customers while you learn the ropes. Service management at this level is hit and miss, and about 25% of the time you'll get a micro-manager with no people skills listening to your customer calls and telling you the "right" way to interact with other human beings. 100% of the time your breaks and lunches will be scheduled for you, your efficiency will be monitored and you'll feel like you are in grade school with bulletin boards to decorate, nonsensical "campaigns", dress down days etc. You can either choose to stay in this spot forever taking these horrible calls (which is the type of employee most of the negative reviews seem to come from) or take the steps to move on to better paying areas where you are treated like a professional adult and largely left alone and trusted to produce.

headline: Management deficiencies at every level.
pros: Good compensation and benefits.  Beautiful campus.
cons: Management skills are not measured or appreciated.  Position is more often political and based on who you know rather than qualifications.  Mismanagement has resulted in a entirely dysfunctional IT organization that is hobbled by a bizarre anti Microsoft sentiment that is supposedly present at the highest levels.  Company spends millions trying to integrate mismatched solutions rather than just adopting any single vendor.  Used to be a technology leader but is currently technology schizophrenic.   This company also used to develop its management leaders internally, those days have seemingly ended with recent management additions brought in form various other Wall Street firms.

headline: Good place to work overall, but experience can vary wildly depending on manager and group
pros: Great compensation package- higher than average salary for IT, excellent health benefits, good bonuses, matching 401k, profit-sharing, yearly raises plus the chance for extra money through "internal shares" (it is a private company).  Can be a great place to spend some time and get some good experience.
cons: It's big, and made up of very individual groups that rarely interact with each other.  If you're not careful, you can get lost.  Same politics as everywhere else, and middle-management turnover is huge.  New manager comes in and brings all his/her friends with them (at all levels).  That's pretty much expected here.  If you're not part of that "in" crowd, you're on the outside looking in.

headline: Overall, satisfied

Innovation encouraged
Flexible as regards working from home, coming in late/leaving early if something comes up
Reasonable deadlines... I do not generally need to work much beyond the standard 9-5 type hours to meet my deliverables
cons:
Salaries err on low side of competitive

You may end up on a team where none of the pros apply, especially the last one. Look to join a development team attached to a specific business function, rather than something like their Corporate Technology Group (which manages various services shared across the enterprise)... the "closer to the money" you are, the more you will be looked after.

headline: Place is a circus act and real investors should run away, fast!
pros: Great name brand that people seem to trust, for now. Free coffee. Well, that's about it folks.
cons: The mangers at the branch could care less about the clients and their assets. It is all about what the account executives are doing with the clients money. Get that money invested at all costs. Stick 'em in mutual funds, annuities or PAS managed program so they can charge them fees. Fidelity investors do not realize they are being duped by purchasing their no load funds. Why? Because their funds tend to have higher turnover ratios that in turn allow their fund managers to perform trades. This equates to significant trading costs that are not disclosable under current law. Investors only see the fund expenses and forget the hidden fees. Do you really think they are going to give good advixe and not be charging you anything people?  Really?  Furthermore, they treat their superstar higjly experienced people the same as the ones they are getting rid of. It's all about brown nosing at that place. Quality employees leave within 24 months. The bad ones stay because they cannot get hired anywhere else. Their micro management, cukture of fear and intimidation, and peanuts for pay make this place highly avoided by the top 10% of financial advisors from other firms.

headline: Great Company, Great Work Culture, Good pay

headline: Challenging environment, until they kick you out
pros: Good challenging work. If you thrive on pressure, this is good for you. You should be able to get opportunities to work on new and interesting tasks. Compensation is good - bonus and benefits.
cons: It seems that management learned to avoid plant-closing laws by phasing their layouts over time. From roughly 2009 through 2011, we would hear about a layoff at one business group or another on the first Tuesday of each month. Later in 2011 and 2012. there was a heavy push on "site strategy", where they were moving jobs out of Boston and other Northeast offices to Texas, North Carolina and offshore. Lots of disruption with that.

headline: Fidelity Review

headline: Filled with people who have been working there too long and are afraid to ever work anywhere else.
pros: Great 401k matching, year-end bonus & shares. Good health benefits. Some quality people still work there.
cons:
Comparatively low salary, unless you come in at a certain level. I was at Fidelity for several years -- in the beginning I was excited to be there, and I got great reviews and I moved up, and I did meet some really good people, so I thought there was a future there for me. But after seeing behind the curtain and realizing every part of the business was messed up, I jumped ship when the opportunity presented itself.

In every business unit I was in, I saw a shocking lack of leadership. Projects are started and stopped in a haphazard, wasteful way based on whichever direction the political wind is blowing. Projects take years to complete when they shouldn't, and sometimes things launch and then they are immediately discarded. Or subpar work -- the standards, when you are talking about technology or communications or design, are way too low for a company of this size and reputation -- is allowed to launch and is weirdly celebrated. The website is terrible, and the technology at Fidelity is frighteningly behind, yet they spend billions on it every year.

Many VPs (and there are oh-so-many) are afraid to say what they think, so naturally everyone underneath them is. People who move slowly and don't make waves are rewarded. People who suggest new ways to approach things are often viewed as threatening by people who have been sitting comfortably in their roosts for too long. Very little actual work gets done and I think Fidelity customers would be shocked to see how much money is wasted by this company on people who are paid way too much for producing way too little by the end of the year. Typically you'll see a business unit with a couple of overworked worker bees and several VPs who go to a lot of meetings but don't do much except talk at each other in meetings and try to figure out how to work the politics.

HR is obsessed with the upper echelon of management, and could care less about the employees. They'll drive themselves crazy over how some memo looks to Executive A or all the SVPs and meanwhile they put very little forethought into a relocation strategy that affects thousands of employees and will bite them in the long run. For example, how many future genius fixed income portfolio managers will sign up to work in Merrimack, New Hampshire when they can go to the competitors in New York or London? And how many dollars is this firm saving by outsourcing HTML work to India when the work takes three times as long to be completed because every single piece of it must be explained, checked, and then checked and requested three more times until it is correct (and each round takes 2 weeks)?

The word on the street is with the up-and-coming leadership regime, it's all about the yes-men, and there's no heart there. Some of the old benefits have already disappeared, and most of the people in the know expect that when the Chairman retires, his successor wants to get rid of things like the long-loved employee shares. Believe me, this will happen. 

This company loves layers, and insecure management lets incompetence reign in those layers -- especially directors and VPs -- because they can manipulate those employees or because they're too afraid to fire people who are in over their heads. Management and HR love to market to themselves internally.

Yet Fidelity will continue to make money in spite of this because it has reached a certain size in the marketplace. When I left, I took my money with me because after seeing how the sausage is made, this really isn't the best place to put your money. (Unless you are a high net-worth customer, they push you into the Freedom Funds, which are consistent underperformers.)

It's sad, because from what I understand from people who were there for a really long time, it used to be a really great company. This sentiment is heard around the firm, but I know a lot of people are afraid to leave because they're shackled to the benefits.

Life is short -- there are a lot of companies out there. If you're not overly committed to your kids' private schools or college tuitions, get the heck out while you still can. There is a world outside Fidelity.

headline: The big green line
pros: They have spent billions on the brand, and it worked, they spent billions on the tools, and they rock, the products are cheep and won't hurt anyone unless you lie to them in the sales process.
cons:
!Its a big company and if you are not aware of how you are perceived it could possibly hurt your chances to move up. This is not anything different from any other large company. To the people complaining about how they were passed over or done wrong, so sorry for you but getting ahead in life is about more than just how you think you did at your job, your bosses have feelings to and if you don't make them feel like they made a good decision (At any company) you will not get ahead. 

In terms of the people in call centers and computer programming roles, well it is probably tough to stick out from the thousands of other people, but it is still a great company and they don't really expect too much of you from a performance standpoint so why complain about it. Just do your job and try to improve.

headline: Great benefits, good starting pay,  great training program, decent incentives...
pros: Company fully trains and pays for you to get your financial licenses. Great health benefits. Company 401k match and profit share is good. Products and services offered by firm are great for customers. Offers tuition reimbursement and gym reimbursements. There are several different positions on the same level to move to within phone sites.
cons:
Micromanagement - clock in and out for your scheduled breaks - metrics to make sure you follow this exactly as planed.
Bonuses are based off of customer surveys of your entire team (not individually) you get % based off phone metrics. 
Metrics are not designed for you to keep the customers interest in mind (ex: if you have to call back to a customer - break between calls to finish a project or do some research for a customers issue - your metrics take a hit). 
You get 3 calls/month monitored and graded on if you said what your manager wanted you to say (can be a little childish at times and not a good measurement  3/500 calls graded) 
Days you will take 60-70 phone calls a day for 8-10hrs (cant focus on customers individually - turn and burn).  
Branch employees are viewed as more valuable to the company and are told to "dump" issues to phone centers (they do not know how to complete any processes for clients). 
Limited movement: most managers in current roles have been there for 10-20 years with no position to move higher into.
Pay is lower then other financial firms in the same market.

headline: SYSTEMS ENGINEER
pros:

cons: No cons on broader spectrum
