headline: Overall, good experience. Wish secular environment was better
pros:
Benefits - been at the company 20 years, I hope I can be there another 20. If you have a good manager, don't leave. The benefits are stellar, great match, retiree medical, health, dental, tuition reimbursement.
I've moved from Salt Lake, to Marlborough, to Westlake with Fidelity. If you are at a site with growth that's the place to be.
Starting diversity groups - Women's Networking Group, Aspire (Hispanic), etc.
If you can find the right niche, it's great to be entreprenurial with the company.
You must work on networking and be proactive in finding your proper place in the company.
There are so many things to learn and do if you are pro-active. You cannot wait for someone to recognize you - find your passion and pursue it!
cons:
Functions are still somewhat siloed. There are so many cost pressures in the industry right now that is constrains budgets and opportunities. It used to be sky's the
If you want to grow, try to get out of phones or operations.
Perfectionistic - bar is always raised.
Failure is punished severely, but if you can endure experience can push you to a better spot.

headline: Great people, good products and services
pros: Privately held, great people, superior benefits. Product and service mix is outstanding. The chairman is visionary and has created a well diversified business model
cons: High management movement, lack consistent leadership. The culture encourages rapid turnover (3 yrs) of business unit management which means that priorities shift within the business unit as leadership changes

headline: Amazing experience
pros: Working with great people, exposure to cutting edge technology with no fear of spending what is required to get the job done, and a sense of being part of a team with direct impact on the success of major initiatives are just a small part of what was amazing about working for FMRCo.  Also
cons: The high pressure environment isn't made for everyone.  The department I was in was also left hanging occasionally by being left out of inter-departmental project meetings and then still left to deal with the decisions and timelines that resulted, leaving us in "drop-everything-and-work-on-something-different" situations more than once.

headline: A once great company...
pros:
Ten years ago Fidelity was a great company to work for.  Five years ago, before Lawson's reign of error chased out much of the core of long-term senior executives, Fidelity was a good company to work for.

Benefits are still good (though much reduced from earlier days).  Compensation has been been flat for years, while the workload and responsibilities have increased as headcount has dropped.
cons:
Today Fidelity is a place you should look to only as a last resort.  You will live in constant fear of having your job off-shored, eliminated, or moved halfway across the country.  Some choice anecdotes from the last few years:
- Sold your house to follow your job to another state two years ago?  Good for you, you can move again this year, right?  
- Involuntary transfer from the East Coast to the Midwest last year?  So sorry, you make too much money, here's a 20% pay cut; you can take the pay cut, or take a severance package at your *new* pay rate.
- Great news!  We eliminated our on-shore development team to save money, so you'll need to work with the new offshore development team to complete your projects.  PS - they're twelve hours ahead, and they aren't allowed to work remotely, so you'll have to work with them during their business hours (9 PM - 5 AM EST).  Make sure you're in the office 8 AM to 6 PM though, wouldn't want to people to think you're slacking.
- Due to the economic climate, there will be no merit or cost-of-living increases this year, and bonuses and incentive programs are being cut for individual contributors.  The good news is, we did manage to scrape up 300 million dollars for off-cycle bonuses for our top 270 executives.
- It's the first Tuesday of the month.  The good new is, it will be way easier to find a parking spot tomorrow.  The bad news is, you'll have no idea whether that key contributor on your project has been laid-off, or if they're on vacation for a week (unless you're the key contributor, of course).

headline: Excellent company with good benefits and decent pay
pros: Open ideas are encouraged and a strong work/life balance is encouraged.  It is easy to move around within the company and find your niche.
cons: Overall the people are easy to work with and the atmosphere is positive.  I really don't have many negative things to say.  The overall benefit package is very good but when people leave the company it is usually because they have found a similar job that pays 10-15% more than what they currently make.

headline: Nice to be part of fidelity

headline: Great company to settle down and retire from; not best for earlier in your career if you wish to learn.

Since a big part of salaries ( specially from senior levels) are tied to bonuses, focus changes from overall team goal to personal goals and marketing, making environment unpleasant. If you are a technical personal specially earlier in your career and want to grow technically, this might not be the right place to start.

headline: Negative Culture and Values
pros: Decent Pay and Good Benefits. A general willingness to invest in business development and IT. Modern and updated facilities with decent amenities. Tight security both physically and on the customer data side.
cons:
Does not pay for performance or set performance expectations well. There are unwritten or absent expectations regarding "success" in job roles; performance is not necessarily judged against what your assignments are and how you execute them. 

For example, recently I had achieved all of my performance goals for the review period, such as being ahead of project completion schedules, under budget and delivered targeted business scope. Two weeks prior to the performance review the performance assessment criteria was changed to "measure" me against targets that I had no chance to meet since they were completely different than the job assignments.  The manager conducting the review admitted that the assessment criteria was "new" and "unfair" and the lack of communication was deliberate in order to send a "message" to the organization.

After over a decade of service with eighty percent of my performance reviews being "above average" under the various grading scales (and never having had a poor review before), it was a very strange turn of events.

It appears as though it may be a targeted "reduction in force" or "desired attrition" by targeting people at certain pay and/or years of service, since I was only one of several colleagues who held similar positions that expressed a very similar situation. 

Rewards are more and more concentrated at the very top level, with the middle layer becoming hollow and the entry level positions are subject to RIF's regularly.

Exceptionally poor planning in just about every business unit, and the company as a whole. A general  inability to keep focus.

headline: Very good company for bright career

pros: Decent salary.  Huge investment in IT.  Able to move sideways to new jobs. Willing to try new things.
cons: Shuffle, shuffle, shuffle.  Lots of people movement which has to be expensive.  Cutting a lot of IT jobs in Boston and moving to TX, NC or overseas.  sometimes there is too much willingness to try new things; there are 4 tools for everything, little is integrated, and standardization is not often found.  Certain groups have lots of politics. Not a lot of upward mobility.

headline: The company culture is very relaxed and positive.
pros: Excellent training, nice benefits package.
cons: Entry level has high turn over after year, many competitors pay more.

headline: Financial Services Reprentative
pros: Work with a good group of people
cons: Lack of  growth opportunity in branch

headline: I love this company.
pros: Fidelity investments has phenomenal benefits. The healthcare premiums are fairly low and provide full coverage. The firm matches 7% of your 401(k) contributions and adds annual profit sharing money which is a percentage of your salary. The quarterly bonuses are quite nice too! There are many other corporate perks/discounts as well. I like the fact that I work with young professionals that range in age, sex, and race. Everyone at the firm is very charismatic. I've been there for 6 months now and I can easily see myself retiring with Fidelity. I honestly can't think of anything bad, especially since there is PLENTY of room for advancement/growth.
cons: It can be tough to advance (change roles) if you are an introvert. Moving around in the company happens by shadowing others, so you better show charisma and the drive to take control of your own development. Many of the roles require communication skills, so if you don't feel comfortable with public speaking then this is NOT for you.

headline: High Talented Work Force
pros: Offers good training and pay.
cons: Senior Mgmt constantly making changes that are poorly communicated.   Some who have made it to high senior levels are very un-professional.  ie  yelling, loud phone converstations even behind closed doors.

headline: Excellent culture, Best Pay
pros:
- Very good culture of mutual respect
- Opportunities to bring ideas to the table
- Work-life balance
- Industry leading pay
cons:
- Being a captive, quality of work at B'lore not high-end
- Outside employability might suffer and career tends to stagnate if you become too comfortable with the pay, work and easy life
- Company becoming top heavy now and office politics has increased because of that

headline: Consider carefully
pros: Pays well for most positions.
cons: Company is not focused.  Tries to be best in class in all areas along with riding on previous accomplishments.  No evidence of strong innovative strategy for future.

headline: The people are great and there is good work/life balance. The work isn't always creative enough.
pros: Dedicated, smart, passionate people in every department, including design. A huge focus on great user experience. Great benefits and pay. Flexible hours.
cons: Slow pace. Don't always have the tools or help you need. Frustratingly behind the times technology and development. Development that has been almost completely outsourced overseas - working closely with your developers is next to impossible.

headline: Worst Professional Experience Of An Otherwise Productive Career
pros: The Pay was good compared to the S. Ohio / N. Kentucky area as a whole. Benefits were good as well.
cons:
As has been stated in various reviews on this site, if you are too intelligent, attractive, or bring sound business experience with you to the role, expect to be shunned eventually if not immediately. In the S. Ohio/N. Kentucky region there are not many opportunities, even for college graduates so its easy to scare the majority into conforming into whatever management requires at the time. Where else can they go? This was true even before the world blew up.

They will hire minorities but they expect them to be docile, weak and just smart enough to do what is asked of them. No matter how smart you are, if you are a black male you have little chance of making any real progress. Of course there are the "tokens" to make things look good on the surface. Once a manager even sent out an email to his team that had a Martin Luther King speech in it that said the Negro was still not free. Imagine that in this day and age. This kind of behavior is condoned in Covington Kentucky.

headline: Great company to work for ...
pros: Of all the companies I have worked for or known, Fidelity can boast of its HR policies for its employees.
cons: Growth within the organization, as the structure is relatively flat.

headline: Good company to work long term
pros: good benefits, culture and values
cons: slow career growth/opportunities, top management heavy, bureaucracy

headline: Very good from monetary perspective

good salary

Latest technologies to work with if you are from technical side
Work life balance, amazing events and parties
cons: Not as much promotions as consulting firms

headline: The best working culture

headline: Excellent training program and potential for growth.

headline: positive enviornment, high level of internal competition

cons: The group I worked for did a poor job on Career development and with the work environment morale. Just a reminder that this does not occur across Fidelity Investments.

Boring work
Mid level managers are just people who have been around too long and have nothing better to move on to

pros: Generous salary with bonus on top of it.  Very generous contributions to 401K.   Good technology and opportunities to learn new things
cons: Constant downsizing and job re-locations, (which was just another way to downsize).   Major effort going on company wide to replace veteran empolyees with college students.   Used to be a great place to work - many years ago.  Now it is not, so I averaged that out and gave company an "OK" rating.

headline: A learning experience

good shift timings
cabs
helpful colleagues

HR not helpful.. Not strong enough to take any decision in case of any harassment.

headline: Huge difference between FMR and FMR India

cons: Dirty politics, No value to individual.  No growth in career unless you are a kith and kin of higher management.

headline: Good company for work here

headline: It was amazing
pros: Work life balance, food and money as well

headline: Great people, great company
pros: Fantastic benefits, amazing people and a culture of learning and personal development. I highly recommend working here, especially if you are just starting a career in finance.
cons: Work can sometimes be a bit boring however the people make up for it. Also, in order to advance in the company you may have to move around a bit.

headline: Elephants cannot survive off peanuts; and yes, they count them often.
pros: Mobility and other opportunities abound if you are patient. Good name within the industry and loyal client base. Great inexpensive investment lineup.
cons:
Corporate politics abound here. To move up carry toilet paper around often to wipe your nose. They only want to hear the truth if its what they want to hear. You can be #1 in sales but if you dont further their agenda you will stall your career. Micro management is well over the top. Worst I have ever encountered. The compensation is extremely weak (My gross income here is what I used to pay in taxes at my other jobs and I am in the top 20 people out of 300  in the nation for 2 years running) Great place to get hired if you are desperate or looking for a stepping stone but will never be long term. They are short term focused but always talk about the long term. Do not let this fool you!  Middle management and some mkt mgrs truly have no clue how to manage. They are failed sales people with brown crust on their noses that micro manage and have little to zero outside experience ( this is their only real job since college).  The work and dealing with clients is ok as the Fido client is a cheapskate and know-it-all. It takes time to build trust, realtionships and for the client to self discover they need your/Fido help. Management wants you to slam them into products today. A "what have you done for me today" mentality. If your response is "built a deeper relationship 
based on trust and confidence" the branch mgr will look at you like a cyborg and keep repeating  "that does not calculate" until his brain starts to smoke. Corp vision is a lie. They say they want to retain top talent and build long term relationships. Look at their actions. It is a lie. 5 top Senior Accountt execs left in the last 12 months. Everyone of them were threatened on the way out by their mgr rather than spoken to for retention measures. If this were a public company I would buy a put 3 years in the future so i could put it to someone I hated and make a killing from their lose. It is a truly broken system and the mend is at minmum 5 years away. Possibly a decade. Lastly, once you do sell something you have to track it and a third of the time sent up exception as they are not crediting it to you but atbthe same time will be delivering you an oral warning of termination for low production which they will not rescind once its credited and also become part of your HR file. It is purely about power, fear and control at this place. It is only for the weak and timid not top talent.

headline: Good for fresh graduates
pros:
-flexibility of schedule and for time off
-great benefits
-great location
-wonderful scenery
cons:
-promotions are limited
-too much group rotation 
-low pay
-holiday vacation is limited

headline: Good Company/Job - Bad Management at FCPMS
pros: Great Co-Workers, Excellent Benefits, Good Hours
cons: Senior Management don't know how to do their job, Not good at delegating responsibility to Associates, Under-staffed, Could have a better Training schedule/program for new hires.

headline: not so bad
pros: great environment to work in with good benefits. Management is willing to hear your opinions and help you enjoy working or them. I like their corporate perks and their discount of car insurance and corporate perks.
cons: the constant "strategic relocation" since this started to happen i have seen many team members leave the team due to location. Team members leave and the work load increases and it starts to get hard to balance your work life and social life.

headline: Sexist towards women.  Lots of politics.
pros: Ok base salary with great benefits beginning after a year. Longevity is the key to their vesting. Great hours which is unique in this business.
cons: As a woman you will feel like you are living in the 50's...there is sexism allowed in this company. Look elsewhere if you are a woman.  If you are male and have connections you can get by with many things that are unethical and the other men will cover for you. It really is amazing to see inside what goes on and what is covered up.

headline: Exceptional organization that is client-centric and values its people
pros: As a private company Fidelity is able to focus on the long-term best interests of its clients and people rather than on quarterly results.  Excellent benefits, strong management, exceptional market position, and very talented people.
cons: sometimes it is difficult to navigate across business units

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Profit Sharing, Health Insurance, Life/Work Balance, 7% match + 10% profit sharing into your 401k annually, frequently provided lunch when it was busy.
cons: Huge company so there is often too much information to keep up on regarding other business units. As is the case in this industry there is so much waste (both time and resources) due to unnecessary and useless regulations.

headline: IT developer and lead role
pros: great culture, supportive mgmt, good work-life balance, open door policy
cons: none that i can think of

headline: Tough Environment and ever changing
pros:
Private Ownership gives great autonomy
good benefits
cons: Tough environment and not alot of growth potential into bigger positions

headline: Comfortable org. nice people
pros: Stable environment, friendly co-workers. The company offers good benefits
cons: Not enough challenge, relatively slow working pace

headline: Far too political!
pros: Some very good employees but they lack any real understanding of the business.  They are too busy trying to manage the poltical atmosphere in order to protect thier jobs.
cons: Too political.  Sr. management has no clue as to what needs to be done to make the company successful.  Not a proactive culture to solving business issues.

headline: If you are debating between this company and another -- GO THERE!
pros: It's a job and pays the bills.  That is what I can say about Fidelity.  It USED to be a good place to work, but things have changed there dramatically.
cons: Very condescending, little or no advancement if you are female with children or an ill spouse.  They treat you like dogs because they know they can in this economy.  Best friend comes home in tears - lecherous treatment of women in the finance side of the business.  You have to be gorgeous and LIKE that kind of attention, or male and have little or no encumbrances.  They are turning all of their business over the India.

headline: 2 years ,2 projects , big team experience at Fidelity Investments from India
pros:
Very safe environment for the employees and added benefits such as cabs all time.
Very amicable and professional colleagues.
High quality facilities such as team rooms,communication devices, computers and equipment , all of which are very updated.
Very responsive HR Team.
Good number of leaves available.
cons:
Excessive meetings sometimes.
Dearth of Subject matter experts in teams.
Not the best in company training programs

headline: Continuous improvement makes for continual employment
pros: Continuous improvement both technically and professionally is one of the basis-es of  employment.  FI holds all employees, business partners, vendors, and contractors accountable to the highest ethical standards.  Management is diverse, but most will provide defined expectations to give their employees the ability to improve and grow.  FI provides decent compensation to their employees.  The work environment is great = great people, quality professionals.
cons: Management expects proof of ability over word.  This means if you are being considered for a promotion, such an employee is given the ability to prove their abilities.

headline: Financial analyst
pros: Great benefits, great management, godd environment
cons: Nothing negative, employees tend to stay causing the company not o have lots of open positions

headline: Sr QA Engineer
pros: Great work/life balance, good for family life
cons: No room to grow if looking for Management positions

headline: Fidelity excels in Ethics, Values and Culture
pros:
-> Company is very well organized
-> Fidelity has very good foundation
-> A very stable company
-> There is no compromise on ethics
-> Good payer
-> Provides excellent facilities
cons: Slow personal growth especially with respect to designations.

headline: A secure job in a tightly controlled environment
pros: Friendly work place, a steady paycheck. Opportunity for advancement. Fidelity is a good name for the company. For the most part I feel like I am an advocate for my clients.
cons: Fidelity seems to apply more to the clients than to the employees. WAY too many metrics. Way to many excuses for not getting a full bonus, even for the high performers. End up top ten in the nation and be told all the things that you are doing wrong and that you could do better. Usually by a manager that has not been on the front lines under the same metrics for years, and never produced at a comparable level. Too many levels from the front lines to the actual end rep who will handle the client. Finally at least some movement as the company seems to have just realized that it needs to ramp up hiring or it will not be able to compete for a relevant position in the coming tsunami of retiring baby boomers. Mediocre compensation for even the best performers.

headline: Great company
pros: Competitive salary, concerned about people, flexible work hours, work at home, challenging and interesting job, given the authority to make decisions, collaborative team.
cons: Too much red tape to get things done, internal technology is flawed - systems down, conference rooms don't have latest equipment causing most meetings to start 10 minutes late; not the greatest communication of our benefits packages.

headline: Investments
pros: Benefits. 401k. Training is very good.
cons: Sweat shop. Expect 40 to 70 calls a day. Tied to your desk with old head sets that squeak.

headline: Fidelity has a very old legacy mainframe they are married to
pros: theres steady paycheck at least
cons: boring work, they have vending machines but make you pay for the beverages. that's so out of date.

headline: Great place to work
pros: There are good perks, a lot of opportunities to learn in Fidelity. There is nothing like work-life balance in financial world, it is 24X7X365
cons: A lot of politics in some of the groups that is taking the toll on the morale of the workforce there. The folks are scared to say anything due to the bad economy.

headline: Fidelity no longer the company it used to be...
pros: Flexibility to work from home.  Salary and benefits better than average but Fidelity has made many changes to reduce these in recent years (i.e. elimination of pension plan; change in merit and bonus review program; move to high deductible medical plan).
cons:
Fidelity is a sweatshop.  If you job involves client services, you find yourself working on vacation and holidays with no appreciation or reward.  Fidelity has been doing consistent reductions in force over the last several years so less employees do more work.  The company also recycles the same managers year after year which do nothing but provide lip service to upper management.  The old boys club rules at Fidelity.  If you are part of the club you are in.  However, if you are honest and speak the truth, you are out.  Senior management does not want to hear the truth and doesn't care about what the rank and file employees want or need or for that matter what the clients need.  On the institutional side of the business, what is best for the client is what is in the best interest of Fidelity.  
Client Boards are just ways for senior management to goes to posh hotels/locations to schmooze with clients and give them lip service.  Recent changes in the merit review process results in most employees being rated as average.  This review process is a bell curve so only a handful are rated as excellent and requires that some employees fall into the need to improve category.  This certainly makes it easy to determine who is out for the continual reductions in force.  Finally, if you manage clients beware that if that client leaves, the buck stops with you.  Even if the decision is out of your control (i.e. senior management won't budge on pricing or the client is bought by another company that is not with Fidelity) your manager will hold you accountable and your job will be on the line.

headline: good place to work
pros: personal space and pay both are good
cons: you have to stay in the same job role for 18 months

headline: One of the best employers wrt to Work Environment and Culture
pros:
Excellent work culture and environment
Excellent HR policies
cons:
Too formal
Sometimes take a short term view where a long term perspective is required
For business operations group, advice to become more sensitive towards employees

headline: The benefits don't outweigh the lack of pay
pros: There are a lot of benefits.
cons: People are "cliquey". There is a general feeling of bureaucracy. It's just the average big business. I feel like I just get lost in the crowd.  You pay to have great benefits, so a large amount of your check goes to have the medical, dental, 401K, etc.

headline: best job in the world
pros: Great place to work with lots of independence and responsibilities. Best job in the world, otherwise wouldn't have come here
cons: all good. nothing else to say

headline: Senior Project Manager
pros:
Pay well - competitive across any industry 
Treat you well - Employee respect is unparalleled
Job satisfaction is great
Plenty of resources and Non-stop learning
Ability to change jobs with out changing employer
Work for a top Financial Services firm with stable track record
Genuinely care about customers and you
cons: Bureaucracy can disappoint you since company is too complex to navigate and too many ticketing systems and teams get involved.  Some very simple things can take months to get done.  Regardless though i think it is still a better company to work for.

headline: industry veteran
pros: decent salary and benefits including onsite doctor office
cons: every group has different policies - no consistency

headline: Plenty of opportunities
pros: Great profit sharing, 401k, and benefits.  Plenty of opportunity if you put in the time and perform well.
cons: Pay can be frustrating at first but the benefits make up for it and the pay can come if you are patient and perform well.  Lots of bureaucracy, not a very flat organization.

headline: Best decision ever!
pros: Many firms won't give you a salary while they sponsor you to get your broker's license- Fidelity does and also provides a very thorough study course.  Supports employees immensely.  Love the people- great environment.  You might think call center and think of Office Space, but it's nothing like that.  So much fun.  Lots of opportunities for promotions and bonuses.
cons: Doesn't pay the highest, but when combined with all the benefits and bonuses, I think it's worth it.

headline: Good benefits but true leadership is lacking
pros: There are a lot of good people who work there. The benefits are good including profit sharing and a generous 401k match.
cons: Directors and VP's in general claim to want input from all levels but only if you agree with them. If you disagree you stand the chance of being chastised. Unfortunately, many are afraid to speak their minds.  The pay is OK but there is not much room for advancement and even when those opportunities come up, the increase in pay is minimal.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros:
IT is important in Fidelity
very innovative/smart people
team oriented projects
agile
beneifit
cons: pay is lower than direct competitors for non investment professionals

headline: Mixed bag - very political
pros: If you are lucky enough to land with a secure, mature manager you will have many opportunities to exceed at your work.  Confident managers excel at training, advancing, promoting their subordinates into better positions.  They advise, challenge, critique, encourage and correct your work and presentations in a productive, positive manner.  They look for opportunities for their subordinates.
cons: If you are unlucky and land on one of the insecure manager teams you will go nowhere.  Expect no directions, no clarifications, no assistance with projects and tasks assigned to you.  Expect no contact from these managers until your yearly review, then expect the worst possible annual review where you will be blamed for all of this manager's short comings.  You can write a rebuttal to the BS in your review, but that rebuttal will never get looked at and you're left with a tarnished reputation, no raise, lousy bonus but - gosh - at that moment, your manager sure looks happy!

headline: Great financial products and great place to be a financial advisor, VERY political.
pros: They offer the most cost-effective financial product solutions.  Very focused on customer-service and have some of the best employee benefits a private company could offer.
cons: Extremely political environment for managers in their call centers.  Pay for managers is horrible.  When financial crisis hit in late 2008 they quickly lost my confidence as an employee-centric company as they unloaded a ton of people and talent.  They also cut employees pay in a massive way.

headline: Great place to start your career
pros:
Promote from within
Great 401k match
cons:
Lots of OT
College degree isn't highly regarded; more of who you know not what you know

headline: Easy captive unit
pros: Fidelity is great for work life balance, and provides many employee friendly perks like free food and cab transportation. Work culture is great.
cons: Technical work is not cutting edge, and is mostly repetitive month on month. Lateral inter department movement is very difficult. Office politics also exists. Pay structure is not tax friendly at all.

headline: Great place to start a career in finance, SLC is not a great place long-term for high level talent
pros:
- Excellent training program to obtain knowledge of the industry and financial licenses
- Good company culture with mid-level management that cares about your work/life balance
- Industry leading benefits package (health, dental, 401k with 7% match and 10% profit sharing bonus - essentially a 17% match if you contribute 7% to your 401k, tuition reimbursement is $10,000, Company covers most or all of the cost of mass transit passes, etc.)
cons:
- Benefit package is great at the cost of low base pay compared to industry competitors.
- If you get an MBA or advanced degree, there are virtually no opportunities in SLC to take advantage of that. The only high paying career opportunities are in phone sales and management.  However management has virtually no turnover which is because of the great situation they have (Many have +10 year tenure), but this is bad if you want to try to get into management - be prepared to wait years for that opportunity or be forced to find an opportunity somewhere else.
- For those in SLC who want to move elsewhere in the country most of the opportunities are only for representatives who want to go to branches, if you want to go to a higher value added position in Boston or any other location good luck if you don't have connections or years of experience. Getting an advanced degree while working means nothing if you are trying to get in the door outside of their conventional channel of campus recruiting at mostly Ivy league or east coast universities.

headline: Great company to start a career
pros:
- Managers that care about your career and personal development
- Great benefits - dollar per dollar match to 7% of salary in 401k - Having a ROTH 401k was a great attraction for me
- Currently growing - Opportunities to move into your desired career path - Great for people who get hired on just to get in the door with a less desirable position 
- The company is big on following the kaizen philosophy
- The company is moving a lot of positions from Boston to Westlake - Great growth opportunity as many of the Boston employees do not want to relocate - Not having a state income tax was probably a driver for the move
cons:
- Your desk moved frequently, within 6 months my team/department has relocated within the same building 2 times - I think they do this as it is the only way some people clean their desk
- Slow moving changes
- Lags behind industry changes - Needs to move faster with offering of ETF's

headline: FIL experience
pros: Good values and opportunities at work
cons: captive unit so business exposure limited to a domain

headline: Run the Other Way
pros: You work indoors. Good 401K match.
cons: Low pay. Poor treatment from management. Lack of meaningful advancement opportunity due to culture emphasizing certain groups that meet growth targets. Excessively demanding performance requirements. Stressful work environment due to politics and favoritism.

headline: Great Company with lots of room to grow
pros: The people are great and training is exceptional. The campus is beautiful with walking trails, a lake, and full size gym and cafeteria.
cons: Pay is less than other firms but the experience you get is awesome.

headline: Associate software engineer responsible for software development
pros: None that i can think of right now
cons: This place has a low learning curve

headline: It's not quite the Borg, but it is an intense place to work. Not for the squeamish.
pros:
Diverse business lines present opportunities for internal movement
Many smart, customer-focused, collaborative professionals
Compensation including bonuses is lucrative, depending on job role
Many opportunities for internal training, especially for managers
Very structured, hierarchical environment which some people like
cons:
Extremely siloed, due to the diverse business lines and operational complexity
Constant, relentless organizational changes at all levels, with entire groups being relocated, realigned or disbanded without sufficient explanation
Communication from executive and senior management was lacking and/or confusing
Middle managers were under intense pressure to produce results but often not given the needed resources
Depending on group, morale was often a problem due to offshoring concerns

headline: Fidelity with Fidelity
pros: Its a good company to maintain work-life balance. Help you groomed to the core.
cons: Growth is very slow. Salary structure is also not great .

headline: Difficult corporate culture
pros: Shares, Bonus, compensation structure and financial growth
cons: Corporate culture is difficult to navigate

headline: Great Company!!!
pros: Corporate culture is great!!! Great benefits and training.
cons: I didn't like the call center environment.

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
Structured organization
Well defined goals and priorities
Good work was often acknowledged in forms of appreciation emails and awards
Good work culture
cons: Salary appraisals were not always fair and often driven by tenure in the company rather than on merit and performance

headline: Great place....great people
pros:
Management wants you to succeed
Tons of training available
Respected company
cons:
Opportunities can be challenging
Reorganizations occur a little too frequently

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good Pay, great benefits, flexible work schedule, family friendly work place.  Provide tuition reimbursement, bonus etc.  Great place to work in IT. They spend lot of money in technology
cons: Moving jobs to south. Need to network to get ahead.  People stay in the same job for decades without moving and they form cliques.

headline: 401K Benefits Customer Service
pros: Better pay than most call centers.  Managers feeds the staff well by bringing in food/pizzas/treats.
cons: You better be a robot and repeat the script given to you.  No deviation.  And the "optional' overtime - if you are not working all the extra hours asked of you, it will be remembered.

headline: Good Company for Senior Positions and Bad company for the Starters
pros: Very Good Company for Senior Positions where they will get good compensations and a good work life balance, which is very important for life.
cons: Bad for starters and mid level position holders. Very less onsite opportunity.

headline: bad work environment and bad company policies.
pros: the pay was decent, the benefits are better than nothing and the 401K was ok but only if you work there your entire career
cons: the work place is very cliquish and catty. Women are treated badly, there is an undercurrent of sexism. If you are too intelligent or too attractive, be prepared for a lot of hostility. Also very bigoted. They employ minorities but then treat them as "token" employees and there is definitely an undercurrent among white workers that you don't socialize or date outside of your race. If your a conservative , very conservative bigot ..and a very suburban woman..then you'll probably do just fine

headline: Awesome place to work if you in to finance or business
pros: Supportive managers, great employee morale,pay is above other places and plenty of training and support to improve . Availabitly to leave early without pay of course.
cons: Its a call center. Most of the jobs are customer service oriented.Very few jobs that don't require a headset.

headline: Fidelity Durham, NC Review
pros: Company reputation with customers, not with employees
cons:
The Fidelity office in Durham office has a hiring quota agreement with the city in return for tax advantages. The agreed hiring quota far exceeds business needs. Fidelity manages to meet the quota, yet at the same time, save their budget by making sure that employee turnover is pretty high in this office. Instead of spreading in-coming calls evenly among associates, they create separate work units called MU's. A particular MU receives ALL incoming calls with other MU's receiving only spill over workload. As a result, people quit constantly in the overloaded MU who are then replaced by newly recruited associates.
Other questionable business practices also exist in this office. People are randomly given additional reponsibilities or promotions with the promise that they will receive increased pay commensurate with their added duties. Months later, promoted employees are still waiting for their increased pay. The excuse by management is that they are still waiting to see if you can actually do the job. Instead of a salary increase, they try to placate these employees by decreasing their workload by dumping their duties on the overloaded MU. This is a widespread practice throughout this office. They also hire people at level I and give them Level III duties once you are in the job with Level I pay.
Because of the widespread unemployment situation employees grit their teeth and put up with the situation until they can find another job. In my experience with local and international organizations, I have never seen such dishonest business practices as witnessed in this office. It is truly regrettable that organizations can actually get away with such behavior right here in the United States. 
You will constantly see numerous job ads by this office but think twice before you apply.

headline: Call Center =  Mind-numbingly slow death
pros: Good Benefits, easy call metrics, easy to learn procedures, ability to learn about investments or benefits side of the business, slightly better pay compared to other call centers in the NC area, pleasant modern decor, very ergonomic desks & chairs, clean facilities, competent co-workers. If you can somehow manage to either get your series 6&7 licenses (which they'll pa for... but only very rarely, to reign in costs), or transfer to HR or IT... the company could be a good place to be in the long run. Whatever you do. Do not stay on the phones. It is seriously a slow, mind-numbing and monumentally uneventful death.
cons: Working in a call center is so, so, sooo very monotonous. The job very quickly becomes, not only uninteresting, but also completely unchallenging. The immediate supervisors (excellent performers and leaders) were laid off a couple of times, and then replaced by lower paid, inexperienced, entry level supervisors. Also, reassignment and relocation is common. I had 4 different managers and constantly rearranged teams over the course of 2 & 1/2 years. Entire departments were suddenly and unceremoniously laid off, as well. Working on the phones gives you a certain amount of security, because they need people to answer the calls... but, there's not very much opportunity for advancement. When you are on the phones you are pretty much tethered to your phone and your desk until your designated breaks, so you need to have a strong bladder or lay off of the fluids for hours at a time. You don't really get a chance to interact or get to know your co-workers. Meetings were cut down, which cut down on goal monitoring, teambuilding and learning opportunities. The part-timers had very little opportunity to become full-time workers. If you are on an evening shift it is practically a Herculean feat to get moved to the day shift, even if you've worked there for years. However, despite this fact, the company will consistently bring on completely new hires and place THEM on the day shift... meanwhile, they'll tell the tenured evening shift-ers that there are "no daytime slots" available at this time, and ask them to please be patient (years into waiting).

headline: Great company, horrible, horrible job.
pros: 401k/health benefits are phenomenal, you can switch jobs almost ever 6 months to 1 year, quarterly/annual bonuses, easy to win other rewards which can add up to several thousand a year for doing almost nothing.

I'm not allowed to spend more than an average 480 seconds on the phone with a customer, or I'm penalized.  I'm required to generate sales leads in a non-sales job, or I'm penalized.  I'm required to stick to my minute-by-minute schedule, or I'm penalized.  And last, the job is definitely dependent on if your manager likes you.

headline: It is very difficult to get ahead here
pros:
Profit Sharing/Company Match
Abundant work resources
Good camaraderie amongst most associates
The company genuinely puts the customer first
cons:
Compensation at Fidelity is extremely low. The company as an explicit policy of paying its associates far below market rate. The company cites its share programs and other ancillary benefits as a compensatory alternative. However, those benefits are doled out on a case-by-case basis. Most employees don't benefit from these programs. Also, compensation figures are arbitrary and there is a lack of transparency into compensation. Bonuses are literally figures on the back of a napkin
Management is generally clueless about the day-to-day and treats employees like indentured servants. Brown-nosing is the only way to get ahead in this company. Management only values the opinions of the sycophants within the company, which creates an acrimonious and preferential environment. The company is ultra-poltical; and, management is only concerned with appearances, as opposed to doing the right thing.

pros:
- Fidelity cares about its customers 
- You learn how to help customers achieve their dreams (retirement, financial independence, etc)
- Pay and benefits are competitive 
- The work is meaningful
- You will be treated with respect
cons:
- New ideas are always welcome, but it takes too long to get them installed
- Promotions are slower then other companies I've worked for in the past
- Senior executives are not clear in communicating directives and do not know how to prioritize 
- The workload is much larger than companies I've worked for in the past

headline: Excellent opportunity to Learn low pay
pros: -Ability to learn in industry.
cons: -Low Pay very low even for SLC.

headline: A good experience and very busy and often other offices had power out  issues creating more work for other offices.
pros: Great insurance, Cool co-workers and good training and education from company.
cons: Managers did not treat everyone the same they had their favorites and everybody knew it.  Little praise but when an error occurred you sure did hear about it and even if it was a small error it would go down in your chart/record and go against you when review time came around.  Not a lot of room to grow.

headline: Great Pay, Great Training, Little FREE TIME
pros:
Great Benefits
Collobarative learning environment
Management is engaged
Incredible opportunity to climb ladder
Rewarded with additional compensation for incredible work
cons:
Promotes based on who you know
Zero work likfe balance, especially for women
Reviews are subjective
Your personal time off is of little importance

headline: Great Place to work
pros:
1. employee recognition
2. senior management support
3.respect to all employees
cons:
1.long process to switch internally
2. employee retention strategy- worked for 3.5 years (india+us) still not given enough opportunities to retain me in the US office

headline: Okay
pros:
Stable job, 
Stable company.
Not a lot of pressure
cons: Your attributes to the company aren't really valued as a developer.

headline: Good People, Outstanding Benefits
pros:
- Backed by a strong brand, respected in the market place
- Conservative values.  Company seems to always try to do the right thing.
- Benefits are outstanding.
cons: - The company is so conservative that new initiatives can take a long time to pass through legal/compliance review to implement.

headline: The best job I ever had
pros:
1. They empower you to do your job well
2. Salary was competitive
3.Training was fantastic
cons: The organizational structure was somewhat difficult to understand.

headline: It's okay
pros: Pay is decent. Co-workers are competent and for the most part respectful of one another. Tuition reimbursement is good deal.
cons: It is a very stressful environment. Management lacks transparency. There are quite a bit of politics going on, and the matrix organizational structure does not help.

headline: High job security, average pay
pros:
Fidelity has created a pleasant work culture by incentivizing managers to advance their team members in their professional development.
Benefits at Fidelity are outstanding and begin on day one.
You are continually learning in whatever job function you have. If you like change, Fidelity will offer you plenty of it.
Fidelity provides good job security. If you are honest and a hard worker, you won't be let go.
cons: It is not a place to go if money is your prime carrot. You can make much, much more by going to a firm where you have your own book.

headline: A company that creatively uses benefits to retain employees.
pros: Fast paced environment, interesting work and room to grow your knowledge.
cons: Tends to hire in large groups so competition for advancement is above average for good performers.

headline: Good opportunities
pros: For a financial company, Fidelity Investments has a very advanced technological environment. Any one looking to make a career in project/product management, software development, quality assurance or release engineering I recommend considering Fidelity Investments.
cons: For a company with 10,000+ employees they have presence in only few cities in USA which may result in the company not benefiting from the talent across the country.

headline: Good
pros: Good Place to work. nice pay
cons: Need to have more direction for career advancement. But overall good Place to work.

headline: A fast paced work environment with ability to multi-task and grasp concepts as a minimum requirement.
pros: Benefits and perks are excellent and one would be hard pressed to find any better out there in the workplace environment today
cons: Very intense fast paced environment with very little time to think independently between assigned tasks. More team meetings would be beneficial.

headline: Good place to work and grow within securities industry
pros: Broad range of organizations to work at within Fidelity which leads to opportunities to expand your knowledge of the industry
cons: A feeling that you have to pay your dues to get a promotion.

headline: A good place to work
pros: They give you time to learn the business
cons: Systems really need to be intergrated. It will cut down on inefficiency

headline: A good overall experience
pros: The benefits and opportunities to move internally
cons: The compensation is on the lower side

headline: Very good learning experience, ability to take risks, and work indepently
pros:
Very good benefits package
Leader in Community
If you are willing to move fields very good opportunities here
Company has lots of integretiy and asks the same of employees
cons:
Very Boston centric, harder to find opportunities in Regions
Your development is your own
Due to the very good benefits package pay is sometimes lower than other companies in same field

headline: Great benefits low pay.
pros: Great benefits, good life work balance.
cons: Pay not comparable to other employers in the same industry.

headline: Horrible.The manager I was under lacked knowledge on the job itself.
pros: The company has good benefits.
cons: Fidelity managers do a lot of double talk.Rigid environment and some employees are rigid.People walk around like zombies.The manager I was under always stated on our breaks to get away from our desk,go outside for fresh air but how in the world can you go outside when your breaks are 15 minutes and how the building is built it would be impossible to go downstairs,take in fresh air and be back upstairs and on the phone  in 15 minutes and your metrics are being monitored every second,what a joke.I was let go after being on the floor for a month stating my metrics wasn't where they should be and I was being rude to customers and this never occurred. This comopany

headline: Not growing stand still.
pros: Technology growth through the programs conducted thorugh classes , online trainings and collaborative programs learning is more , growth is less good for beginners.
cons: not good Management understand the project and its issues, not at all good in technology, Managers think it a govt organization.

headline: Misguided
pros: Benefits, big name, financial industry, prestigious, well liked.  This was the best place to start a career out of college.
cons: Lack of leadership from management.

headline: Overall a good company to work for
pros: Great health, 401k, and profit sharing benefits. The majority of middle management care about the employees. Good work/live balance.
cons: Compensation is very low. The only way to get a higher salary is to move around a lot, or leave and come back.

headline: Stable, Increased Benefits Over Time, Stellar Reputation Within The Industry, Pay Is Below Average
pros: Support in learning the industry, terrific 401k match and profit sharing, gain a lot of experience in a short amount of time
cons: Very political in regards to getting promotions, rigid policies, managers monitor image more than professionally develop employees in most cases

headline: Great place to start your career.
pros: Great place to start you career out of school. They pay you to study for you series 7 and 63. You are paid hourly so OT can help bring up you pay amount. The training if one of the best in the business.
cons: Tough to go to other departments. They try to get you to go to other roles that are on the phone. Very hard to get a role off the phone. After a year the job becomes very repetitive.

headline: solid company
pros:
-excellent benefits
-excellent training and paid study time for licensing
-technology was constantly being upgraded
-good people to work with
-young and fun culture
-family owned so the company doesn't have to give in to the pressure of shareholders
cons:
-pay was just average
-constant reorgs and policy changes, sometimes with little notice
-have to play the politics game to advance
-tied to your desk for phone roles with very little break
-sales goals constantly change

headline: Good
pros: Nice managers, good people, amazing series 7 support, paid study time, good training, nice clean office space, professional yet fun, easy going, good job satisfaction, lots of support
cons: some fo the systerms were old and outdated, they monitored your personal trading very closely, the pay wasn't anything amazing,

headline: Akin to working on an assembly line
pros: The Benefits are very generous
cons: Little challenge or advancement on merit

headline: Ability to learn many industries under one company umbrella
pros: Fidelity offers many different companies and industries to move around in while employed - many opportunities to learn different things. The 'Fidelity' name is very strong to have on your resume. Fidelity provides a fantastic total compensation/benefits package that other companies have a hard time competing with and there are many perks to working on the campus too such as a gym, running trails, softball field and league, etc. It's a home away from home.
cons: Over 36K employees, it's easy to lose your voice and become a number. You're at the mercy of Exec and Sr management making decisions on projects you are working on and invested in. Tough to move up and increase grade level.

headline: Punative Environment With Little Appreciation
pros: If you need a stable job it is ok
cons: They change the employee expectations for performance with no ramp up time and then threaten corrective action if you do not keep up. They nit pick on unimportant issues such "that sweater has a hood attached, wear it again and we will send you home." You are not a person you are a resource to be used as they wish.

headline: Good
pros: Best place to work managing  work culture and personal life.
cons: Diffcult to keep up with market  space technology.

headline: Great training program and company culture.
pros: Great training programs, friendly people are hired, good food, safe work environment, clean facilities, profit sharing even if you leave and come back to the firm, fair internal dispute resolution processes in place
cons: large corporation which makes it difficult to advance, retail/representative work is all done on the phone with a strict clock in/out system.

headline: Great work/life balance
pros:
Great pay and bonus structure
Best 401k benefits in the industry
cons: Big company feel, often can be difficult to communicate between groups.

headline: Retail service and trading specialist.
pros: Excellent training and knowledge of the financial services industry with ample hands on experience. Career path opportunities within and outside fidelity.
cons: Direct managers not as involved in your personal developement. To make a career for yourself and to take full advantage of the companies resources you have to do all the networking yourself. There are a ton of opportunities however.

headline: Good place to work, lots of politics
pros: Excellent compensation and benefits, central locations, lots of internal opportunity, growth, travel possibilities
cons: many layoffs, incompetent management, continuous change in direction - no focus on business at hand, top heavy (too many VP's)

headline: A great place to prove yourself
pros: Senior Management is awesome. Good vision and execution.
cons: As with any company, lots of re-orgs. This is part of the evolution of the company.

headline: Good place to start
pros: Great place to obtain securities license a lot of room for growth.
cons: The pay is low for the amount of money brought into Fidelity

headline: Lots of changes in direction every few months
pros:
Benefits
Salary
Campus Amenities
Suburban Location
Remote working
cons:
Constant Re-orgs
Same Sr "Leaders" moved around to fail again
Business strategy changes monthly

headline: Moderately adequate
pros: Good coworkers. Decent benefits. Paycheck.
cons: Political hoops that can't be jumped through

headline: Great place to have worked
pros: You get experience.  Through on the job and licensing there are opportunities.
cons: It's a treadmill.  A job but not a career.

headline: Call Center Excellent place to work
pros:
-Plenty of Time off
- Good Pay
-Good Benefits
-If you want to advance with the company , you know how to do it and the management is very supportive.
-Always opportunity for growth
- Loved my Coworkers
- Calm relaxed environment
-Company is very generous with its money (i.e. Upper management always supplying funding for team supervisors to buy their respective teams lunch)
cons: - Good Ole boy system, Very political.

headline: Great experience, room to grow and successful career opportunities
pros:
Promotion Growth
Great benefits
Tuition Reimbursement
Profit Sharing Plan
Great work life balance
Career development
Professional and friendly co-workers
Professional development
cons:
Knowledge is so specialized its not very transferrable out side the company.
Compensation is below the norm

headline: High net work phone representative.
pros: Fidelity has a good compensation package. They pay better than most of their direct competitors. The training is also good.
cons: My division no longer exists. It was consolidated into another division. In the last few years before the consolidation, management did not seem to care that their approach to managing the company was very detrimental to employee morale i. e. revoking scheduled vacation for some employees within a few weeks of the scheduled vacation due to customer call volume. They knew the end was near for them and they simply did not care.

headline: Used to be good, now is a sweatshop
pros:
worked with great people
good technology
cons:
no prospects for growth or career advancement
management was weak
endless hours for very little recognition or merit raises
was great in late 90's but slowly decined over the years

headline: Punative Environment
pros: The people I worked with my colleagues and fellow employees were great
cons: Leadership style there is beat them until they obey, reward them as little as you have to and then force them out if they do not drink the coolaide

headline: It is a great place to start
pros:
Very professional work environment
Ethical sales culture
Great benefits
cons:
Managers are often not  the most impressive individuals
Can be very political in terms of hiring/promotions
Bottomline centered

headline: Great experience, didn't think I'd ever leave. I was part of a reduction in work force. Great place to start your career
pros: Fair salary and bonus program. If you did well and proved yourself you were compensated very well. Great opportunities to grow your career, plenty of opportunity for upward or lateral movement. Advancement was supported by Mgt
cons: Work life balance was a little tough, depending on the area you worked.. Not a 9-5 company.

headline: Great
pros: wonderful work environment.  Great place to work.
cons: frequent reloacting groups to different sites.

headline: Politics gets in the way of work
pros: Fidelity pays well and keeps work load reasonable. Employees are given flexibility such as being able to work from home or choose to access their work related data from their own devices.
cons: Politics tend to get in the way of getting work done. Coworkers often take credit for work done by others.

headline: Awesome
pros:
Good experience
opportunity to move up
cons:
No relations with management.
Call Center culture overwhelms the company's culture.

headline: Nice place to start your carrier
pros:
Lots of opportunities.
Learn and experience the professionalism.
Good work-life balance
cons:
Need to differentiate between 'Partner' and 'Client'.
confused management decisions.
Politics you will find everywhere.

headline: Good for short-term
pros:
1. Beautiful Campus 
2. Nice cafeteria and break-areas
3.Professional and competent staff. 
4. Management is hands-off
5. Availability of resources required to complete work
cons:
1. Management is aloof, arrogant. Doesn't know whats really going on. Out of touch with staff. 
2. Management draws conclusions without investigating facts.
3. Contractors are not treated as part of the team. For example, contractors are three to a cubicle while employees have their own. There are many unoccupied cubicles.

headline: Reconciliation of 401(k) Account
pros:
Employee Freedom
Respect for individual
Great place to work for freshers
cons:
Salary not upto the mark
Politics in the management level
Work is routine
Cann't think out of the box

headline: Good employer who pays well, has excellent benefits and challenging work.
pros: Pay, benefits, interesting job assignments
cons: Management could not decide on the direction of the company in the area I worked in.

headline: Nice start out; don't stay
pros:
Good benefits
Most managers are fair
Ability to learn new things (up to a point)
Tuition reimbursement

No progression
Cumbersome duties, no challenge
Must love sales, b/c you're doing it to customers or employees as management.

headline: ensure you know what your applying for
pros:
Great company as far as job growth is concerned.
Good structure in place for employees to prosper.
Good compensation compared to other jobs of a similar
cons:
lines of communication with senior management is non existent.

The job descriptions are terrible. I applied for a job and it was nothing as described. Extremly vague an the interviews did not help me understand what I was getting myself into.

headline: Na
